Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate Two facts: 1. SBRT/Cyberknife is a whole gland treatment. It uses a precision targeting system to deliver highly focused radiation dosages. It is no more "focal" than a surgical cut, an EBRT beam, or a brachy seed. All whole gland treatments involve a series of local actions. 2. SBRT/Cyberknife is not new. It was FDA approved in 2001, and has treated over 40,000 patients, with the numbers sharply increasing in recent years. http://meetinglibrary.asco.org/record/119573/abstract https://www.sciencedaily.com/release...0418145458.htm While I am not a fan of super-star Dr. Samadi, just to throw a little gasoline on the Cyberknife discussion, here are his thoughts on the subject from his website: Q. What are the side effects of Cyber Knife? A. The negative side effects of CyberKnife® can be expected to mirror those of other targeted radiation therapies. Over the short term, radiation therapy for prostate cancer can cause: Urination problems including burning and blood in the urine Urinary urgency and frequency Weakened urinary stream Incomplete emptying of the bladder Anal and rectal irritation, rectal bleeding, hemorrhoids, and stool problems Fatigue and nausea Long-term CyberKnife® and prostate cancer radiation side effects may include: Sexual impotence and/or erectile dysfunction for up to 2 years after treatment Delayed orgasm or ejaculation Temporary or permanent reduction in sperm count; fertility should be discussed with your physician prior to CyberKnife® treatment Impaired bowel function Potential increased risk of bladder or rectal cancer by 5% And post-treatment patient satisfaction surveys repeatedly show Cyberknife as the LEAST popular method of treating prostate cancer, primarily due to radiation burns from the massive doses of radiation versus the decades-old gold standard of 35 - 40 sessions of EBRT.

If cancerous, the entire right middle lobe must be surgically removed. 6/13/14 - Nodule shrank by 1/3. Not cancer. Surgery cancelled. Next scan 9/14. Nodule "resolved" - gone. Posts.Title: So much for Active Surveillance, for me anyway

Posts.Content: Pratoman: I can't speak to the lymph node but I reiterate your observation that the tiny 3mm lung nodule is only 2 more than one silly little millimeter. If you look closely at my lung history, you will find a nodule SIX TIMES larger at 1.8 CM. It scared me. Three doctors had their fingers on the slice-and-dice machine but the damn thing disappeared at the end of 3 months. One thing I did learn about pulmonology is that the overall public would be aghast if they knew the junk that floats intermittently into and out of their lungs -- some harmful, some not. This MAY be nothing -- stay strong. Jim

Posts.Title: So much for Active Surveillance, for me anyway

Posts.Content: You raise the "quality of life" question that many people eventually have to address. Do you want to extend life as long as possible? Or do you want to retain the "quality of life" that you have always experienced? It's a dilemma that touches on joint philosophical beliefs. Some people turn to religious guidance while others do not. In my view, that is a question that can never be adequately answered on a forum. Only you and your spouse can decide what is best for yourselves. What the rest of us would do is irrelevant.

Posts.Title: Help! Would it be crazy to decline HT???

Posts.Content: From your husband's history: "Planning on DaVinci after chemo & probable radiation" Michael caught that -- I missed it. I'd be interested in knowing the name and specialty of the doctor who made that recommendation. In years and years of following prostate cancer outcomes, I have NEVER seen treatment offered in that sequence. Or is this a plan of action that you arrived at on your own? Normally, when radiation is employed as primary treatment for PC, surgery is not an option later. Good luck, Jim

Posts.Title: 4 Days till surgery - any advice?

Posts.Content: jefft: Thank you for sharing that wonderful news. It will go a long way toward helping others who find themselves in similar circumstances. I agree that the DaVinci machine has brought this disease to a level where it allows patients to experience the modern advances of science without the fear of so many who don't want to undergo the rigors of open surgery. Even more remarkable (at least to me) are the benefits rendered by the PSA test. The PSA led me to surgery. The PSA found the cancer when it returned and allowed me to proceed with salvage radiation. So, it may have saved my life twice. Whenever I'm in the company of guys over 50 who are friends or relatives, I beseech them to get annual PSA tests. Some never heard of the PSA and that's unfortunate because this is a disease that is almost always curable with early treatment. And the people on that government panel who want to save money and eliminate the PSA because it "may" lead to unnecessary treatment and unwanted side effects can go pound sand up their kazoo. They claim that only one life is saved for each PSA test, which I think is a horrible underestimate. What they fail to mention - even if you accept their numbers - is that for every one million PSA tests, a thousand lives are saved. If ANY test can save a thousand lives, that's a good thing, right? Again, congrats. Jim

Posts.Content: Since only a little more than a year has passed from the date of your surgery, I would be inclined to agree with Allen and Michael that a PSA every six months would be prudent. Allen and I can speak from experience, as we both encountered a return of PC after surgery in the one to three year time frame. We had to employ salvage radiation to deal with it. So far, so good. And I also thank you for your service.

Posts.Title: PSA Frequency

Posts.Content: My first psa <.008 My oncologist/surgeon’s advice - psa are high start radiation straight away i.e > 1 - psa between .02 and 1 then another psa in 2 weeks time - psa below <.02 then wait for another psa in 6 weeks Hi Jack: As someone who has had salvage radiation (although G7 for me, not G9), I believe your use of a PSA of "1" actually should read "0.1" when considering commencement of radiation. The distinction between those numbers is significant. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by newporter . For example, an Italian study published in 2010 looked at post op PNI found by post op pathology and recurrence. Here is a link to the report: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20516669 And here is the statement they made: The actuarial biochemical progression-free survival rate for all patients was 96.9 and 93.5% at 60 and 84 months, respectively, and the stratification based on the presence or absence of PNI did not allow us to identify different prognostic groups. Here is a summary by The "NEW" Prostate Cancer Infolink: http://prostatecancerinfolink.net/20...me-of-surgery/ who stated: This study appears to suggest that the prognostic impact of PNI on risk for progressive prostate cancer is actually much lower than has been assumed in the past. So, I believe mom2two should not worry too much about the PNI finding in the pathology report. Peace. AN ITALIAN STUDY?? With all of the high tech medical resources in this country, we're going to fall back on a 4-year-old ITALIAN study?

Posts.Title: SM88 therapeutic treatment for cancer

Posts.Content: My only cystoscopy had nothing to do with my prostate cancer. In 2008 and 2014, I had a kidney stone block my left ureter -- horrible, horribly painful -- and had to have surgery to have it removed (two nights in hospital -- fun, fun, fun). After each surgery, standard procedure is to place a stent in the ureter that must remain in place for 7 to 10 days to prevent it from collapsing. In 2008, the stent caused me to have significant pain. Couldn't wait to get it out. In 2014, three days after surgery, I awoke at home to find that I could not urinate. Not a drop. Very scary. I had visions of my bladder expanding and exploding. Called the uro and he had me come to the office where he used a temporary catheter to clear the blockage. On the fifth day after surgery, the same thing happened. No pain but couldn't pee. Back to the office where he started to insert the cystoscope. I started moaning. He said "What's wrong?". I said I was scared to death something very bad was about to happen. He put the scope in -- no pain at all, just a weird feeling. He cleared the blockage, then removed the scope and went back in and removed the stent. Also, no pain or discomfort after the procedure. All in all, I found the cystoscopy to be a piece of cake. Hope you have the same experience.

Posts.Title: Cystoscopy with a possible dilation???

Posts.Content: "Depressed and barely functioning" Welcome Ernie: Your reaction to learning you have the "Big C" is certainly understandable. At age 55, you should not have to deal with this. As our esteemed moderator, Chuck, has pointed out based upon your test results, treatment is indicated. He listed the options available to you. I'd like to point out that the primary focus should always be on the mortality issue. With that in mind, if you're going to have cancer, this is the one you want because when caught early and treated, it is almost always 100% survivable. Following treatment, most PC patients go on to lead a normal life. Yes, there are sometimes side effects but we're still here and you will be, also. If you really want to know what it's truly like to be depressed, when you have time, take a look at some of the other cancer threads on this website. Some have 5-year survivor rates of only 6-16%. I have friends on the lung cancer thread and I find it difficult to communicate with them without crying-- and I don't cry easily. So, as I see it, we're the lucky ones. And you'll still be here with plenty of time to settle with the IRS. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Dr Robert Reiter at UCLA and Dr Garrett S Matsunaga at Torrance Memorial

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate Two facts: 1. SBRT/Cyberknife is a whole gland treatment. It uses a precision targeting system to deliver highly focused radiation dosages. It is no more "focal" than a surgical cut, an EBRT beam, or a brachy seed. All whole gland treatments involve a series of local actions. 2. SBRT/Cyberknife is not new. It was FDA approved in 2001, and has treated over 40,000 patients, with the numbers sharply increasing in recent years. http://meetinglibrary.asco.org/record/119573/abstract https://www.sciencedaily.com/release...0418145458.htm While I am not a fan of super-star Dr. Samadi, just to throw a little gasoline on the Cyberknife discussion, here are his thoughts on the subject from his website: Q. What are the side effects of Cyber Knife? A. The negative side effects of CyberKnife® can be expected to mirror those of other targeted radiation therapies. Over the short term, radiation therapy for prostate cancer can cause: Urination problems including burning and blood in the urine Urinary urgency and frequency Weakened urinary stream Incomplete emptying of the bladder Anal and rectal irritation, rectal bleeding, hemorrhoids, and stool problems Fatigue and nausea Long-term CyberKnife® and prostate cancer radiation side effects may include: Sexual impotence and/or erectile dysfunction for up to 2 years after treatment Delayed orgasm or ejaculation Temporary or permanent reduction in sperm count; fertility should be discussed with your physician prior to CyberKnife® treatment Impaired bowel function Potential increased risk of bladder or rectal cancer by 5% And post-treatment patient satisfaction surveys repeatedly show Cyberknife as the LEAST popular method of treating prostate cancer, primarily due to radiation burns from the massive doses of radiation versus the decades-old gold standard of 35 - 40 sessions of EBRT.

Posts.Title: So much for Active Surveillance, for me anyway

Posts.Content: jefft: Thank you for sharing that wonderful news. It will go a long way toward helping others who find themselves in similar circumstances. I agree that the DaVinci machine has brought this disease to a level where it allows patients to experience the modern advances of science without the fear of so many who don't want to undergo the rigors of open surgery. Even more remarkable (at least to me) are the benefits rendered by the PSA test. The PSA led me to surgery. The PSA found the cancer when it returned and allowed me to proceed with salvage radiation. So, it may have saved my life twice. Whenever I'm in the company of guys over 50 who are friends or relatives, I beseech them to get annual PSA tests. Some never heard of the PSA and that's unfortunate because this is a disease that is almost always curable with early treatment. And the people on that government panel who want to save money and eliminate the PSA because it "may" lead to unnecessary treatment and unwanted side effects can go pound sand up their kazoo. They claim that only one life is saved for each PSA test, which I think is a horrible underestimate. What they fail to mention - even if you accept their numbers - is that for every one million PSA tests, a thousand lives are saved. If ANY test can save a thousand lives, that's a good thing, right? Again, congrats. Jim

Posts.Title: Path report clear....my story..

Posts.Content: "Bottom line MRI showed nothing to worry about a few months ago," Really? Except for the fact that you had ALREADY been diagnosed with prostate cancer prior to the MRI? Hi namvet6971: Got to be honest with you -- I've never seen a history quite like yours. You had a biopsy in August, 2015 revealing a Gleason 6 prostate cancer in 2 cores with an 80% involvement in one core. You went to Aruba. Then, in December 2015, after your PSA had inexplicably doubled in four months to 9.54, you decided on surgery and scheduled it for April. But, then because the PSA dropped in March, you cancelled the surgery and returned to active surveillance. Now, you underwent an MRI and another biopsy??? My head is starting to do that Linda Blair-type 360-degree spin from The Exorcist. You were diagnosed with prostate cancer via a biopsy!! Yes, it's a G6, however as Chuck noted, it's 80% involved. When your PSA number decreased in March, that didn't change the fact that you have prostate cancer. The lower PSA number doesn't mean the cancer went away!! If you had decided on surgery, the change in PSA IMHO had no bearing whatsoever on anything. What did you expect to accomplish with a second biopsy? You already know you have prostate cancer. What did you expect to accomplish with the recent MRI? You already know you have prostate cancer. Sorry. Had to wait for my head to stop spinning. Good luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Stay on WW or Opt for Surgery?

Posts.Content: Welcome fixit: This is the place to find support and caring people who will "gently" help to guide you. Unfortunately, I'm more pragmatic. Your urologist said to get a biopsy. Your response: "Oh, what should I do?". Again, following another PSA test, your doctor said to get a biopsy. Again, you procrastinated. Next, you have a 4k blood test which is a confirmation of nothing -- never is. You could have just as easily spent money on a palm reader. She can't confirm anything, either. As noted, only a biopsy will provide confirmation of cancer -- nothing else. It's not rocket science -- you need a biopsy. You have no monopoly on scared -- few of us can say we weren't afraid but it's a necessary evil -- you need the biopsy. It's nothing more than a diagnostic test, just as the PSA test is diagnostic and you didn't hesitate there. Complications arise in a very small percentage of biopsies. On the other hand, there is no debate about the fact that this can be a deadly disease but it's nearly 100% curable when found early and treated. Thirty thousand men die in the U.S. every year from prostate cancer. Don't be one of them. Your urologist went to medical school for a zillion years and he got it right. You need the biopsy. NOTE: A 3T MRI is performed in SUPPORY of a biopsy, not an opportunity to REJECT a biopsy which has ALREADY been determined is needed. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: 52 years old - don't know what to do. Please help

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pratoman I would like to correct a fallacy that's been stated here a number of times.. It is incorrect to say that surgery cannot be done after radiation. There are surgeons who do it, and some specialize in it. For example. The surgeons at MSKCC do it. Specifically, Dr James Eastham, you can go to his website and see that it's an area that he specializes in. It is clearly more difficult after radiation, and side effects Alan be more severe, but it can be done. Called Salvage surgery. I discussed this with my RO, in our consult. Also, there are other alternatives if brachybor EBRT fail, such as cryosurgery, and other treatments . So to say surgery is not an option after radiation is not correct. It's not as straightforward , but can be and is, done. Also, in my consult with the RO at MSKCC, he explained that salvage radiation, after failed surgery, is only successful 50% of the time. Two pints of contention: Whenever the discussion of not being able to have surgery after radiation, most members, including me, use the term "rarely". That's because only a handful of surgeons across the country will attempt it and most patients would have to fly to a strange city to be treated by a doctor whom they've never seen before. After the hospital stay, short-term recovery will be in a local hotel/motel before flying back home. Then what happens if there are complications once you return home? No local doctor is going to want to resolve problems created by a high-risk out-of-town surgery. And to say that salvage radiation is only successful 50% of the time is factually incorrect.

Posts.Title: First time posting

Posts.Content: "Depressed and barely functioning" Welcome Ernie: Your reaction to learning you have the "Big C" is certainly understandable. At age 55, you should not have to deal with this. As our esteemed moderator, Chuck, has pointed out based upon your test results, treatment is indicated. He listed the options available to you. I'd like to point out that the primary focus should always be on the mortality issue. With that in mind, if you're going to have cancer, this is the one you want because when caught early and treated, it is almost always 100% survivable. Following treatment, most PC patients go on to lead a normal life. Yes, there are sometimes side effects but we're still here and you will be, also. If you really want to know what it's truly like to be depressed, when you have time, take a look at some of the other cancer threads on this website. Some have 5-year survivor rates of only 6-16%. I have friends on the lung cancer thread and I find it difficult to communicate with them without crying-- and I don't cry easily. So, as I see it, we're the lucky ones. And you'll still be here with plenty of time to settle with the IRS. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: New patient in the box

Posts.Content: Hi Mike: Over the years, patients always seem to be in a rush to get their first post-surgery PSA result and it can often be misleading. At six weeks post-surgery, your PSA of 1.1 is certainly not undetectable, but it may not tell the whole story. History has shown that the PSA reading at 3 months post-surgery is a more reliable number. With that said, it is not intended to minimize the G8-9 you are dealing with and the anticipated follow-up radiation and HT. My salvage radiation is nearly 4 years in the rear-view mirror and, although I was G7, my PSA remains at 0.00. So, a successful outcome IS possible. For how long? Who knows? Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Content: From your husband's history: "Planning on DaVinci after chemo & probable radiation" Michael caught that -- I missed it. I'd be interested in knowing the name and specialty of the doctor who made that recommendation. In years and years of following prostate cancer outcomes, I have NEVER seen treatment offered in that sequence. Or is this a plan of action that you arrived at on your own? Normally, when radiation is employed as primary treatment for PC, surgery is not an option later. Good luck, Jim

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by newporter . For example, an Italian study published in 2010 looked at post op PNI found by post op pathology and recurrence. Here is a link to the report: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20516669 And here is the statement they made: The actuarial biochemical progression-free survival rate for all patients was 96.9 and 93.5% at 60 and 84 months, respectively, and the stratification based on the presence or absence of PNI did not allow us to identify different prognostic groups. Here is a summary by The "NEW" Prostate Cancer Infolink: http://prostatecancerinfolink.net/20...me-of-surgery/ who stated: This study appears to suggest that the prognostic impact of PNI on risk for progressive prostate cancer is actually much lower than has been assumed in the past. So, I believe mom2two should not worry too much about the PNI finding in the pathology report. Peace. AN ITALIAN STUDY?? With all of the high tech medical resources in this country, we're going to fall back on a 4-year-old ITALIAN study?

Posts.Title: Finally post-op pathology results...input welcome!

Posts.Content: Welcome fixit: This is the place to find support and caring people who will "gently" help to guide you. Unfortunately, I'm more pragmatic. Your urologist said to get a biopsy. Your response: "Oh, what should I do?". Again, following another PSA test, your doctor said to get a biopsy. Again, you procrastinated. Next, you have a 4k blood test which is a confirmation of nothing -- never is. You could have just as easily spent money on a palm reader. She can't confirm anything, either. As noted, only a biopsy will provide confirmation of cancer -- nothing else. It's not rocket science -- you need a biopsy. You have no monopoly on scared -- few of us can say we weren't afraid but it's a necessary evil -- you need the biopsy. It's nothing more than a diagnostic test, just as the PSA test is diagnostic and you didn't hesitate there. Complications arise in a very small percentage of biopsies. On the other hand, there is no debate about the fact that this can be a deadly disease but it's nearly 100% curable when found early and treated. Thirty thousand men die in the U.S. every year from prostate cancer. Don't be one of them. Your urologist went to medical school for a zillion years and he got it right. You need the biopsy. NOTE: A 3T MRI is performed in SUPPORY of a biopsy, not an opportunity to REJECT a biopsy which has ALREADY been determined is needed. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Content: Pratoman: I can't speak to the lymph node but I reiterate your observation that the tiny 3mm lung nodule is only 2 more than one silly little millimeter. If you look closely at my lung history, you will find a nodule SIX TIMES larger at 1.8 CM. It scared me. Three doctors had their fingers on the slice-and-dice machine but the damn thing disappeared at the end of 3 months. One thing I did learn about pulmonology is that the overall public would be aghast if they knew the junk that floats intermittently into and out of their lungs -- some harmful, some not. This MAY be nothing -- stay strong. Jim

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate Two facts: 1. SBRT/Cyberknife is a whole gland treatment. It uses a precision targeting system to deliver highly focused radiation dosages. It is no more "focal" than a surgical cut, an EBRT beam, or a brachy seed. All whole gland treatments involve a series of local actions. 2. SBRT/Cyberknife is not new. It was FDA approved in 2001, and has treated over 40,000 patients, with the numbers sharply increasing in recent years. http://meetinglibrary.asco.org/record/119573/abstract https://www.sciencedaily.com/release...0418145458.htm While I am not a fan of super-star Dr. Samadi, just to throw a little gasoline on the Cyberknife discussion, here are his thoughts on the subject from his website: Q. What are the side effects of Cyber Knife? A. The negative side effects of CyberKnife® can be expected to mirror those of other targeted radiation therapies. Over the short term, radiation therapy for prostate cancer can cause: Urination problems including burning and blood in the urine Urinary urgency and frequency Weakened urinary stream Incomplete emptying of the bladder Anal and rectal irritation, rectal bleeding, hemorrhoids, and stool problems Fatigue and nausea Long-term CyberKnife® and prostate cancer radiation side effects may include: Sexual impotence and/or erectile dysfunction for up to 2 years after treatment Delayed orgasm or ejaculation Temporary or permanent reduction in sperm count; fertility should be discussed with your physician prior to CyberKnife® treatment Impaired bowel function Potential increased risk of bladder or rectal cancer by 5% And post-treatment patient satisfaction surveys repeatedly show Cyberknife as the LEAST popular method of treating prostate cancer, primarily due to radiation burns from the massive doses of radiation versus the decades-old gold standard of 35 - 40 sessions of EBRT.

Posts.Content: You raise the "quality of life" question that many people eventually have to address. Do you want to extend life as long as possible? Or do you want to retain the "quality of life" that you have always experienced? It's a dilemma that touches on joint philosophical beliefs. Some people turn to religious guidance while others do not. In my view, that is a question that can never be adequately answered on a forum. Only you and your spouse can decide what is best for yourselves. What the rest of us would do is irrelevant.

Posts.Title: SM88 therapeutic treatment for cancer

Posts.Content: "Depressed and barely functioning" Welcome Ernie: Your reaction to learning you have the "Big C" is certainly understandable. At age 55, you should not have to deal with this. As our esteemed moderator, Chuck, has pointed out based upon your test results, treatment is indicated. He listed the options available to you. I'd like to point out that the primary focus should always be on the mortality issue. With that in mind, if you're going to have cancer, this is the one you want because when caught early and treated, it is almost always 100% survivable. Following treatment, most PC patients go on to lead a normal life. Yes, there are sometimes side effects but we're still here and you will be, also. If you really want to know what it's truly like to be depressed, when you have time, take a look at some of the other cancer threads on this website. Some have 5-year survivor rates of only 6-16%. I have friends on the lung cancer thread and I find it difficult to communicate with them without crying-- and I don't cry easily. So, as I see it, we're the lucky ones. And you'll still be here with plenty of time to settle with the IRS. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Dr Robert Reiter at UCLA and Dr Garrett S Matsunaga at Torrance Memorial

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pratoman I would like to correct a fallacy that's been stated here a number of times.. It is incorrect to say that surgery cannot be done after radiation. There are surgeons who do it, and some specialize in it. For example. The surgeons at MSKCC do it. Specifically, Dr James Eastham, you can go to his website and see that it's an area that he specializes in. It is clearly more difficult after radiation, and side effects Alan be more severe, but it can be done. Called Salvage surgery. I discussed this with my RO, in our consult. Also, there are other alternatives if brachybor EBRT fail, such as cryosurgery, and other treatments . So to say surgery is not an option after radiation is not correct. It's not as straightforward , but can be and is, done. Also, in my consult with the RO at MSKCC, he explained that salvage radiation, after failed surgery, is only successful 50% of the time. Two pints of contention: Whenever the discussion of not being able to have surgery after radiation, most members, including me, use the term "rarely". That's because only a handful of surgeons across the country will attempt it and most patients would have to fly to a strange city to be treated by a doctor whom they've never seen before. After the hospital stay, short-term recovery will be in a local hotel/motel before flying back home. Then what happens if there are complications once you return home? No local doctor is going to want to resolve problems created by a high-risk out-of-town surgery. And to say that salvage radiation is only successful 50% of the time is factually incorrect.

Posts.Title: New patient in the box

Posts.Content: "Bottom line MRI showed nothing to worry about a few months ago," Really? Except for the fact that you had ALREADY been diagnosed with prostate cancer prior to the MRI? Hi namvet6971: Got to be honest with you -- I've never seen a history quite like yours. You had a biopsy in August, 2015 revealing a Gleason 6 prostate cancer in 2 cores with an 80% involvement in one core. You went to Aruba. Then, in December 2015, after your PSA had inexplicably doubled in four months to 9.54, you decided on surgery and scheduled it for April. But, then because the PSA dropped in March, you cancelled the surgery and returned to active surveillance. Now, you underwent an MRI and another biopsy??? My head is starting to do that Linda Blair-type 360-degree spin from The Exorcist. You were diagnosed with prostate cancer via a biopsy!! Yes, it's a G6, however as Chuck noted, it's 80% involved. When your PSA number decreased in March, that didn't change the fact that you have prostate cancer. The lower PSA number doesn't mean the cancer went away!! If you had decided on surgery, the change in PSA IMHO had no bearing whatsoever on anything. What did you expect to accomplish with a second biopsy? You already know you have prostate cancer. What did you expect to accomplish with the recent MRI? You already know you have prostate cancer. Sorry. Had to wait for my head to stop spinning. Good luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Stay on WW or Opt for Surgery?

Posts.Content: Welcome fixit: This is the place to find support and caring people who will "gently" help to guide you. Unfortunately, I'm more pragmatic. Your urologist said to get a biopsy. Your response: "Oh, what should I do?". Again, following another PSA test, your doctor said to get a biopsy. Again, you procrastinated. Next, you have a 4k blood test which is a confirmation of nothing -- never is. You could have just as easily spent money on a palm reader. She can't confirm anything, either. As noted, only a biopsy will provide confirmation of cancer -- nothing else. It's not rocket science -- you need a biopsy. You have no monopoly on scared -- few of us can say we weren't afraid but it's a necessary evil -- you need the biopsy. It's nothing more than a diagnostic test, just as the PSA test is diagnostic and you didn't hesitate there. Complications arise in a very small percentage of biopsies. On the other hand, there is no debate about the fact that this can be a deadly disease but it's nearly 100% curable when found early and treated. Thirty thousand men die in the U.S. every year from prostate cancer. Don't be one of them. Your urologist went to medical school for a zillion years and he got it right. You need the biopsy. NOTE: A 3T MRI is performed in SUPPORY of a biopsy, not an opportunity to REJECT a biopsy which has ALREADY been determined is needed. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Content: My only cystoscopy had nothing to do with my prostate cancer. In 2008 and 2014, I had a kidney stone block my left ureter -- horrible, horribly painful -- and had to have surgery to have it removed (two nights in hospital -- fun, fun, fun). After each surgery, standard procedure is to place a stent in the ureter that must remain in place for 7 to 10 days to prevent it from collapsing. In 2008, the stent caused me to have significant pain. Couldn't wait to get it out. In 2014, three days after surgery, I awoke at home to find that I could not urinate. Not a drop. Very scary. I had visions of my bladder expanding and exploding. Called the uro and he had me come to the office where he used a temporary catheter to clear the blockage. On the fifth day after surgery, the same thing happened. No pain but couldn't pee. Back to the office where he started to insert the cystoscope. I started moaning. He said "What's wrong?". I said I was scared to death something very bad was about to happen. He put the scope in -- no pain at all, just a weird feeling. He cleared the blockage, then removed the scope and went back in and removed the stent. Also, no pain or discomfort after the procedure. All in all, I found the cystoscopy to be a piece of cake. Hope you have the same experience.

Posts.Content: Shortly after the government panel recommended that men NOT have PSA testing because of POSSIBLE unnecessary treatment and was cause for anxiety, the head doctor at AARP went on record agreeing with that finding. I immediately cancelled my membership in AARP, because PSA tests helped to save my life TWICE (primary and secondary PC) and I will not associate myself with any asshole doctor who publically makes comments that can cost the lives of patients. Since 1992, when PSA tests first became widely available, death by prostate cancer has fallen 44%. Government panels are only interested in saving money by reducing or eliminating testing (including recommending no mammograms for women before age 50) and the many dead bodies created by such mindlessness are simply collateral damage to them.

AgeInfo.Phrase: mammograms for women before age 50  and the many dead bodies

Posts.Title: New Finding Regarding PSA Testing

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pratoman I would like to correct a fallacy that's been stated here a number of times.. It is incorrect to say that surgery cannot be done after radiation. There are surgeons who do it, and some specialize in it. For example. The surgeons at MSKCC do it. Specifically, Dr James Eastham, you can go to his website and see that it's an area that he specializes in. It is clearly more difficult after radiation, and side effects Alan be more severe, but it can be done. Called Salvage surgery. I discussed this with my RO, in our consult. Also, there are other alternatives if brachybor EBRT fail, such as cryosurgery, and other treatments . So to say surgery is not an option after radiation is not correct. It's not as straightforward , but can be and is, done. Also, in my consult with the RO at MSKCC, he explained that salvage radiation, after failed surgery, is only successful 50% of the time. Two pints of contention: Whenever the discussion of not being able to have surgery after radiation, most members, including me, use the term "rarely". That's because only a handful of surgeons across the country will attempt it and most patients would have to fly to a strange city to be treated by a doctor whom they've never seen before. After the hospital stay, short-term recovery will be in a local hotel/motel before flying back home. Then what happens if there are complications once you return home? No local doctor is going to want to resolve problems created by a high-risk out-of-town surgery. And to say that salvage radiation is only successful 50% of the time is factually incorrect.

Posts.Title: New patient in the box

Posts.Content: "Depressed and barely functioning" Welcome Ernie: Your reaction to learning you have the "Big C" is certainly understandable. At age 55, you should not have to deal with this. As our esteemed moderator, Chuck, has pointed out based upon your test results, treatment is indicated. He listed the options available to you. I'd like to point out that the primary focus should always be on the mortality issue. With that in mind, if you're going to have cancer, this is the one you want because when caught early and treated, it is almost always 100% survivable. Following treatment, most PC patients go on to lead a normal life. Yes, there are sometimes side effects but we're still here and you will be, also. If you really want to know what it's truly like to be depressed, when you have time, take a look at some of the other cancer threads on this website. Some have 5-year survivor rates of only 6-16%. I have friends on the lung cancer thread and I find it difficult to communicate with them without crying-- and I don't cry easily. So, as I see it, we're the lucky ones. And you'll still be here with plenty of time to settle with the IRS. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Dr Robert Reiter at UCLA and Dr Garrett S Matsunaga at Torrance Memorial

Posts.Content: Welcome fixit: This is the place to find support and caring people who will "gently" help to guide you. Unfortunately, I'm more pragmatic. Your urologist said to get a biopsy. Your response: "Oh, what should I do?". Again, following another PSA test, your doctor said to get a biopsy. Again, you procrastinated. Next, you have a 4k blood test which is a confirmation of nothing -- never is. You could have just as easily spent money on a palm reader. She can't confirm anything, either. As noted, only a biopsy will provide confirmation of cancer -- nothing else. It's not rocket science -- you need a biopsy. You have no monopoly on scared -- few of us can say we weren't afraid but it's a necessary evil -- you need the biopsy. It's nothing more than a diagnostic test, just as the PSA test is diagnostic and you didn't hesitate there. Complications arise in a very small percentage of biopsies. On the other hand, there is no debate about the fact that this can be a deadly disease but it's nearly 100% curable when found early and treated. Thirty thousand men die in the U.S. every year from prostate cancer. Don't be one of them. Your urologist went to medical school for a zillion years and he got it right. You need the biopsy. NOTE: A 3T MRI is performed in SUPPORY of a biopsy, not an opportunity to REJECT a biopsy which has ALREADY been determined is needed. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Content: Shortly after the government panel recommended that men NOT have PSA testing because of POSSIBLE unnecessary treatment and was cause for anxiety, the head doctor at AARP went on record agreeing with that finding. I immediately cancelled my membership in AARP, because PSA tests helped to save my life TWICE (primary and secondary PC) and I will not associate myself with any asshole doctor who publically makes comments that can cost the lives of patients. Since 1992, when PSA tests first became widely available, death by prostate cancer has fallen 44%. Government panels are only interested in saving money by reducing or eliminating testing (including recommending no mammograms for women before age 50) and the many dead bodies created by such mindlessness are simply collateral damage to them.

Posts.Title: New Finding Regarding PSA Testing

Posts.Content: Hi George: I'm a little confused by your post where you identified "Final Surgical Pathology Report" which indicates that surgery has taken place. Then, you mentioned a PET Scan to determine if the cancer has spread. I could be wrong but my experience has been that the scan has normally been performed before surgery because if the cancer has metastasized, there is no surgery. As you are almost certainly aware by now, a Gleason score of 10 represents an advanced aggressive form of prostate cancer. Certainly, if your Dad is comfortable with you being present, I would strongly encourage you to join him for the doctor's consultation. Rather than provide a long list of questions to ask the doctor on this page, I recommend you simply Google a request for prostate questions on any reputable cancer website and print it out and bring it with you. Best of luck. Jim

Posts.Title: Dad was Just Diagnosed

Posts.Content: Hi Mike: Over the years, patients always seem to be in a rush to get their first post-surgery PSA result and it can often be misleading. At six weeks post-surgery, your PSA of 1.1 is certainly not undetectable, but it may not tell the whole story. History has shown that the PSA reading at 3 months post-surgery is a more reliable number. With that said, it is not intended to minimize the G8-9 you are dealing with and the anticipated follow-up radiation and HT. My salvage radiation is nearly 4 years in the rear-view mirror and, although I was G7, my PSA remains at 0.00. So, a successful outcome IS possible. For how long? Who knows? Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Content: Granted I was older. But each of us have a tendency to either view the glass as half-full or half-empty. I fall into the former category so depression was never an issue for me. For my whole life, I have dealt with negative issues by simply accepting that each of us must play the cards we are dealt (you may have guessed I'm a poker player -- played 5 times in the World Series of Poker). And, when asked, I offer the opinion that sex is highly over-rated when compared to death. Perhaps that's too simplistic but that's my view. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Content: I am slightly familiar with the "tools" that Chuck referred to but they never made much sense to me. Depending on the questionable accuracy of those tests, you could receive a worrisome result or a possible non-worrisome number that is false. If all roads lead to the biopsy, which is the only way to confirm cancer, then I would be inclined to skip the middle step and simply proceed with a biopsy, albeit a somewhat uncomfortable test, as you are fully aware.

Posts.Content: Houndly: You had a $3k biopsy and your doctor didn't tell you in advance that your insurance -- out-of-network crap -- wouldn't cover the cost? Of course, they will say that it was your obligation to confirm the coverage before the test but, nevertheless, if they pulled that stunt on me, you would have to scrap me off of the ceiling. And I would be inclined to change urologists because of it. Jim

Posts.Title: Choosing Surgeon in NYC

Posts.Content: Brett: Please don't apologize for providing "too much detail". On the contrary, it's the detail that helps guide others on this site who may still be in the decision stage as to how to move ahead in the treatment of prostate cancer. All information is valued and appreciated. I'm sorry you have had such a difficult family and personal history that included thyroid cancer. Under the category "Misery loves company", next month it looks like I'll be needing a biopsy of the thyroid too, to determine whether some suspicious growths are cancerous. I have come to view cancer overall as equivalent to the carnival game called "Whack a Mole". No sooner do you knock it down with a large mallet, the damn stuff pops up somewhere else. For the time being, at least, I am able to sign all of my e-mails with the post-script "I'm still here". Wishing you the best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Surgeon in Northern VA?

Posts.Content: DR said it was not in all of the 12 samples In addition to your Gleason score, you will want to know exactly how many cores were cancerous and their degree of involvement by percentage. Our esteemed moderator, Chuck, should drop by shortly and recommend that you obtain a copy of the "bible" of prostate cancer, a book written by Dr. Pat Walsh. You will learn that this disease has many variables, including treatment options. While surgery and radiation have almost similar "cure" rates, at age 56, the doctor may lean toward surgery. But don't put the cart in front of the horse. First, gather as much info as possible from your doctor. On the positive side, prostate and colon cancer have nearly a 100% survival rate, when caught early and treated. Other types of cancer (pancreatic and lung), not so much. There are no MDs on this site -- only guys who have gone through the process and who can share with you their experiences which is often helpful to those newly diagnosed. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Content: Hi: While my Gleason score was not as high at 3+4=7, the history below may be helpful as you read my signature regarding the success of salvage radiotherapy following robotic surgery. As Chuck pointed out, a decision on SR may be premature unless there is a higher detected PSA reading. My only suggestion is that, rather than wait the full six months to schedule the next PSA test, I would probably want it performed at 3-month intervals. Best of luck. Jim

Posts.Content: Target number of ??? Who picks the number -- you or a doctor? Damn, you've already been through the worst of it. You did all of that because you recognized the risk of not getting treatment. Do you really want to play a numbers game NOW and possibly get it wrong? If you are here seeking input, my input is that you are indeed already trending and I would not dick around with playing Russian roulette with the numbers. Please listen closely to the oncologist next week and, if you are so inclined, get a second opinion. Then formulate a game plan and act on it. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: New Member

Posts.Content: While I agree with everything Chuck said, I'd just like to add (as I often do) that if you experience a recurrence after primary treatment, if you choose surgery, you will have the opportunity for salvage radiation. Not so if you select radiation as the primary treatment. That fact was what led me to choose surgery and, as you can see from my history, it was a good thing that I did because the PC returned 3 years after my surgery. This decision is not for everyone but by getting a second bite at the apple, it has, so far at least, worked well for me as all PSA tests taken since my salvage radiation have resulted in readings of 0.00. Again, best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Just found out

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by timeshifter That's a very modest change, and many people wouldn't consider that to necessarily be failure as above; nevertheless, the goal PSA after surgery is zero. Two main options include continued monitoring or radiation (due to it being Gleason 8, some people would use hormone therapy for 6 months around radiation). How's the recovery of continence going? The radiation doctors often prefer to allow maximum recovery of urinary continence before going with radiation. I respectfully disagree that a reading of 1.8 PSA following a prostatectomy is "modest". If fact, any reading exceeding 0.2 PSA sets off flashing red lights and bells and loud whistles in my urologist's office. Three years after my Da Vinci prostatectomy in Nov., 2010, my PSA has inched back up to 0.16 while doubling in less than one year. After consultations with my urologist and an oncology radiologist, last summer I received 40 treatments of radiation to the prostate bed area. This was followed 3 months later by my first ever true 0.00 PSA reading. It's worth noting that the $240,000 worth of radiation was approved by Medicare even though my PSA reading was less than 10% of Beeman's friend's reading. If the OP can wait until his October Medicare coverage kicks in, he may find less resistance in seeking out insurance payments for services that may be needed.
Posts.Title: PSA creeping up after Da Vinci surgery

Posts.Content: Hi Tilly: If the biopsy comes back confirming prostate cancer (and, of course, it's not cancer yet until the biopsy says it is -- we may be jumping ahead too quickly), then age 77 may indeed become a factor in treatment recommendations. As a general rule of thumb -- and there are always exceptions -- in my doctor's group of 9 urologists, they lean toward surgery before age 60, it's a toss-up between surgery and radiation between ages 60 and 70, and over age 70 radiation is the treatment of choice. Even a person who is a "fit" age 77 may be encouraged to forego surgery to avoid a potential traumatic reaction to the rigors of surgery -- both open and robotic. As long as the cancer has not metastasized to other distant areas of the body (normally found via a full-body bone scan), then radiation has a successful "cure" rate about equal to surgery. As Chuck mentioned, the main focus will be on whether the cancer remains encapsulated within the prostate. Best of luck, Jim

As far as "Where to from here", there doesn't seem to be much urgency at this point, even with 70% involvement of a single G6 core. As far as paying for focal treatment out of pocket, it's like setting fire to a stack of hundred-dollar bills for no reason. While I'm personally not a fan of active surveillance, your case may be a perfect fit until such time that changes occur. Your doctor will likely contribute more to your knowledge base and provide a recommendation when you meet with him in a month. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Where to from here

Posts.Content: Welcome Mike: Please correct me if I'm wrong. You are scheduled on Sept. 28th to have prostatectomy surgery but you are vacillating over whether you should have chosen brachytherapy? On this site, among other things, we try to provide support to those who have decided on a particular treatment. With that said, other than the known potential side effects of surgery, may I ask what caused you to focus on brachytherapy? While there is certainly a place for brachytherapy among various options in treating prostate cancer, it fits a niche outside the mainstream of either surgery or external radiation and comes with its own set of side effects. With all due respect to the doctor who quoted brachytherapy as the choice of 25% of men at age 50, my research shows brachy as the overall choice of only 2% of patients. And, if that 2% is correct, then if I were you, I would investigate why 98% of patients reject it or do not qualify to receive it. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Content: While I agree with everything Chuck said, I'd just like to add (as I often do) that if you experience a recurrence after primary treatment, if you choose surgery, you will have the opportunity for salvage radiation. Not so if you select radiation as the primary treatment. That fact was what led me to choose surgery and, as you can see from my history, it was a good thing that I did because the PC returned 3 years after my surgery. This decision is not for everyone but by getting a second bite at the apple, it has, so far at least, worked well for me as all PSA tests taken since my salvage radiation have resulted in readings of 0.00. Again, best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Just found out

Posts.Content: If you have a leaking roof, you would accept the recommendation of a roofer to fix it. If the lights are flickering in your house, you would accept the recommendation of an electrician to fix it. But when you have a rising PSA and you know that 30,000 men die every year from prostate cancer, you TWICE reject the recommendations of highly-educated urologists to, at the very least, perform a diagnostic biopsy to learn what you are dealing with. Unlike deadly other cancers (think pancreatic cancer) that give you virtually zero options for a cure, prostate cancer is nearly 100% curable but ONLY when found EARLY and treated. Your home may be dry from a repaired roof and the risk of an electrical fire can be resolved with the work of a skilled electrician but neither will be of any value to you if next year the list of men who die from prostate cancer have 29,999 names on it plus yours. Don't dick around. Don't give it a chance to spread. Get the biopsy -- NOW.

Posts.Title: Elevated and rising PSA, what should I do?

Posts.Content: Hi Donald: I'm sure it is not much consolation but last Sunday, I, too, had severe pain and wound up in the ER. It was my birthday and friends were visiting from three states to help me celebrate. Talk about a party killer. The source of my pain was a kidney stone completely blocking the left ureter. Although I was able to urinate, it appeared to be just blood. After six hours of intravenous saline, the hydration apparently was sufficient to break loose the stone that was ripping into the side of the ureter creating the blood and I was able to pass it. In an identical occurrence six years ago, I was admitted to the hospital, my first-ever catheter was implanted, I was placed on morphine for 24 hours and my first kidney stone had to be surgically removed. That was followed by the insertion of a stent in the ureter, almost as painful as my reason for being there originally, that had to remain in place for five days. In your case, Chuck is almost certain to be correct about a BPH complicated by an infection (especially with your history involving Flomax), because the only other scenario that seems reasonable/logical to explain your inability to pass any urine would be the unlikely blockages of both ureters at the same time, allowing a small amount of urine to flow through to the bladder and the catheter. But the odds of that happening would probably be equal to being struck by lightning twice in one week. Since we are not medical personnel on this site, we can share with you only our personal experiences and can't offer medical advice. But I would neither worry about having the catheter the rest of your life nor the likelihood that you're looking at cancer -- at least not yet. We all fear the unknown and your wife is probably more frightened than you are but everything has an explanation and you will almost certainly learn the cause when you consult with the urologist, assuming a Cat Scan or MRI was performed to try to identify the location of the blockage. Please let us know your outcome. Wishing you the very best, Jim

Posts.Title: Elevated and rising PSA, what should I do?

Posts.Content: Welcome fella: With a family history of prostate cancer, you are doing an excellent job of keeping an ongoing record of any changes in your PSA results. But, while qualifying any comments to follow as coming from a non-medical professional, I see nothing at this point that is outside normal parameters for your age. As Southsider correctly points out, when antibiotics reduced your PSA numbers, it also confirms that the prior rise in your PSA was not due to cancer simply because cancer would likely not be affected by an antibiotic. I believe the current medical protocol is to consider a biopsy if your PSA reaches or exceeds a reading of 4.0. If you have confidence in your urologist, I would tend to follow his recommendations while keeping a close eye on your PSA or, as suggested by ASAdvocate, a free PSA test may help to put your mind at ease. Finally, try to not let the issue take a disproportionate amount of your time and mindset. It appears that much would have to change before PC should be feared as life-threatening in your case. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: HDR Brachytherapy as a mono therapy vs. Surgery

Posts.Content: Welcome Mike: Please correct me if I'm wrong. You are scheduled on Sept. 28th to have prostatectomy surgery but you are vacillating over whether you should have chosen brachytherapy? On this site, among other things, we try to provide support to those who have decided on a particular treatment. With that said, other than the known potential side effects of surgery, may I ask what caused you to focus on brachytherapy? While there is certainly a place for brachytherapy among various options in treating prostate cancer, it fits a niche outside the mainstream of either surgery or external radiation and comes with its own set of side effects. With all due respect to the doctor who quoted brachytherapy as the choice of 25% of men at age 50, my research shows brachy as the overall choice of only 2% of patients. And, if that 2% is correct, then if I were you, I would investigate why 98% of patients reject it or do not qualify to receive it. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Newbie: From Lurker to Club Member

Posts.Content: Hi Tilly: If the biopsy comes back confirming prostate cancer (and, of course, it's not cancer yet until the biopsy says it is -- we may be jumping ahead too quickly), then age 77 may indeed become a factor in treatment recommendations. As a general rule of thumb -- and there are always exceptions -- in my doctor's group of 9 urologists, they lean toward surgery before age 60, it's a toss-up between surgery and radiation between ages 60 and 70, and over age 70 radiation is the treatment of choice. Even a person who is a "fit" age 77 may be encouraged to forego surgery to avoid a potential traumatic reaction to the rigors of surgery -- both open and robotic. As long as the cancer has not metastasized to other distant areas of the body (normally found via a full-body bone scan), then radiation has a successful "cure" rate about equal to surgery. As Chuck mentioned, the main focus will be on whether the cancer remains encapsulated within the prostate. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Newbie: From Lurker to Club Member

Posts.Content: If you have a leaking roof, you would accept the recommendation of a roofer to fix it. If the lights are flickering in your house, you would accept the recommendation of an electrician to fix it. But when you have a rising PSA and you know that 30,000 men die every year from prostate cancer, you TWICE reject the recommendations of highly-educated urologists to, at the very least, perform a diagnostic biopsy to learn what you are dealing with. Unlike deadly other cancers (think pancreatic cancer) that give you virtually zero options for a cure, prostate cancer is nearly 100% curable but ONLY when found EARLY and treated. Your home may be dry from a repaired roof and the risk of an electrical fire can be resolved with the work of a skilled electrician but neither will be of any value to you if next year the list of men who die from prostate cancer have 29,999 names on it plus yours. Don't dick around. Don't give it a chance to spread. Get the biopsy -- NOW.

Posts.Title: Prostate cancer size

Posts.Content: Hey Bull: Anyone who says he wasn't somewhat nervous prior to surgery would likely not pass a polygraph test. I always think of it as nothing more than the equivalent of repairing a part that might become defective on your car. The only difference is that the car doesn't have to deal with a catheter afterwards. But even though the catheter was a nuisance, it caused me zero pain. In fact, I took a single pain pill following surgery. Since you asked, my "suggestion" is to appreciate the fact that you are almost certainly enroute to an actual cure. Many patients suffering from other types of cancer are not nearly so lucky. All the best to you, Sir, Jim

Posts.Title: Time set for my Robotic Prostatectomy

Posts.Content: Hi Donald: I'm sure it is not much consolation but last Sunday, I, too, had severe pain and wound up in the ER. It was my birthday and friends were visiting from three states to help me celebrate. Talk about a party killer. The source of my pain was a kidney stone completely blocking the left ureter. Although I was able to urinate, it appeared to be just blood. After six hours of intravenous saline, the hydration apparently was sufficient to break loose the stone that was ripping into the side of the ureter creating the blood and I was able to pass it. In an identical occurrence six years ago, I was admitted to the hospital, my first-ever catheter was implanted, I was placed on morphine for 24 hours and my first kidney stone had to be surgically removed. That was followed by the insertion of a stent in the ureter, almost as painful as my reason for being there originally, that had to remain in place for five days. In your case, Chuck is almost certain to be correct about a BPH complicated by an infection (especially with your history involving Flomax), because the only other scenario that seems reasonable/logical to explain your inability to pass any urine would be the unlikely blockages of both ureters at the same time, allowing a small amount of urine to flow through to the bladder and the catheter. But the odds of that happening would probably be equal to being struck by lightning twice in one week. Since we are not medical personnel on this site, we can share with you only our personal experiences and can't offer medical advice. But I would neither worry about having the catheter the rest of your life nor the likelihood that you're looking at cancer -- at least not yet. We all fear the unknown and your wife is probably more frightened than you are but everything has an explanation and you will almost certainly learn the cause when you consult with the urologist, assuming a Cat Scan or MRI was performed to try to identify the location of the blockage. Please let us know your outcome. Wishing you the very best, Jim

Posts.Content: If you have a leaking roof, you would accept the recommendation of a roofer to fix it. If the lights are flickering in your house, you would accept the recommendation of an electrician to fix it. But when you have a rising PSA and you know that 30,000 men die every year from prostate cancer, you TWICE reject the recommendations of highly-educated urologists to, at the very least, perform a diagnostic biopsy to learn what you are dealing with. Unlike deadly other cancers (think pancreatic cancer) that give you virtually zero options for a cure, prostate cancer is nearly 100% curable but ONLY when found EARLY and treated. Your home may be dry from a repaired roof and the risk of an electrical fire can be resolved with the work of a skilled electrician but neither will be of any value to you if next year the list of men who die from prostate cancer have 29,999 names on it plus yours. Don't dick around. Don't give it a chance to spread. Get the biopsy -- NOW.

Posts.Title: Lymphadenectomy?

Posts.Content: Hi Donald: I'm sure it is not much consolation but last Sunday, I, too, had severe pain and wound up in the ER. It was my birthday and friends were visiting from three states to help me celebrate. Talk about a party killer. The source of my pain was a kidney stone completely blocking the left ureter. Although I was able to urinate, it appeared to be just blood. After six hours of intravenous saline, the hydration apparently was sufficient to break loose the stone that was ripping into the side of the ureter creating the blood and I was able to pass it. In an identical occurrence six years ago, I was admitted to the hospital, my first-ever catheter was implanted, I was placed on morphine for 24 hours and my first kidney stone had to be surgically removed. That was followed by the insertion of a stent in the ureter, almost as painful as my reason for being there originally, that had to remain in place for five days. In your case, Chuck is almost certain to be correct about a BPH complicated by an infection (especially with your history involving Flomax), because the only other scenario that seems reasonable/logical to explain your inability to pass any urine would be the unlikely blockages of both ureters at the same time, allowing a small amount of urine to flow through to the bladder and the catheter. But the odds of that happening would probably be equal to being struck by lightning twice in one week. Since we are not medical personnel on this site, we can share with you only our personal experiences and can't offer medical advice. But I would neither worry about having the catheter the rest of your life nor the likelihood that you're looking at cancer -- at least not yet. We all fear the unknown and your wife is probably more frightened than you are but everything has an explanation and you will almost certainly learn the cause when you consult with the urologist, assuming a Cat Scan or MRI was performed to try to identify the location of the blockage. Please let us know your outcome. Wishing you the very best, Jim

Posts.Title: Looking back

Posts.Content: Getting kicked out of Medicare Advantage may not be a bad thing. Overall, the history of Advantage plans are not very inviting. I assume your former employer was paying at least a portion of your Advantage premiums. However, Advantage in many instances has such high deductibles and co-pays, it is sometimes referred to as "non-insurance". An example would be that my neighbor with Medicare Advantage has a co-pay of $40 for each family doctor visit and an $80 co-pay to visit a specialist. On the other hand, traditional Medicare has no networks for you to adhere to and you don't need a "permission slip" to see a specialist. Since turning 65, I have had Medicare plus supplemental coverage. During that time, I have never filled out an insurance form nor paid a single penny of deductible (covered by my Medigap insurance) or ever paid any co-pays. Personally, I think it's the best route to take (although I'm sure others have a different point of view).

Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed husband - ?'s to ask Doc at our first appt?

Posts.Content: Hi Pratoman: Newporter is on the right wave length. It's not so much how high a PSA reading has increased in a year -- more so the PSADT, or PSA doubling time, that concerns most urologists. Your doctor may be right about a >50% chance of cancer -- or not. After my biopsy, I asked what the odds were that I had cancer. The response: 20%. He was wrong. After my prostatectomy, I asked the surgeon what the odds are of my cancer returning. The response: 20%. He was wrong, too. After my salvage radiotherapy, I asked the oncologist what the odds are of my cancer returning. The response: about 20%. So -- true story -- in the company of my daughter, I placed a $20 bet several times on #20 on the roulette wheel at the Borgata in Atlantic City. I won $700 (35 to 1). My point is that if my docs were wrong at 20%, in order to have an equal balance to the universe, your doc could be wrong about >than 50%. Good luck. Jim

Your doctor may be right about a >50% chance of cancer -- or not. After my biopsy, I asked what the odds were that I had cancer. The response: 20%. He was wrong. After my prostatectomy, I asked the surgeon what the odds are of my cancer returning. The response: 20%. He was wrong, too. After my salvage radiotherapy, I asked the oncologist what the odds are of my cancer returning. The response: about 20%. So -- true story -- in the company of my daughter, I placed a $20 bet several times on #20 on the roulette wheel at the Borgata in Atlantic City. I won $700 (35 to 1). My point is that if my docs were wrong at 20%, in order to have an equal balance to the universe, your doc could be wrong about >than 50%. Good luck. Jim

Posts.Content: Hi 08: Not sure if I understand what you mean by "your company carved you out". If you are still employed, then your company's health insurance is primary and Medicare is secondary. And a doctor may or may not accept your employer-provided insurance. But if you are no longer working (...carved out...?), then Medicare becomes your primary coverage and you have the option to purchase Medicare supplemental coverage for the 20% of costs not covered by Medicare (or purchase a Medicare Advantage policy). If the urologist accepts Medicare assignment, which means that the supplemental insurance approves whatever Medicare approves, then injections administered by the physician should be covered. And, if you are still working and you plan to retire soon, then depending on the extent of the injection costs, you may want to expedite your retirement in order to move Medicare into position as your primary insurer. Good luck. Jim

Posts.Content: Three years ago, when the federal panel recommended the abolishment of PSA testing, the chief medical officer of AARP went on television in support of the panel's findings. At the time, I wrote a letter of protest to AARP and included my AARP membership card cut in half. In doing so, I cancelled my AARP membership and encouraged all family and friends who were members to do the same. PSA tests saved my life, not once but twice, and any suggestion to eliminate them undoubtedly has led to unnecessary prostate cancer deaths.

Posts.Title: Editorial: Bad Prostate Cancer Advice

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by akai Hi Jim 215, thanks for the suggestion. Johns Hopkins confirmed the results and also upgraded one of the 3+4 to 3+5, then added another 3+3 of less than 5%. I was diagnosed with 3+3 in August 2012, tracking PSA religiously, every three to four months at two different places to avoid false readings. One Prolaris Test, low risk of 2%. Two Oncotype DX tests, low risk. Two subsequent biopsied from first Bx showed G6s. PSA gradually rose from 3.2 to 5.3, brought that up with my uro but my uro just said PSA was not the best indication. Last Bx on 05/05/2017, one G9, one G8, one G7, two G6s. I think the first three biopsied missed the G9, genomic tests gave me false sense of security, they are only as good as the samples tested. All biopsies were T3MRI fused, two at USC and two at UCLA. MRI never picked up this G9 or G8 spots. I thought that the 3TMRI would pick up aggressive type of PCa but apparently not. The G9 spot was from the systematic 12 samples not from the targeted spots pointed by the MRI. akai: I share in your disappointment. Most of us would not have expected such large Gleason scores on your fourth biopsy. Most of us would not have expected the complete failure of 3T MRIs to identify areas of concern on all four biopsies. Hell, we have a new poster who is chasing all over the Southwestern states just trying to get a doctor to provide a scrip for access to a 3T MRI. It provides little benefit to beat a dead horse (the testing failures, not the patient) but have your doctors provided any explanation how, after you did everything according to the book, that this could have happened? Again, best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Start Hormone Therapy with Firmagon?

Posts.Content: Hi Darwyn: I liked your story about the counter lady at the super-store. It reminded me of when I was first diagnosed with PC and I asked my urologist directly "Am I going to die?". He paused and said, "Yes, Jim, you are going to die. But not now and certainly not from this". Next, I must confess that my directness has sometimes caused me to get my wrist slapped on this site. With that said, I must tell you that I am not thrilled with your urologist for a number of reasons: First and foremost, your PSA results exceeded 4.0 for more than two full years before he recommended a biopsy. Not good. Second, he defended that position with the announcement that you had no abnormalities in the DRE exam. Not relevant if the PSA is over 4.0. Third, he recommended only a six-core biopsy because you "..had no other signs or symptoms " which to me sounds unprofessional since this is a disease that RARELY demonstrates its presence via symptoms. Finally, that same six-core biopsy (even though six out of six were positive), on average, could have missed hard-to-locate tumors. Many doctors who do not utilize a standard 12-core biopsy go in the other direction and perform a saturation biopsy with 20 or more cores. Yours is the first six-core biopsy I have EVER read about in thousands of posts on this and other websites. And, to be perfectly honest, it is my suspicion that if he found G6 in six out of six cores (100% - fairly rare), there is a considerable likelihood that cores NOT sampled could indeed harbor cancer at a higher Gleason score. Unless you find a competent urologist more in step with the rest of the medical community, however, you may never know the answer to that. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Content: I'd suggest you send your 5/5/17 slides to Johns Hopkins for a second opinion. Do I think they are wrong? No, but it seems strange that G8 AND G9 would suddenly pop up on your 4th biopsy, after only finding G6 on the first 3 biopsies (if I am reading your history correctly). And if it is accurate, you have certainly gotten the attention of many AS devotees on this website who may rethink their strategy.

Posts.Title: Crossed over into the "normal" zone...

Posts.Content: Allen: Not sure I understand your question. You're not on HT, right? Why think negatively when your salvage radiation -- like mine -- seems to be doing the job it was intended to? It sounds like the perennial argument of whether the glass is half-full or half-empty. Like you, I am 3 years post-SR but March's 6-month PSA came and went for me without a single thought that I would or would not remain a true zero. It was just a date on the calendar to get a blood test, nothing more. If it didn't, then it was time to deal with the next step, but not before. Before coming to this thread today (and since I had a lung cancer scare), I was on the lung cancer thread where it seems the latest news is rarely good. Try to focus on the positive aspects of PC. We're still here. Things could have been much worse. Try to re-evaluate the contents of that glass. Jim

Posts.Title: Crossed over into the "normal" zone...

Posts.Content: Some patients find chemo to be harsh and choose to forego it in favor of quality of life versus quantity of life. But that's putting the cart before the horse (you'll find a myriad of similar clichés here -- some of us are geezers) because that is only one type of treatment among many. The words "natural remedies" scare me because there are a lot of charlatans out there looking for people just like your Dad to take his money under false promises. Once he has been confirmed with prostate cancer, there are NO REMEDIES like green tea or garlic, etc. that will make it go away. Standard treatment usually consists of either surgery or radiation with both being equal in success rates but each harbors some side effects. Don't be dismayed by only a few responses today because the weekend activity on this site is slower than the rest of the week.

Posts.Title: Dad detected with prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Welcome, Sandra: As Chuck said, the UTI may have been the cause of his elevated PSA result, but the biopsy left no doubt that he has prostate cancer. The questions Chuck asked will help determine to what extent the cancer may hold minimum risk (such as a Gleason 6 and/or a small number of positive cores found in the biopsy) and could be treated routinely with surgery or radiation. The test you cited is probably not a bone marrow exam but, as Chuck noted, is likely a full-body bone scan, also routine, that will show if the cancer has spread. And, even if it has escaped the prostate, there are numerous treatments available. The book by Dr. Walsh (we get no share of the book royalties) is an excellent starting point. There are many forum members here who have "been there, done that" and they stand at the ready to answer any questions you may have. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Dad detected with prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by akai Hi Jim 215, thanks for the suggestion. Johns Hopkins confirmed the results and also upgraded one of the 3+4 to 3+5, then added another 3+3 of less than 5%. I was diagnosed with 3+3 in August 2012, tracking PSA religiously, every three to four months at two different places to avoid false readings. One Prolaris Test, low risk of 2%. Two Oncotype DX tests, low risk. Two subsequent biopsied from first Bx showed G6s. PSA gradually rose from 3.2 to 5.3, brought that up with my uro but my uro just said PSA was not the best indication. Last Bx on 05/05/2017, one G9, one G8, one G7, two G6s. I think the first three biopsied missed the G9, genomic tests gave me false sense of security, they are only as good as the samples tested. All biopsies were T3MRI fused, two at USC and two at UCLA. MRI never picked up this G9 or G8 spots. I thought that the 3TMRI would pick up aggressive type of PCa but apparently not. The G9 spot was from the systematic 12 samples not from the targeted spots pointed by the MRI. akai: I share in your disappointment. Most of us would not have expected such large Gleason scores on your fourth biopsy. Most of us would not have expected the complete failure of 3T MRIs to identify areas of concern on all four biopsies. Hell, we have a new poster who is chasing all over the Southwestern states just trying to get a doctor to provide a scrip for access to a 3T MRI. It provides little benefit to beat a dead horse (the testing failures, not the patient) but have your doctors provided any explanation how, after you did everything according to the book, that this could have happened? Again, best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Crossed over into the "normal" zone...

Posts.Content: Hi Darwyn: I liked your story about the counter lady at the super-store. It reminded me of when I was first diagnosed with PC and I asked my urologist directly "Am I going to die?". He paused and said, "Yes, Jim, you are going to die. But not now and certainly not from this". Next, I must confess that my directness has sometimes caused me to get my wrist slapped on this site. With that said, I must tell you that I am not thrilled with your urologist for a number of reasons: First and foremost, your PSA results exceeded 4.0 for more than two full years before he recommended a biopsy. Not good. Second, he defended that position with the announcement that you had no abnormalities in the DRE exam. Not relevant if the PSA is over 4.0. Third, he recommended only a six-core biopsy because you "..had no other signs or symptoms " which to me sounds unprofessional since this is a disease that RARELY demonstrates its presence via symptoms. Finally, that same six-core biopsy (even though six out of six were positive), on average, could have missed hard-to-locate tumors. Many doctors who do not utilize a standard 12-core biopsy go in the other direction and perform a saturation biopsy with 20 or more cores. Yours is the first six-core biopsy I have EVER read about in thousands of posts on this and other websites. And, to be perfectly honest, it is my suspicion that if he found G6 in six out of six cores (100% - fairly rare), there is a considerable likelihood that cores NOT sampled could indeed harbor cancer at a higher Gleason score. Unless you find a competent urologist more in step with the rest of the medical community, however, you may never know the answer to that. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Crossed over into the "normal" zone...

Posts.Content: Hi Ralph: First, allow me to apologize for Arthur. His jokes are SO bad, there may be a suspension coming for him. Haha. But he does highlight one area that I shared during my 8 days with the catheter. Beyond whatever exercise you are comfortable with, I too immersed myself in an oversize recliner and just let myself become a human vegetable. I had the luxury of a ManCave where my wife acted as gate-keeper -- didn't want any well-meaning visitors -- guess I'm a grumpy old man because I had the attitude "Just leave me the (blank) alone until I get rid of this bag". On that 8th day, we celebrated with a big restaurant dinner. I sincerely hope you're feeling better soon -- based on my experience and on other posts, the absence of bloating will likely occur within the next 24 hours. Welcome to the site. Jim
Posts.Title: Had RALP surgery wedenesday 5/28

Posts.Content: Don't put too much emphasis on the PSA today. One month from surgery seems like an awfully quick expectation because, even if you are fully "cured", the PSA may not have had enough time to clear completely out of your bloodstream. My recollection is that a PSA at the 90-day mark after surgery should provide a more definitive overview. Good luck.
