Posts.Title: Crossed over into the "normal" zone...

Posts.Content: Welcome ddvh: On this site, you will find many people who will gladly share their experiences in order to help others and I have no doubt that you will be the beneficiary of some very intelligent and caring feedback. At the same time, many of us continue to learn via this sharing mechanism. With that said, I am floored by the fact that your Dad, at age 50, began to religiously obtain and record his many PSA tests over the next 10 years, BUT apparently took no action relative to his PSA test results. Of the 28 PSA tests listed, every one of the 28 had a reading that should have caused bells to start ringing and red lights flashing to alert him that his PSA results FAR exceeded the norm. Has your Dad declined a biopsy and treatment for the last 10 years? Michael asked: - What did his primary care MD tell your dad about his steadily rising PSA over the past 10 years? Uh-huh!! Patients are free to accept or reject a doctor's recommendation for a prostate biopsy; however, after demonstrating 28 out of 28 times that the patient "could" be suffering from prostate cancer and he rejects same, some doctors would fire the patient. Could you share with us what happened that possibly allowed prostate cancer to spread for 10 years unabated? You wrote: My father(Age 59), has recently been diagnosed with PC on 2/25, we are still trying to soak it all in. That's simply not true as nearly any non-medical professional on this website could have told you the same thing 8 years ago based on his PSA test results. And if your Dad was not the one who declined follow-up, than he almost certainly has a viable malpractice case against the doctor who failed to recommend action. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Newly Diagnosed- My Father

Posts.Content: Hi Ralph: First, allow me to apologize for Arthur. His jokes are SO bad, there may be a suspension coming for him. Haha. But he does highlight one area that I shared during my 8 days with the catheter. Beyond whatever exercise you are comfortable with, I too immersed myself in an oversize recliner and just let myself become a human vegetable. I had the luxury of a ManCave where my wife acted as gate-keeper -- didn't want any well-meaning visitors -- guess I'm a grumpy old man because I had the attitude "Just leave me the (blank) alone until I get rid of this bag". On that 8th day, we celebrated with a big restaurant dinner. I sincerely hope you're feeling better soon -- based on my experience and on other posts, the absence of bloating will likely occur within the next 24 hours. Welcome to the site. Jim
Posts.Title: Had RALP surgery wedenesday 5/28

Posts.Content: Welcome Davii: Very glad to see your first post-surgery PSA is undetectable and that you experienced a rapid return to full continence. You said in your first post that you're keeping an open mind but have ruled out adjuvant radiation. From among your G9 band of brothers, what has been their post-surgery experiences and are they in Australia or world-wide? In the States, "the original reason for surgery" on a G9 patient (assuming surgery is not denied) is frequently only Step One on the road to trying to cure the most aggressive form of prostate cancer. Some patients, like myself, experience a recurrence months or years after surgery and require salvage radiation (Step Two) to clean up any remaining residue of PC. And that's true for a moderate number of run-of-the-mill G7 cases. In higher level Gleason patients, it's fairly common to initiate AR or SR as a proactive measure, focused primarily on mortality issues, not side effects. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Just wondering

Posts.Content: Hi Frank: Speaking with a professional demonstrates a proactive desire to address the problems you are experiencing. I'm just an old guy with no magic resolution except to reiterate that with surgery only 6 months ago, you are still in recovery mode. And you may be well served to read back through the many posts on this site -- obviously not all will apply to you -- to seek out the ways that other patients -- many in your age group -- have dealt with similar issues. Please accept the fact that others have gone through this journey and found ways to successfully cope. You're not alone. Finally, I would direct your attention to the issue of mortality. If you had to have cancer, apart from the ED, this is the one you wanted because, as long as you were treated early, PC has almost a 100% survival rate. Not so with lung cancer (16% five-year survival rate) or pancreatic cancer (6% five-year survival rate). I find it difficult to read some of the posts on those threads because I get choked up. Wishing you the very best, sir, Jim

Posts.Title: Trimix update

Posts.Content: Welcome Jaybee: First, did your husband have a full-body bone scan prior to surgery? If so, it likely would have ruled out metastatic PC. Indeed, if metastasis had been found, he probably would have been disqualified from having surgery in the first place. The logic is that there is no point in removing the prostate if the cancer had already spread elsewhere. Since you have "scoured" the Internet for info, I'm frankly surprised at your reaction over pre-surgery PSA numbers. 21.6 versus 23.6 has little or no bearing on the situation. To assume, without evidence, that number somehow exceeded 30 is unreasonable. His post-surgery pathology report trumps anything and everything that came before. Although the 4+3=7 Gleason is less desirable than a 3+4=7 score, everything about the pathology report is worth celebrating. News flash: It was a victory, not a defeat. Most patients would be thrilled with a similar outcome. While an ashen color is not desirable, has he lost any significant weight since surgery? Keep in mind that 5 weeks post-surgery still places him in recovery mode. Prior to his August 5th surgeon appointment, perhaps a quick check with a GP may reveal some other issue that may be unrelated to his surgery. With respect to surgery versus radiation as primary treatment, my history shows that I had a recurrence 3 years post-surgery. And yet, if I had it to do over again, I would change nothing. That's because surgery gave me the option for salvage radiation, if needed, and it was needed. No one knows what my future may hold but currently, the cancer is undetectable, a luxury that would almost certainly not have been available had I chosen radiation as my primary treatment. At this point, your husband's glass is half-full, not half-empty. Best of luck and please let us know the outcome of his Aug. 5th visit. Jim

Posts.Title: So freaked out - have we made the wrong decision? (and is this normal?)...

Posts.Content: Welcome Davii: Very glad to see your first post-surgery PSA is undetectable and that you experienced a rapid return to full continence. You said in your first post that you're keeping an open mind but have ruled out adjuvant radiation. From among your G9 band of brothers, what has been their post-surgery experiences and are they in Australia or world-wide? In the States, "the original reason for surgery" on a G9 patient (assuming surgery is not denied) is frequently only Step One on the road to trying to cure the most aggressive form of prostate cancer. Some patients, like myself, experience a recurrence months or years after surgery and require salvage radiation (Step Two) to clean up any remaining residue of PC. And that's true for a moderate number of run-of-the-mill G7 cases. In higher level Gleason patients, it's fairly common to initiate AR or SR as a proactive measure, focused primarily on mortality issues, not side effects. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer and Talcum Powder Connection? And one other subject.

Posts.Content: Hi Wayno2: I apologize in advance to my fellow posters as I probably sound like a broken record by now but I note that one caveat, in deciding between radiation or surgery, isn't mentioned enough. With surgery, if the cancer returns (as it did in my case 3 years after DaVinci surgery), then salvage radiation still offers a potential "cure". With radiation as your primary treatment, if the cancer returns, then follow-up surgery is rarely an option. The thing that appealed to me was that I got 2 bites at the "cure" apple instead of just one. And, as you can see from my history, I needed and invoked that option. So far, so good but the future always remains unknown. As far as the "poor wife" comments, I have an analogy from 4 years ago. After picking up my wife at the airport late at night, we were returning home over an interstate highway when a very large deer jumped in front of my car. The collision was horrific with much blood and detached animal limbs scattered across the highway. We weren't hurt but as I managed to bring the demolished vehicle onto the shoulder of the road, my wife uttered the words, "Oh, that poor animal". My response: "Are you kidding me? What about my poor Cadillac?" Best of luck to you, Jim

Posts.Title: No one on same page...frustrating!

Posts.Content: Allen: Not sure I understand your question. You're not on HT, right? Why think negatively when your salvage radiation -- like mine -- seems to be doing the job it was intended to? It sounds like the perennial argument of whether the glass is half-full or half-empty. Like you, I am 3 years post-SR but March's 6-month PSA came and went for me without a single thought that I would or would not remain a true zero. It was just a date on the calendar to get a blood test, nothing more. If it didn't, then it was time to deal with the next step, but not before. Before coming to this thread today (and since I had a lung cancer scare), I was on the lung cancer thread where it seems the latest news is rarely good. Try to focus on the positive aspects of PC. We're still here. Things could have been much worse. Try to re-evaluate the contents of that glass. Jim

Posts.Title: 164 ng/ml?

Posts.Content: dml: I assume, like Izicc, you are under age 65. Once reaching that age, you may want to explore the ED drug costs under Medicare Part "D". When I took early retirement 19 years ago, my employer provided us with lifetime generic and/or brand-name drugs for free. It's worked well since my wife suffered a moderate stroke 12 years ago and is on 13 different daily meds to mainly prevent a recurrence. The problem will be if I croak first because the former employer's prescription plan dies with me. That's when she will have to buy Medicare Plan "D" but it will be without penalty since she currently has "credible coverage". Jim

Posts.Title: So freaked out - have we made the wrong decision? (and is this normal?)...

Posts.Content: Some patients find chemo to be harsh and choose to forego it in favor of quality of life versus quantity of life. But that's putting the cart before the horse (you'll find a myriad of similar clichés here -- some of us are geezers) because that is only one type of treatment among many. The words "natural remedies" scare me because there are a lot of charlatans out there looking for people just like your Dad to take his money under false promises. Once he has been confirmed with prostate cancer, there are NO REMEDIES like green tea or garlic, etc. that will make it go away. Standard treatment usually consists of either surgery or radiation with both being equal in success rates but each harbors some side effects. Don't be dismayed by only a few responses today because the weekend activity on this site is slower than the rest of the week.

Posts.Title: No one on same page...frustrating!

Posts.Content: NightHiker: It sounds like you have already done your research, come to a decision and now that the surgery date is approaching, you are having second thoughts. I concur with Flkjr. If it was open-heart surgery, I might also be having second thoughts. Am I going to survive the operation, etc., etc.? But that doesn't apply here. You should have zero fear of what is a standardized procedure. After my DaVinci surgery, I took one pain pill! One! And, at your age, you are so LUCKY to have one of the few cancers that offers a likely CURE. I was 68 when I had my DaVinci surgery in November, 2010. In the exact same month, the president of a local university in my area, also age 68, died of prostate cancer. I'm not as smart as a university president but I was smart enough to keep an eye on my PSA and have the surgery. He didn't. I'm still here and he's not. Don't make the same mistake that he did. Go with your first inclination and have the surgery. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Decisions, decisions. Surgery or remain on AS with Gleason 3+4

Posts.Content: Welcome Jaybee: First, did your husband have a full-body bone scan prior to surgery? If so, it likely would have ruled out metastatic PC. Indeed, if metastasis had been found, he probably would have been disqualified from having surgery in the first place. The logic is that there is no point in removing the prostate if the cancer had already spread elsewhere. Since you have "scoured" the Internet for info, I'm frankly surprised at your reaction over pre-surgery PSA numbers. 21.6 versus 23.6 has little or no bearing on the situation. To assume, without evidence, that number somehow exceeded 30 is unreasonable. His post-surgery pathology report trumps anything and everything that came before. Although the 4+3=7 Gleason is less desirable than a 3+4=7 score, everything about the pathology report is worth celebrating. News flash: It was a victory, not a defeat. Most patients would be thrilled with a similar outcome. While an ashen color is not desirable, has he lost any significant weight since surgery? Keep in mind that 5 weeks post-surgery still places him in recovery mode. Prior to his August 5th surgeon appointment, perhaps a quick check with a GP may reveal some other issue that may be unrelated to his surgery. With respect to surgery versus radiation as primary treatment, my history shows that I had a recurrence 3 years post-surgery. And yet, if I had it to do over again, I would change nothing. That's because surgery gave me the option for salvage radiation, if needed, and it was needed. No one knows what my future may hold but currently, the cancer is undetectable, a luxury that would almost certainly not have been available had I chosen radiation as my primary treatment. At this point, your husband's glass is half-full, not half-empty. Best of luck and please let us know the outcome of his Aug. 5th visit. Jim

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ddayglo In my case, if I were diagnosed with G6, AS would have been an option... I then would have had a second opinion to validate the first diagnosis. If BOTH were G6, then a second opinion would have been a huge benefit. (I decided since I was "awarded" a G3+4 on my first biopsy, my "threshold" for AS was exceeded and it was time for active treatment.) I know this does not directly answer your question, but at least in my case of deciding whether AS would have been appropriate for me, if my first biopsy was G6, then a second opinion would have been absolutely essential. ddayglo: Are you reading the OP's signature correctly? He is Gleason 7, not G6. Jim

Posts.Content: Welcome Scurrent: Is that a typo? "...biking over 7,000 miles a year?..." That seems extreme. I didn't even think that world-class riders spent that much time on a bike. First, are you still riding that much? Second, have you discussed with your doctor whether the bike riding could be related to your problem? Third, even with Michael's excellent suggestion, I just don't see (with road hazards and potholes and that many miles) how you can avoid taking a beating to an area that should not be taking a beating. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: So freaked out - have we made the wrong decision? (and is this normal?)...

Posts.Content: I concur with all that has been said above. In fact, I would be surprised if the overwhelming majority of responses didn't support that position. While none of us are doctors on this site, the medical protocol for your situation tends to point with large, blinking neon arrow signs toward chemo. And, of course, as suggested, a second opinion can never hurt. But I'm also positive that you have done much research on your own since your mets were diagnosed four months ago. It's absolutely none of my business, however I must ask: if you have confidence in your oncologist, why have you allowed four precious months to slip by while failing to accept his recommendation? Other than the well-known bouts of sometimes severe nausea with chemo, is there a specific reason why you haven't acted yet? Best of luck to you, Sir. Jim

Posts.Title: Decisions, decisions. Surgery or remain on AS with Gleason 3+4

Posts.Content: October, 2014 Consumed delicious, super-greasy Five Guys cheeseburger. Don't know what magical ingredient causes it to taste SO much better than other burgers. Noticed it was undercooked in center. No worries. Hours later, experienced violent projectile vomiting. Ok, food poisoning -- just have to deal with it. BUT, volatile vomiting dislodged a stone from the left kidney which get jammed in the left ureter causing unbearable pain. Hospital ER visit unable to dislodge kidney stone. Surgery to remove kidney stone completed next day as hospital in-patient after 24 hours on pain-killer Dilauded (poor spelling). Stent inserted in ureter for 10 days to prevent collapse. Discharged from hospital after 2 days. On third day with stent, unable to pass any urine. Painful. Doctor's office visit resulted in a jack-hammer approach to break free blockage caused by stent. Relief, only to repeat the same blockage scenario on the 7th day following surgery when stent was finally removed. Lesson learned: Don't eat undercooked beef.

Posts.Title: Thought I was doing great!

Posts.Content: Welcome kdb: As our esteemed moderator has pointed out, the different PC treatment modalities have similar success rates. Warning: there appears to be a significant contingent of supporters of surgery on this site. I'm one of them. Some of our forum brothers have found success with brachytherapy and they will be able to share details with you. But, even if your Dad is a brachy candidate as you mentioned, know that brachy represents only 2% of patients treated for prostate cancer. That means 98% of PC patients chose to reject it or were not eligible. Your research may want to explore the reason(s) for that anomaly. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Help with tx options--da Vinci vs. brachytherapy?

Posts.Content: Vit D - any particular kind, how much, how often? Not a lot of sun in Oregon.... Fresh Garlic cloves - How much how often? CQ10 - expensive, does it really work? How much? How often? And is umbiquitol better? Pomegranite supplement - How much how often? Reversetol supplement - How much how often? Flax seeds - How much and how often? Spices: How much and how often? Cayenne pepper Tumeric or Curcumin Oregano Curry powder Ginger powder Alternative treatment? Please!! If your 70-year-young father decides to consume garlic, fine, but it will only give him bad breath. And it sure as hell isn't going to cure his cancer or anyone else's, nor will cayenne powder, oregano or anything else on your list. You did an excellent job of detailing his history -- much better than most people. That's why I find it surprising that you would even entertain consideration of such absurdities. Forgive me but I'm being blunt for a reason. If you want to help your father, get Dr. Pat Walsh's book on prostate cancer and educate yourself about REAL options in dealing with PC. No one here is a medical professional but you have access to the history and experiences of patients who have already dealt with this issue and are here to help. With Gleason 6, your Dad has the mildest strain of PC if the biopsy is accurate. Yes, active surveillance is a reasonable choice with most Gleason 6s, however there are a myriad of variables that come into play. For example, if your Dad decided he wanted surgery instead of AS, he is rapidly reaching an age where many surgeons will not operate. If the doctor offered radiation, surgery, chemo or active surveillance -- all sensible time-proven medical protocols -- and instead you're pursuing curry powder, why bother seeing a doctor at all? I know it's not what you want to hear and I may well be censured but you REALLY need to snap out of it. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Need help with my two options, VMAT or Proton

Posts.Content: I concur with all that has been said above. In fact, I would be surprised if the overwhelming majority of responses didn't support that position. While none of us are doctors on this site, the medical protocol for your situation tends to point with large, blinking neon arrow signs toward chemo. And, of course, as suggested, a second opinion can never hurt. But I'm also positive that you have done much research on your own since your mets were diagnosed four months ago. It's absolutely none of my business, however I must ask: if you have confidence in your oncologist, why have you allowed four precious months to slip by while failing to accept his recommendation? Other than the well-known bouts of sometimes severe nausea with chemo, is there a specific reason why you haven't acted yet? Best of luck to you, Sir. Jim

Posts.Title: 20 month PSA results are in ......

Posts.Content: Welcome Joy -- and fellow PA resident -- Go Little League World Series: I, too, agree that your husband's G6 stats lean strongly toward a path of active surveillance. However, playing Devil's Advocate as I often do (not to be confused with my respected forum brother ASAdvocate -- I'm highly jealous of Sweden, btw, with their disproportionate supply of hot blondes), I would like to mention two caveats: First, the initial Gleason score may not tell the whole story if there are higher-Gleason score critters still hiding in his prostate; Second, and this is a big one, many doctors prefer to not perform surgery on prostate cancer patients after roughly age 70 and depending upon the overall health of the patient. Since your husband is nearing that age group, I mention this because if he is going to fire the surgery bullet, the window of opportunity may be rapidly closing. Best of luck to you both, Jim

Posts.Content: Hi RILEYO: According to my urologist, as recently as five years ago, many doctors waited until the PSA hit 0.5 before triggering action toward dealing with a cancer recurrence following a prostatectomy. Most now believe (according to him) studies have shown that definitive action taken when the PSA reaches 0.2 has better long-term results. In my case, I began salvage radiotherapy at 0.16 but the decision to go ahead with it was already made at 0.11. Others on this site have also taken similar early action and they will likely add to this thread. So far, as noted below, I have been fortunate in the outcome. Fingers crossed. Good luck. Jim

Posts.Title: Doubling time & salvage radiation

Posts.Content: October, 2014 Consumed delicious, super-greasy Five Guys cheeseburger. Don't know what magical ingredient causes it to taste SO much better than other burgers. Noticed it was undercooked in center. No worries. Hours later, experienced violent projectile vomiting. Ok, food poisoning -- just have to deal with it. BUT, volatile vomiting dislodged a stone from the left kidney which get jammed in the left ureter causing unbearable pain. Hospital ER visit unable to dislodge kidney stone. Surgery to remove kidney stone completed next day as hospital in-patient after 24 hours on pain-killer Dilauded (poor spelling). Stent inserted in ureter for 10 days to prevent collapse. Discharged from hospital after 2 days. On third day with stent, unable to pass any urine. Painful. Doctor's office visit resulted in a jack-hammer approach to break free blockage caused by stent. Relief, only to repeat the same blockage scenario on the 7th day following surgery when stent was finally removed. Lesson learned: Don't eat undercooked beef.

Posts.Title: Thought I was doing great!

Posts.Content: "I have chosen AS in hopes of a preferred or new breakthrough in treatment of PC" After extensive research and a PSA of 10, that's what you arrive at? Well, here's some data to consider: As of 2015, a person diagnosed with lung cancer had a 16% five-year survival expectation. Exactly fifty years earlier, in 1965, a lung cancer patient had a 15% five-year survival expectation. True, lung cancer is not prostate cancer but at a 1% improvement rate each half-century, very few people will be around for the cure in 4,200 years. Choosing AS with a PSA of 10, in this poster's humble opinion, is a ripe environment for metastasis to occur while you wait for a better choice of a cure. And if you're waiting for "national guidelines", the President's Panel has already issued a belief that men don't need PSA testing because it causes undue anxiety and may lead to unnecessary treatment. In the meanwhile, 30,000 men die every year from prostate cancer.

Posts.Content: Dear mom2two: There is every reason to believe that your Dad's surgery and recovery will go well. But if it's "success" you seek, keep in mind that the scheduling of his surgery has already met a plateau of success. Not every patient is as lucky to progress toward a potential "cure", specifically if the cancer has metastasized. You have read their posts on this site. Some must be satisfied with modalities designed only to extend life. In that way, your Dad is already a winner. Best of luck. Jim

Posts.Title: Newbie... Tomorrow my love meets with urologist for treatment options

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Kermica True, Fairwind. I started drawing SSDI off of the Compassionate Allowance list for my lymphoma when I was 62. There was minimal paperwork and approvals were in hand within weeks. I will continue to draw until my Social Security Retirement date of November 2017. During the time I have been on SSDI, I have not once had to recertify for benefits. Kermica: If my wife's case is an example, I don't think you'll see any change in your benefits in November, 2017, when I assume you will reach your full-retirement age of 67. In 2003, at age 56, my wife, a university administrator, suffered a stroke that compromised her cognitive abilities. She lost her job and applied for SSDI. Denied. We appealed. Denied again. We hired a lawyer and went before an SSDI administrative appeals judge. Denied again. Finally, we appealed the judge's ruling and an appeals panel over-ruled the judge and granted her full disability and benefits. Upon reaching her full retirement age, nothing changed with respect to her monetary benefits. In fact, SS never noted or sent any correspondence when she reached full-retirement age. To the best of my knowledge, SSDI is most often higher or equal to the cash benefit attained at full-retirement age and it continues for life. No changes. At least that was true in her case. Jim

Posts.Title: SSDI & SSI available for Stage 4 people...

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Kermica True, Fairwind. I started drawing SSDI off of the Compassionate Allowance list for my lymphoma when I was 62. There was minimal paperwork and approvals were in hand within weeks. I will continue to draw until my Social Security Retirement date of November 2017. During the time I have been on SSDI, I have not once had to recertify for benefits. Kermica: If my wife's case is an example, I don't think you'll see any change in your benefits in November, 2017, when I assume you will reach your full-retirement age of 67. In 2003, at age 56, my wife, a university administrator, suffered a stroke that compromised her cognitive abilities. She lost her job and applied for SSDI. Denied. We appealed. Denied again. We hired a lawyer and went before an SSDI administrative appeals judge. Denied again. Finally, we appealed the judge's ruling and an appeals panel over-ruled the judge and granted her full disability and benefits. Upon reaching her full retirement age, nothing changed with respect to her monetary benefits. In fact, SS never noted or sent any correspondence when she reached full-retirement age. To the best of my knowledge, SSDI is most often higher or equal to the cash benefit attained at full-retirement age and it continues for life. No changes. At least that was true in her case. Jim

Posts.Content: OMFG Pratoman: From the movie Casablanca (1942): "Of all the gin joints in all the towns in all the world, she walks into mine." In your case, "In all the PSA tests in all the medical communities in the world, they had to screw with yours". My suspicion is that the blood labs have been reading your postings on this website and they saw an opportunity to drive you into total madness. All kidding aside, here we go again with that silly single decimal point on the PSA results. If I was as focused as you are about your PSA, I would take absolute full control of the issue. Why not get the scrip (or maybe even without a scrip), find a blood lab to YOUR liking, follow Michael's criteria of what YOU want from the lab and then have YOUR lab send you the results and copy your doctor? And, again, because it is so important to you, I would ignore whether insurance paid for the test or payment needs to be out-of-pocket. It would be worth every penny to allow you to sleep comfortably at night. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Got my PSA Results

Posts.Content: Hi RILEYO: According to my urologist, as recently as five years ago, many doctors waited until the PSA hit 0.5 before triggering action toward dealing with a cancer recurrence following a prostatectomy. Most now believe (according to him) studies have shown that definitive action taken when the PSA reaches 0.2 has better long-term results. In my case, I began salvage radiotherapy at 0.16 but the decision to go ahead with it was already made at 0.11. Others on this site have also taken similar early action and they will likely add to this thread. So far, as noted below, I have been fortunate in the outcome. Fingers crossed. Good luck. Jim

Posts.Title: Got my PSA Results

Posts.Content: Welcome, David: I'm sorry to hear of your difficulties with the VA. However, yours is a cautionary tale of not getting PSA tests that could be avoided and the message should shine as a bright blinking red light to others who find themselves in the same situation. You repeatedly refer to the fact that "they", meaning the VA, failed to provide PSA tests which is (allegedly) the reason that your prostate cancer was allowed to grow. Newporter points out that the federal government stopped providing PSA testing several years ago. So, what is a VA patient to do? Answer (for all current VA patients): Get an annual PSA test and, since it is not a major expense, pay for it yourself. Only YOU can adequately take care of you. You've had a tough time, David. I wish you well and thank you for your service. Jim

Posts.Title: How painful is catheter removal?

Posts.Content: Hi Lawr: Welcome. Since you are only one day removed from the catheter, the first thing that comes to mind is: why aren't you resting? And why do you feel the need to take such a long walk so soon? Although you didn't have open surgery (which takes longer to heal), nevertheless, your body has just experienced major surgery and it needs time to adjust. You may feel great (except for the incontinence) but if you over-exert yourself, it is counter-productive. And be sure to do your Kegels at home religiously every day. I wish you a speedy (but not too fast) recovery. Jim

Posts.Content: Welcome Rylee: Twenty years of active surveillance has worked for you. That's great. Could you share your age with us? I ask that question because if you are leaning at any time in the future to receiving primary treatment (surgery or radiation), then you should be cognitive of the fact that many doctors prefer to not perform surgery after the patient reaches roughly age 70. So, if you are approaching that stage, you have many options to consider moving forward. If AS is working for you, fine. But keep in mind that AS will never make the confirmed cancer disappear. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Second opinion John's Hopkins

Posts.Content: Hi Sheldon: Welcome and sorry you have to be here. There may be several reasons why your PSA is at 0.91 only 5 months after a prostatectomy. The doctor on Tuesday may be able to pin down an explanation. If your surgery margins (a surgical pathology report would help us understand your issue better) were positive as mine were, the remaining cancer may have to be addressed with salvage radiation. My prostate cancer took 3 years to return but my urologist just shrugged and said, "No problem. We'll just go in with radiation and clean this up". He spoke as if he had forgotten to wash a couple of dishes while hand washing a larger number of dishes. As you can see from my history/signature, so far it has worked out well for me. Could this be your future? Don't know but it's certainly possible. Please get back to us with the doctor's opinion and we will try to provide info relative to our real-time experiences. Best of luck. Jim

Posts.Title: Good Luck Tomorrow MM16

Posts.Content: The first question can only be answered by the doctor who performed the biopsy. Since an MRI guided biopsy was not available in your area (and keep in mind that none of us are medical professionals), then it would appear that the full benefit of the 3T MRI could not be employed. Also, the fact that "...3 prostate expert radiologists reviewed your MRI..." and did not find the low-level G6 is not surprising because the 3T MRI is only "suggestive" of where cancer may be present. The biopsy is the only current device that is "definitive" of the presence of cancer and, even then, it can -- and often does -- miss areas that may have the same G6 or higher, simply because of the small portion of the prostate removed for study. You didn't mention your age or your previous PSA results that could be indicative of something more serious than the low-level G6 found. For the moment, and without additional info, I think most of us would agree with ASAdvocate that you show no need yet for interventional action. Keep a close watch on your next PSA tests.

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with questions

Posts.Content: Hi Allen: How low is the pain in your "lower" region? Groin area or higher? Seven times in the last seven years, I have experienced a sharp stabbing pain in the lower left quadrant. The difference between your issue and mine is that my pain never subsided. They were kidney stones jammed in the left ureter. Worst pain I've ever had. Twice had to have surgery to remove the stones (2008 & 2014) which included the necessity to implant a long stent in the ureter for 2 weeks each time following the surgery. Then, last year, bad things happened with the stent twice. In my case, the offending kidney stones only showed up on a Cat Scan, not an ultrasound. In your case, it's possible the blood could be caused by stone(s) tearing up the inside of your ureter on their way to the exit. BUT, with no medical training, I can only speculate. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Good Luck Tomorrow MM16

Posts.Content: Hi Tom: You'll be hearing from many other members shortly. Your age tends to point toward surgery, which you have likely discovered. As Chuck asked, is there some specific reason (scar tissue or hernia, etc.) that would lead you to select open surgery instead of robotic? On this site, I think you will find an admitted bias toward surgery versus radiation and a subset of patients who favor robotic over open surgery. DaVinci robotic surgery is long past any experimental stage if that is a concern. Everyone should press for a highly experienced surgeon but the fact that you reference your local surgeon has been performing open surgery since 1973 is not necessarily (in my humble estimation) a "good" thing as he may be averse to accepting and learning new procedures. I see you live in a small town. Is it possible that the DaVinci machine is not available to you in your immediate area? The "gold standard" open surgery you describe, while equally effective, has a longer and more painful recovery period. You will be well served to hear the stories and histories of both series of patients. Best of luck. Jim

Posts.Title: SBRT, Gleason 4+3, unfavorable. Concerned!

Posts.Content: Hi Rob: Welcome to the forum and sorry you have to be here. It was only a few years ago that the point of alarm for the recurrence of prostate cancer following a prostatectomy was a PSA of 0.5. You mention 0.2 as being a "warning level" but that number, depending on your doctor, could easily be outdated. When I was referred to an oncology radiologist last year for salvage radiation, the trigger was when my PSA passed 0.1. Please see my history/signature below. Others on this site have also had SR based on their PSA exceeding 0.1, so you are certainly correct to keep an eye on it. Best of luck. Jim

Posts.Title: Brachy or Open Surgery? My Dilemma

Posts.Content: Hi Michele: I concur completely with Chuck and Pratoman. While your Dad had radiation as a primary prostate cancer treatment followed by brachy, my experience with radiation came three years after a robotic prostatectomy, which is referred to as salvage radiotherapy. I apologize if I sound like a Monday morning quarterback but one area of your Dad's history jumps out at me. In May, 2014, when his PSA level returned to a reading of 7, did that not trigger any concerns from his uro at that time? Was there any mention of trying hormone therapy then or did he just say "Let's wait another year for another PSA test."? Wishing you and your Dad the best possible outcome, please let us know the next step you pursue. We will be glad to share our experiences which, hopefully, will be helpful. And any info you provide may be of assistance to others. Jim

Posts.Title: Worried About My Dad - PSA Level 100

Posts.Content: I view the PSA as having saved my life, not once, but twice. First, it alerted my uro to do a biopsy which led to surgery and secondly, it was the PSA that raised a red flag that my PC had returned 3 years post-surgery which led to salvage radiation. The Federal Panel that denounces PSA testing, as causing unnecessary anxiety, claims that only one life is saved for every one thousand PSA tests given and, therefore, is not a prudent use of limited resources. My retort is that, if you accept their numbers, for every one million PSA tests given, ONE THOUSAND LIVES are saved. And, IMHO, anytime you can save ONE THOUSAND LIVES, that's a good thing and screw the costs. Just one old guy's opinion.

Posts.Title: PSA 6 weeks post

Posts.Content: Welcome Paul: Your mental attitude is not surprising. It is often the case when someone new to prostate cancer starts to think the worst -- "OMG! I'm going to die.". And the associated anger of being cheated out of a large piece of your remaining life span is not unusual either. Since you're miserable, you want to make those around you miserable also -- perhaps not consciously, but that's the end result. Well, say hello to life again and snap out of it because with a G6, you're not going anywhere. You have a 5-year survival rate of nearly 100%. If you REALLY want to get choked up, pay a visit to the lung cancer thread on this website (5-year survival rate: 16% -- that's just 1% higher than the 5 year survival rate of 15% from the year 1965). Or worse yet, visit the pancreatic cancer thread where patients have a 5-year survival rate of only 6%. Now that you're going to be around for a while longer, be nice to your wife. My wife of 52 years -- whom I lovingly refer to as my legally-wedded nightmare -- had to listen to me complain for 8 days about the post-surgery catheter, which caused no pain but was a nuisance. If our roles were reversed, I likely would have dumped a bucket of cold water on the patient. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Due to have Radical Prostatectomy in 2 weeks

Posts.Content: Hi Tom: You'll be hearing from many other members shortly. Your age tends to point toward surgery, which you have likely discovered. As Chuck asked, is there some specific reason (scar tissue or hernia, etc.) that would lead you to select open surgery instead of robotic? On this site, I think you will find an admitted bias toward surgery versus radiation and a subset of patients who favor robotic over open surgery. DaVinci robotic surgery is long past any experimental stage if that is a concern. Everyone should press for a highly experienced surgeon but the fact that you reference your local surgeon has been performing open surgery since 1973 is not necessarily (in my humble estimation) a "good" thing as he may be averse to accepting and learning new procedures. I see you live in a small town. Is it possible that the DaVinci machine is not available to you in your immediate area? The "gold standard" open surgery you describe, while equally effective, has a longer and more painful recovery period. You will be well served to hear the stories and histories of both series of patients. Best of luck. Jim

Posts.Title: Brachy or Open Surgery? My Dilemma

Posts.Content: Hi Lu: My investigation into Cyberknife and its sister applications - Stereotactic Body Radiation Therapy (SBRT) - shows that it seems to be most beneficial to patients with other forms of cancer who have definitive tumors that can be targeted, not so much with prostate cancer that may be diffuse. On another front, Cyberknife uses advertising that implies people who elect to have primary radiation (30 to 40 sessions - the gold standard for decades) are idiots while Cyberknife patients only have to receive 5 treatments, on average. This is accomplished by receiving massive doses of radiation via Cyberknife that does not always end well. I personally know two patients - both in Florida - who experienced radiation burns from Cyberknife that penetrated the anal walls and has remained painful. And, finally, a simple Google search of prostate cancer patients who received all available forms of treatment will show Cyberknife patients were the LEAST satisfied with their outcomes. Please don't take my word for it -- it's easily accessible. So, you are correct about what appears to be a majority of posters who are biased toward surgery and the info contained above could very likely be at least one reason why that is so. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Any Cyperknife folks out there?

Posts.Content: The first question can only be answered by the doctor who performed the biopsy. Since an MRI guided biopsy was not available in your area (and keep in mind that none of us are medical professionals), then it would appear that the full benefit of the 3T MRI could not be employed. Also, the fact that "...3 prostate expert radiologists reviewed your MRI..." and did not find the low-level G6 is not surprising because the 3T MRI is only "suggestive" of where cancer may be present. The biopsy is the only current device that is "definitive" of the presence of cancer and, even then, it can -- and often does -- miss areas that may have the same G6 or higher, simply because of the small portion of the prostate removed for study. You didn't mention your age or your previous PSA results that could be indicative of something more serious than the low-level G6 found. For the moment, and without additional info, I think most of us would agree with ASAdvocate that you show no need yet for interventional action. Keep a close watch on your next PSA tests.

Posts.Title: Interesting radio ads by Joe Torre, regarding AS

Posts.Content: You are not alone, Seacock, in believing that the extraction of a prostate would logically lead one to believe that the days of those delightful DREs were history. I was shocked -- shocked, I say -- when my uro pulled on the gloves at a post-surgery office visit. He said he still needed to seek out "rough" spots where the prostate once rested. My offer to wash and wax his car instead fell on deaf ears. Oh, well. We've been through worse and managed to survive. But, given the same set of circumstances, I would have first shown the door to my legally-wedded nightmare (merely a loving reference). Jim

Posts.Title: Good news!

Posts.Content: Hi Dooley: Just a suggestion: When the same poster creates multiple threads, it is hard for the reader to make a connection that you are the same guy who inquired about a specific concern, asked about a particular doctor, posted/didn't post their history, etc., etc. It's usually best to maintain a linear storyline so that you can receive the most attention from people who have experienced a similar path. Just one guy's opinion. It's not mandatory.

Posts.Title: Nerve Sparing DaVinci if already Impotent pre-op?

Posts.Content: Hi Nicnic: Welcome to the forum. Sorry any of us have to be here. After reading your post, my first reaction is to tell you to calm down. With a Gleason score of 6, nothing is going to happen overnight to you. Also, that one-month jump in your PSA from 6.3 to 9.7 seems suspect. It may simply be an inflammation or infection. Can you give us more info about your biopsy, specifically the number of cores that tested positive and the percentage of involvement? While we are not medical professionals on this site, we can share our actual prostate cancer experiences with you which, hopefully, will put your mind at ease that you're not alone in dealing with this issue. We have all walked the same walk. Others will chime in shortly, many of whom have shared your same surprise and sense of urgency. In addition, try to learn as much as you can about PC because there are many different facets of the disease. Reading several of the threads on this PC site should also be helpful. Best of luck. Jim

Posts.Title: Confuzed

Posts.Content: Regardless of the numbers involved, the only important number is YOU the patient and if you have no way of knowing which group of numbers you are actually in (cancer may return in X% cases, etc.), then numbers are best left exclusively to Las Vegas odds-makers. It's nothing more than an exercise in futility.

Posts.Title: SBRT, Gleason 4+3, unfavorable. Concerned!

Posts.Content: Welcome Mike: No one here is going to sugarcoat anything. Gleason 8 sucks. But -- and it's a very big BUT -- you are eons better off with a Gleason 8 at a young, strong age 54 than a Gleason 8 if you were a 72-year-old horse-on-the-way-to-the-glue-factory geezer like me. One step at a time. We are here for you with all the support we can muster. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: It's My Turn

Posts.Content: Dear Mrs. GG: In the 1992 film A League of Their Own, baseball manager Tom Hanks famously states, "There's no crying in baseball". The same is true with Gleason 7. Please -- please -- no more crying -- no more blathering mess. You've got this. A year from now, this episode has a 98% chance of being nothing more than a faint memory, an infinitesimal "blip" along life's highway. The "C" word can to frightening to many but if your husband was going to have cancer, this is the cancer he wants. Caught early, it has a nearly 100% cure rate. Not so with pancreatic or lung cancer. At age 68, I had a DaVinci robotic prostatectomy. At age 71, the cancer returned and I had 40 sessions of salvage radiotherapy. Today, I am cancer-free (although no one can ever predict the future). On September 27th, I will be featured on a tape from April of the TV program, The World Poker Tour, as the online winner of a $17,500 package at the Borgata Casino in Atlantic City where I beat more than 3,200 other entrants. Television cameras followed my wife and I around for a week. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CcTiYiwMBh8 Our moderator, Chuck, gave me permission to post this 90-second clip. I like to needle my grandchildren by asking them to inquire how many of their friends has a grandfather with his own YouTube video. So, after 72 years, I finally received my 15 minutes of fame. But this site is far more important than any silly fleeting fame as it can sometimes be of benefit to others as we share our non-medical suggestions, experiences and support. And your future feedback will be of help to others. Best of luck to you and your husband, Jim

Posts.Title: A wife with questions

Posts.Content: Welcome Ray: Your history of multiple heart attacks makes prostate surgery at age 73 a remote, unnecessarily risky and unwise decision. Your doctor's recommendation of radiation appears to be on target. Prostate cancer is the second leading cause of cancer deaths among men. Your insurance man may be correct that you should do nothing because something else will probably kill you first. But before you do that, you may want to ask him about the 30,000 men who died last year (and every year) from prostate cancer. If he had given those men the same advice that he is giving you, then he would have been wrong THIRTY THOUSAND TIMES. A second opinion -- already scheduled -- sounds like a much more practical path to take. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Psa 25.54

Posts.Content: You are not alone, Seacock, in believing that the extraction of a prostate would logically lead one to believe that the days of those delightful DREs were history. I was shocked -- shocked, I say -- when my uro pulled on the gloves at a post-surgery office visit. He said he still needed to seek out "rough" spots where the prostate once rested. My offer to wash and wax his car instead fell on deaf ears. Oh, well. We've been through worse and managed to survive. But, given the same set of circumstances, I would have first shown the door to my legally-wedded nightmare (merely a loving reference). Jim

Posts.Title: It's My Turn

Posts.Content: Welcome Philly from Delaware County: Of course, we all wish you luck but after reading your history, one date (perhaps a typo?) literally jumps off the page at me. It's absolutely none of my business but after being biopsied in Feb., 2014 and diagnosed with a 4+3=7 moderately aggressive form of prostate cancer, why -- why, why, why -- would you wait three years and three months before implementing treatment? It's clear that your PSA remained low, but once a biopsy confirms the actual presence of cancer, everything else is just peripheral "noise". I see that you have selected a celebrity doctor for your surgery. Are you traveling to Lenox Hill Hospital in New York for the operation? Just wanted you to be aware of this info on Dr. Samadi posted on Wikipedia, referencing an article in the Boston Globe newspaper. On March 12, 2017 the Boston Globe reported that Samadi is under investigation for a practice of booking multiple simultaneous surgeries and having medical residents perform many of the surgeries without proper supervision of training, while promising patients that he will personally treat them.[1] All the best to you, Jim

Posts.Title: Good news!

Posts.Content: Not sure what << means but you may have noticed there are two schools of thought on this thread regarding a PSA with one decimal or two decimals. If you have one decimal and a reading of <0.1, our administrator Chuck, the Mayo Clinic and many others feel that this is adequate and qualifies a patient to be a member of the ZERO Club. Due to my history (see sig.), I respectfully disagree because the 2-decimal method allowed me to be prepared when the cancer returned and it was necessary to act. I suppose it boils down to personal preference.

Posts.Title: Gleason 10 / robotic prostectomy 6 days ago

Posts.Content: Welcome Ray: Your history of multiple heart attacks makes prostate surgery at age 73 a remote, unnecessarily risky and unwise decision. Your doctor's recommendation of radiation appears to be on target. Prostate cancer is the second leading cause of cancer deaths among men. Your insurance man may be correct that you should do nothing because something else will probably kill you first. But before you do that, you may want to ask him about the 30,000 men who died last year (and every year) from prostate cancer. If he had given those men the same advice that he is giving you, then he would have been wrong THIRTY THOUSAND TIMES. A second opinion -- already scheduled -- sounds like a much more practical path to take. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Hello to all

Posts.Content: Hi Max: You and I and Allen have followed the same pathway. Ditto to Allen and lancepeace's comments. A consultation with a radiation oncologist will likely show that your "team" is about 5 years behind the curve if they're prepared to wait until you reach a PSA of 0.4. I scheduled treatment (please see below) when my recurrence reached PSA 0.11 and commenced 40 sessions of salvage radiation at PSA 0.16. So far, so good. I would be more concerned with your PSADT (PSA doubling time). In your case, the PSA doubled in only 3 months when most urologists would stand up and wave a red flag if it happened in one year. The only impediment may the point at which you can receive insurance approval for salvage radiation. Medicare approved my treatment and received a bill for $240,000 (not a typo). Best of luck. Jim

Posts.Content: Welcome Mike: No one here is going to sugarcoat anything. Gleason 8 sucks. But -- and it's a very big BUT -- you are eons better off with a Gleason 8 at a young, strong age 54 than a Gleason 8 if you were a 72-year-old horse-on-the-way-to-the-glue-factory geezer like me. One step at a time. We are here for you with all the support we can muster. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: It's My Turn

Posts.Content: Hi Bill: As you can see from my history, our paths are similar. With respect to salvage radiation following surgery - I had 40 sessions, 5 days a week for 8 weeks - the only thing I experienced was some slight fatigue close to the very end of treatment. In speaking with others receiving the same treatments, I never found anyone who had any "sickness" or side effects related to SR. Pretty much just lay on a table for 10-12 minutes each session while getting zapped. After experiencing a recurrence 3 years after surgery, I am now 2 years "cancer-free" as shown by PSA readings of 0.00. Do I consider myself cured? I honestly don't know. Ask me that question again in 10 years. I have this view of cancer as acting like the "Whack a Mole" game at carnivals where you hit the mole with a mallet only to have it pop up elsewhere. John Wayne famously announced to the world that he had beaten the Big "C" by having lung cancer surgery. He was right but he then proceeded to die of stomach cancer. You can only take it one step at a time. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Content: "Hubby saw uroligist for his 6 mt check up., and his psa has risen. Every time we went it was good news, until NOW." Hi September: My path has been similar to your husband's journey except for G7 versus his G9 and my PSA following salvage radiation has stayed undetected at 0.00. Your comment above says he had good news until now but his history shows a PSA of 0.1 during the 2-year period after salvage radiation which is actually not that good. Is it possible that his post-salvage radiation numbers were <0.1, rather then 0.1? If I experience any rise at all in my PSA, I'm pretty sure I will circle the wagons and take the ADT plunge immediately. For me, side effects would be of zero consequences as the mortality issue looms larger. Since you favor waiting to implement ADT until a higher PSA number is reached based on Dr. Walsh's recommendation (that is the 3rd edition of his book, right?), do you have a PSA number in mind that would trigger action? Wishing you both the very best possible outcome, Jim

Posts.Title: Thoughts on stopping HT and doing AS

Posts.Content: My wife had a moderate stroke in 2003 at age 56. It caused "cognitive deficits" and cost her a great job as a college administrator. Our research indicated that even if she had the best medical support in the world, her family history of strokes meant that she had a 1-in-3 chance of a full-blown stroke within five years. Too often, we heard friends say, "OMG! John and I were going to travel the world after he retired and now he's dead of a heart attack at age 59. I wish we had (...fill in the blanks...) and now it can never happen." In the five years after my wife's stroke, we took a total of 29 "vacations" and saw most of the world except for a couple of continents. Couldn't afford it but it didn't matter. I just could not stomach being in the "I wish we had...." category. Pratoman -- instead of taking a week or month off of this site where you do good work helping others, my suggestion is to take a month and do something totally spontaneous. On a Thursday a few months after my wife's stroke, I told my secretary that I had just decided that I was going to take my wife to lunch the next day -- and I did -- in Paris. We're all only here for the blink of an eye. Don't run short of time.

Posts.Title: Need a break

Posts.Content: Hi Kamie: You will receive much good info on this site. First of all, while your ideas are certainly admirable, no diet has ever cured prostate cancer. Eating smartly will help in other areas, but not this one -- the horse is already out of the barn. On the bright side, Gleason 6 is considered the mildest form. As our astute moderator will tell you shortly, there is a saying that "No man has ever died of Gleason 6", so please put that thought to rest. In your upcoming research, you may find that Active Surveillance could be the best route to follow now. Some people, however, just can't abide the thought of cancer anywhere within their body and choose a route that will, hopefully, lead to a "cure", such as surgery or radiation. You will be advised to get the "Bible" of prostate cancer, a book written by Dr. Walsh and read about all of the options available. Deep breath now. Your husband isn't going anywhere. Best of luck. Jim

Posts.Title: I don't like this club!!

Posts.Content: Want to decide on some additional term life before any possible diagnosis Welcome TN Bigfoot: As a former licensed life insurance agent, if you happen to croak from prostate cancer, the insurer could always point to your earlier PSA results as likely proof of a "pre-existing condition" which took your life and voids any obligation for them to pay a benefit. So, you can try to buy additional life insurance but don't think you can outsmart the insurance industry. It's not their first rodeo. Waiting another 3 months, after a uro has suggested a biopsy, has the added risk of allowing the cancer to spread if it happens to be of the fast-moving aggressive (though less prevalent) variety. So, while you're trying to think of reasons not to have the biopsy, you could possibly be reaching a point where some treatment options, like surgery, could be eliminated due to metastasis. Generally speaking, if a uro says to get a biopsy, then get a biopsy. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Hello and Thanks

Posts.Content: Hi Sue: According to my urologist, there is no reason to give up hope. In fact, there is no reason to stress. Three years after my robotic prostatectomy, my PSA started rising (please see below). My urologist used the analogy that the surgery cleaned up nearly all of the contents of an automatic dishwasher. It missed a few dinner plates. Salvage radiotherapy needed to be employed to hand wash a couple of remaining dishes to "clean up the residue". Of course, I was concerned but he said there is absolutely nothing to worry about. I had 40 sessions of radiation with no side effects whatsoever and, as you can see from my history, my PSA has remained at 0.00 for the last two years. Life goes on. In fact, I will be profiled on September 27th on the national TV show, The World Poker Tour. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CcTiYiwMBh8 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2WWy1zt4nYk Of course, no one can predict the future. For the moment, though, all is well. Hopefully, your friend (age 40 is horribly too young to have to deal with this) will have a similar outcome. Feel free to have him ask anything via private message if he wishes. Allen from Toronto had an almost identical experience except his PC returned just one year after surgery. I expect he will describe a similar journey. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Prostate cancer at 40

Posts.Content: With life insurance, the general rule is that if there is any way for them NOT to pay a claim, they will find it. Granted, a PSA reading is not a confirmation of cancer but they have armies of lawyers that can keep the case court-bound for years at a time when your dependents may be in need. When that happens, a lowball "settlement" is sometimes offered and the dependents may be forced to accept it if they are destitute from paying their own lawyers. Specific disease (like cancer) life insurance policies belong in Las Vegas only because you are betting on the method of your demise and if you guess wrong, then SNAKE EYES -- your beneficiaries get nothing. You are better off with whole life insurance. And don't be misled by hybrid policies like "variable life" and "universal life" and other types. There are only two kinds of life insurance: whole life and term life -- everything else is the same with slight add-ons, including "investment" products that have no relationship to life insurance. BTW, even if you can afford the premium for term insurance at your present age of 59, you will find that (should you live), it will quickly become cost-prohibitive. Term life insurance is ideal for a young family with kids to raise because it provides about seven times the face value of an ordinary life policy for the same premium dollar. However, as one approaches around age 60 and slightly older, term life premiums become painfully expensive to the point where most policyholders must let it lapse. Good luck, Jim

Posts.Title: colostomy & prostate cancer

Posts.Content: "Hubby saw uroligist for his 6 mt check up., and his psa has risen. Every time we went it was good news, until NOW." Hi September: My path has been similar to your husband's journey except for G7 versus his G9 and my PSA following salvage radiation has stayed undetected at 0.00. Your comment above says he had good news until now but his history shows a PSA of 0.1 during the 2-year period after salvage radiation which is actually not that good. Is it possible that his post-salvage radiation numbers were <0.1, rather then 0.1? If I experience any rise at all in my PSA, I'm pretty sure I will circle the wagons and take the ADT plunge immediately. For me, side effects would be of zero consequences as the mortality issue looms larger. Since you favor waiting to implement ADT until a higher PSA number is reached based on Dr. Walsh's recommendation (that is the 3rd edition of his book, right?), do you have a PSA number in mind that would trigger action? Wishing you both the very best possible outcome, Jim

BTW, even if you can afford the premium for term insurance at your present age of 59, you will find that (should you live), it will quickly become cost-prohibitive. Term life insurance is ideal for a young family with kids to raise because it provides about seven times the face value of an ordinary life policy for the same premium dollar. However, as one approaches around age 60 and slightly older, term life premiums become painfully expensive to the point where most policyholders must let it lapse. Good luck, Jim

Posts.Content: "Hubby saw uroligist for his 6 mt check up., and his psa has risen. Every time we went it was good news, until NOW." Hi September: My path has been similar to your husband's journey except for G7 versus his G9 and my PSA following salvage radiation has stayed undetected at 0.00. Your comment above says he had good news until now but his history shows a PSA of 0.1 during the 2-year period after salvage radiation which is actually not that good. Is it possible that his post-salvage radiation numbers were <0.1, rather then 0.1? If I experience any rise at all in my PSA, I'm pretty sure I will circle the wagons and take the ADT plunge immediately. For me, side effects would be of zero consequences as the mortality issue looms larger. Since you favor waiting to implement ADT until a higher PSA number is reached based on Dr. Walsh's recommendation (that is the 3rd edition of his book, right?), do you have a PSA number in mind that would trigger action? Wishing you both the very best possible outcome, Jim

Posts.Title: 2.5 yrs later - psa rises.

Posts.Content: With life insurance, the general rule is that if there is any way for them NOT to pay a claim, they will find it. Granted, a PSA reading is not a confirmation of cancer but they have armies of lawyers that can keep the case court-bound for years at a time when your dependents may be in need. When that happens, a lowball "settlement" is sometimes offered and the dependents may be forced to accept it if they are destitute from paying their own lawyers. Specific disease (like cancer) life insurance policies belong in Las Vegas only because you are betting on the method of your demise and if you guess wrong, then SNAKE EYES -- your beneficiaries get nothing. You are better off with whole life insurance. And don't be misled by hybrid policies like "variable life" and "universal life" and other types. There are only two kinds of life insurance: whole life and term life -- everything else is the same with slight add-ons, including "investment" products that have no relationship to life insurance. BTW, even if you can afford the premium for term insurance at your present age of 59, you will find that (should you live), it will quickly become cost-prohibitive. Term life insurance is ideal for a young family with kids to raise because it provides about seven times the face value of an ordinary life policy for the same premium dollar. However, as one approaches around age 60 and slightly older, term life premiums become painfully expensive to the point where most policyholders must let it lapse. Good luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Hello and Thanks

Posts.Content: Allen: The full bladder issue is really interesting. I completed my salvage radiation 3 months before you and the first oncology radiologist that my urologist sent me to insisted on a full bladder by drinking 48 oz. of water one hour before each of the 40 treatments began. The problem was that the only appointments available were at 8AM, during rush hour, and his office was reached via two major highways. On any given day, one or both of those highways could be gridlocked during morning rush. I could envision no way that I would be caught in the middle lane and be able to hold a bladder about to burst. So, instead of that scenario, I decided that I would arrive an hour early and drink the fluid in his parking lot. But with 40 sessions scheduled, that meant that I would waste 40 hours sitting in his parking lot over the course of the treatments. I didn't like that any better than the bladder-busting on the Interstate highway. So, I interviewed a local oncology radiologist who was located 12 minutes from my home over local roads. After signing up with the second guy and solving the distance problem and fluid consumption timing problem, I asked how much he wanted me to drink before each session. He gave me a funny look and said, "Why would I care how much you drink? It has no bearing on your radiation treatment." Bottom line: My last four PSA tests following his 40 sessions of IMRT salvage treatments a year ago have all been 0.00. Jim

Posts.Title: Day 14 of forty

Posts.Content: Want to decide on some additional term life before any possible diagnosis Welcome TN Bigfoot: As a former licensed life insurance agent, if you happen to croak from prostate cancer, the insurer could always point to your earlier PSA results as likely proof of a "pre-existing condition" which took your life and voids any obligation for them to pay a benefit. So, you can try to buy additional life insurance but don't think you can outsmart the insurance industry. It's not their first rodeo. Waiting another 3 months, after a uro has suggested a biopsy, has the added risk of allowing the cancer to spread if it happens to be of the fast-moving aggressive (though less prevalent) variety. So, while you're trying to think of reasons not to have the biopsy, you could possibly be reaching a point where some treatment options, like surgery, could be eliminated due to metastasis. Generally speaking, if a uro says to get a biopsy, then get a biopsy. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Hello and Thanks

Posts.Content: Whether it's standing in a supermarket checkout line or waiting for a test result, patience has never been among my limited virtues. In February of 2013, my local hospital chain initiated online patient access to all diagnostic studies done by them -- blood tests, X-rays, Cat Scans, MRIs, surgical pathology reports, etc. The clincher was that, with just a couple of exceptions, they GUARANTEED the results would be posted online no later than 36 hours after the test. So far, they have kept that promise and now all of my specialists are aligned with that hospital group for that very reason. If you investigate, you may find similar arrangements in your local areas.

Posts.Content: Hi Jeff: I hate to sound like I'm just jumping on the bandwagon of "sooner is better than later" but I can offer nothing else other than to share with you my textbook salvage radiation treatment following Da Vinci surgery and excellent results so far (kindly see history below). Please note that I say "so far" because I have no idea what the future may hold. Some posters have expressed a concern over radiation exposure long-term, however with a Gleason 9 and a PSA that has quickly doubled (PSADT), I think you would agree that you have everything to possibly gain and very little to lose by exploring SR or, as newporter mentioned, a combination employing HT with a highly experienced oncologist. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Content: Love to hear stories like yours because I read of some people who visit this site who are solidly against the very thought of surgery due to fear of complications. True, some patients do experience less than perfect outcomes, however I think the majority who elect surgery are closer to the textbook result that you have shown after 18 months. I'm approaching four years post-surgery and although I had a recurrence, like you, if I had it to do all over again, I would select DaVinci robotic surgery.

Posts.Content: Welcome Pete: So sorry to hear of your catheter difficulties. I was among the fortunate who simply had to endure the presence of the apparatus for 8 days at home post-surgery. But while sitting at home recovering on the East Coast of the U.S., I was stunned by the amount of repetitive television commercials that focused on people who had to "self-catherize" while trying to sell them catheter supplies. Although I'm not the brightest bulb on the string, I concluded that costly television commercials must be funded by a high volume of customers who bought the products advertised -- and that surprised the hell out of me that tens of thousands of people have to daily self-cath because I had no idea of the enormity of the problems. Best of luck, Jim

I question because I haven't seen doubling PSA incidents noted in many of the posts. age 54 dx PC. 7/14 psa 5.1 4/15 psa 5.5 5/15 biopsy 2 of 12 samples positive 3 + 3 gleasonT1 c (I think) 7/15 psa 7.1 12/15 psa 9.7 12/15 MRI - from what I read on the report no areas of real concern. for now doing the active surveillance and will do biopsy again in may 2016. i'm ok with waiting but the only thing that makes me wonder is the rising PSA. if I use the doubling time calculator i'll be in the 14 range by June 2016. thanks for input. Welcome Thom: It's fine that you're OK with waiting but you bring up one of the weaknesses in an active surveillance program. What do you do if the PSA keeps rising? Do you wait until the PSA reaches 14 -- or 20 -- or 30? Where do you draw the line? Who makes that decision? Speaking only for myself (and perhaps a handful of others), I would be measuring the distance that I needed to cover in doing a somersault onto an operating table. But that's just me. We all have different comfort levels. I wish you the best, Jim

Posts.Title: PSA Doubling Time

Posts.Content: Welcome Steve: I concur with Chuck. My initial interpretation (with no medical training whatsoever) is that you seem to be a strange candidate for a "trial". In my limited experience, I have always viewed trials as being for those patients who have exhausted virtually all other means of treatment without success. Your presentation appears to be somewhat straightforward (a likely biochemical recurrence that is frequently treated with salvage radiation, sometimes supported with hormone therapy). The scenario whereby "...There are a bunch of bench marks you must meet..." sounds counter-productive. If something is broken, it needs to be fixed, sooner rather than later. I must tell you that if I found myself in the same set of circumstances, I would not dick around with any "trial". Rather, I would move forward and get the treatment needed. What's best for the trail moderators/organizers is not necessarily what is best for you. Have you discussed your case with any radiation oncologist who is unrelated to this "trial"? Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: PSA Doubling Time

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by lazythom hi and I agree great information here. any thoughts on the following? I question because I haven't seen doubling PSA incidents noted in many of the posts. age 54 dx PC. 7/14 psa 5.1 4/15 psa 5.5 5/15 biopsy 2 of 12 samples positive 3 + 3 gleasonT1 c (I think) 7/15 psa 7.1 12/15 psa 9.7 12/15 MRI - from what I read on the report no areas of real concern. for now doing the active surveillance and will do biopsy again in may 2016. i'm ok with waiting but the only thing that makes me wonder is the rising PSA. if I use the doubling time calculator i'll be in the 14 range by June 2016. thanks for input. Welcome Thom: It's fine that you're OK with waiting but you bring up one of the weaknesses in an active surveillance program. What do you do if the PSA keeps rising? Do you wait until the PSA reaches 14 -- or 20 -- or 30? Where do you draw the line? Who makes that decision? Speaking only for myself (and perhaps a handful of others), I would be measuring the distance that I needed to cover in doing a somersault onto an operating table. But that's just me. We all have different comfort levels. I wish you the best, Jim

Posts.Title: PSA Doubling Time

Posts.Content: Love to hear stories like yours because I read of some people who visit this site who are solidly against the very thought of surgery due to fear of complications. True, some patients do experience less than perfect outcomes, however I think the majority who elect surgery are closer to the textbook result that you have shown after 18 months. I'm approaching four years post-surgery and although I had a recurrence, like you, if I had it to do all over again, I would select DaVinci robotic surgery.

Posts.Title: Check-Up 18 months after Da Vinci

Posts.Content: Original questions: What does radiation actually do to the prostate? what condition will the prostate be in after the conclusion of all of the treatments? Will it be a mass of scar tissue with a urinary passage through it. Allen's original response: ....my understanding was it really clobbered the prostate, and there was heavy scarring to the point where robotic surgery could not be done later if the radiation did not kill the cancer. OP reply: "That does not really answer my question". It certainly sounded like a valid answer to me. Question: Will it be a mass of scar tissue with a urinary passage through it? My answer: YES

Posts.Title: What does radiation actually do to the prostate?

Posts.Content: As a non-medical professional, I must agree with Fairwind and ASAdvocate. With an unremarkable PSA of 2.5 at your age, an excellent free PSA score and a slightly enlarged prostate, I, too, would be looking elsewhere for an explanation of your various points of pain. Best of luck to you, Sir.

Posts.Title: PSA MRI and Pain

Posts.Content: One thing not mentioned: For many patients, the bowel cleansing the day before the procedure is the most annoying/disgusting/time-consuming part. You must perform a thorough bowel cleansing prior to a virtual colonoscopy just as with a conventional procedure. That means if the virtual method identifies a polyp to be removed, the conventional method must be employed in a second procedure which will trigger A SECOND BOWEL CLEANSING. I find the thought of doing something THAT unpleasant (like a bowel cleansing) more than once to be counter-productive if it can be avoided by simply submitting to a single bowel cleansing with a conventional colonoscopy.

Posts.Title: Off Topic: Virtual Colonoscopy

Posts.Content: Hi Jimbo: One step at a time. Research. Write down any questions you have before seeing the urologist and bring the list with you and write down the answers. It's sometimes best to have a significant other accompany you to the visit because four ears tend to hear more than two. Next, formulate a plan of attack. It's natural to worry whenever The Big "C" may be hovering but take comfort in the fact that should you be diagnosed, then prostate cancer is definitely a cancer you want since it's almost always curable when caught early. Others are not as fortunate. Best of luck and please keep us updated, Jim

Posts.Title: Off Topic: Virtual Colonoscopy

Posts.Content: Welcome Steve: I concur with Chuck. My initial interpretation (with no medical training whatsoever) is that you seem to be a strange candidate for a "trial". In my limited experience, I have always viewed trials as being for those patients who have exhausted virtually all other means of treatment without success. Your presentation appears to be somewhat straightforward (a likely biochemical recurrence that is frequently treated with salvage radiation, sometimes supported with hormone therapy). The scenario whereby "...There are a bunch of bench marks you must meet..." sounds counter-productive. If something is broken, it needs to be fixed, sooner rather than later. I must tell you that if I found myself in the same set of circumstances, I would not dick around with any "trial". Rather, I would move forward and get the treatment needed. What's best for the trail moderators/organizers is not necessarily what is best for you. Have you discussed your case with any radiation oncologist who is unrelated to this "trial"? Best of luck, Jim
