Posts.Title: Hello new member first test ever 5.9 at age 58.

Posts.Content: Wow, Delta. I thought I was the only patient who REALLY closely monitored PSA post-surgery but someone needs to grab a spatula and scrape you down off of the ceiling. Many large cancer centers don't even recognize a movement until 0.1 PSA is reached, although I agree with MichiganMan16 to be super-vigilant as my history attests in preparation for what may -- or may not -- come next. Above and beyond that issue, I cannot figure out your aversion to salvage radiation. Side effects? I had NONE, unless you count some slight fatigue toward the end of my 40 sessions. It was a piece of cake. One of the easiest things I've ever encountered. Hell, after two barium enemas in the early Nineties, I'd gladly trade those for 500 sessions of salvage radiation. Try to relax. You can't fight an adversary that has not yet raised its head to be recognized. Just keep an eye on your PSAs and you'll be ready for the battle if it comes. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: The waiting game - or is there something I can do?

Posts.Content: I agree with Chuck that your future looks promising. The catheter removal was one of the happiest days of my life -- not because it was painful, it wasn't -- because I found the eight-day experience to be emotionally taxing. But, even considering a worst case scenario, because you chose to have surgery, rather than radiation as your primary treatment, if the cancer should return (as it did for Allen from Toronto and me), then you have the fallback option of adjuvant or salvage radiation to knock it down. In the meantime, think positive.

Posts.Title: Catheter Out and Path Lab Results

Posts.Content: "...but starting to think I am not going to beat this thing and should just bury my head in the sand and concentrate on enjoying myself??? Welcome Francij4: In reply to your above comments, my immediate thoughts are "No", "No" and "No". Did I mention "No"? BTW, I view myself not as cantankerous or crotchety, but rather a kindly curmudgeon. Your recent PSA tests would not even register on a standard PSA testing machine, many of which simply show <0.1, so it's somewhat early to declare a full-scale alert. Is it a biochemical recurrence? Too soon to know for sure -- the jury is still out. However, it is wise to continue to monitor PSA changes and prepare yourself when the day could arrive that would warrant treatment. As Michael noted, for a 3-year period following my DaVinci surgery, I kept a close eye on my incrementally rising PSA (please see my history below). When it exceeded 0.1, I commenced 40 sessions of salvage radiation. It's now been six years since surgery and 3 years since SR and my PSA tests all show 0.00. Is that a good thing? Yes, it is. Do I consider myself cured of cancer? Absolutely not. I would never be so presumptuous. Cancer has a habit of dropping out of sight in one area and then rearing its ugly head elsewhere. So, I can enjoy it while it lasts. I'll be appearing on TV for the third time on the World Poker Tour from the Bicycle Casino in Los Angeles in late August as I approach age 75. I'm not burying my head in the sand and neither should you. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Content: Welcome Pat: As Michael noted, we are not medical professionals here but the people who contribute to this forum have experienced pretty much everything related to prostate cancer and can share the benefit of their accumulated knowledge of the subject. Two things are of immediate interest in your post: First, with such a serious G9 diagnosis, it may be advantageous to send your slides to Johns Hopkins for confirmation. Secondly, as RobLee pointed out, an MRI seems of little value at this point. Kind of like locking the barn door after the horse has escaped. An MRI often helps to locate areas of suspicion in the prostate. If you and your doctor have already decided that the prostate is coming out, then the location of the cancer within the prostate becomes a moot point. It will be thoroughly examined during post-surgery pathology. And, again, if a prostatectomy is your weapon of choice, history indicates that more treatment may be in your future. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Alternative Medicine Claims

Posts.Content: It's been said that special diets can help to ward off the onset of cancer. Who knows? But once you have been diagnosed and it is confirmed that you have cancer -- as in 11 out of 12 positive samples, including one 4+3=7 aggressive Gleason sample -- no herbal remedy or diet is going to cure you of cancer. You've seen the bias toward surgery by the majority of our forum brothers. I would just add, as I often do, that surgery allows for a second chance at an actual "cure" with salvage radiation if the cancer should recur, as it did with me. With radiation as your primary treatment, not so much. Good luck.

Posts.Content: "For me, hope seems to be slipping quickly, so I'm trying to find a way to stay positive." h60: I concur with MM16. Your above observation is not consistent with your pathology report. Why think negatively when you haven't received your first post-surgery PSA test result yet? You're only 14 days from the trauma of surgery. You don't need to complicate it with mental trauma that is unsupported. The PSA at 3 months post-surgery is the test that should help to guide future action or non-action. Until then, relax. Jim

Posts.Content: Hi Jimbo: One step at a time. Research. Write down any questions you have before seeing the urologist and bring the list with you and write down the answers. It's sometimes best to have a significant other accompany you to the visit because four ears tend to hear more than two. Next, formulate a plan of attack. It's natural to worry whenever The Big "C" may be hovering but take comfort in the fact that should you be diagnosed, then prostate cancer is definitely a cancer you want since it's almost always curable when caught early. Others are not as fortunate. Best of luck and please keep us updated, Jim

Posts.Title: What questions should I ask a radiology oncologist?

Posts.Content: Ok. You haven't ruled out the radiation but when I calculate 75 minutes each way plus the minimal time to get zapped, then you're looking at a 3-hour a day crunch for 8 weeks (often 40 sessions). If you are employed, that could be problematic. Not sure how you felt it would take 5 weeks to recover from surgery. Usually, if it's robotic, you spend one night in the hospital then about a week at home with a catheter (some people actually go to work or go out in public with the catheter using a leg bag but I couldn't bring myself to do that). Normally, some leakage will follow but is mostly manageable. Some people have a longer road to full dryness. So, unless I've missed something, you're looking at 8 weeks (radiation) versus 8 days (surgery) for basically the same outcome with respect to a potential cure. Plus, as Chuck pointed out, surgery -- not radiation -- is the resolution for BPH if it rears its ugly head. And as Allen mentioned, if the cancer returns after surgery, you can have salvage radiation, as I did, as a fallback Plan "B". If the cancer returns after primary radiation, surgery is rarely an option due to the damage done to the prostate. Please let us know what you decide and why, which may be helpful to others who follow in your (our) footsteps. Best of luck to you.

Posts.Title: Thought I had a plan

Posts.Content: Welcome Pat: As Michael noted, we are not medical professionals here but the people who contribute to this forum have experienced pretty much everything related to prostate cancer and can share the benefit of their accumulated knowledge of the subject. Two things are of immediate interest in your post: First, with such a serious G9 diagnosis, it may be advantageous to send your slides to Johns Hopkins for confirmation. Secondly, as RobLee pointed out, an MRI seems of little value at this point. Kind of like locking the barn door after the horse has escaped. An MRI often helps to locate areas of suspicion in the prostate. If you and your doctor have already decided that the prostate is coming out, then the location of the cancer within the prostate becomes a moot point. It will be thoroughly examined during post-surgery pathology. And, again, if a prostatectomy is your weapon of choice, history indicates that more treatment may be in your future. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Prostate surgery??

Posts.Content: It's been said that special diets can help to ward off the onset of cancer. Who knows? But once you have been diagnosed and it is confirmed that you have cancer -- as in 11 out of 12 positive samples, including one 4+3=7 aggressive Gleason sample -- no herbal remedy or diet is going to cure you of cancer. You've seen the bias toward surgery by the majority of our forum brothers. I would just add, as I often do, that surgery allows for a second chance at an actual "cure" with salvage radiation if the cancer should recur, as it did with me. With radiation as your primary treatment, not so much. Good luck.

Posts.Title: new psa results

Posts.Content: "What is the benefit of having my PSA tested every 3 months if a biopsy would be repeated in a year?" That's an easy one. If, by chance, you develop an aggressive version of PC -- even Epstein uses the term "suspicious" -- then you sure don't want to wait a year and find that you have a PSA of 300. Basically, if you don't keep a close eye on the issue, you give the cancer -- if it is cancer -- an opportunity to metastasize.

Posts.Content: Another way to look at it statistically: None of the estimated 29,480 men who died from prostate cancer in 2014 are posting on this site or any other. They are past the stage of sharing info. And the fallacy that men "seldom" die of prostate cancer is refuted by the disease ranking second in cancer fatalities only to lung cancer in the U.S.

Posts.Title: Forum as reality?

Posts.Content: Hi Sparky: Keeping a close eye on your PSA is always a good proactive and preventive measure to guard against the possible onset of prostate cancer. At age 57, though, with a PSA of 2.9, which is very close to a normal reading for your age group, you may be reading too much into your results. No need to fear a biopsy, IMHO, because you may very well be years away, if ever, from needing one. If you have confidence in your uro, I would be inclined to accept his apparent view of your situation as a non-event. I share your propensity for kidney stones -- 7 attacks in the last 7 years of which two had to be surgically removed. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: New beginnings in prostate awareness

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Logic1 Jim - thanks. I didn't realize surgery recovery (back to work fulltime, I mean) is often only a couple of weeks. I thought that many people have significant incontinence for a month or more, and healing to do, that would maybe add up to 4 weeks or more. Would 4 weeks be unusually long to recovery from surgery? My bad! Just about everything comes with a qualifier and this is one that I should have expanded on -- sorry. With respect to length of recovery time after surgery, the short answer is...it depends (no pun intended related to Depends pads, although I found them to do the job well). As an office worker who is desk-bound and performs little physical exertion related to the job, then sufficient pads to protect against leakage should dramatically shorten your "recovery" stage. If you are obligated to carry 90 lb. bundles of shingles up a ladder all day, then you will want to wait considerably longer before returning to work, allowing for a return to full strength in addition to protecting against leakage. On this site, posters have documented the length of leakage time following the removal of the catheter from anywhere close to one week to more than one year. I achieved full dryness in 60 days but could have resumed work (if not retired) in about a week using adequate padding.

Posts.Title: Navigating medical providers: GP vs Specialist

Posts.Content: At age 70 with a history of rectal cancer, it was YOU, not your doctor, who asked for your first PSA? I know being a Monday morning quarterback accomplishes nothing, but I just have one question. What planet did this doctor come from? You sound very calm -- I would have been ballistic. If the biopsy shows malignancy, your doctor is guilty of malpractice, in my view. I would be preparing a formal complaint against him with the American Medical Society. Sorry -- when I hear stuff like this, it makes me crazy. It didn't have to be this way -- you should have had PSA tests every year for the last twenty years.

Posts.Title: Very high PSA, but no cancer found yet. What's going on ?

Posts.Content: Welcome Madan: Thank you for sharing your experiences. Was the Feb., 2016 discovery of prostate cancer in your lungs (both lungs?) confirmed by biopsy? As you can see by my history, I had lung and prostate issues, too. After a prostatectomy, I asked my pulmonologist if the cancer believed to be in my right lung was related to my prior prostate cancer. He advised that when escaping from the prostate, cancer usually finds its way to the nearest organs (bladder, kidney, liver, pancreas, etc.) before it would reach the lungs. Has your doctor related whether he thought it was rare for your cancer to "jump" from the prostate to the lungs without affecting any other organ? You mentioned that salvage radiation in the pelvic area in your case was "..uncalled for, a waste and invasive". I'm very sorry to hear that but please recognize that the practice is effective in the majority of cases, including mine. With three years of zero PSAs following salvage radiation, I attribute it to saving my life. Is your lung issue considered resolved at this point? You've had a rough journey, my friend. Glad to hear the Lupron and chemo have successfully suppressed the PSA. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer Lung metastasis

Posts.Content: 06/18/13 First post-op PSA: <<0.04 "All PSA test up to January 2016 have came back zero." Hi Brandon: I suppose it depends on what you accept as zero. Do you consider the PSA from 6/13 to be zero? As Chuck noted, a biochemical recurrence is somewhat unusual in a confirmed post-surgery Gleason 6. My BR occurred three years after surgery with a path report of G7. However, as shown below, it recurred as a slow steady aggression, so it was not a surprise. I also had a single margin and was told it was nothing to worry about. I agree that another PSA in about 2 months, rather than wait 4 months, would be prudent. "What, if anything can be done if it is indeed back? I am freaking out." If the next PSA is equal or higher than the last, medical protocol normally leans toward salvage radiation. My 40 sessions of SR were without incident or side effects, although I did experience some minor fatigue toward the end of the treatment. Others on this site have had similar journeys with success, so it's really nothing to "freak out" about. One of the benefits of surgery is that "second bite" at the apple -- if necessary -- toward an actual "cure". It was the primary reason I chose surgery. No one can predict the future with true accuracy but, so far at least, my SR has withstood the test of over 3 more years. How old is your Dad? Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Ultra Sensitive PSA. Should I Be Worried?

Posts.Content: Hi Goldbass: You've twice asked about side effects of radiation which leads me to believe that you may benefit from further research into primary radiation to treat a cancerous prostate gland versus salvage radiotherapy to "clean up" any remaining cancer following surgery to remove the prostate. In the former example, the oncology radiologist is mainly focused on a specific "target" tumor(s) and zaps the crap out it (sorry, that's not a professional description found in medical literature). It is this type of primary radiation treatment that frequently comes with side effects, some of which are delayed. In the latter case, the prostate is already gone and the likelihood of finding a remaining identifiable tumor is small. Therefore, the radiologist often sends gy forces to the prostate bed (where the prostate used to reside) in much smaller doses of intensity as the entire area is radiated. For that reason, there is significantly less concern about "side effects" of the salvage radiation. In fact, of the guys on this site who have had SR (as I have), I don't recall any major radiation problems (but, please chime in if you have). Basically, don't make the mistake of viewing the two treatments equally. It's like mixing apples and oranges. Just not the same. I agree with checking your PSA in 3-month intervals from this point on. Jim

Posts.Title: Side Effects Short and Long Term of Salvage Radiation Therapy

Posts.Content: For all of the thousands of people who lurk on this site, your story can be helpful to others. "Don't do like I did". Don't wait until you're sick. Everyone should have an annual physical. After age 50, every male should have a PSA test (or risk waking up with a PSA of 570). If you want to have a normal life span -- or longer, you MUST be your own health care advocate.

Posts.Title: Very high PSA, but no cancer found yet. What's going on ?

Posts.Content: Welcome: After I experienced a recurrence of PC three years after surgery, I had 40 sessions of salvage radiation at age 71 which, as you can see below, has worked out well so far. Of course, no one knows what the future holds. Your surgical pathology report indicates that your doctor's recommendation is on target, in my non-professional opinion. Others on this site with similar histories will chime in shortly. In my case, the salvage radiation caused zero side effects except for some slight fatigue toward the end of the sessions. You recognize that with Gleason 9 and the rest of your path report that you are dealing with a serious issue -- no one here will try to sugarcoat it. So, I can tell you that if I found myself in your circumstances, I would proceed ASAP with adjuvant radiation, possibly accompanied by hormone therapy, because I would conclude that I have everything to gain and very little to lose. Best of luck and please let us know how you are progressing, Jim

Posts.Title: Need advice on radiation therapy pros and cons

Posts.Content: Hi Brahms: I suppose the primary reason to be here is that, although none of us are doctors, some of us have had the experiences that you are about to encounter and, as such, you will likely "benefit" from our histories. Then, again, maybe not. It's totally dependent on your desire to view the uncertainty of what lies ahead. The logic involved may be best explained that my only grandson died at age 19. No one can say they know the pain of such a tragedy unless they themselves have gone through it. Same thing with prostate cancer. No one will sugarcoat Gleason 9 here -- it sucks. While I personally have had the surgery, I needed salvage radiation three years later. Everyone is somewhat different, although hms03049 seems to have a history very similar to yours. It's OK to be a cat on the front porch. You may even run into a dog named Toto here. He was from Kansas, too, wasn't he? Stick around and welcome aboard. Best of luck. Jim

Posts.Title: Radiation begins in 2 days!

Posts.Content: Welcome Mark524: On the surface, it may indicate that monitoring with future PSA tests is reasonable. However, if the doctor is recommending a biopsy now, I have to wonder whether he has additional information not listed in your post. For example, do you have any family history of prostate cancer? If so, that could be a contributing factor that increases your risk. You list "peace of mind" as a reason to have the biopsy. Please consider that it could be much more than that. Specifically, it could be life-saving. Keep in mind that 30,000 men die each year from this disease and it is the second leading cause of men's cancer deaths after lung cancer. Most important, though, is that you continue to stay on top of the situation. Whether you decide on another PSA or the biopsy, don't allow it to go "..out of sight, out of mind". Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Content: 06/18/13 First post-op PSA: <<0.04 "All PSA test up to January 2016 have came back zero." Hi Brandon: I suppose it depends on what you accept as zero. Do you consider the PSA from 6/13 to be zero? As Chuck noted, a biochemical recurrence is somewhat unusual in a confirmed post-surgery Gleason 6. My BR occurred three years after surgery with a path report of G7. However, as shown below, it recurred as a slow steady aggression, so it was not a surprise. I also had a single margin and was told it was nothing to worry about. I agree that another PSA in about 2 months, rather than wait 4 months, would be prudent. "What, if anything can be done if it is indeed back? I am freaking out." If the next PSA is equal or higher than the last, medical protocol normally leans toward salvage radiation. My 40 sessions of SR were without incident or side effects, although I did experience some minor fatigue toward the end of the treatment. Others on this site have had similar journeys with success, so it's really nothing to "freak out" about. One of the benefits of surgery is that "second bite" at the apple -- if necessary -- toward an actual "cure". It was the primary reason I chose surgery. No one can predict the future with true accuracy but, so far at least, my SR has withstood the test of over 3 more years. How old is your Dad? Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: PSA recurrence

Posts.Content: Chuck: With all due respect, the patient's latest PSA reading is 0.13. Most indicators now show that the old criteria of waiting until the PSA reaches 0.2 on at least two tests have pretty much been debunked. The new threshold to trigger action seems to be a PSA of 0.1 on two successive tests (I started salvage radiation at a PSA of 0.11, followed by 0.16, as have others). The consensus seems to be the sooner salvage radiation starts, the better the long-term outcome. I'll leave it to others to offer their thoughts. Jim

Posts.Title: PSA recurrence

Posts.Content: Welcome Barbaralynn: As a life-long resident of the Philadelphia area, I can say with confidence that you will repeatedly hear the name Dr. David Lee of the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania (HUP) as the go-to guy for prostate surgery. He has led the robotic prostatectomy field for more than a decade and has completed thousands of prostatectomies. Six years ago, I had to make a decision to either stay with my uro's group in suburban Delaware County for PC robotic surgery or go into the big bad city. I chose the former but that doesn't mean that I doubt Dr. Lee's credentials for a moment. The MRI should help guide you toward a path to pursue. I can understand how multiple negative biopsies can be horribly frustrating. My only question would be, if his most recent PSA was 8.2, three points above the previous PSA, why no action was taken when it reached 5.2. With a ten-year history of high PSAs, suspicion lurks around every corner. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: PSA recurrence

Posts.Content: Chuck: With all due respect, the patient's latest PSA reading is 0.13. Most indicators now show that the old criteria of waiting until the PSA reaches 0.2 on at least two tests have pretty much been debunked. The new threshold to trigger action seems to be a PSA of 0.1 on two successive tests (I started salvage radiation at a PSA of 0.11, followed by 0.16, as have others). The consensus seems to be the sooner salvage radiation starts, the better the long-term outcome. I'll leave it to others to offer their thoughts. Jim

Posts.Title: PSA recurrence

Posts.Content: Hi Goldbass: Wow! Fourteen years is a long time to go without a recurrence and then -- HELLO!! -- back again??? Following my DaVinci Surgery in 2010, the cancer returned three years later and I had 40 sessions of salvage radiotherapy to knock it down. So far, so good (see below). I can't share any side effects from the SR because there were none. Pretty much textbook -- sailed right through it. Have you asked your urologist if these last two PSA tests showing 0.2 (which meets the criteria to take action) could possibly be just a flare-up or infection of some kind that does not relate to the cancer returning? Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Content: True story. Our daughter owns a Hand & Stone Spa, which is a national chain of stores providing massages and facials. My wife, as you might expect, gets lots of freebies. On Saturday, accompanied by 2 of her girlfriends, she went for a full massage and (I couldn't believe it) topped it off with a pumpkin foot massage. I'm not making this stuff up. If only I had known, I could have avoided my DaVinci prostate cancer surgery through the use of a fresh broccoli facial. With a little ranch dressing on the side. Sarcasm intended. Jim

Posts.Title: Dad's Post-op PSA at 0.1

Posts.Content: Welcome: After I experienced a recurrence of PC three years after surgery, I had 40 sessions of salvage radiation at age 71 which, as you can see below, has worked out well so far. Of course, no one knows what the future holds. Your surgical pathology report indicates that your doctor's recommendation is on target, in my non-professional opinion. Others on this site with similar histories will chime in shortly. In my case, the salvage radiation caused zero side effects except for some slight fatigue toward the end of the sessions. You recognize that with Gleason 9 and the rest of your path report that you are dealing with a serious issue -- no one here will try to sugarcoat it. So, I can tell you that if I found myself in your circumstances, I would proceed ASAP with adjuvant radiation, possibly accompanied by hormone therapy, because I would conclude that I have everything to gain and very little to lose. Best of luck and please let us know how you are progressing, Jim

Posts.Title: PSA recurrence

Posts.Content: 06/18/13 First post-op PSA: <<0.04 "All PSA test up to January 2016 have came back zero." Hi Brandon: I suppose it depends on what you accept as zero. Do you consider the PSA from 6/13 to be zero? As Chuck noted, a biochemical recurrence is somewhat unusual in a confirmed post-surgery Gleason 6. My BR occurred three years after surgery with a path report of G7. However, as shown below, it recurred as a slow steady aggression, so it was not a surprise. I also had a single margin and was told it was nothing to worry about. I agree that another PSA in about 2 months, rather than wait 4 months, would be prudent. "What, if anything can be done if it is indeed back? I am freaking out." If the next PSA is equal or higher than the last, medical protocol normally leans toward salvage radiation. My 40 sessions of SR were without incident or side effects, although I did experience some minor fatigue toward the end of the treatment. Others on this site have had similar journeys with success, so it's really nothing to "freak out" about. One of the benefits of surgery is that "second bite" at the apple -- if necessary -- toward an actual "cure". It was the primary reason I chose surgery. No one can predict the future with true accuracy but, so far at least, my SR has withstood the test of over 3 more years. How old is your Dad? Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Content: Hi Dsweetie: It's unusual that your Dad remains incontinent 15 months after surgery. Additional info will certainly help. As Allen stated above, he attacked the recurrence problem when the PSA reached 0.17. As you can see from my history, I started salvage radiation upon reaching a PSA of 0.16. Allen's cancer returned about the same time frame as your Dad's following DaVinci surgery -- mine came back three years after surgery. Fingers crossed, we are both doing well (PSA: 0.00) more than a year after treatment. As others have noted, the "standard" protocol is to wait for two PSA readings over 0.2 before moving ahead with SR, but it's strictly a personal decision. My suggestion is to keep a close watch on his PSA, perhaps having it drawn every three months, if you are so inclined. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Psa of 0.11 after prostate removal

Posts.Content: Hi kb: With such a dramatic rise in your Dad's PSA levels, my first thought (prostatitis) was immediately stated by Ray. This suggestion is coming from a medical non-professional but, while you wait for the next PSA test, I would ask the doctor if he considered commencing with antibiotics in case the problem is prostatitis. If the next PSA test reverts back to a normal range after administering antibiotics, you can feel (reasonably) comfortable that the spike in the PSA was due to an infection. Your Dad is very fortunate to have you as his advocate. Good luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Questioning next steps after Dad's negative biopsy

Posts.Content: A surgical analogy: In 2011, I bought a one-year-old Caddy with a low price and high mileage from a dealer who tried to talk me out of it because it was part of his full-page newspaper "teaser" ad that brought customers in the door. I may not be the brightest bulb on the string but with some miles left on the factory warranty and the purchase of a long-term warranty, I figured that I had implemented a fail-safe protection that nothing bad could happen to me in years. Indeed, in the first year I owned it, I experienced two blown head gaskets ($4,000), an engine rear seal failure (another $4,000) and two broken motor mounts ($1,000). All costs were absorbed by the factory warranty. I paid nothing. Unlike most motorists, I look forward to mechanical failures as I get all new parts plus labor for free. With respect to selecting surgery as my primary treatment for prostate cancer, I figured that I had implemented a fail-safe protection that nothing bad could happen to me in years. Specifically, if I had a recurrence, I could fall back on a "second chance" at a cure via salvage radiation, an option not normally available if you choose any other primary treatment. When the PC came back 3 years later, it confirmed that (perhaps for once in my life), I had made the right choice.

Posts.Title: Michigan Man's path report...

Posts.Content: Welcome: After I experienced a recurrence of PC three years after surgery, I had 40 sessions of salvage radiation at age 71 which, as you can see below, has worked out well so far. Of course, no one knows what the future holds. Your surgical pathology report indicates that your doctor's recommendation is on target, in my non-professional opinion. Others on this site with similar histories will chime in shortly. In my case, the salvage radiation caused zero side effects except for some slight fatigue toward the end of the sessions. You recognize that with Gleason 9 and the rest of your path report that you are dealing with a serious issue -- no one here will try to sugarcoat it. So, I can tell you that if I found myself in your circumstances, I would proceed ASAP with adjuvant radiation, possibly accompanied by hormone therapy, because I would conclude that I have everything to gain and very little to lose. Best of luck and please let us know how you are progressing, Jim

Posts.Title: Need advice on radiation therapy pros and cons

Posts.Content: Chuck: With all due respect, the patient's latest PSA reading is 0.13. Most indicators now show that the old criteria of waiting until the PSA reaches 0.2 on at least two tests have pretty much been debunked. The new threshold to trigger action seems to be a PSA of 0.1 on two successive tests (I started salvage radiation at a PSA of 0.11, followed by 0.16, as have others). The consensus seems to be the sooner salvage radiation starts, the better the long-term outcome. I'll leave it to others to offer their thoughts. Jim

Posts.Title: PSA recurrence

Posts.Content: Hi Dsweetie: It's unusual that your Dad remains incontinent 15 months after surgery. Additional info will certainly help. As Allen stated above, he attacked the recurrence problem when the PSA reached 0.17. As you can see from my history, I started salvage radiation upon reaching a PSA of 0.16. Allen's cancer returned about the same time frame as your Dad's following DaVinci surgery -- mine came back three years after surgery. Fingers crossed, we are both doing well (PSA: 0.00) more than a year after treatment. As others have noted, the "standard" protocol is to wait for two PSA readings over 0.2 before moving ahead with SR, but it's strictly a personal decision. My suggestion is to keep a close watch on his PSA, perhaps having it drawn every three months, if you are so inclined. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: PSA after SRT

Posts.Content: 06/18/13 First post-op PSA: <<0.04 "All PSA test up to January 2016 have came back zero." Hi Brandon: I suppose it depends on what you accept as zero. Do you consider the PSA from 6/13 to be zero? As Chuck noted, a biochemical recurrence is somewhat unusual in a confirmed post-surgery Gleason 6. My BR occurred three years after surgery with a path report of G7. However, as shown below, it recurred as a slow steady aggression, so it was not a surprise. I also had a single margin and was told it was nothing to worry about. I agree that another PSA in about 2 months, rather than wait 4 months, would be prudent. "What, if anything can be done if it is indeed back? I am freaking out." If the next PSA is equal or higher than the last, medical protocol normally leans toward salvage radiation. My 40 sessions of SR were without incident or side effects, although I did experience some minor fatigue toward the end of the treatment. Others on this site have had similar journeys with success, so it's really nothing to "freak out" about. One of the benefits of surgery is that "second bite" at the apple -- if necessary -- toward an actual "cure". It was the primary reason I chose surgery. No one can predict the future with true accuracy but, so far at least, my SR has withstood the test of over 3 more years. How old is your Dad? Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: PSA after SRT

Posts.Content: A surgical analogy: In 2011, I bought a one-year-old Caddy with a low price and high mileage from a dealer who tried to talk me out of it because it was part of his full-page newspaper "teaser" ad that brought customers in the door. I may not be the brightest bulb on the string but with some miles left on the factory warranty and the purchase of a long-term warranty, I figured that I had implemented a fail-safe protection that nothing bad could happen to me in years. Indeed, in the first year I owned it, I experienced two blown head gaskets ($4,000), an engine rear seal failure (another $4,000) and two broken motor mounts ($1,000). All costs were absorbed by the factory warranty. I paid nothing. Unlike most motorists, I look forward to mechanical failures as I get all new parts plus labor for free. With respect to selecting surgery as my primary treatment for prostate cancer, I figured that I had implemented a fail-safe protection that nothing bad could happen to me in years. Specifically, if I had a recurrence, I could fall back on a "second chance" at a cure via salvage radiation, an option not normally available if you choose any other primary treatment. When the PC came back 3 years later, it confirmed that (perhaps for once in my life), I had made the right choice.

Posts.Title: Michigan Man's path report...

Posts.Content: "Until the last 2 days I had some control don't know what happened. Maybe trying to do to much. It just gets so frustrating." Ron: Deep breath. Step back and view it as if the symptoms belong to another patient. Realize that you are only 17 days post-catheter. It is simply the nature of this form of recovery with the incontinence that you take one step forward and, inexplicably, you take two steps backward. Guys tend to agonize over this aspect -- think it is only happening to them -- when, in fact, it is just part of the normal process. Some patients recommend that you measure success by weekly plateaus. My doctor said that if you never did a Kegel in your life, you -- at least the overwhelming majority of guys -- would still be dry in 60 to 90 days (I was dry exactly on the 60th day). Patience -- as Pratoman noted -- is the key word here (I know it's not easy). Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: PSA after SRT

Posts.Content: A surgical analogy: In 2011, I bought a one-year-old Caddy with a low price and high mileage from a dealer who tried to talk me out of it because it was part of his full-page newspaper "teaser" ad that brought customers in the door. I may not be the brightest bulb on the string but with some miles left on the factory warranty and the purchase of a long-term warranty, I figured that I had implemented a fail-safe protection that nothing bad could happen to me in years. Indeed, in the first year I owned it, I experienced two blown head gaskets ($4,000), an engine rear seal failure (another $4,000) and two broken motor mounts ($1,000). All costs were absorbed by the factory warranty. I paid nothing. Unlike most motorists, I look forward to mechanical failures as I get all new parts plus labor for free. With respect to selecting surgery as my primary treatment for prostate cancer, I figured that I had implemented a fail-safe protection that nothing bad could happen to me in years. Specifically, if I had a recurrence, I could fall back on a "second chance" at a cure via salvage radiation, an option not normally available if you choose any other primary treatment. When the PC came back 3 years later, it confirmed that (perhaps for once in my life), I had made the right choice.

Posts.Title: I am worried about these results from final prostate surg/path report:

Posts.Content: When you speak of "actual tumor", you leave the impression that there is a single point of focus. In fact, to the best of my knowledge, most cancers detected in and surrounding the prostate are diffuse. One example might be a biopsy showing different core Gleason scores (3+4=7) indicating more than one single tumor. A post-surgery pathology report can help to reveal the specifics of the prostate contents and whether single or multiple tumors were involved.

Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer and IP6?

Posts.Content: Welcome Throwaway: As Ron mentioned, there could be many reasons for a high PSA result that is not cancer, so try to stay calm. If he is having a biopsy (and a biopsy is the only way to confirm prostate cancer), then you should have the information you/he need to move forward. Even under a worst case scenario, if he has to have cancer, this is the one he wants because it is almost always 100% curable when found early and treated. Please give us an update when you can. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Hopefully this thread will help others

Posts.Content: Welcome Hammer: Very sorry to hear of the loss of your Dad. With such a family history of PC, including your brother, you were wise to keep a close eye on your PSA results at such a young age. Whenever I encourage men of your age group to make sure they get a PSA test annually, you would be amazed at the number of men who have never heard of the PSA test. Based on your biopsy results, there are some posters on this site who might have recommended active surveillance but you have already done your due diligence in investigating your options and, with your family history of PC and your age, your choice of robotic surgery would be the same decision that I and many others would have chosen. And just to prove that there is life after prostate cancer, at age 73, exactly 12 days before your surgery, I will be flying to Vegas on an all-expenses-paid poker package after winning an online poker tournament. I keep telling my wife that she is fortunate to have a Trophy Husband but she seems more concerned that I take out the trash. Please keep us updated on your progress -- there are many great contributors on this site who will be happy to provide helpful info. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer Diagnosed on 5/13/16

Posts.Content: Hi Bill: Welcome. Sorry you find yourself here. In your case, I understand that surgery may be a challenge but I would urge you to do as much research as possible before agreeing to Cyberknife. Cyberknife ads play upon the theory that you are the exceptionally "smart" patient because you will only have to show up for five treatments (of massive doses of radiation) whereas all of those people who elect to drive back and forth to 40 sessions of radiation (the gold standard for decades) are obviously stupid. First, among the thousands of patients on this prostate cancer site, Cyberknife represents an incredibly small group. Second, of the people who did select Cyberknife, short-term and long-term complications were numerous, primarily caused by radiation burns. I personally know two patients who experienced radiation burns that penetrated the anal walls. Finally, if you perform a Google search of patient satisfaction with various prostate cancer treatment options, in virtually every survey, Cyberknife is listed as being the LEAST popular. But please don't take my word for anything. Check it out yourself. Wishing you the best treatment, Jim

Posts.Title: Psa of 0.11 after prostate removal

Posts.Content: Hi: On this site, you will encounter patients who have made different personal choices even though their basic medical scenarios are close to being identical. Only you can decide what's best for you, given your research on the subject of PC. My input is twofold and brief: My urologist said that in his practice containing 9 urologists, with a Gleason score of 7, under age 60, do surgery. Over age 70, do radiation. Between ages 60 and 70, flip a coin. Secondly, if you choose surgery and the cancer returns (see my signature), you can always have salvage radiation to eradicate any remaining cancer. However, if you choose radiation as your primary treatment and the cancer returns, surgery is not an option (except in extremely rare cases). All the best to you. Jim

AgeInfo.Phrase: score of 7  under age 60  do surgery <Z> <Z> <Z>
<Z> <Z> <Z> Over age 70  do radiation <Z> <Z> <Z>

Posts.Title: Just Diagnosed with Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Just try to take it one step at a time. We'll be here. Others will chime in shortly. I would tend to lean toward Chuck's warning that if you could be guaranteed your 3+4=7 Gleason score is accurate, you have lots of breathing room time-wise. However, if your true Gleason score is actually higher (only to be learned AFTER removal of the prostate), then your timeframe to make a decision is dramatically shortened. In that way, the whole damn thing becomes somewhat of a crapshoot. A lot of people decide to just get rid of the prostate via surgery and (hopefully) be done with it. That was my intention but, as noted in my signature, there can be deviations along the pathway.

Posts.Title: Just Diagnosed with Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Prior to having prostate cancer surgery 4 years ago, I performed some extensive research on the pros/cons of that Cyberknife gadget. Now, I'm sure the device has been helpful to some people. But, when it was applied to the prostate (I didn't look at lung application), on a large-scale population survey, out of 5 different treatment choices of people who had already been treated, the Cyberknife was listed in a distant 5th place. One complaint among patients was that it was sold to them as "you are so much smarter to have only 5 Cyberknife treatments instead of those stupid people who have 40 radiation treatments - which has been the gold standard for many decades". In looking for a quick fix, the most common complaint was that the Cyberknife uses massive doses of radiation at each session, frequently resulting in painful radiation burns. In applying the beam to the prostate area, I read of numerous instances where the radiation burned a hole through the anal wall. So, if you're looking to pursue that treatment, I would gather as much information as possible. Jim
Posts.Title: Cyber Knife Surgery

Posts.Content: Hi Katyana: Welcome and sorry you find yourself here. Your question, of course, is impossible to answer. With or without cancer, none of us come with an expiration date. As you likely know by now, Stage 4 does not offer a cure but if you read a number of posts on this prostate cancer site, you will find an awful lot of people whose lives have been extended -- some for many years -- mainly through recommended medical treatment, which you described. Some patients, not all by any means, do have difficulty in dealing with the side effects of those treatments. Others, like your Dad, may forego treatment using the logic that they would rather have limited quality time rather than quantity of time. There are no right or wrong positions on the subject. Others will chime in shortly but I think I can say without too much fear of contradiction that, prior to outright rejection of treatment, your Dad would be well served to have an extended sit-down with an oncologist specializing in prostate cancer. The oncologist could evaluate your Dad's specific medical situation and explain to him in detail exactly what he views as the best case/worst case scenario with respect to his prognosis. With that information in hand, your Dad may still stick with his initial decision or he may be swayed to at least consider other options. Best wishes to you and your Dad. Jim

Posts.Title: Good news on ED

Posts.Content: Hi: On this site, you will encounter patients who have made different personal choices even though their basic medical scenarios are close to being identical. Only you can decide what's best for you, given your research on the subject of PC. My input is twofold and brief: My urologist said that in his practice containing 9 urologists, with a Gleason score of 7, under age 60, do surgery. Over age 70, do radiation. Between ages 60 and 70, flip a coin. Secondly, if you choose surgery and the cancer returns (see my signature), you can always have salvage radiation to eradicate any remaining cancer. However, if you choose radiation as your primary treatment and the cancer returns, surgery is not an option (except in extremely rare cases). All the best to you. Jim

Some of that dietary stuff sounds horrible. Have a Big Mac. Intense exercise? My most intense exercise is to walk to the kitchen for a beer. Enjoy.

Posts.Title: PSA reduction curiosity

Posts.Content: Welcome Hammer: Very sorry to hear of the loss of your Dad. With such a family history of PC, including your brother, you were wise to keep a close eye on your PSA results at such a young age. Whenever I encourage men of your age group to make sure they get a PSA test annually, you would be amazed at the number of men who have never heard of the PSA test. Based on your biopsy results, there are some posters on this site who might have recommended active surveillance but you have already done your due diligence in investigating your options and, with your family history of PC and your age, your choice of robotic surgery would be the same decision that I and many others would have chosen. And just to prove that there is life after prostate cancer, at age 73, exactly 12 days before your surgery, I will be flying to Vegas on an all-expenses-paid poker package after winning an online poker tournament. I keep telling my wife that she is fortunate to have a Trophy Husband but she seems more concerned that I take out the trash. Please keep us updated on your progress -- there are many great contributors on this site who will be happy to provide helpful info. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer Diagnosed on 5/13/16

Posts.Content: No one has performed a DRE - digital rectal exam yet? That is usually Step One in protecting against an abnormality in your prostate. As Allen mentioned, a GP could monitor your case or a urologist is normally the starting point in this area. Sorry to hear that your Dad and your uncle contracted the disease but, based on your age and low PSA numbers, it may have caused you to have a greater concern about your own well-being than, say, someone else with the same stats. It is actually GREAT that you are keeping a close eye on your PSA (lots of guys never bother at all) but a urologist should be able to help guide you in this area and provide a balanced perspective. Good luck. Jim

Posts.Title: Hopefully this thread will help others

Posts.Content: Newporter: I'm very, VERY sorry you have decided to leave. Your contributions have benefited many people who have sought help here. I'm certain that Chuck will agree (Whoops, he beat me to it). I toyed with the idea of asking if you had a bus to catch, hopefully to get you to stay, but your decision must be respected. November 8th is my six-year anniversary post-surgery and I'll be staying. My thinking is that since we're all here for just a blink of the eye overall, if I have helped only one person in those six years to step back and recognize that the diagnosis of The Big "C" in prostate cancer is not potentially terminal compared to, say, pancreatic cancer, then all of the hours online have been worth it. Interacting with strangers from around the world, both forum brothers and new patients, for the purpose of providing support just seems like the right thing to do. Of course, there are sometimes bumps along the way. Although I'm an East Coast guy, my wife and I normally visit California about once a year. In your area, we especially liked the Harborside Restaurant in Balboa with it's water views. And further north, twelve miles north of San Francisco, my great-grandfather helped to found a town in Marin County in 1890. I call it Utopia but the real name is Mill Valley. Please stop back and visit from time to time. We're going to miss your insightful opinions. Jim

Posts.Title: Six-Year Anniversary

Posts.Content: Hi Max and Welcome: I concur with Chuck that your question is an unusual one. Basically, unless there was some unexpected complications post-surgery, there is virtually no need to address a question of pain management because there is mostly very little and it's quite manageable. After arriving home following a one-night hospital stay, I took a single pain pill. Over the next few days, I popped a couple of Tylenol. With all of the various things to worry about related to PC, this subject is definitely low on the concern meter. You should be fine. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Overthinking? LOL

Posts.Content: Kermica: Also, in an unrelated matter, I know that advertising is the life blood of web sites. But, on a cancer forum web site, where patients deal daily with the precipitous venue of possible life and death issues for themselves and friends and family members, do they really need to be exposed to paid advertising for a pornographic web site? I'm talking about Thaimatches.com where a scantily clad young Asian woman beckons one and all to call and "chat" with her. I never considered myself a prude but, considering the primary subject matter of this site, it just seems to jump out as entirely inappropriate. Jim

Posts.Title: Tested positive on Biopsy. What next?

Posts.Content: Hi Max and Welcome: I concur with Chuck that your question is an unusual one. Basically, unless there was some unexpected complications post-surgery, there is virtually no need to address a question of pain management because there is mostly very little and it's quite manageable. After arriving home following a one-night hospital stay, I took a single pain pill. Over the next few days, I popped a couple of Tylenol. With all of the various things to worry about related to PC, this subject is definitely low on the concern meter. You should be fine. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Pain Management right after surgery

Posts.Content: Welcome function2: I see that pretty much all of the key points have already been covered by my forum brothers. The only thing I would reiterate is that a return to work in just 2 weeks post-surgery seems overly optimistic and I agree that 4 weeks (even with a desk job) is more realistic. And while some patients do indeed experience full urinary control within one month, the majority reach the Land of Dryness in about 2 to 3 months. These two items are inter-related because if you try to return to work in 2 weeks, you may have zero urinary control at that point. Pads may not be sufficient for an office environment if that happens. Your Gleason 8 should be taken quite seriously, keeping in mind that the actual surgical pathology may be lower or higher. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Getting Ready for Post Prostatectomy Radiation

Posts.Content: What do you guys think of delaying? As you can see from the replies (and none of us are medical professionals, just guys who have dealt with our own PC), there are different opinions of your case which some may see as borderline without a need for immediate action and others suggest that you consider commencing treatment quickly. I fall into the latter camp. At age 57, if you devote too much time to posturing ("Do I do this or that or nothing?"), you may be giving the cancer an opportunity to metastasize. I only had 2 out of 12 cores positive, the same Gleason 3+4=7 and I leapt onto the operating table. And if you arrive at a decision to either have surgery or radiation as primary treatment, remember that with surgery if you have a recurrence, as I did, you can always have salvage radiation to knock it down. With radiation as the primary treatment, that "second chance" is not an option. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Tomorrow is the day...

Posts.Content: Welcome Steve: Due to your age, you should benefit from the lively discussion of treatment options under the thread "surgery vs. radiation for younger patients". Keep in mind that surgery or radiation are the two primary forms of treatment, with surgery recommended nearly universally for patients in your age group. At any age, seeds therapy is implemented in only 2% of all prostate cancer treatments. And, since most PC patients perform extensive research prior to treatment, I always ask why 98% of patients reject the seeds. A search of this thread shows a number of patients who suffer for years later with seeds complications. But it is best that you perform your own research in deciding what is acceptable to you. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: I'm that guy

Posts.Content: What do you guys think of delaying? As you can see from the replies (and none of us are medical professionals, just guys who have dealt with our own PC), there are different opinions of your case which some may see as borderline without a need for immediate action and others suggest that you consider commencing treatment quickly. I fall into the latter camp. At age 57, if you devote too much time to posturing ("Do I do this or that or nothing?"), you may be giving the cancer an opportunity to metastasize. I only had 2 out of 12 cores positive, the same Gleason 3+4=7 and I leapt onto the operating table. And if you arrive at a decision to either have surgery or radiation as primary treatment, remember that with surgery if you have a recurrence, as I did, you can always have salvage radiation to knock it down. With radiation as the primary treatment, that "second chance" is not an option. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Getting Ready for Post Prostatectomy Radiation

Posts.Content: Welcome function2: I see that pretty much all of the key points have already been covered by my forum brothers. The only thing I would reiterate is that a return to work in just 2 weeks post-surgery seems overly optimistic and I agree that 4 weeks (even with a desk job) is more realistic. And while some patients do indeed experience full urinary control within one month, the majority reach the Land of Dryness in about 2 to 3 months. These two items are inter-related because if you try to return to work in 2 weeks, you may have zero urinary control at that point. Pads may not be sufficient for an office environment if that happens. Your Gleason 8 should be taken quite seriously, keeping in mind that the actual surgical pathology may be lower or higher. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: post-surgery experiences

Posts.Content: Welcome Moonshadow: The others have pretty much covered everything, including the reality that a hope for a cure is not an option -- something you are already aware of. We don't say that to be cruel but rather for you to know that everyone on this forum will be completely honest with you. Here's a thought: see if you can figure out something he always wanted to do but didn't -- and then surprise him with it. My wife, for example, in her 70 years always yearned to visit Hawaii. I couldn't take her because, completely unrelated to my two bouts with prostate cancer, the idea of spending 24 hours in the air round-trip was impossible as I am a white-knuckle flyer. I told her that she would have to go with her next husband (after dealing with me for 53 years). Last week, our elder daughter finally took her to Hawaii using her frequent flyer miles for first-class all the way and, while we have taken dozens of trips, this was The Big One and they both loved it. I can't really add anything to the supportive and knowledgeable comments already stated, however I would like to make one observation after several years on this forum. We get some sons of PC patients who seek out information here but the daughters -- oh, the daughters, so many daughters -- that I get choked up just thinking about their love for their ailing fathers. This old geezer must bore you with an old cliché: "A son is a son until he takes a wife; a daughter is a daughter all of her life". Best of luck to you and your Dad, Jim

Posts.Title: The Forum

Posts.Content: Kermica: Also, in an unrelated matter, I know that advertising is the life blood of web sites. But, on a cancer forum web site, where patients deal daily with the precipitous venue of possible life and death issues for themselves and friends and family members, do they really need to be exposed to paid advertising for a pornographic web site? I'm talking about Thaimatches.com where a scantily clad young Asian woman beckons one and all to call and "chat" with her. I never considered myself a prude but, considering the primary subject matter of this site, it just seems to jump out as entirely inappropriate. Jim

Posts.Title: The Forum

Posts.Content: Hi Valar: Finding your husband's prostate cancer during a routine physical at age 50 was a stroke of good luck. The numbers you reported, as you already know, are indeed serious, although the clear bone scan is definitely a celebratory finding. Pratoman has provided an excellent list of subjects to consider. Personally, I focused on Items #1 & #2. I sincerely hope you don't think my comments are too dramatic but I would press the doctors to tell you whether they realistically expect a complete "cure" versus an extension of life. I'm not trying to paint a picture of gloom. The latter path can last for decades with the proper treatment. Again, we are not doctors and can only offer our personal experiences with this disease. Best of luck. Jim

Posts.Title: Some advice

Posts.Content: Hi Jeri: I concur with Michael on your husband's upcoming surgery, then "radiation"? Never heard of that before. Normally, with surgery as primary treatment, follow-up adjuvant or salvage radiation IF NEEDED is scheduled at a later date. For example, the need for salvage radiation in my case (please see history below) didn't surface until a full three years after my DaVinci robotic surgery. As Michael stated, there is no need to be scared to death. When I expressed a similar concern to my urologist upon being diagnosed with The Big "C", prostate cancer and Gleason 3+4=7, he said, "Relax. Don't be overly dramatic. What you have is a basic garden-variety episode of PC that we see every day and you have very little cause for concern". Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: newbie from Vancouver

Posts.Content: I see that you consulted with a medical oncologist in July, 2014 and decided to take no action with a post-SR PSA of 0.1. That was reasonable. But, with all you learned as a DaVinci and salvage radiation prostate cancer patient (me, too), did you not realize a year ago (December, 2014) that you were in trouble with a PSA of 0.3? I'm sorry to say that you should have been yelling "YIKES!" back then, or at the very least, "YIKES!" should have been uttered at your PSA tests in January, March, June and/or September this year. Particularly with a post-surgery Gleason 8. When you received those PSA results, did you coordinate the findings with any medical professional that you previously dealt with? If so, I'm puzzled as to why action -- likely hormone therapy -- was not taken sooner. Hopefully, some of our forum brothers who had similar experiences can shed more light on this for you. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Post Op, Post Salvage Radiation PSA quadrupled in 6 months

Posts.Content: I see that you consulted with a medical oncologist in July, 2014 and decided to take no action with a post-SR PSA of 0.1. That was reasonable. But, with all you learned as a DaVinci and salvage radiation prostate cancer patient (me, too), did you not realize a year ago (December, 2014) that you were in trouble with a PSA of 0.3? I'm sorry to say that you should have been yelling "YIKES!" back then, or at the very least, "YIKES!" should have been uttered at your PSA tests in January, March, June and/or September this year. Particularly with a post-surgery Gleason 8. When you received those PSA results, did you coordinate the findings with any medical professional that you previously dealt with? If so, I'm puzzled as to why action -- likely hormone therapy -- was not taken sooner. Hopefully, some of our forum brothers who had similar experiences can shed more light on this for you. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Post Op, Post Salvage Radiation PSA quadrupled in 6 months

Posts.Content: Rob: I'm truly sorry to hear that you are hurting so much. It would be easy to say that you can depend on us, here on this website, as we have been through a small part of what you have suffered. It would be easy for me to tell you that we somehow managed to get through the death of our only grandson at age 19, ten years ago, from substance abuse. It remains the most crushing event of our lifetime. It would be easy to tell you that my wife at age 56, a successful college administrator, suffered two strokes that caused her to lose her job due to cognitive deficits. I might ask her what we're having for dinner tonight and the response could be, "It's going to be partly cloudy next Thursday". I never know what's coming next. But none of that would be of help to you other than watching people try to adjust. Respectfully, support groups may be of help but, frankly, my thoughts turn to a leaking roof. If you have one, you would call a roofer because he is the one most trained to repair the damage. With that in mind, you may want to seek professional therapeutic help to ease your emotional pain. Depression can fester, if left untreated. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Nowhere to turn

Posts.Content: Welcome Oliver: After reading of your experiences with the Russian form of TRUS surgery, a few things come to mind: You received wonderful value for your money. An 8-day hospital stay seems awfully long for such a procedure. Forty-five days of pain sounds excessive. I'm very sorry to hear that. The Gleason 6 evaluation of the incidental portion of the prostate removed reveals little or nothing about whether your prostate harbors any tumors that could remain in the prostate that may be G6 or higher. Your PSA history did not seem to warrant a biopsy but it's unfortunate that it did not because if it did and you chose a prostatectomy, all of your problems (BPH, cancer, urination difficulties, etc.) would have been history by now with perhaps a one-night hospital stay and less than 45 days of pain. I'm not being critical of anything -- just such a damn shame that the sequence of events played out as they did. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: My prostate operation

Posts.Content: Gunrun: The logic of celebrating a finding of no cancer in October after you were already diagnosed WITH cancer escapes me. And to schedule a third biopsy in January to "...find out where I'm at..." makes even less sense. If you search all 51,000 prostate cancer forum posts on this site, I assure you that there is no other identical experience listed. Not sure what is going on. You say, "Yes, I have cancer" but you're acting as if you are in denial. Please perform due diligence and seek appropriate consultation -- and treatment, if warranted. But, another biopsy in January is likely to cause pain and nothing more. You already have the answer that you seek. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Tomorrow is the day...

Posts.Content: "Urologist wanted to do a biopsy, but we did a 3T MRI instead." Welcome Fred: Your use of the word "instead" is puzzling. Usually, a 3T MRI (which cannot confirm cancer) is used as a support tool in trying to identify areas that a biopsy (the only thing that CAN confirm cancer) might target. Over the years on this website, we have seen a number of instances where a low PSA does not tell the whole tale. The entire issue comes down to the amount of risk you are willing to take with respect to avoiding a biopsy. Another MRI seems kind of pointless if it is not scheduled in coordination with a biopsy. But this is just the opinion of one old guy without a medical degree. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Should I get another 3T MRI

Posts.Content: Hi Valar: Finding your husband's prostate cancer during a routine physical at age 50 was a stroke of good luck. The numbers you reported, as you already know, are indeed serious, although the clear bone scan is definitely a celebratory finding. Pratoman has provided an excellent list of subjects to consider. Personally, I focused on Items #1 & #2. I sincerely hope you don't think my comments are too dramatic but I would press the doctors to tell you whether they realistically expect a complete "cure" versus an extension of life. I'm not trying to paint a picture of gloom. The latter path can last for decades with the proper treatment. Again, we are not doctors and can only offer our personal experiences with this disease. Best of luck. Jim

Posts.Title: Some advice

Posts.Content: Welcome Steve: Due to your age, you should benefit from the lively discussion of treatment options under the thread "surgery vs. radiation for younger patients". Keep in mind that surgery or radiation are the two primary forms of treatment, with surgery recommended nearly universally for patients in your age group. At any age, seeds therapy is implemented in only 2% of all prostate cancer treatments. And, since most PC patients perform extensive research prior to treatment, I always ask why 98% of patients reject the seeds. A search of this thread shows a number of patients who suffer for years later with seeds complications. But it is best that you perform your own research in deciding what is acceptable to you. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Another younger guy

Posts.Content: [QUOTE=Steve2017;334456]Thanks Jim. I have been taking generic Flomax since 2014. It is becoming less efficient recently possibly due to prostate increased 20% in size in the last few months from 40 to 50 gm. I don't believe urine flow decreased due to PC. My father was diagnosed with PC at about age 80. He took one $1000 pill that gave him hot flashes so he stopped any further treatment. He had to catheterize for the last several years of his life until he was 89. His bladder was fine. One of my brothers had a radicle open prostatectomy 15 years ago. He goes for his last PSA test next month. He has been in the zero club since surgery. My other brother had radiation last year. Seems to be doing ok. This prostate cancer thing is becoming burdensome to me so I am leaning toward robotic removal before the end of the year. I freaked out when first diagnosed in 2014. This Forum helped me enormously. Thanks for your input. ======================================== Thanks, Steve. That's very interesting. If your Dad had to catheterize for the last years of his life and his bladder was not the issue, do you know the confirmed reason for his daily catheterization? Do you know if he had any issues with kidney stones (I ask that because I've had seven kidney stone hospitalizations in the last decade, two of which caused total urine blockage and required surgical removal of the stones which completely blocked my left ureter)? Have you had any kidney hydronephrosis or kidney stone problems that might relate to the poor urination? Jim

Posts.Content: Hi Shortstuff: So sorry to hear of your Dad's problems at such a young age. It would appear that any future treatment is contingent on the results of the full-body bone scan and the CT scan. With his history, any attempt to diagnose his case without that info would be pure speculation. Please provide an update when you can and we will be glad to share any experiences that could be helpful in moving forward. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Can anyone advice - high PSA

Posts.Content: Welcome hayu: With the caveat that none of us are medical professional on this website, it has always been my understanding that prostate cancer, unless it has metastasized to the bones (not likely with Gleason 6), rarely presents with pain. Could you provide us with more of your history (PSA history, number of cores involved in your G6 diagnosis, degree of involvement of the cores, etc.) so that our forum brothers and sisters can better understand your case? You may wish to consult with your primary doctor to pursue some alternate cause of the symptoms. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: A pain in the Prostate :(

Posts.Content: Hi DD: I respectfully ask you to explore a "glass is half full" state of mind by stepping back and looking at the big picture. Gleason 9 sucks BUT adjuvant or salvage radiation still offers a light at the end of the tunnel along with a potential "cure". That's a light that would likely not be shining if you had instead elected radiation as your primary treatment. So far, it's worked for me (see below). Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: My Post-Op Pathology

Posts.Content: I agree with Allen. My experience with the biopsy was discomfort but not pain. Some posters have mentioned having anesthesia -- didn't make sense to me -- kind of like having general anesthesia to have a tooth filled. It would be beneficial if you recognize this biopsy for what it is. It's merely a diagnostic test, nothing more. You've had it before so there should be no surprises. I know it's a cliché but you need to take it one step at a time. If you require treatment for a disease that is almost always 100% curable if caught early, there will be plenty of time to stress about it then, while recognizing that millions of men have gone before you without incident and millions more will follow. And we'll be here to share our experiences which will, hopefully, take away some of the unknown to make your journey go smoothly. Jim

Posts.Title: Questions

Posts.Content: Hi Rev: As Chuck said, a PSA reading of 0.04 seems remarkably premature to be talking about salvage radiotherapy although it "could" eventually lead to that as seen in my signature/history. Are you sure it wasn't 0.4 instead? That would seem to be the only justification for even making an appointment with an oncologist at this point. But the thing that would most concern me is exactly what the doctor meant by describing your cancer as "very advanced". In fact, I would ask for a detailed written explanation of that terminology directly from the doctor. Please let us know what the oncologist has to say tomorrow. And the very best of luck to you, Sir. Jim

Posts.Title: Post Surgery PSA

Posts.Content: [QUOTE=Steve2017;334456]Thanks Jim. I have been taking generic Flomax since 2014. It is becoming less efficient recently possibly due to prostate increased 20% in size in the last few months from 40 to 50 gm. I don't believe urine flow decreased due to PC. My father was diagnosed with PC at about age 80. He took one $1000 pill that gave him hot flashes so he stopped any further treatment. He had to catheterize for the last several years of his life until he was 89. His bladder was fine. One of my brothers had a radicle open prostatectomy 15 years ago. He goes for his last PSA test next month. He has been in the zero club since surgery. My other brother had radiation last year. Seems to be doing ok. This prostate cancer thing is becoming burdensome to me so I am leaning toward robotic removal before the end of the year. I freaked out when first diagnosed in 2014. This Forum helped me enormously. Thanks for your input. ======================================== Thanks, Steve. That's very interesting. If your Dad had to catheterize for the last years of his life and his bladder was not the issue, do you know the confirmed reason for his daily catheterization? Do you know if he had any issues with kidney stones (I ask that because I've had seven kidney stone hospitalizations in the last decade, two of which caused total urine blockage and required surgical removal of the stones which completely blocked my left ureter)? Have you had any kidney hydronephrosis or kidney stone problems that might relate to the poor urination? Jim

Posts.Title: My Post-Op Pathology

Posts.Content: "I was not prepared for the profound psychological impact my cancer diagnosis would have on me". Zencat: At age 68, those were also my thoughts exactly. At your age 54, it must have been worse. So, I shared my thoughts with my urologist who was spectacularly unimpressed. He explained that a 3+4=7 Gleason score was nothing more than run-of-the-mill PC that his group sees every day and that the cure rate, when treated early, is nearly 100%. He referred me to a scene in the 1987 movie "Moonstruck" where Cher slaps Nicholas Cage hard in the face and says, "Snap out of it". A tour of other cancer forums on this website will quickly convince you that, if you were going to have cancer, this is the one you want --really!! Again, you are looking at a nearly 100% survival rate where others may fall into the 6-16% rate. The only tears to be shed in the near future will probably be from your wife when she realizes that she may have to pamper you for the week after surgery as you maneuver at home with the cumbersome -- but not painful -- catheter. Relax. You're not going anywhere soon. Others will chime in later with virtually guaranteed similar comments. Deep breath now. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Should I have a bone scan?

Posts.Content: Welcome Moonshadow: The others have pretty much covered everything, including the reality that a hope for a cure is not an option -- something you are already aware of. We don't say that to be cruel but rather for you to know that everyone on this forum will be completely honest with you. Here's a thought: see if you can figure out something he always wanted to do but didn't -- and then surprise him with it. My wife, for example, in her 70 years always yearned to visit Hawaii. I couldn't take her because, completely unrelated to my two bouts with prostate cancer, the idea of spending 24 hours in the air round-trip was impossible as I am a white-knuckle flyer. I told her that she would have to go with her next husband (after dealing with me for 53 years). Last week, our elder daughter finally took her to Hawaii using her frequent flyer miles for first-class all the way and, while we have taken dozens of trips, this was The Big One and they both loved it. I can't really add anything to the supportive and knowledgeable comments already stated, however I would like to make one observation after several years on this forum. We get some sons of PC patients who seek out information here but the daughters -- oh, the daughters, so many daughters -- that I get choked up just thinking about their love for their ailing fathers. This old geezer must bore you with an old cliché: "A son is a son until he takes a wife; a daughter is a daughter all of her life". Best of luck to you and your Dad, Jim

Posts.Title: Father with metastatic prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Gunrun: The logic of celebrating a finding of no cancer in October after you were already diagnosed WITH cancer escapes me. And to schedule a third biopsy in January to "...find out where I'm at..." makes even less sense. If you search all 51,000 prostate cancer forum posts on this site, I assure you that there is no other identical experience listed. Not sure what is going on. You say, "Yes, I have cancer" but you're acting as if you are in denial. Please perform due diligence and seek appropriate consultation -- and treatment, if warranted. But, another biopsy in January is likely to cause pain and nothing more. You already have the answer that you seek. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: First Post, Struggling to Stay Positive

Posts.Content: Welcome Neighbor Emar: As mentioned, the bone scan is absolutely standard procedure after PC diagnosis and the test itself is nothing to worry about. In the unlikely event that the bone scan finds remote mets, that would be a different story that needs to be addressed separately. With a Gleason 6 biopsy, in just 2 cores, often a doctor's recommendation would lead to active surveillance. However, your husband's 8 biopsies (I don't think we have any forum brothers who can beat that number) combined with years of highly elevated PSA tests, to say nothing of the self-catheterization, pains me just to read about the anxiety you have both experienced for more than a decade. As our esteemed moderator pointed out, surgery resolved his many problems with BPH and urination. As a non-medical professional I cannot provide medical advice but if I had suffered as long as your husband has, I'd want to bring this odyssey to an end, sooner rather than later. And if surgery was likely to end this misery, then surgery would be my choice, as long as the bone scan was clean. Wishing you the very best, Jim

Posts.Title: Years Of Elevated PSA

Posts.Content: LC: While it is likely of little consolation, rest assured that your experience is not an isolated case. My barber has had PSA readings of around 10 for the last decade. He has had a total of seven biopsies and all have been negative. As he approaches his 80th birthday, he has decided that he will have no more PSA tests or biopsies. Hopefully, in your case, the upcoming MRI will provide proper guidance enroute to a resolution. Jim

Posts.Title: First Post, Struggling to Stay Positive

Posts.Content: Gunrun: The logic of celebrating a finding of no cancer in October after you were already diagnosed WITH cancer escapes me. And to schedule a third biopsy in January to "...find out where I'm at..." makes even less sense. If you search all 51,000 prostate cancer forum posts on this site, I assure you that there is no other identical experience listed. Not sure what is going on. You say, "Yes, I have cancer" but you're acting as if you are in denial. Please perform due diligence and seek appropriate consultation -- and treatment, if warranted. But, another biopsy in January is likely to cause pain and nothing more. You already have the answer that you seek. Best of luck, Jim
