Posts.Title: First Post, Struggling to Stay Positive

Posts.Content: Hi Steve: I agree with Robert's last comment. Logically, why bother going to a specialist at all if you don't plan on acting on his recommendation? Although his comment of "probably nothing" would deter the need for a biopsy, I can think of one reason why he might want to delay it. The soft "nodule" may not be there on his next DRE. If it's gone and with your low PSA, it's possible that the need for a biopsy could yet be years away. Any family history of prostate cancer? Best of luck. Jim

Posts.Title: Prostate Questions

Posts.Content: I agree with Allen. My experience with the biopsy was discomfort but not pain. Some posters have mentioned having anesthesia -- didn't make sense to me -- kind of like having general anesthesia to have a tooth filled. It would be beneficial if you recognize this biopsy for what it is. It's merely a diagnostic test, nothing more. You've had it before so there should be no surprises. I know it's a cliché but you need to take it one step at a time. If you require treatment for a disease that is almost always 100% curable if caught early, there will be plenty of time to stress about it then, while recognizing that millions of men have gone before you without incident and millions more will follow. And we'll be here to share our experiences which will, hopefully, take away some of the unknown to make your journey go smoothly. Jim

Posts.Title: Questions

Posts.Content: Rob: I'm truly sorry to hear that you are hurting so much. It would be easy to say that you can depend on us, here on this website, as we have been through a small part of what you have suffered. It would be easy for me to tell you that we somehow managed to get through the death of our only grandson at age 19, ten years ago, from substance abuse. It remains the most crushing event of our lifetime. It would be easy to tell you that my wife at age 56, a successful college administrator, suffered two strokes that caused her to lose her job due to cognitive deficits. I might ask her what we're having for dinner tonight and the response could be, "It's going to be partly cloudy next Thursday". I never know what's coming next. But none of that would be of help to you other than watching people try to adjust. Respectfully, support groups may be of help but, frankly, my thoughts turn to a leaking roof. If you have one, you would call a roofer because he is the one most trained to repair the damage. With that in mind, you may want to seek professional therapeutic help to ease your emotional pain. Depression can fester, if left untreated. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Nowhere to turn

Posts.Content: Robert: With the vast amount of medical info available to you, I am somewhat surprised that you would even mention the possibility of a Kevorkian-like solution. With proper treatment, patients with Stage IV prostate cancer can frequently live to a normal life expectancy and even beyond that age. Recognize that the dreaded term "cancer" can be the catalyst for the onset of depression in so many of us on this site. Try to deal with that aspect of this beast and gravitate toward a more positive outlook. Maybe I'm delusional but I like to think of the glass as being half-full, not half empty and end my e-mails with "I'm still here!". Jim

Posts.Title: Hello

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Hawk Just contacted Mayo Clinic in Rochester, MN. They told me my PSA has to be 1.5 or higher so I guess I just wait. Hopefully it will be at least 2 years before I hit that level. Hawk: While I have much confidence in Mayo, I would be inclined to reach out to an equally reputable secondary source for a confirmation that a PSA of 1.5 or higher is needed before you qualify for a C11 Choline PET Scan. Did Mayo indicate what treatment protocol you could expect to receive after the PET scan? Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Access to C11 Acetate PET for recurrent PCa

Posts.Content: Since I had salvage radiotherapy following a DaVinci, you would think that I could shed some light on your query, but, unfortunately, I can't. In fact, during my extensive investigation of SR and in consultation with two highly respected radiation oncologists, the subject of hormone therapy as an addendum to the radiation never came up in conversation. Perhaps the combo is utilized in conjunction with a more aggressive biochemical recurrence than the one I experienced. I'd also be interested in knowledgeable feedback from the generous people who frequent this site.

Posts.Title: People over 70 not take PSA

Posts.Content: LC: While it is likely of little consolation, rest assured that your experience is not an isolated case. My barber has had PSA readings of around 10 for the last decade. He has had a total of seven biopsies and all have been negative. As he approaches his 80th birthday, he has decided that he will have no more PSA tests or biopsies. Hopefully, in your case, the upcoming MRI will provide proper guidance enroute to a resolution. Jim

Posts.Title: Nowhere to turn

Posts.Content: Welcome Ready: As you may have read, we have a very knowledgeable moderator. Invariably, after reading a first post, I formulate a response and as I start to type, I note that Chuck has already hit one or more of the key points in response. One thing missing in your post is whether your husband has a family history of PC that might make him more susceptible to this disease. In your husband's case -- at age 48 -- I would respectfully agree with Chuck that two PSA tests 30 days apart MAY still represent merely a bad case of prostatitis. Hopefully, the biopsy will bring a definitive answer. You seem focused on the 4-week PSA movement from 6.48 to 7.22. Again, that COULD be explained as an infection. I hate to be repetitious but if you have read a lot of posts on this thread, you can take comfort in knowing that if it is indeed the "C" word, then this is actually the "C" you want to have, as it is nearly always 100% curable if found early and treated. A tour around this website will find other "C"s that frequently tend to be life-threatening and that doesn't likely apply to your husband. We look forward to hearing his biopsy results and while we are medical non-professionals (with a few exceptions), we can share our experiences that may be helpful further down the road. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Content: Welcome Oliver: After reading of your experiences with the Russian form of TRUS surgery, a few things come to mind: You received wonderful value for your money. An 8-day hospital stay seems awfully long for such a procedure. Forty-five days of pain sounds excessive. I'm very sorry to hear that. The Gleason 6 evaluation of the incidental portion of the prostate removed reveals little or nothing about whether your prostate harbors any tumors that could remain in the prostate that may be G6 or higher. Your PSA history did not seem to warrant a biopsy but it's unfortunate that it did not because if it did and you chose a prostatectomy, all of your problems (BPH, cancer, urination difficulties, etc.) would have been history by now with perhaps a one-night hospital stay and less than 45 days of pain. I'm not being critical of anything -- just such a damn shame that the sequence of events played out as they did. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: My prostate operation

Posts.Content: Welcome Ready: As you may have read, we have a very knowledgeable moderator. Invariably, after reading a first post, I formulate a response and as I start to type, I note that Chuck has already hit one or more of the key points in response. One thing missing in your post is whether your husband has a family history of PC that might make him more susceptible to this disease. In your husband's case -- at age 48 -- I would respectfully agree with Chuck that two PSA tests 30 days apart MAY still represent merely a bad case of prostatitis. Hopefully, the biopsy will bring a definitive answer. You seem focused on the 4-week PSA movement from 6.48 to 7.22. Again, that COULD be explained as an infection. I hate to be repetitious but if you have read a lot of posts on this thread, you can take comfort in knowing that if it is indeed the "C" word, then this is actually the "C" you want to have, as it is nearly always 100% curable if found early and treated. A tour around this website will find other "C"s that frequently tend to be life-threatening and that doesn't likely apply to your husband. We look forward to hearing his biopsy results and while we are medical non-professionals (with a few exceptions), we can share our experiences that may be helpful further down the road. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Content: Welcome Ponyroller: As far as symptoms, there is normally no pain associated with early stage PC. Obviously, the biopsy results hold the answer to the primary question of PC or no PC. In the meanwhile, I would not be satisfied with a verbal report of a "couple of spots" shown on the bone scan. Maybe I'm just a cynical old doofus (also age 68 when diagnosed) but I would insist on obtaining a printout copy of the bone scan report and read it with my own eyes. If the doctor "isn't worried", then unlike PSA blood tests which could be administered three months after the previous one, full-body bone scans usually aren't. And if you're getting this information third-hand from your Dad, sometimes fathers may "soften" certain facts -- I know I would -- in order to not cause anxiety to loved ones. (This was written prior to reading of your anxiety disorder) That being said, the biopsy results will guide the pathway to be taken next. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: High PSA and spots on bone scan

Posts.Content: Hi Prowler: Such a small change in your PSA three years post-surgery, as mentioned, is likely nothing to worry about. At the same time, it is prudent to keep an eye on it without the need to stare at the ceiling as you try to go to sleep each night. After my surgical pathology showed a positive margin, I was told there was nothing to be concerned about. When my first PSA post-surgery at three months read 0.02, I was told there was nothing to be concerned about. Three years after surgery, I experienced a recurrence and required 40 sessions of salvage radiation. So far, so good. I am probably one of the few forum brothers who advocate for ultrasensitive PSA monitoring because, as I watched the PSA number climb over those three years (please see signature below), it helped me to mentally prepare for what came next (SR). Think about those patients who only receive one-decimal test results and are stunned when, out of nowhere, they are informed of a recurrence. To put your concerns at rest, it would probably be best to draw your PSA every six months or even every three months if it will give you peace of mind. Best of luck, Jim

Could you provide us with more of your history (PSA history, number of cores involved in your G6 diagnosis, degree of involvement of the cores, etc.) so that our forum brothers and sisters can better understand your case? You may wish to consult with your primary doctor to pursue some alternate cause of the symptoms. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Biopsy Prep Question

Posts.Content: "I was not prepared for the profound psychological impact my cancer diagnosis would have on me". Zencat: At age 68, those were also my thoughts exactly. At your age 54, it must have been worse. So, I shared my thoughts with my urologist who was spectacularly unimpressed. He explained that a 3+4=7 Gleason score was nothing more than run-of-the-mill PC that his group sees every day and that the cure rate, when treated early, is nearly 100%. He referred me to a scene in the 1987 movie "Moonstruck" where Cher slaps Nicholas Cage hard in the face and says, "Snap out of it". A tour of other cancer forums on this website will quickly convince you that, if you were going to have cancer, this is the one you want --really!! Again, you are looking at a nearly 100% survival rate where others may fall into the 6-16% rate. The only tears to be shed in the near future will probably be from your wife when she realizes that she may have to pamper you for the week after surgery as you maneuver at home with the cumbersome -- but not painful -- catheter. Relax. You're not going anywhere soon. Others will chime in later with virtually guaranteed similar comments. Deep breath now. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Content: While your reaction to the possibility of PC is only natural, please keep in mind exactly what is taking place tomorrow. The biopsy is nothing more than a diagnostic test. By imagining a worst case scenario, you do yourself a disservice. Try taking it one step at a time and if you have a need to pursue further investigation, the people on this site can share their experiences so there should be no surprises. Good luck. Jim

Posts.Title: Prostate Biopsy

Posts.Content: Welcome: DaVinci would be one of several choices if he was about 10 years younger, which is around the age that I had the surgery. There are always exceptions to every "rule" but in the U.S., many doctors will decline to perform PC surgery (open or robotic) past around age 70. At age 77, unless he is in extremely good physical condition, it would be my guess that it wouldn't be an option in Russia, either, because of the risk/reward ratio of major surgery (and even the robotic version is major surgery). Radiation, possibly combined with hormone therapy, particularly when dealing with an aggressive Gleason 8, would seem to be a logical choice of treatment. It surprises me that there was such a large degree of top-of-the-line medical devices available (ultrasound, MRI, Cat scan, PET scan, etc.) for him while at the same time the medical community didn't want to spend a minimal amount of rubles to pay for a PSA blood test to prevent the need for those later devices. In the United States, the federal government is trying to discourage PSA testing, also, primarily to save money while stating a desire to reduce "anxiety" and alleged unnecessary side effects of some treatment. Best of luck to you and your Dad, Jim

Posts.Title: Sky high PSA of 85 and Gleason 4+4

Posts.Content: Hi Barry: Welcome aboard but, as others will reiterate, sorry you have to be here, especially at age 46. The only stupid question is the one not asked. I'm not a doctor but I have never in my life heard of spreading prostate cancer through sex. To feel certain, that's one to ask your doc. You didn't mention how long ago you had the full body bone scan but you are certainly correct that it will determine if the cancer has spread to other organs and, ultimately, help to decide the path to follow in your treatment. But don't get ahead of yourself. My prostate biopsy was similar to yours -- 3+4=7 -- 2 of 12 cores positive. When I expressed my panicked concern to my urologist, he simply said, "Will you please calm the hell down? Yes, you have cancer but we can fix it because the cancer you have is just everyday run-of-the-mill prostate cancer. It's nothing special. We see it every day". At one point, 300 people reported to me. Being chastised was something new for me. Waiting for test results drive me crazy, too. I now deal only with a hospital group that posts all test results online within 36 hours for that reason. Since you likely have more diagnostic tests in your future, you may want to inquire whether that option is available to you. Posts.Content: Hi Barry: Welcome aboard but, as others will reiterate, sorry you have to be here, especially at age 46. The only stupid question is the one not asked. I'm not a doctor but I have never in my life heard of spreading prostate cancer through sex. To feel certain, that's one to ask your doc. You didn't mention how long ago you had the full body bone scan but you are certainly correct that it will determine if the cancer has spread to other organs and, ultimately, help to decide the path to follow in your treatment. But don't get ahead of yourself. My prostate biopsy was similar to yours -- 3+4=7 -- 2 of 12 cores positive. When I expressed my panicked concern to my urologist, he simply said, "Will you please calm the hell down? Yes, you have cancer but we can fix it because the cancer you have is just everyday run-of-the-mill prostate cancer. It's nothing special. We see it every day". At one point, 300 people reported to me. Being chastised was something new for me. Waiting for test results drive me crazy, too. I now deal only with a hospital group that posts all test results online within 36 hours for that reason. Since you likely have more diagnostic tests in your future, you may want to inquire whether that option is available to you. I, too, have found this site to be beneficial as I am about to travel on my next journey. Others will chime in shortly. Best of luck to you -- please keep us updated Jim

Posts.Title: Just Diagnosed.........

Posts.Content: Welcome Neighbor Emar: As mentioned, the bone scan is absolutely standard procedure after PC diagnosis and the test itself is nothing to worry about. In the unlikely event that the bone scan finds remote mets, that would be a different story that needs to be addressed separately. With a Gleason 6 biopsy, in just 2 cores, often a doctor's recommendation would lead to active surveillance. However, your husband's 8 biopsies (I don't think we have any forum brothers who can beat that number) combined with years of highly elevated PSA tests, to say nothing of the self-catheterization, pains me just to read about the anxiety you have both experienced for more than a decade. As our esteemed moderator pointed out, surgery resolved his many problems with BPH and urination. As a non-medical professional I cannot provide medical advice but if I had suffered as long as your husband has, I'd want to bring this odyssey to an end, sooner rather than later. And if surgery was likely to end this misery, then surgery would be my choice, as long as the bone scan was clean. Wishing you the very best, Jim

Posts.Title: SpaceOAR Hydrogel

Posts.Content: Robert: With the vast amount of medical info available to you, I am somewhat surprised that you would even mention the possibility of a Kevorkian-like solution. With proper treatment, patients with Stage IV prostate cancer can frequently live to a normal life expectancy and even beyond that age. Recognize that the dreaded term "cancer" can be the catalyst for the onset of depression in so many of us on this site. Try to deal with that aspect of this beast and gravitate toward a more positive outlook. Maybe I'm delusional but I like to think of the glass as being half-full, not half empty and end my e-mails with "I'm still here!". Jim

Posts.Content: You have obviously given the subject much thought and consideration. And, as Chuck has said, we must respect your decision and I certainly do. But you mentioned your age (47) as a reason to take the HIFU route now and, if necessary, surgery later. Assuming, if you will, that other posters have done research similar to yours and are reasonably intelligent, there is one aspect of your conclusion that stop me in my tracks. In a random review of the 42,828 posts currently shown on this prostate cancer thread, I can find no one your age who came to the same decision that you did. Is that or should that be a concern?

Posts.Content: Just wanted to be sure you saw this post from last month on the SpaceOAR issue. 01-13-2016, 04:50 PM #3 Ron_G Ron_G is offline Senior User -------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Join Date:Mar 2015Location:Scenic Severn River MarylandPosts:296 Experience with Spaceoar Gel Diagnosis: Gleason 4+3, several tissue samples with cancer cells. Therapy: Radiation About 3 weeks ago the gel was injected between prostate and colon as a shield to protect colon from radiation. Radiation is underway now. This gel is a new development ho help reduce radiation side efects. Problem: Spaceoar Gel apparently to low positioned and eventually some gel in the injection cannula holes. Situation: Permanent pain in the perineum area between scrotum and anus. Very uncomfortable. This gel gets hard right after the injection. Now it is pressing hard and rubbing permanently from the inside. No seating for lunch or dinner, no car driving. Pain is always there. Gel gets dissolved and disappears apparently after 2-3 months. I can't imagine waiting so long with that pain. Any experience with such a situation or any advice? Thank you Chuck, found his only other post from a couple years ago. Makes me wonder if it's the gel that was supposed to dissolve/disappear. I've never heard of this gel, not being a radiation guy (at least not yet!).

Posts.Title: SpaceOAR Hydrogel

Posts.Content: Since the OP had treatment with SpaceOAR (Space Organs At Risk) gel two years ago, he is likely outside of the U.S. because the procedure was only recently approved by the FDA in April, 2015. According to the literature, it is primarily used to protect the rectal wall from radiation directed at the prostate and prostate bed. The injected liquid (supposedly) turns into a gel for about a 3-month period, then is intended to dissipate and dissolve within the body and exit via urine after 3 to 6 months.

According to Google, the average life expectancy of a Caucasian male in the U.S. is 74.4 years. That means I'm only good until December. She looked at me as if I was crazy. You know, I seem to get that a lot lately. Don't understand why. Jim

In your husband's case -- at age 48 -- I would respectfully agree with Chuck that two PSA tests 30 days apart MAY still represent merely a bad case of prostatitis. A tour around this website will find other "C"s that frequently tend to be life-threatening and that doesn't likely apply to your husband. We look forward to hearing his biopsy results and while we are medical non-professionals (with a few exceptions), we can share our experiences that may be helpful further down the road. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: I can now sleep

Posts.Content: Hi Barry: Welcome aboard but, as others will reiterate, sorry you have to be here, especially at age 46. The only stupid question is the one not asked. I'm not a doctor but I have never in my life heard of spreading prostate cancer through sex. To feel certain, that's one to ask your doc. You didn't mention how long ago you had the full body bone scan but you are certainly correct that it will determine if the cancer has spread to other organs and, ultimately, help to decide the path to follow in your treatment. But don't get ahead of yourself. My prostate biopsy was similar to yours -- 3+4=7 -- 2 of 12 cores positive. When I expressed my panicked concern to my urologist, he simply said, "Will you please calm the hell down? Yes, you have cancer but we can fix it because the cancer you have is just everyday run-of-the-mill prostate cancer. It's nothing special. We see it every day". At one point, 300 people reported to me. Being chastised was something new for me. Waiting for test results drive me crazy, too. I now deal only with a hospital group that posts all test results online within 36 hours for that reason. Since you likely have more diagnostic tests in your future, you may want to inquire whether that option is available to you. I, too, have found this site to be beneficial as I am about to travel on my next journey. Others will chime in shortly. Best of luck to you -- please keep us updated Jim

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Otago I don't exactly understand why being 67 and having Type 2 diabetes would make anyone "be pro-active and not consider active surveillance" ? . Because at age 67, the clock is ticking, Otago. When I had the DaVinci at age 68, I was rapidly approaching a cut-off at around age 70 when many doctors remove the option of surgery in favor of radiation. And, with Obamacare continually reducing payments on virtually all aspects of Medicare, it would not surprise me if that cut-off age dropped even further, removing a patient's options unless they want to pay for the surgery themselves. So, if a patient at age 67 or 68 is leaning toward active surveillance, the "watchful waiting" may actually eliminate the choice of surgery as calendar months pass by. And, as Chuck mentioned, the actual Gleason score could easily be higher. Sitting around, hoping things will get better (which won't happen) would not be my first choice. Best of luck to you, Engel. Jim

Posts.Title: Catheter after DaVinci

Posts.Content: Welcome: DaVinci would be one of several choices if he was about 10 years younger, which is around the age that I had the surgery. There are always exceptions to every "rule" but in the U.S., many doctors will decline to perform PC surgery (open or robotic) past around age 70. At age 77, unless he is in extremely good physical condition, it would be my guess that it wouldn't be an option in Russia, either, because of the risk/reward ratio of major surgery (and even the robotic version is major surgery). Radiation, possibly combined with hormone therapy, particularly when dealing with an aggressive Gleason 8, would seem to be a logical choice of treatment. It surprises me that there was such a large degree of top-of-the-line medical devices available (ultrasound, MRI, Cat scan, PET scan, etc.) for him while at the same time the medical community didn't want to spend a minimal amount of rubles to pay for a PSA blood test to prevent the need for those later devices. In the United States, the federal government is trying to discourage PSA testing, also, primarily to save money while stating a desire to reduce "anxiety" and alleged unnecessary side effects of some treatment. Best of luck to you and your Dad, Jim

This info may be helpful to others. While you pursued a regimented diet, that same diet did nothing -- in your case -- to prevent the formation and spread of an aggressive form of prostate cancer. I think that diet, in general, has little to do with most serious physical maladies.

Posts.Title: Catheter after DaVinci

Posts.Content: Southsider: Maybe it's just me. Maybe I'm not reading this post properly. I keep reading similar posts and my eyes start rolling around in the back of my head. PSA tests are designed to "indicate" whether prostate cancer may or may not be present. A biopsy is the ONLY definitive way to determine if a patient ACTUALLY has prostate cancer. After your biopsy, you wrote; Considering the fact my PSA is stable, ...I'm going to wait 6 months...." My response: Since the PSA reading is designed to help "identify" whether prostate cancer is present, it is of little value to be comforted in knowing your PSA is "stable" because that issue is no longer relevant. The ONLY thing that is relevant are the three positive cores which confirm the following: YOU HAVE PROSTATE CANCER!!! IN MOST MEDICAL PROTOCOL PROFILES OF PROSTATE CANCER, THREE POSITIVE CORES -- EVEN THE LESS AGGRESSIVE GLEASON 6 -- NORMALLY CALL FOR TREATMENT. You're certainly free to wait six months for another PSA test that will be as meaningless as your last one and it may bring you additional comfort if it is lower but it will only give your PC an additional six months to potentially spread. Comments, please. If I'm wrong, please let me know. Good luck, Sir Jim

Therapy: Radiation About 3 weeks ago the gel was injected between prostate and colon as a shield to protect colon from radiation. Radiation is underway now. This gel is a new development ho help reduce radiation side efects. Problem: Spaceoar Gel apparently to low positioned and eventually some gel in the injection cannula holes. Situation: Permanent pain in the perineum area between scrotum and anus. Very uncomfortable. This gel gets hard right after the injection. I can't imagine waiting so long with that pain. Any experience with such a situation or any advice? Thank you Chuck, found his only other post from a couple years ago. Makes me wonder if it's the gel that was supposed to dissolve/disappear. I've never heard of this gel, not being a radiation guy (at least not yet!).

Posts.Content: Welcome Ready: As you may have read, we have a very knowledgeable moderator. Invariably, after reading a first post, I formulate a response and as I start to type, I note that Chuck has already hit one or more of the key points in response. One thing missing in your post is whether your husband has a family history of PC that might make him more susceptible to this disease. In your husband's case -- at age 48 -- I would respectfully agree with Chuck that two PSA tests 30 days apart MAY still represent merely a bad case of prostatitis. Hopefully, the biopsy will bring a definitive answer. You seem focused on the 4-week PSA movement from 6.48 to 7.22. Again, that COULD be explained as an infection. I hate to be repetitious but if you have read a lot of posts on this thread, you can take comfort in knowing that if it is indeed the "C" word, then this is actually the "C" you want to have, as it is nearly always 100% curable if found early and treated. A tour around this website will find other "C"s that frequently tend to be life-threatening and that doesn't likely apply to your husband. We look forward to hearing his biopsy results and while we are medical non-professionals (with a few exceptions), we can share our experiences that may be helpful further down the road. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: First Ever PSA Test Very Elevated Second Even Higher

Posts.Content: Welcome Dev: As you add to your knowledge of the subject, you will repeatedly hear that surgery or radiation are about equal in providing a "cure". What you will likely hear less often is that surgery provides a second grab at the brass ring of success which radiation rarely does. If your Dad elects surgery (which may not be available based on his age -- some doctors prefer not to perform surgery after age 70), and the cancer returns at a later date, he will have a "second chance" at a resolution via salvage radiation. That's what happened to me and several other PC forum brothers. My cancer returned three years after my DaVinci prostatectomy. Salvage radiation knocked down the cancer and now, three more years later, my PSA remains at zero. So, I tend to be biased in favor of surgery as a primary treatment, as do a large percentage of contributors to this website. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: cystoscopy found PCa in bladder neck. Anyone else?

Posts.Content: Theszak: Please don't be offended by my position but sometimes we overthink an issue to the point of complicating something that is really not that complicated. I had a prostate biopsy in Aug., 2010. Was it uncomfortable? Yes, absolutely. Was it actually painful? No. Cancer was detected. Gleason score: 3+4=7 This was followed shortly thereafter by a prostatectomy via DaVinci robotic surgery. I had a textbook recovery period. For decades the prostate biopsy has been the gold standard in cancer detection of the prostate. While there are always "new" methods of addressing almost anything, so far, none have proven more effective or reliable. If you are focused exclusively on something that is non-invasive, my advice is to consult a fortune teller. I know that may seem insensitive, but the opposite is true. I wish only the best for you. But don't take my word for it. Please continue to seek out the opinion of others, many of whom like me, have actually walked the walk. Jim
Posts.Title: Any hints tips pointers how you kind folks out there sort out medical literature?...

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Joe1 It seems to me that numbers do not lie, for most men the cost of false positive PSA testing and the resulting cost of over treatment of indolent cancers that would have never been an issue, is a waste of limited health care dollars, and yes there is only a limited number of dollars to go around, irregardless how highly one may value their own life. Everyone here who has benefited from early detection by a routine PSA obviously would want everyone else to have the same benefit, but what is lost in this argument is that those of you in this group are a minority of PCa patients as hard as that may be to accept based on your personal experience. The bottom line is this, every dollar spent on the over diagnosis and over treatment of indolent prostrate cancers that never would have threated one's health is a dollar taken away from everyone else with medical conditions that could have actually benefited from those medical dollars. So, Joe, we have a limited number of dollars to "go around" to save/prolong the lives of American citizens? No one mentioned that to me when I spent the last 50 years contributing to the Medicare program out of my earnings to insure that I had adequate medical coverage in my retirement years. I must have missed the part where we're all on monetary rations and must make sacrifices (including our lives, according to you) in order for financial aid to benefit the rest of the world. With hundreds of billion dollars sent to foreign countries via aid packages, they will prosper and thrive through the taxes collected from my years of labor. And we can't AFFORD PSA tests to continue to save lives here? I do not share your views.

Posts.Title: Is it possible?

Posts.Content: Hi Rob: The information you have received so far is accurate and timely. But look closely at my history below and you will find that my PSA post-surgery jumped from 0.02 to 0.04 and I was told that it was meaningless (sound familiar?). It was the advance notice (for me, not necessarily for you) that, three years after surgery, my prostate cancer had returned. And, although the accepted medical protocol confirmation of a biochemical recurrence happens after a patient receives at least 2 PSA readings of 0.2 or above, I opted for salvage radiation when my PSA reached 0.11, since an upward trend was obvious (Jim's protocol). I had zero side effects from the 40 sessions of salvage radiation and, at least for now, the monster is being held at bay, based on my recent pristine PSA results. Of course, no one knows what the future holds. My suggestion is to keep a close eye on your PSA numbers and consider taking action if and when you exceed 0.1, not 0.2. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Proton Radiation vs Photon Radiation?

Posts.Content: Hi Steve: Welcome. Sorry you find yourself here but there are many forum brothers who have experienced similar histories and who will share their views with you shortly. Personally, my "insight", for what it's worth, with respect to predicting cancer outside the prostate via tables, is to use the paper they are written on to wrap dead fish. The only thing that matters is your personal case. No one here will sugar-coat that Gleason 8 is less than desirable. Your age will determine how much importance you assign to the nerve bundles and only you can decide whether you can make the necessary adjustments to do without them. First and foremost, though, is the need to survive the cancer. As our esteemed moderator, Chuck, has often said "A hard-on is of little value to a dead guy". Even if you decide on surgery and require salvage radiation later, I'm a living example that it is doable, having suffered no side effects to speak of (except for the PC recurrence 3 years post-surgery). I'm still here. Read as much as you can, then make your decision. We'll be here for you. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Accuracy of Parton Tables and the like

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Otago I don't exactly understand why being 67 and having Type 2 diabetes would make anyone "be pro-active and not consider active surveillance" ? . Because at age 67, the clock is ticking, Otago. When I had the DaVinci at age 68, I was rapidly approaching a cut-off at around age 70 when many doctors remove the option of surgery in favor of radiation. And, with Obamacare continually reducing payments on virtually all aspects of Medicare, it would not surprise me if that cut-off age dropped even further, removing a patient's options unless they want to pay for the surgery themselves. So, if a patient at age 67 or 68 is leaning toward active surveillance, the "watchful waiting" may actually eliminate the choice of surgery as calendar months pass by. And, as Chuck mentioned, the actual Gleason score could easily be higher. Sitting around, hoping things will get better (which won't happen) would not be my first choice. Best of luck to you, Engel. Jim

Posts.Title: Might as well jump right in

Posts.Content: Bone and CT scans both negative. Gleason downgrade from 4+3 to 3+4 Right and left seminal vesicles not involved by adenocarcinoma Lymph nodes 3 right and 2 left negative All good stuff, Max. PSA not so good BUT hardly insurmountable. When my PC returned three years post-surgery, I was upset however I was prepared because I could watch the slow trend upward. Your recurrence came quickly, but we can still draw a correlation with my uro's observation. He said to view the situation where a dishwasher didn't get all of the dishes clean in the first complete wash. A couple of dishes still had to be "cleaned up" with salvage radiation. So far, so good (please see below). As noted, with the quicker return, you may have to deal with ADT but it's doable. Surely, I can attest to moving on as I flew to Las Vegas just six months ago at age 73 and played in the World Series of Poker with my grandson. And if my legally-wedded nightmare happens to croak first (just kidding, sweetheart), I think Kim Basinger is still single. Many, many miles left. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: A little confused about nerve sparing. What is the criteria?

Posts.Content: Welcome Howard: You raise the never-ending query about which PSA test is better -- the standard biopsy where a post-surgery result of <0.1 is considered "undetectable" as recommended by the Mayo Clinic -- or the readings of an ultra-sensitive machine that takes the number to the second decimal, thereby divulging any underlying "trend". Based on my history below of watching and acting on an increasing trend, my vote would be to always have too much information rather than too little so you can gradually be prepared to act, if need be. The idea that there is still PSA left over from benign tissue 15 months after surgery sounds like a stretch. At the same time, your latest number is lower than your PSA reading just after surgery so I would not hit the panic button just yet. Plus, my salvage radiation bill was $240,000, so it is unlikely that insurers or Medicare would pick up such an expense without a clear demonstration that you have experienced a biochemical recurrence; a post-surgery PSA reading of .07 most likely does not satisfy that criteria. My recommendation would be to accept the opinion of the doctor who said to watch for a trend. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Ultra Sensitive Exam

Posts.Content: Welcome Dev: As you add to your knowledge of the subject, you will repeatedly hear that surgery or radiation are about equal in providing a "cure". What you will likely hear less often is that surgery provides a second grab at the brass ring of success which radiation rarely does. If your Dad elects surgery (which may not be available based on his age -- some doctors prefer not to perform surgery after age 70), and the cancer returns at a later date, he will have a "second chance" at a resolution via salvage radiation. That's what happened to me and several other PC forum brothers. My cancer returned three years after my DaVinci prostatectomy. Salvage radiation knocked down the cancer and now, three more years later, my PSA remains at zero. So, I tend to be biased in favor of surgery as a primary treatment, as do a large percentage of contributors to this website. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Concerned - PC diagnosed :(

Posts.Content: jdsky: There is no link -- possibly deleted by webmaster? I agree with your position. PSA tests saved my life, not once, but twice, following a recurrence. The President's Death Panel has gone on record as saying that only one life is saved for every one thousand PSA tests administered. My position is that 1,000 lives can then be saved with each one million PSA tests. And that's a good thing, even considering any side effects that may result from treatment. If the intent is to keep the population uninformed via a diagnostic test that has led to a 44% decline in PC deaths since 1992, then let's do away altogether with diagnostic testing. X-ray machines ? Trash them. CT scans? Same thing. MRIs? A horribly expensive test that could save millions of dollars for insurance companies and the federal government (Medicare, Medicaid, etc.) if we just destroy all of those machines. Then, like ostriches, we can all sink our heads in the sand permanently. Jim

Posts.Content: [QUOTE=Howard53545;303990]Thanks Jim for clarification. You guys have been great and more helpful than my urologist who I intend to replace once I can change during open enrollment in September. Is there any chance of these cancer cells migrating?[/QUOTE] Hi Howard: As a medical non-professional, my short answer is affirmative. The increase in my post-surgery PSA numbers over a 3-year period seems to indicate that was the case for me. As far as salvage radiation treatment, it's a balancing act to watch whether your PSA number may never exceed 0.1 and therefore follow-up treatment is not needed versus watching for an upward trend that makes it clear the critters are on the loose and there is no doubt that SR is warranted. That's probably an uninformed oversimplification of the issue but that's what I've got. Certainly, I invite our forum brothers to offer their thoughts. Jim

Posts.Title: Ultra Sensitive Exam

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by fishinguy Thanks all. I hadn't originally planned for a second opinion. I've decided this weekend to do just that. My urologist, who has performed over 3000 open surgeries had talked about it right away, and reminded me that this s about me and not him. I like him, and trust him. But I think I may go to Mayo and have a talk with someone there. Funny, almost makes me feel like I'm cheating on a girlfriend going somewhere else. Anyone else ever had that feeling going for a second opinion? --Dan Dan: Yes, we get it. But when your life may depend on obtaining the best information on how to move forward, then cheating is not only condoned but encouraged. Jim

Posts.Title: Some good news

Posts.Content: Hi Traveler: I'm not good with mechanical stuff. I can't cook and plastic flowers die in my care. But I am good with numbers. And the numbers -- about $100 a month -- tell me that no one can afford to be without Medicare Part B. It pays 80% of your doctors fees and most diagnostic tests. Heck, one MRI is probably equivalent to 3 to 4 years of Part B premiums. You MUST have it. On the other hand, if you are destitute and really can't afford it, then you are almost certainly eligible for Medicaid which will cover most of your health care bills at little or no cost. And you should not wait for symptoms with a PSA of 65 which is actually a large red flashing neon sign that is saying you need to take action NOW. You don't have a weight problem -- you have a medical problem. I don't mean to be sarcastic but, really, all of the best diets and green veggies in the world won't change your PSA from 65 to 3. I wish you the best of luck in pursuing a resolution. Jim

Posts.Title: 76 wth ED and PSA of 65

Posts.Content: "One thing I forgot to mention is the biopsy report shows that he has chronic protastisis. Would that be a cause for the higher PSA number?" Hi Dev: Yes, a diagnosis of chronic prostatitis could cause a high PSA number. However, that's a moot point now that the biopsy has confirmed a diagnosis of prostate cancer with a score of Gleason 7. The issue of chronic prostatitis is yet another good argument for surgery versus other treatment methods. Once the prostate is gone, the cancer may return (as in my example) but the chronic prostatitis will be gone forever. I hope I don't sound like a used car salesman. All options should be explored. And, of course, best of luck to him, Jim

Posts.Title: Concerned - PC diagnosed :(

Posts.Content: Welcome MissViv: Could you please provide us with some info, such as your husband's age, medical history and PSA results, within a signature, that led to his Gleason 8 diagnosis? In answer to your question about why both a CT scan and a full-body bone scan are usually recommended, other than being routine investigative tools, they also serve as means to avoid pointless procedures. As I'm sure you are already aware, Gleason 8 represents an aggressive form of prostate cancer. I apologize if this is too direct but the bone scan is looking for whether the cancer has spread (metastasis). If so, it "could" rule out some treatments, such as surgery. As long as the cancer is believed to be confined within the prostate, a "cure" remains possible. However, even under a worst case scenario of metastasis, treatments are available to extend life for years and, sometimes, decades. Of course, it's not possible for us to understand or evaluate how his prior colon cancer may or may not impact upon his current diagnosis. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Spasms after catheter removal

Posts.Content: [QUOTE=Howard53545;303990]Thanks Jim for clarification. You guys have been great and more helpful than my urologist who I intend to replace once I can change during open enrollment in September. Is there any chance of these cancer cells migrating?[/QUOTE] Hi Howard: As a medical non-professional, my short answer is affirmative. The increase in my post-surgery PSA numbers over a 3-year period seems to indicate that was the case for me. As far as salvage radiation treatment, it's a balancing act to watch whether your PSA number may never exceed 0.1 and therefore follow-up treatment is not needed versus watching for an upward trend that makes it clear the critters are on the loose and there is no doubt that SR is warranted. That's probably an uninformed oversimplification of the issue but that's what I've got. Certainly, I invite our forum brothers to offer their thoughts. Jim

Posts.Title: Ultra Sensitive Exam

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate He had a negative biopsy AFTER having positive ones. Same as me. I have read that Johns Hopkins considers a negative biopsy after a positive one to be a strong indicator of indolent cancer. Let's not be so quick to condemn the doctor. BTW, I have also had PSA over 10, and it was just a spike that went back down over time. AS: In 2014, the patient had a biopsy with 4 positive cores. FOUR POSITIVE CORES. Indolent or not, four positive cores are unlikely to be four separate false positives. He has prostate cancer, well beyond the 2 cores that might be considered for AS. Your example of a PSA over 10 is nothing more than an indicator. FOUR POSITIVE CORES confirm his cancer. He could have more negative biopsies but, as Ron stated, that means the cancer was simply missed on the follow-up biopsies. Four positive cores aren't going away. He needs treatment and if he was in the U.S., he would have gotten it already. Unless, under Obamacare, we might next need 8 positive cores before the Federal Government Death Panel will allow us to be treated.

Posts.Title: Is it possible?

Posts.Content: Bone and CT scans both negative. Gleason downgrade from 4+3 to 3+4 Right and left seminal vesicles not involved by adenocarcinoma Lymph nodes 3 right and 2 left negative All good stuff, Max. PSA not so good BUT hardly insurmountable. When my PC returned three years post-surgery, I was upset however I was prepared because I could watch the slow trend upward. Your recurrence came quickly, but we can still draw a correlation with my uro's observation. He said to view the situation where a dishwasher didn't get all of the dishes clean in the first complete wash. A couple of dishes still had to be "cleaned up" with salvage radiation. So far, so good (please see below). As noted, with the quicker return, you may have to deal with ADT but it's doable. Surely, I can attest to moving on as I flew to Las Vegas just six months ago at age 73 and played in the World Series of Poker with my grandson. And if my legally-wedded nightmare happens to croak first (just kidding, sweetheart), I think Kim Basinger is still single. Many, many miles left. Best of luck, Jim

AgeInfo.Phrase: six months ago at age 73 and played in the World

Posts.Title: I wasn't ready for this...

Posts.Content: jdsky: There is no link -- possibly deleted by webmaster? I agree with your position. PSA tests saved my life, not once, but twice, following a recurrence. The President's Death Panel has gone on record as saying that only one life is saved for every one thousand PSA tests administered. My position is that 1,000 lives can then be saved with each one million PSA tests. And that's a good thing, even considering any side effects that may result from treatment. If the intent is to keep the population uninformed via a diagnostic test that has led to a 44% decline in PC deaths since 1992, then let's do away altogether with diagnostic testing. X-ray machines ? Trash them. CT scans? Same thing. MRIs? A horribly expensive test that could save millions of dollars for insurance companies and the federal government (Medicare, Medicaid, etc.) if we just destroy all of those machines. Then, like ostriches, we can all sink our heads in the sand permanently. Jim

But when your life may depend on obtaining the best information on how to move forward, then cheating is not only condoned but encouraged. Jim

Posts.Title: First post, Just got the news......

Posts.Content: Hi Mike: I, too, had the DaVinci procedure at age 68 in 2010. Last year, my PSA started climbing (not as high as yours) and I had 40 sessions of radiation ($240,000 billed to Medicare - I paid zero after Medigap paid their portion) that knocked the PSA down to 0.00. In answer to your question about doctor-administered drugs or shots, I reviewed my Medicare statements and it looks like 80% was paid by Medicare on multiple occasions (but no Lupron). And I suppose you have already done your research to select a Medicare Part "D" policy which will pay for regular prescriptions after a monthly fee and product co-pay. If we had to pay retail for my wife's anti-seizure anti-stroke drugs last year, the out-of-pocket costs would have exceeded $24,000. I'm not sure if I'm permitted to mention a specific Medigap policy to cover the remaining 20% on this website but my wife and I have had excellent results with AARP Medicare Supplemental (Medigap) coverage provided by United Healthcare. The cost in PA is about $200 per person per month. In nearly 7 years of coverage, through multiple surgeries, I have never had a deductible or co-pay of any kind and never filled out a single form after registration. Conversely, my research of Medicare Advantage plans produced a long list of high deductibles and co-pays which caused me to firmly decide against Advantage plans. Hope this helps a little. Jim

Posts.Title: Help With Medicare Medigap Cancer Drug Coverage

Posts.Content: Hi Rob: The information you have received so far is accurate and timely. But look closely at my history below and you will find that my PSA post-surgery jumped from 0.02 to 0.04 and I was told that it was meaningless (sound familiar?). It was the advance notice (for me, not necessarily for you) that, three years after surgery, my prostate cancer had returned. And, although the accepted medical protocol confirmation of a biochemical recurrence happens after a patient receives at least 2 PSA readings of 0.2 or above, I opted for salvage radiation when my PSA reached 0.11, since an upward trend was obvious (Jim's protocol). I had zero side effects from the 40 sessions of salvage radiation and, at least for now, the monster is being held at bay, based on my recent pristine PSA results. Of course, no one knows what the future holds. My suggestion is to keep a close eye on your PSA numbers and consider taking action if and when you exceed 0.1, not 0.2. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Content: Howard: I've never heard of a post-surgery PSA reading of .03 as being considered a recurrence. Chuck's explanation is the industry standard. Are you certain that you have the decimal point in the right location? Medicare did pay for almost all of my salvage radiation while the remainder was paid by my Medicare supplemental insurance. But I could be wrong. You'll want to investigate with Medicare before you give the green light for salvage radiation. Good luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Whaaaa hoooo!

Posts.Content: Welcome MissViv: Could you please provide us with some info, such as your husband's age, medical history and PSA results, within a signature, that led to his Gleason 8 diagnosis? In answer to your question about why both a CT scan and a full-body bone scan are usually recommended, other than being routine investigative tools, they also serve as means to avoid pointless procedures. As I'm sure you are already aware, Gleason 8 represents an aggressive form of prostate cancer. I apologize if this is too direct but the bone scan is looking for whether the cancer has spread (metastasis). If so, it "could" rule out some treatments, such as surgery. As long as the cancer is believed to be confined within the prostate, a "cure" remains possible. However, even under a worst case scenario of metastasis, treatments are available to extend life for years and, sometimes, decades. Of course, it's not possible for us to understand or evaluate how his prior colon cancer may or may not impact upon his current diagnosis. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Content: Thank you for the feedback, MissViv. As MichiganMan16 noted, the only thing that remains somewhat confusing is the MRI. In most attempts at diagnosing the prostate, an MRI is usually ordered prior to the biopsy, not after it, in order to help identify specific areas of interest to draw specimens from. However, the doctor obviously has a reason so far be it from me to argue. Please keep us updated and while we are not medical professionals, we frequently are able to share our experiences that can be helpful to those who face this particular challenge. All the best, Jim

Posts.Title: Ultra Sensitive Exam

Posts.Content: Welcome Howard: You raise the never-ending query about which PSA test is better -- the standard biopsy where a post-surgery result of <0.1 is considered "undetectable" as recommended by the Mayo Clinic -- or the readings of an ultra-sensitive machine that takes the number to the second decimal, thereby divulging any underlying "trend". Based on my history below of watching and acting on an increasing trend, my vote would be to always have too much information rather than too little so you can gradually be prepared to act, if need be. The idea that there is still PSA left over from benign tissue 15 months after surgery sounds like a stretch. At the same time, your latest number is lower than your PSA reading just after surgery so I would not hit the panic button just yet. Plus, my salvage radiation bill was $240,000, so it is unlikely that insurers or Medicare would pick up such an expense without a clear demonstration that you have experienced a biochemical recurrence; a post-surgery PSA reading of .07 most likely does not satisfy that criteria. My recommendation would be to accept the opinion of the doctor who said to watch for a trend. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Content: Hi Samie: As someone who has benefited from salvage radiation, I concur with Michigan Man on virtually every aspect of your husband's case. The zero PSA at 12 weeks is VERY encouraging and yet....something seems out of whack. Although I have about 15 or 20 questions bouncing around in the back of my head, there is one that jumps out at me: If the doctor believes adjuvant or salvage radiation is "...not effective for this type of cancer...", then I would want to know exactly what he means by that statement. And if what he says is accurate, wouldn't that remain true at 3 months, 6 months or 12 months post-surgery and make future PSA tests pointless, with respect to considering AR or SR? John (MM) touched on it briefly -- and it's obviously a sensitive area -- but it almost sounds like the surgeon suspects metastasis has already occurred and radiation of the prostate bed would be a moot point. As the loving spouse, you are certainly entitled to know the answer to that and the only way to find out is to ask the doctor directly. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: To Radiate or not?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by fishinguy Thanks all. I hadn't originally planned for a second opinion. I've decided this weekend to do just that. My urologist, who has performed over 3000 open surgeries had talked about it right away, and reminded me that this s about me and not him. I like him, and trust him. But I think I may go to Mayo and have a talk with someone there. Funny, almost makes me feel like I'm cheating on a girlfriend going somewhere else. Anyone else ever had that feeling going for a second opinion? --Dan Dan: Yes, we get it. But when your life may depend on obtaining the best information on how to move forward, then cheating is not only condoned but encouraged. Jim

Posts.Title: Post op...how much activity is too much?

Posts.Content: As noted on a couple of other threads, you and I have traveled a similar prostate cancer path. Having 6 colon polyps removed is time for celebration, in my view, not stress at all. You have literally hit two home runs by finding and eradicating, not one, but two silent killers - prostate cancer AND colon cancer -- by having timely tests that many others delay until it's too late. I suspect that your next colonoscopy will be scheduled for less than 10 years, which will contribute to staying on top of a potential problem. In answer to your question, however, I can relate to at least one upcoming test that I am not looking forward to on June 13th. It is a simple Cat Scan with contrast of the chest which will determine whether a nodule remains in my right lung middle lobe and will have to be excised via the removal of part or all of that particular lobe. That decision - to remove the entire lobe - will be made while I'm still unconscious on the operating table if the lab says the nodule is cancerous. The national mortality rate for that operation is 3%. The recovery period at home is a full two months. I am worried that once I have part of a lung cut out, it could lead to a downward health spiral which I've seen before in others. With prostate cancer in 2010, I leaped onto the operating table. With horrible jump-off-a-bridge type pain in my right leg, I leaped onto the operating table to undergo spine surgery in 2011 (Success). With the likelihood of lung cancer this time around, I just have a bad feeling about this one. I'll climb onto the table but I won't be leaping.
Posts.Title: After PC do you find other tests more stressful?

Posts.Content: Welcome MissViv: Could you please provide us with some info, such as your husband's age, medical history and PSA results, within a signature, that led to his Gleason 8 diagnosis? In answer to your question about why both a CT scan and a full-body bone scan are usually recommended, other than being routine investigative tools, they also serve as means to avoid pointless procedures. As I'm sure you are already aware, Gleason 8 represents an aggressive form of prostate cancer. I apologize if this is too direct but the bone scan is looking for whether the cancer has spread (metastasis). If so, it "could" rule out some treatments, such as surgery. As long as the cancer is believed to be confined within the prostate, a "cure" remains possible. However, even under a worst case scenario of metastasis, treatments are available to extend life for years and, sometimes, decades. Of course, it's not possible for us to understand or evaluate how his prior colon cancer may or may not impact upon his current diagnosis. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: CT and MRI

Posts.Content: Hi Pierre: With your family history, it is only normal to be concerned about whether you might yet become another prostate cancer patient. And you will find a number of posters on this site who religiously rail against prostate biopsies until the PSA level reaches a point where there is no question that it needs to be done. Normally, I'm in the other camp encouraging biopsies. But with a PSA of only 1.7 and no mention of DRE abnormalities, I would not recommend (again, as a non-professional) a biopsy until you experience significant changes in your PSA or DRE. As Chuck mentioned, you should probably have no trouble in getting a GP to order a PSA based on your age (over 50) and your family history. If you continue to be concerned, you could ask for a PSA scrip every six months. Whether insurance pays for every test is really not relevant because a PSA test is not cost-prohibitive if you have to pay for it out-of-pocket. And it may help to give you peace of mind. Good luck, Jim

AgeInfo.Phrase: based on your age  over 50  and your family history <Z>

Posts.Content: I just never understood all of that physical fitness stuff. A person spends hours exercising and running to get into top shape. Then, one day, they step off a curb and get run over by a truck. Seems like such wasted effort. My oversize recliner envelopes me like a giant pillow. And a good cigar after meals followed by cold beer sets my agenda perfectly. We're all here for just the blink of an eye. Gotta enjoy it.

Posts.Title: Whaaaa hoooo!

Posts.Content: Newporter: Your knowledge of chemo is much more extensive than mine but, please forgive my interjection, I didn't see a mention of any potentially nasty side effects. Apparently, the doctor feels that the patient may not be physically able to withstand the rigors of chemo. From what the OP describes, with his Dad in a weakened condition, would you consider that the time is rapidly approaching when a decision needs to be made regarding quantity versus quality of time remaining? Perhaps a consultation with a medical professional specializing in palliative care could spell out the various scenarios. In fact, as noted, the earlier removal of the patient's testicles (orchiectomy) in January, 2012 is described in medical journals as a form of palliative treatment in dealing with advanced prostate cancer. Just a thought. Jim

Posts.Title: Bruising on abdomen after robotic surgery?

Posts.Content: "I wish there was a definitive way of testing that didn't involve sticking 20 inch needles up my ass. But that is life I guess." You are so right. But at least it provides an enthralling and captivating-topic-of-discussion narrative while having a drink with friends. Forty years ago, they sent men to the moon but they still have to fire a spear gun up our butt to learn what they need to know. It could be worse. Twenty years ago, I had to have TWO barium enemas within one week in a hospital where a tech shoves a garden hose up your kazoo, then from another room inflates your abdomen with barium until it triples in size and looks like you will explode. But the WORST part was that I needed to keep my butt cheeks clenched because if that hose ever came out while the test was being performed, there would be barium spread over many, many acres. If nothing else, there is a measure of empathy extended and a declaration that the guys at cocktail hour were immensely grateful it happened to me and not them. We do what we can.

Posts.Title: Pain and Discharges

Posts.Content: Hi Pierre: With your family history, it is only normal to be concerned about whether you might yet become another prostate cancer patient. And you will find a number of posters on this site who religiously rail against prostate biopsies until the PSA level reaches a point where there is no question that it needs to be done. Normally, I'm in the other camp encouraging biopsies. But with a PSA of only 1.7 and no mention of DRE abnormalities, I would not recommend (again, as a non-professional) a biopsy until you experience significant changes in your PSA or DRE. As Chuck mentioned, you should probably have no trouble in getting a GP to order a PSA based on your age (over 50) and your family history. If you continue to be concerned, you could ask for a PSA scrip every six months. Whether insurance pays for every test is really not relevant because a PSA test is not cost-prohibitive if you have to pay for it out-of-pocket. And it may help to give you peace of mind. Good luck, Jim

Rather than advocate for a biopsy, perhaps you could campaign for the 3T MRI which is less invasive. Best of luck. Jim

Posts.Title: How do you know when to advocate for another biopsy ...

Posts.Content: Thanks, Allen. That's the kind of info I like to hear. For the last 17 years during July/August, my wife of 50 years has traveled out West in the U.S. for 2 weeks with a girlfriend who has a condo in Park City, Utah that they use as a base camp. They've visited 15-16 states. They're into that outdoor stuff - not for me - while I require a hotel with an air-conditioned cocktail lounge. Well, she says she goes with a girlfriend but for some reason, I've never met the girlfriend. Just kidding. Anyway, she cancelled her plans for this year, knowing that I may need her help during my lung cancer surgery rehab. I feel bad that I'm responsible for breaking her streak but I can't seem to teach our Shih Tzu how to change dressings. Jim

Posts.Title: Long Windy Road

Posts.Content: Your etiquette is fine. I can't comment on the testicular pain as I'm not qualified. Please give us an update when you receive your PSA results. Normally, I don't preach but, at age 63, with a "really low" PSA 3 years ago, means you aren't getting annual PSA tests, which you should because prostate cancer (and colon cancers) are almost always 100% curable, when found early and treated. Others, with pancreatic and lung cancer, do not have that luxury. Medical science may have many wonderful break throughs but only YOU can take care of you. Others will chime in shortly with more specifics. Best of luck.

Posts.Title: Long history of prostate problems - wondering about symptoms, etc.

Posts.Content: Quark cheese and flax seed oil??? PLEASE! This supposed "cure" has been around for more than sixty years and is touted as "the cancer cure that the medical community doesn't want anybody to know about". During those sixty years, not one study has proven this diet effective at curing cancer or anything else. Maybe it can cure dandruff. If you have a loved one fighting prostate cancer, he may as well try peanut butter and jelly (which may be more nutritious) but it too will not cure his cancer. There is no magic bullet -- or magic quark cheese. A patient may have only one chance to beat prostate cancer (usually treatable and curable via surgery or radiation, if caught early). Don't waste your time with this crap. P.T. Barnum said there is a sucker born every minute. Don't be that sucker.

But the WORST part was that I needed to keep my butt cheeks clenched because if that hose ever came out while the test was being performed, there would be barium spread over many, many acres. If nothing else, there is a measure of empathy extended and a declaration that the guys at cocktail hour were immensely grateful it happened to me and not them. We do what we can.

Posts.Title: Sustained relatively high PSA confirming next steps

Posts.Content: My thoughts are: Your plan to wait three months for another PSA is valid; Your plan to STILL avoid a biopsy if the next PSA is the same (7.9) or higher is questionable. In the U.S., a common pursuit after a high initial PSA is to try antibiotics to rule out infection (yes, I know it's not perfect). Absent that path, on receiving a second high PSA reading, I would not dick around anymore with alternatives. Don't be concerned about a biopsy being "cost effective" to an insurer. Be more concerned about a biopsy being an "anti-death effective" option to you, the patient. Once again, a biopsy is the ONLY way to confirm the existence of prostate cancer. Why settle for anything less?

Posts.Title: High PSA level - worried

Posts.Content: Hi Samie: As someone who has benefited from salvage radiation, I concur with Michigan Man on virtually every aspect of your husband's case. The zero PSA at 12 weeks is VERY encouraging and yet....something seems out of whack. Although I have about 15 or 20 questions bouncing around in the back of my head, there is one that jumps out at me: If the doctor believes adjuvant or salvage radiation is "...not effective for this type of cancer...", then I would want to know exactly what he means by that statement. And if what he says is accurate, wouldn't that remain true at 3 months, 6 months or 12 months post-surgery and make future PSA tests pointless, with respect to considering AR or SR? John (MM) touched on it briefly -- and it's obviously a sensitive area -- but it almost sounds like the surgeon suspects metastasis has already occurred and radiation of the prostate bed would be a moot point. As the loving spouse, you are certainly entitled to know the answer to that and the only way to find out is to ask the doctor directly. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: One year post surgery update

Posts.Content: Chuck: I do indeed remember John Wayne's lung cancer history. Shortly after his surgery, he triumphantly proclaimed that he had "beaten the Big C". Years later, as my family and I watched the 1979 Academy Awards on TV, John Wayne, age 72 at that time, looking horribly gaunt, was a presenter. I recall saying to my two teenage daughters that they were watching Mr. Wayne's last Academy Award appearance. The 14-year-old said to me, "How can you possibly know that?". I told her that John Wayne, born Marion Morrison in 1907, had beaten the Big "C" only temporarily. He passed 3 months later. But your point is well taken. I would certainly welcome a 10-year-reprieve. Thank you for your good wishes. Jim

Posts.Title: After PC do you find other tests more stressful?

Posts.Content: Thanks, Allen. That's the kind of info I like to hear. For the last 17 years during July/August, my wife of 50 years has traveled out West in the U.S. for 2 weeks with a girlfriend who has a condo in Park City, Utah that they use as a base camp. They've visited 15-16 states. They're into that outdoor stuff - not for me - while I require a hotel with an air-conditioned cocktail lounge. Well, she says she goes with a girlfriend but for some reason, I've never met the girlfriend. Just kidding. Anyway, she cancelled her plans for this year, knowing that I may need her help during my lung cancer surgery rehab. I feel bad that I'm responsible for breaking her streak but I can't seem to teach our Shih Tzu how to change dressings. Jim
Posts.Title: After PC do you find other tests more stressful?

Posts.Content: Hi Don: Excellent detailed history. More people should keep a journal like yours. Glad your biopsy wasn't as bad as expected. Those online calculators estimating the percentage likelihood of cancer, in my estimation, only add to a person's anxiety levels and serve no useful purpose. For example, at age 72, the likelihood that I would win a $17,500 World Poker Tour online prize package against more than 3,200 opponents was probably less than 1%, yet I did just that last month. Go figure. And to speculate about various scenarios -- no cancer versus aggressive cancer -- again benefits no one, especially you. Only the biopsy will tell the tale. While it often misses finding actual cancer, if it does find a malignancy they will be able to stage it and provide a Gleason score that should reveal what you are dealing with. Once you receive those results, please come back and the caring people on this site who have "been there, done that" will be able to share with you their experiences which, hopefully, will be beneficial to you. Best of luck. Jim

Posts.Title: Psa rising hormone therapy not working very concerned

Posts.Content: As noted on a couple of other threads, you and I have traveled a similar prostate cancer path. Having 6 colon polyps removed is time for celebration, in my view, not stress at all. You have literally hit two home runs by finding and eradicating, not one, but two silent killers - prostate cancer AND colon cancer -- by having timely tests that many others delay until it's too late. I suspect that your next colonoscopy will be scheduled for less than 10 years, which will contribute to staying on top of a potential problem. In answer to your question, however, I can relate to at least one upcoming test that I am not looking forward to on June 13th. It is a simple Cat Scan with contrast of the chest which will determine whether a nodule remains in my right lung middle lobe and will have to be excised via the removal of part or all of that particular lobe. That decision - to remove the entire lobe - will be made while I'm still unconscious on the operating table if the lab says the nodule is cancerous. The national mortality rate for that operation is 3%. The recovery period at home is a full two months. I am worried that once I have part of a lung cut out, it could lead to a downward health spiral which I've seen before in others. With prostate cancer in 2010, I leaped onto the operating table. With horrible jump-off-a-bridge type pain in my right leg, I leaped onto the operating table to undergo spine surgery in 2011 (Success). With the likelihood of lung cancer this time around, I just have a bad feeling about this one. I'll climb onto the table but I won't be leaping.
Posts.Title: After PC do you find other tests more stressful?

Posts.Content: Your etiquette is fine. I can't comment on the testicular pain as I'm not qualified. Please give us an update when you receive your PSA results. Normally, I don't preach but, at age 63, with a "really low" PSA 3 years ago, means you aren't getting annual PSA tests, which you should because prostate cancer (and colon cancers) are almost always 100% curable, when found early and treated. Others, with pancreatic and lung cancer, do not have that luxury. Medical science may have many wonderful break throughs but only YOU can take care of you. Others will chime in shortly with more specifics. Best of luck.

Posts.Title: Post op...how much activity is too much?

Posts.Content: Welcome Jim W: Sorry to hear that your brother had complications with salvage radiation. From what I have read of other forum brothers' experiences, that would appear to be something that a minority of others have suffered. At age 71, I began my forty SR treatments three years after a DaVinci prostatectomy. I had zero side effects except for some minor fatigue toward the end of treatment. My history below continues to show a PSA of 0.00 three years post-SR. While no one can predict the future, I am comfortable that I made the right decision for myself at the time. Personally, given evidence of a biochemical recurrence, I would be focused not on "possible" side effects of salvage radiation but rather on the very real implications of a steadily rising PSA. Seven years ago, you took on PC and won the battle. My suggestion is to not allow The Beast to win the war now. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: High PSA level - worried

Posts.Content: You should also consider the fact that robotic surgery provides a much quicker and less painful recovery period, in general. Open surgery must be used on some patients who have complicating issues, such as a hernia near the site, but it seems that a significant majority of surgery patients now routinely select robotic as the surgery of choice.

Posts.Title: Post Biopsy Symptoms

Posts.Content: PDV: As a veteran poster, you are familiar with the issue that your question goes back to the never-ending discussion of: "You should be kept in the dark regarding any PSA reading under 0.1 because it can only cause anxiety". As Chuck points out, even the Mayo Clinic offers that recommendation. But, since you ask, and since I just received my latest post-surgery, post salvage radiation semi-annual PSA test result within the last hour (0.00 -- three years straight), my response to your question is: it depends. It depends on the specific machinery -- or assay -- used to reach the "actual" PSA result. In some cases, <0.02 or 0.01 may indeed be considered truly "undetectable". Only the medical professional -- or the doctor who ordered the test -- processing the results can adequately answer your question. When I received my first post-surgery PSA test result and it was 0.02, I was quite upset and made it clear to the surgeon that I was VERY concerned. He replied that it was nothing to worry about. However, in my case (which may be atypical) the PSA number continued to rise over a 3-year period resulting in the necessity to employ salvage radiation -- so far, so good. Finally, while I would love to say that your 0.01 is nothing to worry about, I can only share with you my personal belief that an unarguable TRUE zero is 0.00 and nothing else. Jim

Posts.Title: So scared with PSA at 53!!! (no.. not 5.3)

Posts.Content: Hi Don: Excellent detailed history. More people should keep a journal like yours. Glad your biopsy wasn't as bad as expected. Those online calculators estimating the percentage likelihood of cancer, in my estimation, only add to a person's anxiety levels and serve no useful purpose. For example, at age 72, the likelihood that I would win a $17,500 World Poker Tour online prize package against more than 3,200 opponents was probably less than 1%, yet I did just that last month. Go figure. And to speculate about various scenarios -- no cancer versus aggressive cancer -- again benefits no one, especially you. Only the biopsy will tell the tale. While it often misses finding actual cancer, if it does find a malignancy they will be able to stage it and provide a Gleason score that should reveal what you are dealing with. Once you receive those results, please come back and the caring people on this site who have "been there, done that" will be able to share with you their experiences which, hopefully, will be beneficial to you. Best of luck. Jim

Posts.Content: Jkeyt: As noted in my signature below, my salvage radiation path was similar to Allen's. My surgery was at age 68 and the SR was completed just before my 71st birthday. My urologist said that there is a growing belief that a proactive (read early) approach to knocking down prostate cancer recurrence is showing better outcomes. For example, both Allen and I started salvage radiation BEFORE the PSA reached 0.2 with excellent results, at least so far. Best of luck. Jim
