Posts.Title: Need advice regarding husband's situation

Posts.Content: It never ceases to amaze me as to how different people react to the same (or nearly the same) set of circumstances. After reading your excellent post detailing such items as being withdrawn and angry (I can certainly understand the anger at age 47) and almost pushing your family away for weeks, I can only conclude that we are sentinels at opposite ends of a pendulum. Neither of us were right or wrong -- just different. My reaction to the diagnosis of the Big "C" was in no way welcoming but, at the same time, after letting the news sink in, I could only describe my feelings as being pragmatic. Something is bad -- something is broken -- let's fix it. Nothing more -- nothing less. I'm happy with the outcome even though the cancer returned 3 years later. If I had it to do over again, I wouldn't change anything. My only acknowledgement to the disease is that I end my e-mails with "I'm still here". Best of luck to you in your recovery, Jim

Posts.Title: Need advice regarding husband's situation

Posts.Content: "I wish there was a definitive way of testing that didn't involve sticking 20 inch needles up my ass. But that is life I guess." You are so right. But at least it provides an enthralling and captivating-topic-of-discussion narrative while having a drink with friends. Forty years ago, they sent men to the moon but they still have to fire a spear gun up our butt to learn what they need to know. It could be worse. Twenty years ago, I had to have TWO barium enemas within one week in a hospital where a tech shoves a garden hose up your kazoo, then from another room inflates your abdomen with barium until it triples in size and looks like you will explode. But the WORST part was that I needed to keep my butt cheeks clenched because if that hose ever came out while the test was being performed, there would be barium spread over many, many acres. If nothing else, there is a measure of empathy extended and a declaration that the guys at cocktail hour were immensely grateful it happened to me and not them. We do what we can.

Posts.Title: Sustained relatively high PSA confirming next steps

Posts.Content: Agreed, earlier is usually better, BUT The decision at what point to start salvage radiation early may not be your choice. You'll want to check with your insurance company first because they may have a protocol to approve payment at a higher PSA reading than, say, 0.05. And you probably don't want to self-pay. My radiation oncologist billed Medicare $250,000 for 40 sessions of salvage radiation.

Posts.Title: Hello - Newbie - advice probably needed

Posts.Content: "Waiting for the urologist on call" jumps out at me. Upon surgical discharge, virtually all patients receive specific written instructions on how to proceed if a post-surgery problem occurs. This should include direct access to YOUR surgeon, not some resident medical student staffing the ER "on call" at 3AM who has never seen your husband before. Since you don't believe that his doctor has received messages left for him, then I suggest a proactive approach: Show up at the doctor's office, unannounced and without an appointment. As you explain the reason for your presence to the counter staff, be sure to do so loud enough that patients in the waiting room overhear your dilemma. You may be pleasantly surprised that, in order to avoid an exodus of potential surgical patients heading for the door after hearing your husband's tale of woe, a block of time may be allocated to you to meet with the surgeon then and there. At this point, you have everything to gain and nothing to lose. Needless to say, complications can always arise, but to receive no response from the surgeon is unforgivable and should not be tolerated. Make noise!
Posts.Title: What nobody told before surgery

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Maverick91 My DW and I met with the radiologist this morning. It was a consult to talk about IMRT as a treatment option. To hear him talk, I haven't found a downside, compared to what I've learned about a surgical option. We meet with the surgeon next week to discuss that option. With my cancer being so early, we're not in a rush, per se. Radiation and surgery have roughly equal successful outcomes. But the "downside" could come if you experience a recurrence. With surgery, you have the fall-back option of salvage radiation to solidify a cure. With radiation as primary treatment, there are little to no fall-back options to a cure. Personally, those two statements caused me to choose surgery and it was fortunate that I did, because my PC returned 3 years post-surgery. As long as your Gleason 6 is accurate, you have time to weigh the choices. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: met with radiologist today

Posts.Content: Welcome 7seas: Our moderator, Chuck, has covered the basics. Thank you for your service. Your reaction -- especially at such a young age -- is normal. When I first heard that I had prostate cancer -- The Big "C" -- I figured at age 68 that I had bought the farm. Then my urologist said, "Snap out of it. Stop being so freaking dramatic. You have a common, garden-variety Gleason 7 version of prostate cancer that we see every day and we almost always treat it successfully. A year from now, it will be a distant memory". While that wasn't exactly true -- I had a recurrence 3 years later -- I'm just fine now. In fact, at age 73, I appeared last month on national television where I won a large poker tournament on the World Poker Tour in Atlantic City. I'm still here. You're going to be just fine. Jim

Posts.Title: NEW GUY needs help with lab results.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Maverick91 Actually, I've been told the differently, by two doctors, and my own research backs up the idea, that after radiation, surgery may still be an option. I would be very interested in the names and locations of the doctors who will even attempt such a surgery, per your "research". In 2014, my research found a total of only 5 doctors in the entire United States who performed salvage surgery after failed primary radiation (2 in L.A., one each in Dallas, Miami and Boston). And, of course, that means traveling to a distant city for the high-risk surgery -- they're not coming to you. Salvage radiation, on the other hand, is performed extensively.

Posts.Title: met with radiologist today

Posts.Content: Quark cheese and flax seed oil??? PLEASE! This supposed "cure" has been around for more than sixty years and is touted as "the cancer cure that the medical community doesn't want anybody to know about". During those sixty years, not one study has proven this diet effective at curing cancer or anything else. Maybe it can cure dandruff. If you have a loved one fighting prostate cancer, he may as well try peanut butter and jelly (which may be more nutritious) but it too will not cure his cancer. There is no magic bullet -- or magic quark cheese. A patient may have only one chance to beat prostate cancer (usually treatable and curable via surgery or radiation, if caught early). Don't waste your time with this crap. P.T. Barnum said there is a sucker born every minute. Don't be that sucker.

Posts.Title: Anyone used or heard of the Budwig protocol

Posts.Content: #2 doesn't make sense. A prostate biopsy is normally performed in a doctor's office with a numbing agent injection and without anesthesia. "General" anesthesia, which entails potential medical risks of its own, is routinely performed in a hospital operating room under the guidance of a licensed anesthesiologist. I would clarify this issue with the urologist in advance.

Posts.Title: Biopsy Scheduled - Just a few questions

Posts.Content: Welcome Al: IndyLou did a great job of providing an realistic overview. From your posting, I think that you already know the most prevalent answer. It's an either/or question and reply. Either the patient wants quality of life (for his remaining time) or he wants quantity of life -- probably with difficult side effects. We can tell you our views -- ie., I'd want quality of life. You might get a 50-50 response summary. But none of us is your Dad. And only he can decide what's best for him. And I know that you know that. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: How soon is too soon for sexual activity after prostatectomy?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Maverick91 My DW and I met with the radiologist this morning. It was a consult to talk about IMRT as a treatment option. To hear him talk, I haven't found a downside, compared to what I've learned about a surgical option. We meet with the surgeon next week to discuss that option. With my cancer being so early, we're not in a rush, per se. Radiation and surgery have roughly equal successful outcomes. But the "downside" could come if you experience a recurrence. With surgery, you have the fall-back option of salvage radiation to solidify a cure. With radiation as primary treatment, there are little to no fall-back options to a cure. Personally, those two statements caused me to choose surgery and it was fortunate that I did, because my PC returned 3 years post-surgery. As long as your Gleason 6 is accurate, you have time to weigh the choices. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: met with radiologist today

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Maverick91 Actually, I've been told the differently, by two doctors, and my own research backs up the idea, that after radiation, surgery may still be an option. I would be very interested in the names and locations of the doctors who will even attempt such a surgery, per your "research". In 2014, my research found a total of only 5 doctors in the entire United States who performed salvage surgery after failed primary radiation (2 in L.A., one each in Dallas, Miami and Boston). And, of course, that means traveling to a distant city for the high-risk surgery -- they're not coming to you. Salvage radiation, on the other hand, is performed extensively.

Posts.Title: met with radiologist today

Posts.Content: Although you have undoubtedly read that incontinence following a prostatectomy varies greatly among patients, if it is of concern to you after 4 weeks post-surgery as it appears to be, contact your surgeon and discuss the issue. The discharge paperwork provided by my surgeon suggested that I would not likely find dryness until the end of the second month. Voila! By the 60th day, I was completely dry and remained so. But, at the same time, based upon the experiences of others in the same situation, I would not be concerned that your 4-week history is out of the ordinary. Best of luck on your journey to drydock.
Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer Incontinence

Posts.Content: Some insurance companies are notorious for trying to find ways NOT to pay and they're willing to spend a little to avoid paying a lot. For example, three years ago, my best friend's brother-in-law had a high PSA and his biopsy was either Gleason 8 or 9. He decided he wanted robotic surgery, his doctor agreed but his employer's insurance company required a full body bone scan first or they would not pay for the surgery. The bone scan revealed metastasis to other areas. Based on those findings, the insurance company refused to pay for a prostatectomy for a patient they considered to have limited time remaining. So, the bone scan can be a double-edged sword.

Posts.Content: Most major hospital websites list the professional profiles of the physicians on staff (age, name of medical school attended, years in practice, etc.). For example, if a surgeon has performed over 1,000 robotic prostate cancer surgeries, I feel confident that he will find a way to have that info listed in order to distinguish himself from his/her less-experienced colleagues.

Posts.Title: How to researh

Posts.Content: Welcome MCM_2: If your insurance will cover it, the 3T MRI is an excellent investigative tool in advance of a second biopsy. As you mentioned, especially at his age, it is most probably BPH. But, if I was in the same boat, I am a great believer that it's always better to have too many diagnostic tests than not enough. I'd at least ask the doctor his/her thoughts on the 3T MRI. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Need advice regarding husband's situation

Posts.Content: Welcome 7seas: Our moderator, Chuck, has covered the basics. Thank you for your service. Your reaction -- especially at such a young age -- is normal. When I first heard that I had prostate cancer -- The Big "C" -- I figured at age 68 that I had bought the farm. Then my urologist said, "Snap out of it. Stop being so freaking dramatic. You have a common, garden-variety Gleason 7 version of prostate cancer that we see every day and we almost always treat it successfully. A year from now, it will be a distant memory". While that wasn't exactly true -- I had a recurrence 3 years later -- I'm just fine now. In fact, at age 73, I appeared last month on national television where I won a large poker tournament on the World Poker Tour in Atlantic City. I'm still here. You're going to be just fine. Jim

Posts.Content: Hi Joe: What if the dementia diagnosis is flawed? What if your cognitive abilities diminished (certainly not demonstrated here as you have done an excellent job articulating your dilemma) over 20 years and not 10 years? If you do have prostate cancer -- which if caught early is nearly 100% curable -- then why not investigate the degree via a biopsy? Especially with young children dependent upon you. Our moderator, Chuck, who is a very easy-going guy, demonstrated his concerns through his words. On the other hand, since this is a prostate cancer forum and you insist that you have no interest in seeking a potential cure, why are you wasting our time? Jim

Posts.Title: Biopsy/Treatment if in early stages of Dementia

Posts.Content: Welcome Drbbt: It's great that you've been on top of this issue for years and have a better grasp of what to expect than, say, someone who is learning for the first time that they have PC. At your age, I believe you have made a wise choice for your future. As you approach 9/14 and after surgery, we should be able to share some tips that you may find helpful from our experiences. For example, I'm the "recliner guy". When you arrive back home with a catheter for a week to 10 days (it was my first-ever experience with a catheter -- wasn't even sure how it worked), it should cause zero pain but it is a nuisance. What I found was that trying to lie flat in bed posed some logistical problems for me as I constantly toss and turn. I slept instead in a recliner with the Foley bag in a bucket at my feet and that worked great for me. Another poster on this site said he liked it SO much, he has remained in the recliner for the last six months, while his wife urges him to return to bed. We'll be here with you every step of the way. The only dumb question is the one left unasked. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: PSA Anxiety

Posts.Content: Hi Janet: Welcome to a club that no one wants to be a member of. While some members prefer specific diets, I'm not a fan. Once cancer is confirmed, no diet is going to make it disappear. The CT and full-body bone scan, as you likely know, will act to determine the next step. It is standard procedure and should reveal whether a patient is actually a candidate for a "cure" (cancer has not metastasized to other areas of the body) usually via surgery or radiation, or whether the objective is to extend life through various applications of hormone therapy. Please don't misinterpret my layman's explanation (none of us are physicians on this site and, therefore, can't make recommendations -- only share our experiences) as extension of life is often many years, even many decades. We will be here for any questions you may have along the way and our esteemed moderator, Chuck, should be along shortly to provide a formal welcome. Generally speaking, if your husband was going to have any cancer, this is the one he wants because the survival rate is nearly 100% if caught early and treated. Others are not as fortunate, as they deal with diminished five-year survival rates (pancreatic and lung cancer). A Gleason 7 is in the moderate range so there is every reason to be hopeful that, following treatment, this will merely be a bump in life's highway and nearly forgotten in the years to come. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed.....

Posts.Content: Hi Janet: Welcome to a club that no one wants to be a member of. While some members prefer specific diets, I'm not a fan. Once cancer is confirmed, no diet is going to make it disappear. The CT and full-body bone scan, as you likely know, will act to determine the next step. It is standard procedure and should reveal whether a patient is actually a candidate for a "cure" (cancer has not metastasized to other areas of the body) usually via surgery or radiation, or whether the objective is to extend life through various applications of hormone therapy. Please don't misinterpret my layman's explanation (none of us are physicians on this site and, therefore, can't make recommendations -- only share our experiences) as extension of life is often many years, even many decades. We will be here for any questions you may have along the way and our esteemed moderator, Chuck, should be along shortly to provide a formal welcome. Generally speaking, if your husband was going to have any cancer, this is the one he wants because the survival rate is nearly 100% if caught early and treated. Others are not as fortunate, as they deal with diminished five-year survival rates (pancreatic and lung cancer). A Gleason 7 is in the moderate range so there is every reason to be hopeful that, following treatment, this will merely be a bump in life's highway and nearly forgotten in the years to come. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed.....

Posts.Content: Hi Mike: Michael F provides excellent observations relative to your inquiry. As a DaVinci AND salvage radiation patient, I would simply add the following: In my case, my urologist recommended and worked closely with a radiation oncologist following a PC recurrence 3 years after DaVinci. In the 2 years since I received salvage radiation, I alternated visits between the urologist and oncologist as they monitored my PSA levels which, thankfully, have remained at 0.00. Last week, I had my final visit with the oncologist who handed me back to my urologist for continued care of my plumbing which has a nasty habit of developing kidney stones (7 attacks in the last 7 years -- two removed surgically from the left ureter in 2008 & 2014). In your case, assuming you are covered by Medicare, you may run into a problem getting approval for salvage radiation if your PSA remains undetectable. My oncologist billed Medicare $240,000 for 40 sessions of SR (no, that's not a typo) and, under Obamacare, you may be required to show a demonstrated need for SR. That's just my non-professional thoughts and I could be wrong, but it is certainly something you may wish to inquire about. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Salvage Radiation Questions, and should I see a Urologist or Oncologist after surgery

Posts.Content: Welcome Al: IndyLou did a great job of providing an realistic overview. From your posting, I think that you already know the most prevalent answer. It's an either/or question and reply. Either the patient wants quality of life (for his remaining time) or he wants quantity of life -- probably with difficult side effects. We can tell you our views -- ie., I'd want quality of life. You might get a 50-50 response summary. But none of us is your Dad. And only he can decide what's best for him. And I know that you know that. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: How Many Angels Can Dance on the Edge of a Pin

Posts.Content: Hi PecenkA: Fathers can be a pain in the butt. They can be unnecessarily hard-headed when they develop an unmovable opinion on a particular subject. And it's especially frustrating when that opinion is DEAD wrong. Many posters on this site -- including me - have had surgery and then salvage radiation when the PC returned. Today, I have no detectable cancer. Oh, by the way, during my treatment and in the 3 years since my 40 sessions of radiation, I have experienced ZERO side effects. If your Dad was not going to have radiation, come hell or high water, then I just have one question. Why did he bother having the surgery? He could have saved himself a lot of wasted energy by simply throwing in the towel pre-surgery. Please encourage him to read the outcomes on this site and try to keep an OPEN mind. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Dad's post op diagnosis question

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Maverick91 Actually, I've been told the differently, by two doctors, and my own research backs up the idea, that after radiation, surgery may still be an option. I would be very interested in the names and locations of the doctors who will even attempt such a surgery, per your "research". In 2014, my research found a total of only 5 doctors in the entire United States who performed salvage surgery after failed primary radiation (2 in L.A., one each in Dallas, Miami and Boston). And, of course, that means traveling to a distant city for the high-risk surgery -- they're not coming to you. Salvage radiation, on the other hand, is performed extensively.

Posts.Title: met with radiologist today

Posts.Content: John: You may have considered this and decided against it but when I was evaluating a similar "hold that bladder" problem, I would have also had to contend with travel after consuming a ton of water. Since the travel was over two major roads that are frequently subject to gridlock, I decided, for me, the best resolution was to arrive an hour early and consume the water on-site at the radiation center. Eventually, I chose a radiologist who didn't believe in inflating the bladder which caused my anxiety level to go back to normal. Glad to hear your SR is going fine. Jim

Posts.Content: Hi Chuck: Broomall is located in Delaware County, just 5 miles west of Philadelphia. Surprisingly, it is a million miles away from the 400-murders-a-year EVERY YEAR in Philly. In fact, in the last 40 years, more people were murdered in Philadelphia than all of the combat troops killed in Iraq and Afghanistan. It's sometimes hard to view the Liberty Bell as the bodies pile up so high. Do I sound cynical? Jim

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed.....

Posts.Content: Although you have undoubtedly read that incontinence following a prostatectomy varies greatly among patients, if it is of concern to you after 4 weeks post-surgery as it appears to be, contact your surgeon and discuss the issue. The discharge paperwork provided by my surgeon suggested that I would not likely find dryness until the end of the second month. Voila! By the 60th day, I was completely dry and remained so. But, at the same time, based upon the experiences of others in the same situation, I would not be concerned that your 4-week history is out of the ordinary. Best of luck on your journey to drydock.
Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer Incontinence

Posts.Content: Hi Joe: What if the dementia diagnosis is flawed? What if your cognitive abilities diminished (certainly not demonstrated here as you have done an excellent job articulating your dilemma) over 20 years and not 10 years? If you do have prostate cancer -- which if caught early is nearly 100% curable -- then why not investigate the degree via a biopsy? Especially with young children dependent upon you. Our moderator, Chuck, who is a very easy-going guy, demonstrated his concerns through his words. On the other hand, since this is a prostate cancer forum and you insist that you have no interest in seeking a potential cure, why are you wasting our time? Jim

Posts.Title: Blood Clots revealed PSA of 94.0

Posts.Content: I cringe whenever I read comments that highlight side effects -- sometimes rare side effects --and ignore prostate cancer mortality facts. FACT: Prostate cancer remains the second-leading cause of cancer deaths among men; FACT: A total of 30,000 men die every year from prostate cancer; FACT: That's 30,000 deaths EVERY YEAR; Try to visualize thirty thousand dead bodies piled atop one another. Then reach into that pile, pull one out and ask him if he would trade places with someone who was uncomfortable with some side effects of prostate cancer treatment. The OP has dealt with this issue for more than 10 years -- probably longer than most of us -- done his research and ALREADY made his decision. Instead of Monday morning quarterbacks, he could use our support.

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed.....

Posts.Content: Welcome Drbbt: It's great that you've been on top of this issue for years and have a better grasp of what to expect than, say, someone who is learning for the first time that they have PC. At your age, I believe you have made a wise choice for your future. As you approach 9/14 and after surgery, we should be able to share some tips that you may find helpful from our experiences. For example, I'm the "recliner guy". When you arrive back home with a catheter for a week to 10 days (it was my first-ever experience with a catheter -- wasn't even sure how it worked), it should cause zero pain but it is a nuisance. What I found was that trying to lie flat in bed posed some logistical problems for me as I constantly toss and turn. I slept instead in a recliner with the Foley bag in a bucket at my feet and that worked great for me. Another poster on this site said he liked it SO much, he has remained in the recliner for the last six months, while his wife urges him to return to bed. We'll be here with you every step of the way. The only dumb question is the one left unasked. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Recent Stage IV Diagnosis

Posts.Content: Hi Joe: What if the dementia diagnosis is flawed? What if your cognitive abilities diminished (certainly not demonstrated here as you have done an excellent job articulating your dilemma) over 20 years and not 10 years? If you do have prostate cancer -- which if caught early is nearly 100% curable -- then why not investigate the degree via a biopsy? Especially with young children dependent upon you. Our moderator, Chuck, who is a very easy-going guy, demonstrated his concerns through his words. On the other hand, since this is a prostate cancer forum and you insist that you have no interest in seeking a potential cure, why are you wasting our time? Jim

Posts.Title: Recent Stage IV Diagnosis

Posts.Content: Featherboy: I respectfully disagree with the logic of sticking one's head in the sand and ignoring the growth in what is called "undetectable" PSA results. As you can see from my history, it was the ultra sensitive PSA tests that alerted me to the return of my cancer and I was not surprised once the 0.1 reading was exceeded. It helped to prepare me with the fortitude to fight PC yet a second time. I think it would have been more traumatic if I had embraced the <0.1 readings and believed that I was in no danger. Jim

I get it that the Mayo Clinic, Highlander, you and many others approve of <0.1 as the PSA gold standard on PC recurrence and admittance to the Zero Club. I guess I'm just an old hardhead when it comes to accepting LESS information as being good for you whether we are discussing PC or how long a piece of fish has been laying on a seafood counter at the supermarket. Somehow, I find it difficult to ignore whether it has been there for one day or four days before I buy it. The more information I have on any subject seems to me to be a good thing. Just another point of view. Jim

Posts.Title: PSA Bumping up 5 years after SRT

Posts.Content: Welcome cliffytom: Blood clots can be very serious, so the need to take action ASAP is certainly understandable. However, a medical opinion that something is "most likely Stage 4 prostate cancer" seems questionable without a solid confirmation. I have no medical training whatsoever, but even to a layman, the commencement of treatment (Firmagon) in the absence of a confirmation of prostate cancer raises a red flag. Have you acquainted yourselves with the substantial side effects of Firmagon (degarelix)? As Chuck said, only a biopsy can confirm PC. Has there been any discussion of performing a prostate biopsy? Could you share with us the specific results of his CT scan? Hopefully, the full-body bone scan will help to reveal whatever underlying problem(s) are present. It's always possible that his urination difficulties are completely unrelated to the blood clots. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Blood Clots revealed PSA of 94.0

Posts.Content: Hi Janet: Welcome to a club that no one wants to be a member of. While some members prefer specific diets, I'm not a fan. Once cancer is confirmed, no diet is going to make it disappear. The CT and full-body bone scan, as you likely know, will act to determine the next step. It is standard procedure and should reveal whether a patient is actually a candidate for a "cure" (cancer has not metastasized to other areas of the body) usually via surgery or radiation, or whether the objective is to extend life through various applications of hormone therapy. Please don't misinterpret my layman's explanation (none of us are physicians on this site and, therefore, can't make recommendations -- only share our experiences) as extension of life is often many years, even many decades. We will be here for any questions you may have along the way and our esteemed moderator, Chuck, should be along shortly to provide a formal welcome. Generally speaking, if your husband was going to have any cancer, this is the one he wants because the survival rate is nearly 100% if caught early and treated. Others are not as fortunate, as they deal with diminished five-year survival rates (pancreatic and lung cancer). A Gleason 7 is in the moderate range so there is every reason to be hopeful that, following treatment, this will merely be a bump in life's highway and nearly forgotten in the years to come. Best of luck, Jim

It's sometimes hard to view the Liberty Bell as the bodies pile up so high. Do I sound cynical? Jim

Posts.Title: Merry Christmas!

Posts.Content: Welcome SR: With 11 out of 12 cores showing positive, the one thing you can rule out is active surveillance. The basic data requested above will help us to provide info and support relative to your specific case. And, in addition to Dr. Walsh's book (no, really -- we don't share in the book royalties), you can absorb a wealth of information by simply reading the various threads of this PC site and how others, like you, have dealt with similar circumstances. We'll be here for you from biopsy to -- every reason to believe in -- a "cure". Good luck, Jim

Posts.Title: biopsy results

Posts.Content: Hi Joe: What if the dementia diagnosis is flawed? What if your cognitive abilities diminished (certainly not demonstrated here as you have done an excellent job articulating your dilemma) over 20 years and not 10 years? If you do have prostate cancer -- which if caught early is nearly 100% curable -- then why not investigate the degree via a biopsy? Especially with young children dependent upon you. Our moderator, Chuck, who is a very easy-going guy, demonstrated his concerns through his words. On the other hand, since this is a prostate cancer forum and you insist that you have no interest in seeking a potential cure, why are you wasting our time? Jim

Posts.Title: Biopsy/Treatment if in early stages of Dementia

Posts.Content: Featherboy: I respectfully disagree with the logic of sticking one's head in the sand and ignoring the growth in what is called "undetectable" PSA results. As you can see from my history, it was the ultra sensitive PSA tests that alerted me to the return of my cancer and I was not surprised once the 0.1 reading was exceeded. It helped to prepare me with the fortitude to fight PC yet a second time. I think it would have been more traumatic if I had embraced the <0.1 readings and believed that I was in no danger. Jim

Posts.Title: PSA Bumping up 5 years after SRT

Posts.Content: A year ago, when you received the diagnosis of prostatitis and BPH, did the uro put you on a regiment of antibiotics? Certainly, at age 40, cancer would be unusual, but not impossible. It seems strange that no follow-up was conducted to determine whether you responded to medication. It seems even stranger that the urologist -- especially the urologist -- would allow 2 years to pass before scheduling another PSA test while attempting to give validity to his original diagnosis. Also, do you have a family history of PC? I make these observations strictly as a layman with no medical background or credentials.

Posts.Title: I'm back, and freakout time again

Posts.Content: Best of luck to your DH, Mimi. Your original question about the pros and cons of ultra-sensitive PSA tests versus the regular tests can best be answered by reviewing my history and asking the question: Would you want to know if the alleged "undetectable" PSA reflects the encroaching return of prostate cancer? My vote would be "Yes". It helped me prepare for dealing with salvage radiotherapy. Others, including the Mayo Clinic, feel that <0.1 is sufficient knowledge for the patient. I suppose it's a personal choice issue.

Posts.Title: Post-surgery PSA tests: ultra-sensitive or regular?

Posts.Content: Hi Featherboy: Thanks for the feedback. I get it that the Mayo Clinic, Highlander, you and many others approve of <0.1 as the PSA gold standard on PC recurrence and admittance to the Zero Club. I guess I'm just an old hardhead when it comes to accepting LESS information as being good for you whether we are discussing PC or how long a piece of fish has been laying on a seafood counter at the supermarket. Somehow, I find it difficult to ignore whether it has been there for one day or four days before I buy it. The more information I have on any subject seems to me to be a good thing. Just another point of view. Jim

Posts.Title: I'm back, and freakout time again

Posts.Content: Hi Angelmum: With respect to treatment, as you can see from my signature, I sampled a little bit of almost everything. When my PC came back three years after robotic surgery, I had 40 sessions of radiation just before I turned 71, a few years younger than your uncle. So far, my outcome has been on target (PSA=0.00) and the salvage radiotherapy I received caused no problems to speak of. A couple of caveats: my radiation dosage was focused on the remaining prostate bed so the dosage was less than for primary treatment of PC. If you do decide on radiotherapy, be wary of "quick fixes" of only 5 radiotherapy sessions with devices like the Cyberknife where massive doses of radiation may result in serious painful burns. I personally know of two patients who suffered burns completely through the anal wall. As long as you gather the info needed from various sources, including recommendations from others on this site who have experienced a similar scenario -- especially the age factor -- then you will gain confidence in arriving at the right treatment decision. Best of luck. Jim

I personally know of two patients who suffered burns completely through the anal wall. As long as you gather the info needed from various sources, including recommendations from others on this site who have experienced a similar scenario -- especially the age factor -- then you will gain confidence in arriving at the right treatment decision. Best of luck. Jim

Posts.Title: Radiotherapy or hormone therapy at age 78

Posts.Content: Chuck points out that your progressively higher PSA readings could be caused by infection or an enlarged prostate. Left unsaid is that you possibly could have prostate cancer which is spreading. And a biopsy is the only way to know for certain. Your words "...single biopsy also can often tell nothing..." and "...one problem might be, saturation biopsy might not be a preferred way for most urologist in Canada..." sound like you're searching for reasons to not have the biopsy. While you vacillate, bad things could be happening internally. When you come onto an online prostate cancer forum and ask for comments, you're not going to like some of the feedback. I'm sure I fit that scenario but, given six progressively higher PSA tests over 4.0, try stepping back and look at the big picture and ask, "What would the average person do?".

Posts.Title: Prostate 3T MRI exam

Posts.Content: Hi Tom: As you can see from the above, our esteemed moderator and others traveled to the Mayo Clinic, while some traveled to places like Johns Hopkins in Baltimore for what they consider to be top-of-the-line treatment. Five years ago, I considered Dr. Lee at HUP since he was the recognized leader in DaVinci surgery in the region at that time and remains so today. In my view, you would be in excellent hands if you decide to choose Dr. Lee for your surgery. I live about 5 miles west of Philadelphia and most doctors that I see are on the Main Line, just outside Philly. If it had been a transplant of some kind, I would have gone into Philly for the surgery. But, while I viewed a prostatectomy as serious surgery, I decided instead to stay out of the city and have my DaVinci robotic surgery performed by the leading surgeon in the western suburbs, Dr. David McGinnis, who is a member of the urology group where I was a patient. My surgery was performed at Bryn Mawr Hospital and was textbook with no pain and 60 days to full continence post-surgery. However, I did have a small positive margin that resulted in a BCR 3 years later and salvage radiation to knock it down. As of now, as you can see from the history below, my PSA levels remain at 0.00 two years after salvage radiation. As for the future, who knows? And while no one wants to be pressured to make a decision quickly ("the price I'm offering you for this car is only good for today"), the fact that you have 4 positive cores - yes, you have prostate cancer, albeit it a Gleason 6 - also means that you would do yourself a disservice if you take a long time to ponder your next step. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Diagnosed Recently

Posts.Content: Thanks, Highlander. As of last summer, my urologist and two oncology radiologists in suburban Philadelphia informed me that the "0.2 PSA threshold following prostatectomy" was being closely watched by their medical communities as possibly being somewhat outdated. They claimed that more recent studies have shown a moderately higher successful radiation outcome when they eyeball and evaluate any reading exceeding 0.1 PSA. That's not to say that everyone who has a reading higher than 0.1 PSA needs immediate radiation. Rather, they check the PSA more often and are particularly concerned about any reading that doubles within a limited time frame. I'm also glad that Jebstart has had a fruitful journey. Just wanted to suggest that he stay on the alert for any changes that may occur. Jim
Posts.Title: PSA, 8 weeks post Robotic Prostatectomy

Posts.Content: PC: You pose a difficult question. Could you be that one in a million who experiences a recurrence ten years after surgery? Could that be the reason you can find little info on post-surgery AS? That's hard to answer but it's impossible to argue against the factual aspects of your currently rising -- and disturbing -- PSA numbers. My recurrence happened three years after surgery. I can only suggest that, if I found myself in the same situation at ten years, I wouldn't spend a lot of time over-thinking the situation. My 40 sessions of SR was accompanied by zero side effects with the exception of some slight fatigue toward the end. You've won the battle so far. With SR, you may finally win the war. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Diagnosed Recently

Posts.Content: Hi Beeswife: Before reading lancepeace's response, the first thing that came to mind was the location of the decimal point. As mentioned, 0.3 is not favorable, but 0.03 is certainly a reasonable number that could continue to go down, go up or stay the same. As long as it remains under 0.1, officially it is considered "undetectable" but (with my) caveat that you should keep a close watch on a rising PSA, even if it is "undetectable", as evidenced by my own history. If you have online access to his records via a patient portal, I would want to see the results in written form for confirmation. In the event that 0.3 is correct, a second PSA test performed at the same location on the same machine would be a logical "next step" in order to not do a knee-jerk reaction to a result that may not be accurate. A wait of one to three months might be reasonable before repeating the test. Good luck, Jim

Posts.Title: PSA test at 47 years old concerning Dr more than me

Posts.Content: With six PSA readings above 4.0, you need a biopsy. If your ultimate desire is to learn whether or not you have prostate cancer, I question why you (or anyone) would fly hundreds of miles, visit a foreign country, spend $895 for a 3T MRI test and STILL not know whether you have PC. As Chuck said, only a biopsy will give you a confirmed diagnosis of PC (assuming the biopsy sample hits active PC). But if you have lots of time and money to squander, go for it.

Rather, they check the PSA more often and are particularly concerned about any reading that doubles within a limited time frame. I'm also glad that Jebstart has had a fruitful journey. Just wanted to suggest that he stay on the alert for any changes that may occur. Jim
Posts.Title: PSA, 8 weeks post Robotic Prostatectomy

Posts.Content: Welcome TLKai: The urologist's decision to not act until your husband's PSA level reached "2" is perplexing. The current industry standard following surgery is that a biochemical recurrence is recognized after two successive PSA tests that equal or exceed a reading of "0.2", not "2.0". Is it possible that there was some misunderstanding? I made my decision to pursue salvage radiation when my PSA reached 0.11 once I noticed an upward trend. As mentioned above, proton therapy is most often effective if there is a finite target and proton has no long term studies yet to support it. Your husband and I have almost a mirror image of our experiences, except that I'm two decades older. As you can see from my history, I had the DaVinci surgery in 2010, only to have the cancer return exactly 3 years later. My route with IMRT as salvage radiation encountered virtually no side effects and, while I am currently cancer-free, no one can predict the future. Whatever decisions you make from this point forward, especially with a doubling of the PSA in less than a year, should probably be made sooner rather than later. Prior to salvage treatment, however, I was required to undergo a full-body bone scan to insure that the cancer had not metastasized. Don't be alarmed if your doctor suggests the same scan as it is often viewed as medical protocol. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Proton vs IMRT for Salvage treatment?

Posts.Content: Allen: Our histories are so similar, both with our DaVinci and salvage radiations. Yet, I suppose strangely, we differ in that I never think about the possible need for hormone therapy in the future. In fact, while I recognize side effects may come into play, there are many guys on this site who have had great success with extending their lives for many years, thanks to HT. And, like yours, my most recent PSA last month continues to look good, so I remain positive about the future, such as it is for a geezer. We've done everything we can to this point -- try to enjoy each day and think of the glass as half-full, not half-empty. I end most e-mails with the line "I'm still here!". Jim

Posts.Title: Stress is over for another 6 months

Posts.Content: Hi Jeb: In answer to your question, I respectfully take issue with the disclaimer below. "Any level under 0.2 mcg/dl is considered clinically insignificant". 11/10 -- Prostate removed via robotic surgery -- textbook recovery -- no issues. 2/11 -- Follow-up PSA test = 0.02. Surgeon says "Nothing to be concerned about -- totally insignificant". OK. 8/11 -- PSA = 0.04 2/12 -- PSA = 0.06 8/12 -- PSA = 0.08 2/13 -- PSA = 0.11 5/13 -- PSA = 0.16 At this point, the urologist sent me to an oncology radiologist. Since the PSA had doubled in less than one year, there was concern that the resurgence of prostate cancer was of a more virulent variety. 8/13 -- Began 40 sessions of radiation to knock it down. Only side effect was some heavy rectal bleeding from 3 internal large hemorrhoids which were medically treated without further problems. 12/13 -- PSA = 0.00. FINALLY prostate cancer free. I only had five days to celebrate when an unrelated Cat Scan showed a nodule in my right lung. Doctors claim the lung issue is not related to the earlier prostate cancer. 3/14 -- PET scan indicates likelihood the irregular 1.8 cm nodule is cancerous (SUV=3.0) -- bad location in right middle lobe for biopsy - will have surgery next month to remove the nodule via a wedge re-section and, if cancerous, the removal of the entire right middle lobe and surrounding lymph nodes plus chemo later. You can find me on the "Lung Cancer" thread on this site under "Is Surgery REALLY justified?". The main crux of this message is that successful action was taken when my PSA reached 0.16 regardless of whether some panel felt it was "clinically insignificant". I wish you the best in your recovery. Jim

Posts.Title: PSA, 8 weeks post Robotic Prostatectomy

Posts.Content: Michael F & Bob Smith: While the info on PSA doubling time is helpful from the standpoint of guidance, sometimes, common sense check-mates charts. For example, I didn't need a chart or a truck to hit me to observe an upward trend in my PSA post-surgery (please see below). It didn't take a rocket scientist to conclude that bad things await on the horizon if proactive measures were not implemented. As far as I was concerned, the recommendation to wait for a PSA >0.2 and rising only gives the cancer an opportunity to spread. I chose to move forward with salvage radiotherapy when my PSA reached 0.11 and it commenced at 0.16. So far, so good. Allen (Bravehardon) from Toronto had a similar view and began SR well before his PSA ever reached 0.2, also with excellent results so far (I say "so far" because no one ever knows what the future holds). For me, it's not a case of being right or wrong -- rather, we all need to be our own doctor to a certain degree. Jim

Posts.Title: Questions about salvage radiation therapy and the Mayo Clinic...

Posts.Content: Welcome Duvall: Although we are not medical professionals, the forum brothers on this site have had various experiences in dealing with prostate cancer that have been helpful, particularly to those newly diagnosed. Since you have not yet had a biopsy or a confirmation that you actually have PC, rest assured that we will be available at all times and at all points along the journey. Even if you do receive a confirmation, if you had to have cancer, this is the one you want because it is almost always 100% curable when found early and treated. That scenario is in contrast to other cancer patients on different threads throughout this website. As my urologist said, "Yes, you are going to die. But not now and certainly not from this". Could you share with us whether you have any family history of prostate cancer? Our esteemed moderator, Chuck, will be along shortly. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Can anyone advise me

Posts.Content: PC: You pose a difficult question. Could you be that one in a million who experiences a recurrence ten years after surgery? Could that be the reason you can find little info on post-surgery AS? That's hard to answer but it's impossible to argue against the factual aspects of your currently rising -- and disturbing -- PSA numbers. My recurrence happened three years after surgery. I can only suggest that, if I found myself in the same situation at ten years, I wouldn't spend a lot of time over-thinking the situation. My 40 sessions of SR was accompanied by zero side effects with the exception of some slight fatigue toward the end. You've won the battle so far. With SR, you may finally win the war. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Recurrent Prostate Cancer and Active Surveillance

Posts.Content: Now the big question is how long will this continue? Hi Osh: Looks like you are on target for a standard recovery. If you are asking how long you will receive PSA testing, my non-professional belief is that it will extend for the rest of your life (a small price to pay for the knowledge that you remain cancer free). Many post-op PC patients have their PSA tested every 3-6 months for the first year, semi-annually for the second year and annually, thereafter. Depending on the urologist, that schedule may vary somewhat. We all have different experiences with incontinence following surgery. My surgeon said his patients were completely dry, on average, at the end of two months. Lo and behold, on exactly the 60th day, I found the Land of Dryness. Don't be discouraged -- you can see the improvements from weighing your pads. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Six-week post-op progress report

Posts.Content: Hi Angelmum: With respect to treatment, as you can see from my signature, I sampled a little bit of almost everything. When my PC came back three years after robotic surgery, I had 40 sessions of radiation just before I turned 71, a few years younger than your uncle. So far, my outcome has been on target (PSA=0.00) and the salvage radiotherapy I received caused no problems to speak of. A couple of caveats: my radiation dosage was focused on the remaining prostate bed so the dosage was less than for primary treatment of PC. If you do decide on radiotherapy, be wary of "quick fixes" of only 5 radiotherapy sessions with devices like the Cyberknife where massive doses of radiation may result in serious painful burns. I personally know of two patients who suffered burns completely through the anal wall. As long as you gather the info needed from various sources, including recommendations from others on this site who have experienced a similar scenario -- especially the age factor -- then you will gain confidence in arriving at the right treatment decision. Best of luck. Jim

Posts.Title: Radiotherapy or hormone therapy at age 78

Posts.Content: Chuck points out that your progressively higher PSA readings could be caused by infection or an enlarged prostate. Left unsaid is that you possibly could have prostate cancer which is spreading. And a biopsy is the only way to know for certain. Your words "...single biopsy also can often tell nothing..." and "...one problem might be, saturation biopsy might not be a preferred way for most urologist in Canada..." sound like you're searching for reasons to not have the biopsy. While you vacillate, bad things could be happening internally. When you come onto an online prostate cancer forum and ask for comments, you're not going to like some of the feedback. I'm sure I fit that scenario but, given six progressively higher PSA tests over 4.0, try stepping back and look at the big picture and ask, "What would the average person do?".

Posts.Title: Prostate 3T MRI exam

Posts.Content: With six PSA readings above 4.0, you need a biopsy. If your ultimate desire is to learn whether or not you have prostate cancer, I question why you (or anyone) would fly hundreds of miles, visit a foreign country, spend $895 for a 3T MRI test and STILL not know whether you have PC. As Chuck said, only a biopsy will give you a confirmed diagnosis of PC (assuming the biopsy sample hits active PC). But if you have lots of time and money to squander, go for it.

Posts.Title: Trimix vs MUSE??

Posts.Content: Welcome Duvall: Although we are not medical professionals, the forum brothers on this site have had various experiences in dealing with prostate cancer that have been helpful, particularly to those newly diagnosed. Since you have not yet had a biopsy or a confirmation that you actually have PC, rest assured that we will be available at all times and at all points along the journey. Even if you do receive a confirmation, if you had to have cancer, this is the one you want because it is almost always 100% curable when found early and treated. That scenario is in contrast to other cancer patients on different threads throughout this website. As my urologist said, "Yes, you are going to die. But not now and certainly not from this". Could you share with us whether you have any family history of prostate cancer? Our esteemed moderator, Chuck, will be along shortly. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Can anyone advise me

Posts.Content: Now the big question is how long will this continue? Hi Osh: Looks like you are on target for a standard recovery. If you are asking how long you will receive PSA testing, my non-professional belief is that it will extend for the rest of your life (a small price to pay for the knowledge that you remain cancer free). Many post-op PC patients have their PSA tested every 3-6 months for the first year, semi-annually for the second year and annually, thereafter. Depending on the urologist, that schedule may vary somewhat. We all have different experiences with incontinence following surgery. My surgeon said his patients were completely dry, on average, at the end of two months. Lo and behold, on exactly the 60th day, I found the Land of Dryness. Don't be discouraged -- you can see the improvements from weighing your pads. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Six-week post-op progress report

Posts.Content: A year ago, when you received the diagnosis of prostatitis and BPH, did the uro put you on a regiment of antibiotics? Certainly, at age 40, cancer would be unusual, but not impossible. It seems strange that no follow-up was conducted to determine whether you responded to medication. It seems even stranger that the urologist -- especially the urologist -- would allow 2 years to pass before scheduling another PSA test while attempting to give validity to his original diagnosis. Also, do you have a family history of PC? I make these observations strictly as a layman with no medical background or credentials.

Posts.Title: Update: T3a Hub started Hormone Therapy (Lupron) & will start radiation this week

Posts.Content: Holy crap, Matt. That's a lot of detail for someone new to this disease. Rather than take your inquiries one at a time, let me be the one to keep it simple (others will address the questions). My uro is among a group of nine uros, two of whom perform robotic prostatectomies. They ALL adhere to the following mantra regarding prostate cancer (with a few exceptions, including active surveillance for low-risk patients): Under age 60 -- surgery Between ages 60 and 70 -- patient's choice of radiation or surgery Over age 70 -- radiation I was age 68 and told him "I'll have what the young guys are having". Three years after my robotic prostatectomy, the cancer returned and I had salvage radiation which has held the disease at bay -- to date. If I had it to do over again, I would change nothing. Your questions show that you have found -- as we all have -- that there can be an infinite number of variables. With an engineer's mindset, you have to guard against information overload. And focus on mortality as the primary issue and not so much the side effects. A general rule of thumb is that an erection is of little value to a corpse. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: PSA Testing Probelms

Posts.Content: Michael F & Bob Smith: While the info on PSA doubling time is helpful from the standpoint of guidance, sometimes, common sense check-mates charts. For example, I didn't need a chart or a truck to hit me to observe an upward trend in my PSA post-surgery (please see below). It didn't take a rocket scientist to conclude that bad things await on the horizon if proactive measures were not implemented. As far as I was concerned, the recommendation to wait for a PSA >0.2 and rising only gives the cancer an opportunity to spread. I chose to move forward with salvage radiotherapy when my PSA reached 0.11 and it commenced at 0.16. So far, so good. Allen (Bravehardon) from Toronto had a similar view and began SR well before his PSA ever reached 0.2, also with excellent results so far (I say "so far" because no one ever knows what the future holds). For me, it's not a case of being right or wrong -- rather, we all need to be our own doctor to a certain degree. Jim

Posts.Content: Hi Hopper: As mentioned above, I would lean toward stocking up now on pads and some shields (for later). Everyone is different with respect to the length of time you will need them, but here's a good reason to buy a lot now and trash the rest that are unneeded. My leakage ceased at the end of 60 days but during the second month when I ran short, I went to the supermarket to pick up pads. As I put the Depends on the conveyor belt at checkout, the woman in line behind me gave me a sympathetic look. I never want to see that look again -- fortunately those additional pads were sufficient to see me through. Best of luck to you, Sir, and please return to share your experience which will be helpful to others, Jim

Posts.Title: 2 more days before surgery

Posts.Content: Should I be concern about the 0.28? Yes, you should -- as the reply posts are in agreement. After a DaVinci in 2010, I followed a slow but steady PSA upward trend that caused me to decide to proceed with salvage radiation when the PSA reached 0.11. My SR actually commenced at 0.16. Good results so far, as noted below, but honestly I view cancer in general as being equivalent to the "Whack A Mole" game at a carnival. You knock it down and it pops up elsewhere. Nevertheless you really can't ignore a clear-cut biochemical recurrence and any doctor who tells you to wait until your PSA reaches 0.3 before seeking treatment is locked in a time warp from 1999. Good luck, Jim

Posts.Title: PSA of 0.28 2yrs. after Prostrate removal

Posts.Content: Hi Michael: Thank you for your kind words. On my lung saga, it was my adult daughter who sells body parts (currently, heart valves) who joined my wife and I in consultation with the lung surgeon who was already sharpening his scalpel. It was a risk to wait 3 months because it could have spread. But I was actually more concerned that the removal of part of a perfectly functioning lung (I kill the breathing machine every time) could lead to an overall downward health spiral. I've seen that happen in others and it's not pretty as they struggle to breathe. Just got lucky this time, I suppose. With respect to side effects from salvage radiation, I got lucky there, also, because I've never experienced any problems whatsoever. It's good to see that you are keeping vigil on your PSA, with excellent results 3 years after your surgery. Jim

Posts.Title: Questions about salvage radiation therapy and the Mayo Clinic...

Posts.Content: Oh, brother. I would love to be a fly on the wall as you explain to the wife-unit that some stranger on the Internet named "ddayglo" insists that you MUST have as much sex as possible RIGHT NOW. Not that I disagree, but that should be quite an encounter. You've probably read about government panels stating that unnecessary PSA tests and biopsies lead some men to have treatments/radiation/surgeries that lead to possible impotence and incontinence. And that something other than prostate cancer will likely kill you first. What they never mention is that if something else doesn't kill you first, then prostate cancer will indeed kill you. Prior to my DaVinci surgery, my Gleason score was 3+4=7 and it was explained to me that most men under 60 have surgery and most men over 70 have radiation. Between ages 60 and 70, the patient is left to decide. At age 68, I decided on the surgery. For me, it was a no-brainer. During the same month as my diagnosis, a local university president died of prostate cancer. He was also age 68. I know I'm not as smart as a university president but, apparently, he wasn't smart enough to have a PSA test. As noted above, at your age, surgery seems to be the right choice but you would serve yourself and your family well by doing as much due diligence as possible to consider the potential for unexpected outcomes. A Gleason score of 6 means you are not in imminent danger. You have time. It's very likely that your decision will remain the same and that's fine. I wish you the best. Jim

Posts.Title: Well Crap!

Posts.Content: Hi and welcome fx: Remember the 1987 movie "Moonstruck" where Cher slaps Nicholas Cage across the face and yells at him "Snap out of it"? Well, after receiving the news that my prostate biopsy showed a 3+4=7 Gleason score, I was feeling pretty sorry for myself (I've got cancer. I'm gonna die). My uro sort of played the part of Cher when he told me that there was nothing special about my diagnosis. He said that I simply had a run-of-the-mill case that they saw every day in his office and the "cure" rate was close to 100%. Three years after the 2010 DaVinci surgery, I had a recurrence which he was equally unimpressed by. His analogy focused on a dishwasher that didn't get all of the dishes clean the first time around and salvage radiation was employed to clean the last couple of dishes. No one can guarantee the future but I must be getting a little cocky since I finish most e-mails with "I'm still here". You should be fine. Best of luck. Jim
Posts.Signature: LUNG Age: 71 -- 12/2013 - Cat Scan sees new irregular 1.8 cm nodule in right middle lobe. 3/13/14 - PET Cat Scan confirms presence of same nodule -- same size. If cancerous, the entire right middle lobe must be surgically removed. 6/13/14 - Nodule shrank by 1/3. Not cancer. Surgery cancelled. Next scan 9/14. Nodule "resolved" - gone. Posts.Title: New Diagnosis

Posts.Content: If your uncle did not want any of the "conventional" treatments for prostate cancer, I must question just how much accurate information you are receiving on the subject. For example, after being "diagnosed" -- "biopsy showed certain spread in the gland" -- unknown Gleason score -- borders on the ridiculous. If he was a Gleason 9 three years ago, he is likely terminal now. And, if he was diagnosed 3 years ago with prostate cancer, how many doctors visits has he had in those 3 years to address the issue? It sounds like he has stuck his head in the sand like an ostrich for 3 years while his PSA has gotten out of control and probably metastasized (regardless of negative cat scan and bone scan) BUT that was HIS choice. Naturopathic doctors may recommend healthy foods that DO NOTHING to cure cancer BUT that was HIS choice. Sounds like he just wants to do things HIS way. Unless he has asked you to step in and help control his health care and treatment, maybe he doesn't wish any intervention.

Posts.Title: PSA rising - any feedback much appreciated

Posts.Content: Hi Michael: Thank you for your kind words. On my lung saga, it was my adult daughter who sells body parts (currently, heart valves) who joined my wife and I in consultation with the lung surgeon who was already sharpening his scalpel. It was a risk to wait 3 months because it could have spread. But I was actually more concerned that the removal of part of a perfectly functioning lung (I kill the breathing machine every time) could lead to an overall downward health spiral. I've seen that happen in others and it's not pretty as they struggle to breathe. Just got lucky this time, I suppose. With respect to side effects from salvage radiation, I got lucky there, also, because I've never experienced any problems whatsoever. It's good to see that you are keeping vigil on your PSA, with excellent results 3 years after your surgery. Jim

Posts.Title: Questions about salvage radiation therapy and the Mayo Clinic...

Posts.Content: I had the DaVinci surgery in Nov., 2010 with a small positive margin remaining. My first post-op PSA was 0.02 that I was told was considered "undetectable", which, looking back was indeed detectable. By summer of 2013, the PSA had gradually risen to 0.16 at which time my urologist referred me to an oncology radiologist. Had 40 sessions of salvage radiotherapy ending in late Sept., 2013. Three months later, my first post-radiation PSA test was a true zero -- 0.00 -- and it has remained there. Finally, prostate cancer-free. The celebration lasted only 5 days in early January. Unfortunately, I have developed a nodule in my right lung middle lobe that is in a location difficult to biopsy so I need to have a "wedge re-section" to remove it and determine if the nodule is cancerous, while I'm still on the operating table next month. If it comes back positive, they will continue the surgery and remove my entire right middle lobe, surrounding lymph nodes and I will have chemo at a later date. Is this related to my prostate cancer? The docs say "No" but who the hell really knows for sure?
Posts.Title: Six Weeks After Da Vinci

Posts.Content: "I have to say that large part of my fear Is being able to achieve an erection once all of this is over." Welcome Hunter9: It would be unusual at your age to have PC, but anything is possible. As noted above (we don't pull any punches here), a hard-on is of little value to a corpse. Just take it one step at a time. Please let us know the outcome of your biopsy. We'll be here with you every step of the way. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Confused and scared

Posts.Content: So, "God has already healed you"? Hmmmm. About a million thoughts are rushing through my mind. My first inclination would be to ask her if she is comfortable with you removing her as the beneficiary on your life insurance. Since "God has already healed you", there should be no objection. And, if she is an RN, I'd want to know why God hasn't healed all of her other patients. Is it just because you're a nice guy? Bottom line: Just as the Founding Fathers of this country wisely decided to create a separation of church and state, the same should be true for church and hospital. Believing that "God has already healed you" in the face of definitive, scientific diagnostic tests that say otherwise is a recipe for disaster. If you plan to embrace your wife's proclamation, it may be time to fill out an organ donor card.

Posts.Title: Should I wait another 3 months for a third PSA test?

Posts.Content: Why use the ultrasensitive test if it does not correlate to a specific treatment regimen? Well, one reason would be that if you follow the slow progression of a biochemical recurrence, as I did (below), once the PSA reached 0.1, I was mentally prepared for the need to take action via salvage radiation. If you are kept completely in the dark with a steady reading of <0.1, there is a tendency to believe all is well when, if fact, it may not be so. And that sudden awakening to a BCR can be crushing to some patients who may have thought they were done with prostate cancer forever. Given the choice, I would always want to have too much information, rather than not enough.

Posts.Title: PSA anxiety again....

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by jlynn6864 I realize it is major surgery. Sorry if I ask stupid questions. Dr. Davis was great but as for the nurses, they weren't wealthy with information on what to expect and if they did try to give us any information most of them had a heavy accent that was extremely hard to understand. I've found great information on this site and if I repeat something that was already mentioned, please forgive me. I just want to give my husband the best possible care I can. Hi jlynn: The only stupid question is the one not asked. And don't be concerned about repeating a question. Most men are Neanderthals and without the help of wives like you and significant others, we would have never made it past the evolutionary stage. One suggestion (please don't be offended): when you start a new thread, many readers don't know what has transpired up to that point, so adding new posts to an existing thread is sometimes helpful. Best of luck and get ready to have a big celebration after his catheter removal. Jim

Posts.Title: Post-op question

Posts.Content: Michael: Your observations are mirrored by my beliefs regarding DREs -- but.... even after a prostatectomy six years ago, even after 40 sessions of salvage radiation three years ago, my uro continues to perform annual DREs. Seriously. I thought it was strange and asked him about it. He said it's necessary to try to detect "rough edges" around the prostate bed that once housed the prostate. My suspicion is that he lost his watch and is checking to see if he left it in my cavity during surgery. Jim

Posts.Title: Biopsy Results in, now what?

Posts.Content: My uro is one of nine urologists in a group. He tells me that (with minimal exceptions) the ENTIRE group adheres to the following prostate cancer treatment recommendations: Under age 60: Surgery Between ages 60 and 70: Patient decides between surgery and radiation Age 70 and older: Radiation While this doesn't answer your specific inquiry, there is something to be learned here: If a patient starts to over-think an issue where most signs point in one direction, then he could easily find himself in a much worse quandary than that which he fears. There is a reason why doctors go to school for many years to learn a medical specialty -- and that's to get it right. If a patient wants to go zig while the rest of the medical community is going zag, he does so at his own risk. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: surgery vs. radiation for younger patients

Posts.Content: My uro is one of nine urologists in a group. He tells me that (with minimal exceptions) the ENTIRE group adheres to the following prostate cancer treatment recommendations: Under age 60: Surgery Between ages 60 and 70: Patient decides between surgery and radiation Age 70 and older: Radiation While this doesn't answer your specific inquiry, there is something to be learned here: If a patient starts to over-think an issue where most signs point in one direction, then he could easily find himself in a much worse quandary than that which he fears. There is a reason why doctors go to school for many years to learn a medical specialty -- and that's to get it right. If a patient wants to go zig while the rest of the medical community is going zag, he does so at his own risk. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: surgery vs. radiation for younger patients

Posts.Content: Welcome JJ: It appears that you have done an exhaustive study on the subject of incontinence. As you have found, virtually every patient is different. One poster recently mentioned that he was completely dry one week after the removal of the catheter. I wish I could give you a specific date that you would see an end to the problem but I can only share my uro's experiences. He said that, on average, his patients were dry at the end of two months. Whether I was guided by that statement, I'll never know but on exactly the 60th day after my surgery, I entered the Land of the Dry and remained there to this day. And while he encourages the use of Kegels, as do nearly all doctors and publications on the subject, my doc said that continence would indeed return with or without the use of Kegels. Kegels will just shorten the time needed to return to normal. It sounds like you are very fortunate to have a job with the flexibility to remain in the healing mode for an extended period of time. Due to the demands of your job, my only suggestion would be to maximize the time before returning to work. And, at age 62, I'll bet you are looking forward to the day when you don't have to work grueling 12-hour shifts. I was lucky to snag an early retirement program at age 53 and I'm now entering my 21st year of retirement. If I can live just 5 more years, I will have collected a pension check longer than I worked for the organization and that's my goal. All the best to you, Jim

Posts.Title: Ductal adenocarcinoma of the prostate

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Steve2017 Seems to me, all currently available treatments are from the caveman era. It's pretty disappointing. And then it seems you have to do a coin flip to choose the doctor that you want to mutilate or burn you. How sick is that. Sorry to be so frank in my opinion. I'm ready to deal with the after effects so I'll be flipping the coin soon. Time to move on to the rest of my life. I'm realizing that I have to develop a sense of humor to trudge through this mess to get to the GOOD SIDE. I guess comedy and tragedy really are two heads of the same coin. Steve: There is another way of looking at things. While you wear your "Why me?" hat, take 5 or 10 minutes and read the posts on the pancreatic cancer forum on this website. Then, come back here and bend all the way over and kiss your lucky ass that you have prostate cancer with nearly a 100% survival rate and NOT pancreatic cancer with an average 6% five-year survival rate. Jim

Posts.Title: Post Op Rant

Posts.Content: Hi Carol: It was completely unfair of you to post that link. Once I started reading, I couldn't stop until I reached the end. If it had been in book form, it would have reeled me in like a barracuda for at least 3 days straight. You're a wonderful writer. And the active surveillance you and your husband chose is fine, but in all of your text, I saw nothing regarding Tom's Gleason score. Usually, depending on that crucial number, AS relates well to a Gleason 6, not so much to Gleason 7 or higher. And, forgive me, but the idea that AS is beneficial and somehow contributes to scientific research is a bit of a stretch. In my view (slanted as it is), contributions to science are best left to lab rats. If a car is broken and has problem processing fuel through the engine, we fix it. Ergo, if a human is broken, I'm a great believer that he should be fixed (not in the neutered sense). As you may have read on this thread before stepping forward, there are people on this site who adamantly promote surgery, others are supportive of radiation and we also have a rabid contingent of brachytherapy zealots. All of those procedures, as you have probably already researched, have pros and cons, and at the same time are maddeningly nearly equally effective. I look forward to your future comments, particularly because I have already read your pre-novel. Jim

Posts.Title: Diary of a Prostate Cancer Wife

Posts.Content: Aaron: While I have no medical degree, based upon my knowledge of prostate cancer, at age 20, you have as much chance of having PC as you have of walking down the street and being hit in the head with a falling grand piano. It may be prostatitis, an infection of the prostate. A urologist should be able to quickly handle the problem. In the meanwhile, I would suggest that you don't "handle" it yourself. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Terrified That I Have Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Maybe I'm a little dense but since HIFU is localized ultrasound directed at a specific site, how can a patient know if there is any residual cancer remaining in the prostate that might rear its ugly head at some later time? Is that a gamble that many people want to take? At least with surgery, you know that anything remaining in the prostate can't hurt you if the prostate itself is no longer contained in your body. Granted risk would still remain with positive margins, metastasis, etc., as I discovered when my PC returned 3 years after DaVinci.

Posts.Content: Hi Steve: As someone who has completed 40 sessions of salvage radiation, I can attest to two things: First, it was a piece of cake -- for me, a little fatigue at the end -- nothing more. Secondly, with all due respect to Michael's travelogue of Boston sights (and I never disagree with Michael), I encourage you to Google the benefits of Centerfolds Boston, located on LaGrange Street, one of the highest rated strip clubs in Boston. It has 242 online reviews of which 88% are positive. With all of the crap that we have had to go through, you deserve to treat yourself to a lap dance. Of course, in the absence of a medical degree, I cannot attest to any improvement other than a 10-minute smile on your face. Wishing you the best -- always, Jim

Posts.Title: New Diagnosis

Posts.Content: Welcome Flags: I'm in agreement with Chuck. If you research the specific reasons listed to begin treatment with ADT followed by radiation, your case doesn't seem to fit the mold. Yes, this thread tends to skew toward recommending surgery but the ADT then EBRT normally goes hand-in-hand with a large tumor for the purpose of reducing same prior to radiation, a more aggressive strain of PC and/or if accompanied by modest metastasis. Again, none of us are medical professionals -- we can only share our personal experiences and offer support, so you need to weigh the validity of anything that I or the other contributors recommend. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: About to make the decision

Posts.Content: Welcome Flags: I'm in agreement with Chuck. If you research the specific reasons listed to begin treatment with ADT followed by radiation, your case doesn't seem to fit the mold. Yes, this thread tends to skew toward recommending surgery but the ADT then EBRT normally goes hand-in-hand with a large tumor for the purpose of reducing same prior to radiation, a more aggressive strain of PC and/or if accompanied by modest metastasis. Again, none of us are medical professionals -- we can only share our personal experiences and offer support, so you need to weigh the validity of anything that I or the other contributors recommend. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Not sure I know where I am going

Posts.Content: If your uncle did not want any of the "conventional" treatments for prostate cancer, I must question just how much accurate information you are receiving on the subject. For example, after being "diagnosed" -- "biopsy showed certain spread in the gland" -- unknown Gleason score -- borders on the ridiculous. If he was a Gleason 9 three years ago, he is likely terminal now. And, if he was diagnosed 3 years ago with prostate cancer, how many doctors visits has he had in those 3 years to address the issue? It sounds like he has stuck his head in the sand like an ostrich for 3 years while his PSA has gotten out of control and probably metastasized (regardless of negative cat scan and bone scan) BUT that was HIS choice. Naturopathic doctors may recommend healthy foods that DO NOTHING to cure cancer BUT that was HIS choice. Sounds like he just wants to do things HIS way. Unless he has asked you to step in and help control his health care and treatment, maybe he doesn't wish any intervention.
