Posts.Title: Not sure I know where I am going

Posts.Content: Joey: You didn't do anything wrong. Having your own thread just helps others to focus on your particular concerns. We're just a bunch of strangers from around the world who have had similar experiences and whose backgrounds may serve to aid each other, albeit in a non-medical expert environment. Before I retired, 300 people reported to me. Now, I can't get the dog to come in out of the rain. The idea of joining a forum or support group had always been foreign to me. I was always a leader, rarely a follower. "They" were just people who sat around saying "Oh, woe is me" and lamenting their misfortune. How wrong I was -- at least with respect to this group. With the exception of only a few isolated incidents, I have seen nothing but caring and compassion and a true desire to be of benefit to others, if possible. This mindset is personified by our esteemed moderator, Chuck, who tirelessly maintains an even-keel approach in dealing with so many different personalities. But, overall, it's just people helping people. Jim

Posts.Title: Should I Delay PSA Test After Taking a Long Hike?

Posts.Content: Welcome PC: Your recurrence at 10 years is the longest post-surgery period that I have seen. Mine was three years prior to implementing salvage radiation. You have done an excellent job of researching your options. On the one hand, I find it interesting that both radiologists recommend their modality and the urologists say to pass at this time. So, that would leave most guys scratching their heads -- "What to do?" Gleason 6, notwithstanding the mantra that "No one ever dies from Gleason 6", with a current PSA of 0.20, it seems obvious that something is going on -- and that's not good. You've made it this far by staying on top of the problem. It would be a damn shame to guess wrong now with regard to treatment versus no treatment. Given the same circumstances, I'm pretty certain that I would opt for the SR, probably as soon as possible by using the logic that there is no obvious benefit to waiting. In fact, I would have started to get zapped at 0.1. I found SR to be a piece of cake -- no side effects whatsoever except some slight fatigue toward the end of treatment. Others have experienced side effects. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Surgeons at Johns Hopkins

Posts.Content: Hi Nick: Your question, as ASAdvocate notes, is certainly valid. At 4 weeks post-surgery, your PSA is likely to have decreased but may not yet reflect a true lowest-possible reading. In looking back over many post-surgery PSA tests, a reading at the three-month mark is usually more indicative of accuracy. However, if you come up with a 0.00 at the 4-week test, disregard all of the above. Jim

Posts.Title: Follow up Blood Test Too Soon?

Posts.Content: Hi Carol: It was completely unfair of you to post that link. Once I started reading, I couldn't stop until I reached the end. If it had been in book form, it would have reeled me in like a barracuda for at least 3 days straight. You're a wonderful writer. And the active surveillance you and your husband chose is fine, but in all of your text, I saw nothing regarding Tom's Gleason score. Usually, depending on that crucial number, AS relates well to a Gleason 6, not so much to Gleason 7 or higher. And, forgive me, but the idea that AS is beneficial and somehow contributes to scientific research is a bit of a stretch. In my view (slanted as it is), contributions to science are best left to lab rats. If a car is broken and has problem processing fuel through the engine, we fix it. Ergo, if a human is broken, I'm a great believer that he should be fixed (not in the neutered sense). As you may have read on this thread before stepping forward, there are people on this site who adamantly promote surgery, others are supportive of radiation and we also have a rabid contingent of brachytherapy zealots. All of those procedures, as you have probably already researched, have pros and cons, and at the same time are maddeningly nearly equally effective. I look forward to your future comments, particularly because I have already read your pre-novel. Jim

Posts.Title: It's Back

Posts.Content: Charlie: Since less than 3 weeks have passed after your surgery, even though you may feel great, be sure to recognize that you are still in the healing mode. Walking is fine but no heavy lifting or exertion that might undo internal stitching. We are all just guys and caregivers who have been through the same thing that you have, so while we can't give medical advice, we can sometimes help others to avoid some of the pitfalls we encountered. For example, it's unfortunate that you didn't find us sooner as we would have never let you go to have the catheter removed without bringing protective guards and/or underwear. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Greetings

Posts.Content: Hi Now What?: I notice that your husband's signature path report includes the term "PC contained". Does that confirm there were no positive margins? We have some forum brothers who believe that a PSA of 0.03 post-surgery is evidence of a biochemical recurrence. Twenty years ago, a BCR was viewed as occurring at 0.5. Ten years ago, that number was 0.2. Four years ago when I experienced the PSA numbers creeping up post-surgery, I decided at 0.11 to move ahead with salvage radiation. So far, so good. Forty sessions - a piece of cake - just a little fatigue toward the end. If his doctor feels that a PSA every three months is reasonable, that sounds OK. However, just as I watched my PSA rise post-surgery and was prepared to act, you may want to ask his doctor at what "trigger" point he would recommend moving forward with salvage radiation. As "Another" states, sooner has been proven better that later. The only remaining question is "How soon". And, more importantly, whether you agree or not. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Udate and question

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by njstol01 Do you think it should be higher or lower? If lower, might as well just irradiate all RP patients just'cause? No, not "just 'cause". The other criteria is the identification of a "trend". If you observe a progressive increase in the PSA number, that is a contributing factor to deciding whether to proceed with post-surgery follow-up treatment. There may not be current universal acceptance of a finite PSA number which should trigger a move toward salvage radiation. However, once a clear-cut PSA trend is identified in an upward trajectory, rarely will it ever return to a 0.00 reading. If I had it to do over again, I would have acted before my post-surgery PSA reached 0.1 once I saw the upward trend. But I don't know whether Medicare would have approved the $240,000 billing charge prior to 0.1. Nor do I know what minimal PSA number that will gain current approval for payment by Medicare or insurance companies for salvage radiation.

Posts.Title: Udate and question

Posts.Content: Maybe I'm a little dense but since HIFU is localized ultrasound directed at a specific site, how can a patient know if there is any residual cancer remaining in the prostate that might rear its ugly head at some later time? Is that a gamble that many people want to take? At least with surgery, you know that anything remaining in the prostate can't hurt you if the prostate itself is no longer contained in your body. Granted risk would still remain with positive margins, metastasis, etc., as I discovered when my PC returned 3 years after DaVinci.

Posts.Title: HIFU Treatment Receives FDA Approval

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by LILDOG At what psa level is salvage radiation advised ? Does insurance usually pay when a patient is not at the recurrence level ( 0.2 and rising ) ? Is salvage radiation advised with such low levels of psa even 0.055 to keep from overtreating a patient ? Lildog: Allen and I are recipients of salvage radiotherapy following a radical prostatectomy. Don't know your history but I assume you also have had a RP. In answer to your question as to what PSA level that SR is advised, it seems to deviate among urologists with the overall belief that sooner is better than later. Again, Allen and I fall into that category. As recently as five years ago, some uros were waiting until the PSA reached 0.5 before recommending SR but I think that notion has faded in favor of a number closer to 0.2. My decision was made at 0.11 (0.16 just before SR) and as you can see from my history that has worked out well (at least for now -- no one knows what the future holds). While your numbers are still quite low, I would never suggest that they are too low to take action. As far as insurance, Medicare approved me at 0.16 but I can't offer any knowledge on the actions of other insurers. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Changed labs big difference in ultra sensitive psa results !!!!

Posts.Content: For those with the fortitude to adhere to a healthy diet, I applaud you. For myself, my diet over the last 45 years has remained the same (no kidding): Morning: Two glazed donuts and a can of Pepsi (the sugar intake helps the bones and joints from locking up and atrophying). Late afternoon: one full meal -- usually meat and potatoes. Absolutely zero exercise which I consider a total waste on my time. Over the last 35 years, my weight has remained within a 5-lb range of 170 pounds, ideal for my height and body mass. People can devote themselves to hours of exercise every day for decades and then step off a curb and get hit by a truck and killed. All of their exercise hours could have been devoted to other pursuits, instead. Different strokes for different folks. Enjoy life. Works for me and I'm still here. Jim

Posts.Title: Multiple news items about a study regarding diet and PCa outcomes.

Posts.Content: Welcome brake: Ready2Fight is highly accurate in describing the best way to absorb the initial shock. It's the way that most engineers (I'm not one) analyze a major problem and work toward a solution which is to first break things down into smaller components. The results of the full-body bone scan on Monday will be most helpful because it will assist in being able to rule-in or rule-out certain methodologies in proceeding with treatment. And, as you have likely learned, some form of treatment or combination of treatments will be needed with his Gleason 8 diagnosis. No one here will sugarcoat the fact that G8 is an aggressive form of prostate cancer. But there is absolutely no reason to feel "hopeless". If your husband had to have cancer, this is the one he wants. Prostate cancer has very high survival rates and even in a worst case scenario, if a "cure" is not possible, the number of treatments available will often allow for a full life span. That's not to be taken lightly as, for example, a pancreatic cancer patient is looking at an average 6% five-year survival rate following diagnosis. Please let us know the results of the bone scan. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Post-op question

Posts.Content: I understand your frustration but your reference to passing blood for weeks is far from the norm. As mentioned by others, I didn't experience any pain (discomfort, yes) but no pain and no bleeding at all. Try to think about it this way (and repeat after me): It's a diagnostic test -- it's only a diagnostic test, it's not open-heart surgery. You can do it. There's nothing special about us and we did it. Plus it has the benefit of sending each of us on a journey that, in some cases, may save our lives. This is one of only a few cancers that, if treated early, is nearly 100% curable. Many other cancers are found too late. Anxiety issues or not, this is an opportunity that should not be squandered. When you re-schedule with this doctor (who may have been dealing with an emergency) or some other doctor, explain to the staff that your level of anxiety regarding the biopsy needs to be addressed to avoid a repeat of your first experience. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: biopsy

Posts.Content: Hi: Otago makes an excellent point on learning how many surgeries are performed annually by the operating physician. My DaVinci robotic surgery was in 11/2010 at age 68. I was quite apprehensive but surgery went smoothly and I was walking the hospital corridors just a few hours after the operation. After arriving at home following surgery, I had a portable catheter for 8 days. It was my first experience with a catheter and, while there was absolutely no pain involved, I found it to be challenging. I knew in advance that it would be necessary but I just had a hard time mentally wrapping my mind around the fact that everywhere I went, the catheter went also. I found that sleeping with the catheter was awkward. Since I was older, I asked for and received visits from home health aides every couple of days who monitored my vital signs and to try to catch anything unexpected, like an infection. No problems ever developed. For a period of about two months, you will likely need pads, similar to the brand name "Depends", to deal with leakage which will diminish over time. At two months following surgery, I was completely dry. As mentioned elsewhere on this thread, your Keagel exercises should be closely adhered to. I read and re-read my discharge instructions following surgery and virtually everything that was stated came through like clockwork for me. So, if I had to categorize the recovery period, I had no surprises and can confirm that the two month recovery period was considered to be textbook. Many people, I'm sure, travel with the smaller catheter -- even go to work -- but since I was retired I simply avoided that issue for the 8 days mentioned. Jim

Posts.Title: Psa of 0.1 after op at 6 months no change, at 9 months number is 0.8.

Posts.Content: Let me see if I understand this post correctly. Walnut is willing to surrender one thousand lives in order to avoid some anxiety!! WHAT??? Would anyone reading this post volunteer to be among the 1,000 whose lives or the lives of loved ones would be lost? Let's take this a step further mathematically: The last U.S. census of 2010 showed a population of over 308 million citizens. Of that number, about half are male (150 million). Of the 150 million men, about 30% are 55 or older (roughly 45 million). Assuming this is Day One of the PSA era, if you could save one life in every 1,000 PSA tests, then 45 million PSA tests would hypothetically result in the saving of 45,000 lives. Do we surrender 45,000 lives to avoid "anxiety" in others? Is this even a valid argument? I would trade unlimited "anxiety" for the saving of ONE LIFE, let alone 45,000 lives saved.

Posts.Title: So, what do you think about this?

Posts.Content: "I am writing this blog to warn you not to take a biopsy if at all possible. I have never seen anything as destructive to physical and mental health". Welcome Steve: It is most unfortunate that you have endured such a difficult experience following a prostate biopsy. However, it is important that you recognize that this is a rare and unusual outcome and could be misleading to new patients viewing this website. Currently, a biopsy is the only methodology that can confirm the presence of cancer. The lives of millions of patients depend of knowing the results of such biopsies, so that they can move forward with treatment, if warranted. As such, your recommendation to not undergo a biopsy due to your travails is equivalent to throwing out the baby with the bath water and IMHO is inappropriate. I hope your find a speedy resolution to the symptoms you describe. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Need to decide - what would you do and why did you choose it?

Posts.Content: So often you hear that there is no need to act on the discovery of prostate cancer because "...it's likely something else will kill you first". But prostate cancer is the second leading cause of cancer deaths among men in the U.S. (estimated 29,480 deaths in 2014). That's a pretty impressive number. If you have the opportunity to catch it early and get rid of it, it just seems logical that you would want to do that. Because, as you get older, if nothing else DOES kill you first, then the prostate cancer absolutely will be your demise. If I had it to do over again, I would LEAP onto the operating table. Well, at my age, it would be more of a semi-leap.

Posts.Title: How do you process all the information?

Posts.Content: Charlie: Since less than 3 weeks have passed after your surgery, even though you may feel great, be sure to recognize that you are still in the healing mode. Walking is fine but no heavy lifting or exertion that might undo internal stitching. We are all just guys and caregivers who have been through the same thing that you have, so while we can't give medical advice, we can sometimes help others to avoid some of the pitfalls we encountered. For example, it's unfortunate that you didn't find us sooner as we would have never let you go to have the catheter removed without bringing protective guards and/or underwear. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Greetings

Posts.Content: Hi Now What?: I notice that your husband's signature path report includes the term "PC contained". Does that confirm there were no positive margins? We have some forum brothers who believe that a PSA of 0.03 post-surgery is evidence of a biochemical recurrence. Twenty years ago, a BCR was viewed as occurring at 0.5. Ten years ago, that number was 0.2. Four years ago when I experienced the PSA numbers creeping up post-surgery, I decided at 0.11 to move ahead with salvage radiation. So far, so good. Forty sessions - a piece of cake - just a little fatigue toward the end. If his doctor feels that a PSA every three months is reasonable, that sounds OK. However, just as I watched my PSA rise post-surgery and was prepared to act, you may want to ask his doctor at what "trigger" point he would recommend moving forward with salvage radiation. As "Another" states, sooner has been proven better that later. The only remaining question is "How soon". And, more importantly, whether you agree or not. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Udate and question

Posts.Content: Hi Nick: Your question, as ASAdvocate notes, is certainly valid. At 4 weeks post-surgery, your PSA is likely to have decreased but may not yet reflect a true lowest-possible reading. In looking back over many post-surgery PSA tests, a reading at the three-month mark is usually more indicative of accuracy. However, if you come up with a 0.00 at the 4-week test, disregard all of the above. Jim

Posts.Title: Follow up Blood Test Too Soon?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by njstol01 Do you think it should be higher or lower? If lower, might as well just irradiate all RP patients just'cause? No, not "just 'cause". The other criteria is the identification of a "trend". If you observe a progressive increase in the PSA number, that is a contributing factor to deciding whether to proceed with post-surgery follow-up treatment. There may not be current universal acceptance of a finite PSA number which should trigger a move toward salvage radiation. However, once a clear-cut PSA trend is identified in an upward trajectory, rarely will it ever return to a 0.00 reading. If I had it to do over again, I would have acted before my post-surgery PSA reached 0.1 once I saw the upward trend. But I don't know whether Medicare would have approved the $240,000 billing charge prior to 0.1. Nor do I know what minimal PSA number that will gain current approval for payment by Medicare or insurance companies for salvage radiation.

Posts.Title: Udate and question

Posts.Content: "If you screen men [aged 55 to 69] based on the protocol in those trials, every two to four years for 13 years, five out of 1,000 will die from prostate cancer. If you don't screen, six out of 1,000 men will die from prostate cancer," Bell said. "So the reduction in prostate cancer mortality is one in 1,000 or about 0.1 per cent." This figure of only 1 in 1,000 lives saved by PSA tests is the same ratio cited in the U.S. task force report. Let's say the numbers are correct (which I don't really believe, but let's say they are) Now, I may not be the world's great mathematician, but that means for every one million PSA tests performed, one thousand lives will be saved. Please forgive my ignorance, perhaps I'm missing something, but isn't the saving of ONE THOUSAND LIVES a good thing?

Posts.Title: So, what do you think about this?

Posts.Content: Let me see if I understand this post correctly. Walnut is willing to surrender one thousand lives in order to avoid some anxiety!! WHAT??? Would anyone reading this post volunteer to be among the 1,000 whose lives or the lives of loved ones would be lost? Let's take this a step further mathematically: The last U.S. census of 2010 showed a population of over 308 million citizens. Of that number, about half are male (150 million). Of the 150 million men, about 30% are 55 or older (roughly 45 million). Assuming this is Day One of the PSA era, if you could save one life in every 1,000 PSA tests, then 45 million PSA tests would hypothetically result in the saving of 45,000 lives. Do we surrender 45,000 lives to avoid "anxiety" in others? Is this even a valid argument? I would trade unlimited "anxiety" for the saving of ONE LIFE, let alone 45,000 lives saved.

Posts.Title: So, what do you think about this?

Posts.Content: "If you screen men [aged 55 to 69] based on the protocol in those trials, every two to four years for 13 years, five out of 1,000 will die from prostate cancer. If you don't screen, six out of 1,000 men will die from prostate cancer," Bell said. "So the reduction in prostate cancer mortality is one in 1,000 or about 0.1 per cent." This figure of only 1 in 1,000 lives saved by PSA tests is the same ratio cited in the U.S. task force report. Let's say the numbers are correct (which I don't really believe, but let's say they are) Now, I may not be the world's great mathematician, but that means for every one million PSA tests performed, one thousand lives will be saved. Please forgive my ignorance, perhaps I'm missing something, but isn't the saving of ONE THOUSAND LIVES a good thing?

Posts.Content: And, I would add, if possible, try to book with Southwest Airlines (I know - they have limited destinations) because Southwest does not charge for ticket changes which now average $200 per flight re-booked. Also, the first two bags fly for free on Southwest, saving about $120 a person round-trip. Another option: Check the price of a "refundable ticket", which is more expensive than a non-refundable ticket, BUT it will return ALL of your money if you cancel, whereas travel insurance will cost a premium. Sorry to disagree with shaww, but on virtually ALL airlines, you don't need to check cancellation policies on a "refundable" ticket because there are none. You may cancel at any time prior to the flight and receive a FULL refund without providing any reason for cancelling.

Posts.Title: An Essay on Penis Shortening.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by white08gt sorry to hear the bad news, I was almost there myself. I was staged T3b with positive margins, the HT will suppress the cancer. seems a little early to me to start SRT, my Urologist waited 6 months to make sure I was healed and not incontinent. I know he knows more than me but their is a chance the SRT will clean up anything left. from what I have read they likw to wait a full year before SRT or at least wait to see the PSA doubling time. there alot more on hear that have more knowledge than me that will chime in. I was given a 50/50 chance of beating this, at the least keeping it under control for a long time. your post PSA will tell a lot, I had a steady rise from 0.06 to 0.11 in 4 months time. started my HT at the end of the 4th month and took about 2 months to meet with Radiology Oncologist to schedule my SRT. your husbands age and PSA before surgery will help plus what type surgery? hope for the best Hi White: This quote from the Prostate Cancer Foundation defines the difference between salvage radiotherapy and adjuvant radiotherapy: In some cases, particularly if the tumor was considered high-grade and therefore at greater risk of spreading to the surrounding areas, your doctor might decide to initiate radiation therapy right after you’ve healed from your surgery. This approach, known as adjuvant therapy, typically starts about six weeks after surgery, and is unrelated to "salvage" radiation therapy that is administered if the PSA begins to rise. Jim

Posts.Title: Not what we expected

Posts.Content: Welcome Jason: In No Limit Texas Hold "Em poker, a pair of Queens versus a player holding Ace-King is considered a "classic race". The Queens are favored 55%-45% pre-flop but because the hands are so close in odds, it is considered a coin flip -- could go either way. With your erratic PSA pathway complicated by your family history, the question of whether to have a biopsy at age 41 becomes a similar coin flip. You can postpone it but indications are that you are merely delaying the inevitable. While ASAdvocate correctly points out that your father's passing from an aggressive form of prostate cancer does not increase the likelihood that such a fate awaits you, neither does it absolve you of such a potential diagnosis. While there are risks associated with a biopsy, it remains the only way to confirm a diagnosis of cancer. The key word there is "diagnosis" since a biopsy is nothing more than a diagnostic test that may or may not provide you with helpful information. It is then up to you to decide what to do with the info and how to proceed. If it was me, I wouldn't dick around with the uncertainty. I'd get the biopsy with the caveat that I tend to be pro-biopsy. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Thoughts on high and bouncing PSA

Posts.Content: Welcome Rob: I concur with "Another" that you are VERY fortunate to have discovered this diagnosis at age 44. Since the other forum brothers have addressed the primary issues (as in focus on mortality rather than erections), I note that you have spoken only about "open" radical prostatectomy. Is that because where you reside there is no facility with a robotic option available? Open surgery was the gold standard for prostatectomies for decades but with the advent of the DaVinci robotic method, there is less potential for complications and blood loss and a quicker, less painful path to full recovery. If given the surgical choice, I would always opt for the robotic mode. On the radiation side, Cyberknife may sound like a "quick fix" but if you do a search of patient satisfaction surveys following PC treatment, Cyberknife is nearly always at the bottom of the listings as the massive doses of radiation sometimes leave patients with painful burns through the rectal area that may last for years (I personally know two such patients). A Gleason 6 diagnosis may lead many to a sense of relief but the high degree of involvement of the cores and the observation of capsular abutment causes me to agree with Pratoman that something more potent may be lurking. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Content: If $1,200 is left unpaid for a PET Scan by Medicare, perhaps it's time to consider a Medicare Supplemental (Medigap) Policy. In addition to the list below, in the last 8 years, I've had spine surgery and two major surgeries to remove kidney stones. With a Medigap policy, I never filled out a form, never paid a penny in co-pays or deductibles. And, unlike the dreaded Medicare Advantage that requires you to accept a limited network of doctors and hospitals accompanied by high co-pays and deductibles, with original Medicare and a Medigap policy you can go to any doctor and any hospital in the country that accepts Medicare.

Posts.Title: Update - Highlander

Posts.Content: Hi RAD (hello also from Philly burbs): Sorry to hear of your situation, particularly the depression aspect. In particular, I note your listing of "major depression" in 2015, apparently related to hypogonadism. While I have no personal history in this area, my first suggestion would be to step back and look at the current big picture. At age 65, you are just three weeks away from having robotic surgery with a downgraded post-surgery pathology report, which for many people would be a cause for celebration, not depression. A positive margin, for most patients means virtually nothing. In your case, however, it interacts negatively with your desire to focus on your testosterone for various reasons. With all due respect, while certainly not an ideal situation, you have received the necessary treatment needed to preserve your continued existence. And that by itself, for a lot of patients, is reason enough to be thankful that you will not be among the 30,000 men who die each and every year in the U.S. from this horrible disease. To focus so greatly on the libido aspect of your case misses the point that a dead man has no need for a hard-on. If you pose the question to your significant other as to which of the two choices -- assuming only one choice can be fulfilled -- she would rather have, I feel confident that her vote would be for you to remain with us. Please keep in mind that your situation is not isolated. You are not alone -- many of us have ED problems but we are thankful to still be here. Yes, there are numerous options (injections, pumps, etc.) but each one is fighting a single battle in a war that you have already won. Your loved ones still have you to embrace and cherish. That, in itself, is enough for many people. I realize that I'm just one silly old man trying to reason with you but I'll be glad to buy you a beer and bore you to tears by telling you how I have found new meaning late in life by becoming a television poker semi-celebrity, winning major poker tournaments at ages 72, 73 and, just 11 days ago, at age 74. In August, I fly to Los Angeles on an all-expenses-paid package to play in a $3 million poker tournament. https://www.dropbox.com/s/2tgsaqzh4a...ience.mp4?dl=0 Each of us have the ability to find ways to meaningful enjoyment. All the best to you, Sir, Jim

Posts.Title: Resuming TRT after RP with positive margin?

Posts.Content: Welcome PC: Your recurrence at 10 years is the longest post-surgery period that I have seen. Mine was three years prior to implementing salvage radiation. You have done an excellent job of researching your options. On the one hand, I find it interesting that both radiologists recommend their modality and the urologists say to pass at this time. So, that would leave most guys scratching their heads -- "What to do?" Gleason 6, notwithstanding the mantra that "No one ever dies from Gleason 6", with a current PSA of 0.20, it seems obvious that something is going on -- and that's not good. You've made it this far by staying on top of the problem. It would be a damn shame to guess wrong now with regard to treatment versus no treatment. Given the same circumstances, I'm pretty certain that I would opt for the SR, probably as soon as possible by using the logic that there is no obvious benefit to waiting. In fact, I would have started to get zapped at 0.1. I found SR to be a piece of cake -- no side effects whatsoever except some slight fatigue toward the end of treatment. Others have experienced side effects. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: It's Back

Posts.Content: Welcome Flags: I'm in agreement with Chuck. If you research the specific reasons listed to begin treatment with ADT followed by radiation, your case doesn't seem to fit the mold. Yes, this thread tends to skew toward recommending surgery but the ADT then EBRT normally goes hand-in-hand with a large tumor for the purpose of reducing same prior to radiation, a more aggressive strain of PC and/or if accompanied by modest metastasis. Again, none of us are medical professionals -- we can only share our personal experiences and offer support, so you need to weigh the validity of anything that I or the other contributors recommend. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: A few more days until surgery

Posts.Content: Welcome JJ: It appears that you have done an exhaustive study on the subject of incontinence. As you have found, virtually every patient is different. One poster recently mentioned that he was completely dry one week after the removal of the catheter. I wish I could give you a specific date that you would see an end to the problem but I can only share my uro's experiences. He said that, on average, his patients were dry at the end of two months. Whether I was guided by that statement, I'll never know but on exactly the 60th day after my surgery, I entered the Land of the Dry and remained there to this day. And while he encourages the use of Kegels, as do nearly all doctors and publications on the subject, my doc said that continence would indeed return with or without the use of Kegels. Kegels will just shorten the time needed to return to normal. It sounds like you are very fortunate to have a job with the flexibility to remain in the healing mode for an extended period of time. Due to the demands of your job, my only suggestion would be to maximize the time before returning to work. And, at age 62, I'll bet you are looking forward to the day when you don't have to work grueling 12-hour shifts. I was lucky to snag an early retirement program at age 53 and I'm now entering my 21st year of retirement. If I can live just 5 more years, I will have collected a pension check longer than I worked for the organization and that's my goal. All the best to you, Jim

Posts.Title: undecided

Posts.Content: While I will admit to having no expertise in this area, I see blinking neon lights if the broad medical community rejects this treatment for prostate cancer survivors. The fact that it is sometimes used on "advanced" cancer patients also brings red flags because if their future is limited, it simply may not matter. I can't imagine surviving prostate cancer only to voluntarily put oneself at risk once again. Just one guy's opinion.

Posts.Title: Testosterone injections after the treatments

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Sw1218 what if the apifiny results place me in the low risk category, should i still request the 3T MRI? Since the Apifiny test was only recently made available, there is no real-time history of its accuracy or its value to patients. And it is not a stand-alone test, merely a supplement to the PSA results. For that reason, I would be inclined to not give a lot of weight to the Apifiny test when deciding how to proceed. On the other hand, a 3T MRI is a respected definitive tool that can potentially identify specific points of interest in your prostate. Your age indicates a low likelihood of PC but anything is possible. You may simply be suffering from chronic prostatitis as identified nearly 2 years ago. As noted, if your insurance covers the 3T MRI, that would likely be my first choice to avoid an unnecessary biopsy. Good luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Irreversible Electroporation; surgery; radiation

Posts.Content: Your patience is beyond saintly. If a doctor told me that he would not call with negative results, only if something showed up, it would drive me crazy, not knowing if everything is OK or whether he didn't get around to reading the results yet. He works for you. You get to tell him what results you want. And that you want those results as soon as they become available. If you can stand the wait until September 15th, it's not up to me to say anything -- bite my tongue. BUT, if I wanted those results, I would be calling his office twice a day (morning and afternoon) to learn if they had arrived yet. Best of luck to your Dad and you. Jim

Posts.Title: Just feel comfort in posting here

Posts.Content: Koz: It's good to prepare for surgery by doing your Kegels; however, you should take a deep breath and realize that too much intensity devoted to a single issue may be counter-productive. Try to relax. Gleason 6 is virtually never life-threatening. Here's a tip from my uro: after surgery, you will regain full function even if you never did a single Kegel in your lifetime. You will simply regain function quicker if you do. Try to put everything in perspective and -- I repeat -- try to relax. Millions of men have gone through this process and millions more will follow. We're still here and you will be, too.

Posts.Title: Finished SRT

Posts.Content: OK. I've got this. Numbers relating to life expectancy depend on many variables. For example, an Internet search of the current life expectancy of ALL males currently living in the United States is 74.4 years. I ran the numbers and I am good only until March 24th. In 1942, the year I was born, male life expectancy was 69.6 years. However, if you have ALREADY reached age 65 or older, your life expectancy is increased to 83.2 years. So, you can make the numbers fit any scenario you want.

Posts.Title: A few more days until surgery

Posts.Content: OK. I've got this. Numbers relating to life expectancy depend on many variables. For example, an Internet search of the current life expectancy of ALL males currently living in the United States is 74.4 years. I ran the numbers and I am good only until March 24th. In 1942, the year I was born, male life expectancy was 69.6 years. However, if you have ALREADY reached age 65 or older, your life expectancy is increased to 83.2 years. So, you can make the numbers fit any scenario you want.

Posts.Title: Finished SRT

Posts.Content: Hi Georgia Gal (in Michigan?? - is summer reduced to one week there?): Since you have already decided on surgery, I'd just like to add one more nugget of info which you have likely read about in Dr. Walsh's book but seems to be mentioned only infrequently on this thread: Unlike with primary radiation to treat the cancer, surgery provides the opportunity for a second bite at the apple, if necessary. I'm speaking of a possible recurrence and the fact that salvage radiation is then an option (please see my history below). Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Here for my husband

Posts.Content: Welcome Flags: I'm in agreement with Chuck. If you research the specific reasons listed to begin treatment with ADT followed by radiation, your case doesn't seem to fit the mold. Yes, this thread tends to skew toward recommending surgery but the ADT then EBRT normally goes hand-in-hand with a large tumor for the purpose of reducing same prior to radiation, a more aggressive strain of PC and/or if accompanied by modest metastasis. Again, none of us are medical professionals -- we can only share our personal experiences and offer support, so you need to weigh the validity of anything that I or the other contributors recommend. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: About to make the decision

Posts.Content: Hi Wife: With a positive margin, as the doctor noted, there is a risk of recurrence. In my case, it returned 3 years post-surgery. With some other forum brothers, the recurrence happened quicker. By closely following my ultra-sensitive PSA results, I was able to mentally prepare and act to receive salvage radiation as soon as I saw an upward trend (please see below) before reaching a reading of 0.2. According to my doctor, this is not an unusual occurrence and not something to stress over, with respect to mortality concerns. He equated it to an automatic dishwasher that failed to wash all of the dishes the first time around (surgery) and required the last two dirty dishes to be hand-washed (salvage radiation). I sailed through the SR without any side effects or complications and my outcome has been excellent to date. My only recommendation is to keep a close watch on his PSA numbers. He may never need SR. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Back again....questions about pathology

Posts.Content: Four to six weeks seems fine for most jobs. However, when you say you may have to use physical force, that's another story because you certainly don't want to take a chance that some scumbag might punch you in the lower abdomen. Also, at 4 to 6 weeks, you'll probably not want to encounter the need to climb over a high fence while pursuing a subject. For those reasons, I would suggest stretching your return time somewhat longer.

Posts.Title: 4K score was 13

Posts.Content: Joey: You didn't do anything wrong. Having your own thread just helps others to focus on your particular concerns. We're just a bunch of strangers from around the world who have had similar experiences and whose backgrounds may serve to aid each other, albeit in a non-medical expert environment. Before I retired, 300 people reported to me. Now, I can't get the dog to come in out of the rain. The idea of joining a forum or support group had always been foreign to me. I was always a leader, rarely a follower. "They" were just people who sat around saying "Oh, woe is me" and lamenting their misfortune. How wrong I was -- at least with respect to this group. With the exception of only a few isolated incidents, I have seen nothing but caring and compassion and a true desire to be of benefit to others, if possible. This mindset is personified by our esteemed moderator, Chuck, who tirelessly maintains an even-keel approach in dealing with so many different personalities. But, overall, it's just people helping people. Jim

Posts.Title: Gleason 9, PSA 18

Posts.Content: Hi loves: You're right to be concerned about Gleason 9 which is advanced cancer but I'm not telling you anything that you're not already aware of. If it was wholly encapsulted in the prostate, then you can breathe easier but still must be watchful in the future. If you haven't already received it, I strongly suggest you obtain a copy of the surgical report and study it carefully. Then, if you have any questions, you can ask the doctor at the next appointment. Immediately after surgery, my doctor said he felt they got it all but in actuality they didn't (see signature below). I wasn't smart enough to ask for a copy of the surgical report which stated that the margins weren't clear. Lesson learned. Best of luck to you both. Jim

Posts.Title: Finished SRT

Posts.Content: Welcome JJ: It appears that you have done an exhaustive study on the subject of incontinence. As you have found, virtually every patient is different. One poster recently mentioned that he was completely dry one week after the removal of the catheter. I wish I could give you a specific date that you would see an end to the problem but I can only share my uro's experiences. He said that, on average, his patients were dry at the end of two months. Whether I was guided by that statement, I'll never know but on exactly the 60th day after my surgery, I entered the Land of the Dry and remained there to this day. And while he encourages the use of Kegels, as do nearly all doctors and publications on the subject, my doc said that continence would indeed return with or without the use of Kegels. Kegels will just shorten the time needed to return to normal. It sounds like you are very fortunate to have a job with the flexibility to remain in the healing mode for an extended period of time. Due to the demands of your job, my only suggestion would be to maximize the time before returning to work. And, at age 62, I'll bet you are looking forward to the day when you don't have to work grueling 12-hour shifts. I was lucky to snag an early retirement program at age 53 and I'm now entering my 21st year of retirement. If I can live just 5 more years, I will have collected a pension check longer than I worked for the organization and that's my goal. All the best to you, Jim

And while he encourages the use of Kegels, as do nearly all doctors and publications on the subject, my doc said that continence would indeed return with or without the use of Kegels. Kegels will just shorten the time needed to return to normal. It sounds like you are very fortunate to have a job with the flexibility to remain in the healing mode for an extended period of time. Due to the demands of your job, my only suggestion would be to maximize the time before returning to work. And, at age 62, I'll bet you are looking forward to the day when you don't have to work grueling 12-hour shifts. I was lucky to snag an early retirement program at age 53 and I'm now entering my 21st year of retirement. If I can live just 5 more years, I will have collected a pension check longer than I worked for the organization and that's my goal. All the best to you, Jim

Posts.Title: Post op Day 10

Posts.Content: My uro is one of nine urologists in a group. He tells me that (with minimal exceptions) the ENTIRE group adheres to the following prostate cancer treatment recommendations: Under age 60: Surgery Between ages 60 and 70: Patient decides between surgery and radiation Age 70 and older: Radiation While this doesn't answer your specific inquiry, there is something to be learned here: If a patient starts to over-think an issue where most signs point in one direction, then he could easily find himself in a much worse quandary than that which he fears. There is a reason why doctors go to school for many years to learn a medical specialty -- and that's to get it right. If a patient wants to go zig while the rest of the medical community is going zag, he does so at his own risk. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: surgery vs. radiation for younger patients

Posts.Content: Hi Steven: Chuck covered it better than any of the rest of us could. You obviously have something going on but nothing that fits with anything I've ever seen before related to prostate cancer. At age 43, a PSA reading of 6 is not normal. If nothing is found and you still have problems, then a prostate biopsy may be in your future. No one welcomes the biopsy and, although most say it can't be described as painful, nevertheless, it is uncomfortable. But it is currently the ONLY way to confirm the presence of prostate cancer. Since the biopsy only reviews small sections of the prostate, sometimes the biopsy will be a false negative if it misses the actual cancer present. And I just wanted to reiterate what Chuck said about symptoms of prostate cancer. Most patients on this site never had a single symptom. They investigated only after receiving an abnormal PSA blood test reading. Thanks mainly to the widespread acceptance of PSA testing starting in 1992, overall deaths from PC have dropped 44%. We would be very interested in your outcome, PC or not. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Content: This is not meant to be uncaring or remote but I notice that you refer to wanting a "complete" sexual experience "once this is all done". In my view, right or wrong, there is no need for a sexual experience if you no longer have a pulse. I believe you should be concentrating 100% on defeating the cancer which can kill you and treating the sexual stuff (I know -- you're only 56) as secondary. As mentioned, there is much to be learned and others will chime in shortly but you don't want to win the battle and lose the war. Best of luck.

Posts.Content: With respect to being concerned about potential damage caused by salvage radiotherapy, my experience was the same as Allen's -- no change to ED or continence. But the issue of proposing radiation due to positive margins in the bladder neck in the absence of an increase in PSA is a head-scratcher. I know that the Mayo Clinic is considered to be top-of-the-line, however I would be inclined to get a non-Mayo second opinion before commencing with radiation.

Posts.Title: new member and trying to decide on surgery vs. radiation

Posts.Content: Welcome Samie: In closely reading your post, I note that "open radical surgery" was offered, but there is no mention of the operation that is most frequently utilized today, which is DaVinci robotic prostate cancer surgery. Is that because your local hospital does not offer DaVinci? Normally, I am in lock step with my forum brother, lancepeace, but with a PSA of 39, I would be inclined to act fairly quickly in order to prevent the cancer from continuing to spread. And, as Michael has pointed out, surgery is sometimes supplemented by radiation if the cancer returns or if there is reason to believe that surgery was not successful in removing the prostate with the cancer wholly encapsulated. Your post talks about "surgery followed by probable radiation" which is somewhat unusual, unless the doctor believes that the cancer has already escaped the prostate gland. And, your husband talks about "downsides" to surgery, but seems to ignore the fact that the majority of patients, after performing their due diligence and weighing the risks -- and downsides -- of all forms of treatment, select surgery more often than any other corrective methodology. However, only he and you can make the determination as to what is right for him. As noted, Dr. Walsh's book is a great first step (we receive no royalties -- not trying to sell you anything). Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: 61 yo husband newly diagnosed with high risk prostrate cancer

Posts.Content: Although you will find a number of different opinions on this site with respect to how to proceed, I think the majority of posters favor surgery over radiation, but not by a large margin. As you can see from my signature, that was my choice. However, as you go forward with your research, my history contains vital criteria. If you have surgery and the cancer returns, you can then turn to radiation to finish it off. If you choose radiation as your primary treatment and the cancer returns, surgery is not possible (except in extremely rare cases). That's what sold me on the surgery -- and lucky it did.

Posts.Title: Interesting Statistics on Prostate Cancer Treatment Options

Posts.Content: "I think what I'm looking for is for someone to tell me that my numbers plus age plus whatever don't have the look of the worst case scenario" OK. You've got it. I think it's safe to say that the majority of us "old veterans of this site" believe that you are highly unlikely to be in imminent danger. When I first learned that I had prostate cancer, I got choked up, very much as you did. I'm going to die. I'm going to die. Then, my uro snapped me out of it when he said "Oh, for Christ's sake. You have a routine run-of-the-mill Gleason 7 PC that we see every day in this office and nearly 100% of patients are cured without any future problems. You're not going anywhere. At least, not now". So, worst case scenario -- even if the MRI is suspicious, even if the biopsy is positive, you should still be fine, as long as it's caught early. Please keep us up to date on your results. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: 48 Year Old Ultra Runner W/ Too Many Questions

Posts.Content: "I think what I'm looking for is for someone to tell me that my numbers plus age plus whatever don't have the look of the worst case scenario" OK. You've got it. I think it's safe to say that the majority of us "old veterans of this site" believe that you are highly unlikely to be in imminent danger. When I first learned that I had prostate cancer, I got choked up, very much as you did. I'm going to die. I'm going to die. Then, my uro snapped me out of it when he said "Oh, for Christ's sake. You have a routine run-of-the-mill Gleason 7 PC that we see every day in this office and nearly 100% of patients are cured without any future problems. You're not going anywhere. At least, not now". So, worst case scenario -- even if the MRI is suspicious, even if the biopsy is positive, you should still be fine, as long as it's caught early. Please keep us up to date on your results. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: 48 Year Old Ultra Runner W/ Too Many Questions

Posts.Content: Welcome PC: Your recurrence at 10 years is the longest post-surgery period that I have seen. Mine was three years prior to implementing salvage radiation. You have done an excellent job of researching your options. On the one hand, I find it interesting that both radiologists recommend their modality and the urologists say to pass at this time. So, that would leave most guys scratching their heads -- "What to do?" Gleason 6, notwithstanding the mantra that "No one ever dies from Gleason 6", with a current PSA of 0.20, it seems obvious that something is going on -- and that's not good. You've made it this far by staying on top of the problem. It would be a damn shame to guess wrong now with regard to treatment versus no treatment. Given the same circumstances, I'm pretty certain that I would opt for the SR, probably as soon as possible by using the logic that there is no obvious benefit to waiting. In fact, I would have started to get zapped at 0.1. I found SR to be a piece of cake -- no side effects whatsoever except some slight fatigue toward the end of treatment. Others have experienced side effects. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: It's Back

Posts.Content: Thank you, Allen. My somewhat abrupt post was simply meant to say: You already had the surgery (the worst is over); Now that you've suffered a setback, how can you (with a family history of prostate cancer) not keep an open mind with respect to future treatment that can still produce a "cure" while others are experiencing advanced metastasis and do not have your potential life-saving options? If you are going to give up that easily, then you could have just skipped the surgery in the first place. Don't give up. You have the opportunity to break the chain of prostate cancer deaths in your family. Fight for your life. Jim

Posts.Content: Hi again mom2two: The day may come when a PSA result causes anxiety but this certainly ain't it. As Michael F points out, the difference between <0.01 and 0.015 is.....pretty much zero. When I commenced with salvage radiation, my PSA was more than 10 times higher than your Dad's current numbers. And if his signature is up-to-date, I agree with Michael that, rather than waiting a year (even if the doctor recommends it), consider getting the PSA every three months for peace of mind. Not to worry. All the best, Jim

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Fairwind I also feel Jim's post is way out of line....We are not here to pass judgement on people especially when the criticism reaches the point of ridicule. Jim, that was uncalled for.... Fairwind: I understand your position. My objective was not to ridicule but rather to bring attention to the OP's history and his total disregard for flashing red lights AND, MORE IMPORTANTLY, how that impacts upon first-time visitors to this website. For example, anyone with a family history of PC, who ignores clear-cut warning signs (PSA of 10 for 5-6 years without follow-up) needs to have his case held up to the light as something that NEWBIES SHOULD NOT VIEW AS THE NORM. If it wasn't for unfiltered comments like mine "calling out" the OP for dereliction to saving his own life -- which, of course, is his right, any newbie reading his history could easily view it as acceptable conduct. Of all people, I don't need to remind you of the 30,000 PC deaths every year. A first-time viewer on this site could interpret haha's actions as being similar to his own and simply log off, thinking he's doing just fine, at least as well as haha. If not for fat mouth geezers like me, how else would he know? Being politically correct is not always correct. Jim

Posts.Content: This is not meant to be uncaring or remote but I notice that you refer to wanting a "complete" sexual experience "once this is all done". In my view, right or wrong, there is no need for a sexual experience if you no longer have a pulse. I believe you should be concentrating 100% on defeating the cancer which can kill you and treating the sexual stuff (I know -- you're only 56) as secondary. As mentioned, there is much to be learned and others will chime in shortly but you don't want to win the battle and lose the war. Best of luck.

Posts.Title: Catheter removal times?

Posts.Content: I concur with lancepeace. The commencement of hormone therapy, instead of surgery or radiation as the first line of defense, is telling. Although I know it is painful for you to imagine, is it possible that your Dad could have been shielding you from a diagnosis of a more aggressive form of prostate cancer? For example, if he had any Cat scans or full body bone scans following his initial diagnosis in 2008, they may have divulged metastasis to other areas of his body. You could start there to investigate if you are so inclined. Again, we are not doctors and at this point can only speculate. I, too, am very sorry for your loss.

Posts.Title: Gleason 9, PSA 18

Posts.Content: Hi Wife: With a positive margin, as the doctor noted, there is a risk of recurrence. In my case, it returned 3 years post-surgery. With some other forum brothers, the recurrence happened quicker. By closely following my ultra-sensitive PSA results, I was able to mentally prepare and act to receive salvage radiation as soon as I saw an upward trend (please see below) before reaching a reading of 0.2. According to my doctor, this is not an unusual occurrence and not something to stress over, with respect to mortality concerns. He equated it to an automatic dishwasher that failed to wash all of the dishes the first time around (surgery) and required the last two dirty dishes to be hand-washed (salvage radiation). I sailed through the SR without any side effects or complications and my outcome has been excellent to date. My only recommendation is to keep a close watch on his PSA numbers. He may never need SR. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Back again....questions about pathology

Posts.Content: Hi loves: You're right to be concerned about Gleason 9 which is advanced cancer but I'm not telling you anything that you're not already aware of. If it was wholly encapsulted in the prostate, then you can breathe easier but still must be watchful in the future. If you haven't already received it, I strongly suggest you obtain a copy of the surgical report and study it carefully. Then, if you have any questions, you can ask the doctor at the next appointment. Immediately after surgery, my doctor said he felt they got it all but in actuality they didn't (see signature below). I wasn't smart enough to ask for a copy of the surgical report which stated that the margins weren't clear. Lesson learned. Best of luck to you both. Jim

Posts.Content: Holy crap, PDV. You are rapidly becoming the poster child of all things that could POSSIBLY go wrong following prostate cancer surgery. Murphy's Law, whatever could possibly go wrong, is going wrong. First a lymphocele, now cellulitis. Wow! To have to go back to the hospital every day for two weeks for IV sounds serious. Of course, if you had contracted out the yard work as I suggested BEFORE you got a nose-full of dirt leading to the infection, this episode likely would not have occurred. Please slow down. You have to take care of yourself (he said, again). Those teenage students will eventually graduate with or without your help. Give some thought to turning in your keys and sit back and heal yourself. Jim

Posts.Title: 48 Year Old Ultra Runner W/ Too Many Questions

Posts.Content: Fairwind: By using Pomi-T to cut the PSA doubling time in half, doesn't that just "mask" the true PSA numbers? I see that you have already undergone salvage radiotherapy -- as have I -- but for others who are experiencing a chemical recurrence following a prostatectomy, isn't there a danger that masking an actual PSA reading will provide a false sense of complacency while the cancer possibly continues to spread unabated? I ask these questions, not because I have a finite answer -- I don't, but because I don't know whether delaying SR would be productive for a patient under this scenario. You've provided info on this site longer than most of us. What are your thoughts? Jim

Posts.Title: PSA rising after prostatectomy

Posts.Content: I agree with Michael and Southsider -- very small chance of metastasis with a PSA of 6.1 and Gleason 6. The nurse is correct -- you are deemed low risk. At the same time, after re-reading your other extensive thread, I see no record of an abdominal scan or a full-body bone scan prior to your biopsy or afterwards. For many of us, those two tests were given routinely by a lot of doctors to provide a broader overall picture. Also, if the full body bone scan reveals metastasis, it MAY rule out surgery. No point in removing the prostate if the PC has spread to other areas and possibly to other organs. Was the subject of a bone scan discussed with your doctor prior to biopsy? And a full body bone scan may have offered more definitive information than a genomic prostate score that merely tries to "assess" the potential aggressiveness of your PC. Still, with that said, all indications are that the sky is NOT falling.

Conspiracy theories ("What the cancer industry doesn't want you to know!!") pop up everywhere but there is no place for them on this website. When people become desperate there is a tendency to grasp at straws but it serves no useful purpose and is detrimental to those who seek reliable answers via proven scientific modalities.

Posts.Content: From: The American Cancer Society www.cancer.org -- June 13, 2013 Question: "What's the best treatment for prostate cancer?" Answer: For men with localized prostate cancer who are not candidates for observation alone, or who aren't comfortable with this approach, there are a number of options to treat their disease. The most common treatments chosen by men in the US are surgery (nearly half of all men), followed closely by radiation treatment (about 40%). http://www.cancer.org/cancer/news/ex...t-for-you.aspx

Posts.Content: Thank you, Allen. My somewhat abrupt post was simply meant to say: You already had the surgery (the worst is over); Now that you've suffered a setback, how can you (with a family history of prostate cancer) not keep an open mind with respect to future treatment that can still produce a "cure" while others are experiencing advanced metastasis and do not have your potential life-saving options? If you are going to give up that easily, then you could have just skipped the surgery in the first place. Don't give up. You have the opportunity to break the chain of prostate cancer deaths in your family. Fight for your life. Jim

Posts.Title: PSA test causing so much anxiety....

Posts.Content: "If you screen men [aged 55 to 69] based on the protocol in those trials, every two to four years for 13 years, five out of 1,000 will die from prostate cancer. If you don't screen, six out of 1,000 men will die from prostate cancer," Bell said. "So the reduction in prostate cancer mortality is one in 1,000 or about 0.1 per cent." This figure of only 1 in 1,000 lives saved by PSA tests is the same ratio cited in the U.S. task force report. Let's say the numbers are correct (which I don't really believe, but let's say they are) Now, I may not be the world's great mathematician, but that means for every one million PSA tests performed, one thousand lives will be saved. Please forgive my ignorance, perhaps I'm missing something, but isn't the saving of ONE THOUSAND LIVES a good thing?

Posts.Title: So, what do you think about this?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Nick P MichiganMan Why am I waiting? I'm following the advice I'm given. My Surgeon is the Professor of Urology and my Oncologist is the Professor of Medicine and Surgery, both at the University of Arizona Cancer Center. I figured I was in good hands. I've put in a call to see if I can accelerate this treatment schedule after the comments I've received here. Nick Welcome Nick: Your stats -- age 68 and G7 (3+4, for me) at the time of surgery -- are identical to mine. Was G7 your final post-surgery pathology result, also? The comments from Michael and MM16 are highly knowledgeable but somewhat subdued compared to what you will hear from me. Picture this: bright flashing neon red lights, loud bells gonging, sirens blasting...... Now, take a look at my history that shows my salvage radiation treatment (no HT - never mentioned) BEGAN at 0.11. If your decimal places are correct on your PSA tests, as noted by Michael, your current status of PSA 1.0 without follow-up treatment is TEN TIMES WORSE than when I commenced salvage radiation. My 40 sessions of SR resulted in NO side effects with the exception of some mild fatigue toward the end. Six years after surgery and 3 years after SR, my PSA remains at 0.00. I can only conclude that there must be some other medical reasoning for not addressing your status with some ACTION. Or the acclaimed doctor you listed may be suffering from early-onset Alzheimer's Disease. Thanks to his non-action, you MAY now be past the point of cure (as mentioned) but rather are simply looking for an extension of life treatment. And, based upon your rising PSA numbers, if you don't act QUICKLY you may not get that opportunity. Best of luck, Jim

AgeInfo.Phrase: Welcome Nick  Your stats    age 68 and G7  3 4  for

Posts.Signature: LUNG Age: 71 -- 12/2013 - Cat Scan sees new irregular 1.8 cm nodule in right middle lobe. 3/13/14 - PET Cat Scan confirms presence of same nodule -- same size. Nodule lights up indicating likelihood of lung cancer -- Location not conducive to biopsy. 3/17/14 - Three top doctors say it MUST come out via a wedge re-section. If cancerous, the entire right middle lobe must be surgically removed. 6/13/14 - Nodule shrank by 1/3. Not cancer. Surgery cancelled. Next scan 9/14. Nodule "resolved" - gone. PROSTATE Age: 67 -- 2/2010 - PSA: 4.05 8/2010 - PSA: 4.95 9/2010 - Biopsy - 2 out of 12 cores positive - Gleason: 3+4=7 11/8/2010 - DaVinci RALP - small positive margin - was told it was meaningless. 2/11 - PSA: 0.02; 8/11 - PSA: 0.04; 2/12 - PSA: 0.06; 8/12 - PSA: 0.08; 2/13 - PSA: 0.11; 5/13 - PSA: 0.16 - referred to oncology radiologist. 9/2013: 40 sessions of IMRT salvage radiation completed. 1/14, 4/14, 7/14, 10/14, 1/15, 8/15, 3/16, 8/16, 3/17 - All PSA: 0.00

Posts.Title: 7 Month update

Posts.Content: Hi Fred: One core of Gleason 6 usually falls into the AS category but every case is different, especially with an oversized prostate. Your assessment sounds on point. My urologist belongs to a group of 9 uros whose general (always exceptions) rule of thumb is "under age 60, surgery; over age 70, radiation; between 60 and 70, a coin flip". So, if you are now age 74 and leaning toward surgery, you should probably consider pursuing it sooner rather than later. And, with Obamacare kicking in, you could find yourself on the outside looking in, with respect to Medicare paying for the surgery. I got in under the wire at age 68 -- then salvage radiotherapy at age 71. Good luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Gleason 6, Should I press for surgery?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by LetsDoThis Thanks for that sharing that. It's just so weird that it will be 2 years in November since he's had a Lupron shot....and now he's just developing the gynecomastia, never had an issue during. He's having that very same problem, rolling over and waking up to the pain. Still waiting for the oncologist call back to hear what he has to say. I'm thinking he will probably say the same thing..hormone confusion. Man does this disease really stink for you guys. I know our oncologist said he wouldn't give him testosterone but if this keeps up, I wonder if we should explore too.... We did get the Kidney stone results and they are 100% Uric Acid. So they are doing another c-scan and some blood work done to rule out anything else, but if that turns up ok, than they can start him on some meds so those don't happen again. (I really wish the stone was tested after the first attack and we could have nipped this before the other attacks...argh!) So always get those stones tested people Thanks for the welcome back Michael and Dave. I'm sorry I haven't been keeping up with this. Especially when all of you have been just so supportive and such an awesome resource too. I'll try to do a better job. I'll keep you posted if we hear anything else too Wishing everyone a Happy Memorial Day Weekend and Good PSA test results Gina Hi Gina: Five years ago, after two hospitalizations for kidney stones, including one surgery to remove a stone that completely shut down my left ureter in unbearable pain, my uro started me on a medication (Urocet-K) to hopefully prevent future kidney stone issues. It's good to have a positive outlook for the future but be advised that these horse-size pills that I choke on twice a day, are not the panacea one might hope for. In the last five years, I have been hospitalized five MORE times for severe pain from kidney stones with one incident causing surgical removal. On each of my two surgical removals, a stent had to be placed in the ureter for a week to prevent collapse. Last year, the stent failed and I was unable to urinate AT ALL -- not one drop. That led to a great personal fear of my bladder filling (without consuming any liquids) and exploding before I could be treated in the ER. Fortunately, I got to the ER in time to resolve the issue. Just picture a Roto-Rooter for a private part. My uro said that without the medication, the creation of more kidney stones would have led to even more difficulties. I mention this only so that you do not harbor unrealistic expectations for the kidney stone medication(s). Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: 7 Month update

Posts.Content: Let me see if I understand this post correctly. Walnut is willing to surrender one thousand lives in order to avoid some anxiety!! WHAT??? Would anyone reading this post volunteer to be among the 1,000 whose lives or the lives of loved ones would be lost? Let's take this a step further mathematically: The last U.S. census of 2010 showed a population of over 308 million citizens. Of that number, about half are male (150 million). Of the 150 million men, about 30% are 55 or older (roughly 45 million). Assuming this is Day One of the PSA era, if you could save one life in every 1,000 PSA tests, then 45 million PSA tests would hypothetically result in the saving of 45,000 lives. Do we surrender 45,000 lives to avoid "anxiety" in others? Is this even a valid argument? I would trade unlimited "anxiety" for the saving of ONE LIFE, let alone 45,000 lives saved.

Posts.Title: So, what do you think about this?

Posts.Content: Welcome John: Although I'm from PA, your City by the Bay is my favorite, having visited 20 years in a row. My great-grandfather was one of the founders of a Utopian-type town just north of you in 1890. You've probably heard of it -- it's called Mill Valley. Anyway, others who are more qualified will be able to fill in the answers to many of your questions. As you have already discovered, surgery and radiation are the two primary forms of prostate cancer treatment. Each is considered to be about equally successful with side effects popping up at different times. Brachytherapy has worked well for some of our forum brothers but be advised it is considered to be outside of the mainstream as it is the choice of only 2% of PC patients. If you are comfortable being a two-percenter, then you should be fine. I note you used the phrase "cured of prostate cancer" more than once. Having dealt with it twice (How the hell can you get prostate cancer three years after your prostate has been removed?), I am of the personal opinion that you can never be confident that you are ever "cured", just like an alcoholic is an alcoholic for their entire lives, regardless of their sobriety. I view cancer in general as being equivalent to the "Whack a Mole" carnival game. If you knock it down in one place, it has a tendency to pop up somewhere else. John Wayne famously announced that he had beaten the Big C when he was operated on for lung cancer. A few years later, he died of stomach cancer. But maybe I'm just a pessimist. Finally, it is presumptuous to note in your history that your PC is "confined to the gland". At this point in your journey, it is impossible to know that. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: A little learning is a dangerous thing . . .

Posts.Content: "If you screen men [aged 55 to 69] based on the protocol in those trials, every two to four years for 13 years, five out of 1,000 will die from prostate cancer. If you don't screen, six out of 1,000 men will die from prostate cancer," Bell said. "So the reduction in prostate cancer mortality is one in 1,000 or about 0.1 per cent." This figure of only 1 in 1,000 lives saved by PSA tests is the same ratio cited in the U.S. task force report. Let's say the numbers are correct (which I don't really believe, but let's say they are) Now, I may not be the world's great mathematician, but that means for every one million PSA tests performed, one thousand lives will be saved. Please forgive my ignorance, perhaps I'm missing something, but isn't the saving of ONE THOUSAND LIVES a good thing?

Posts.Title: A little learning is a dangerous thing . . .

Posts.Content: Welcome John: Although I'm from PA, your City by the Bay is my favorite, having visited 20 years in a row. My great-grandfather was one of the founders of a Utopian-type town just north of you in 1890. You've probably heard of it -- it's called Mill Valley. Anyway, others who are more qualified will be able to fill in the answers to many of your questions. As you have already discovered, surgery and radiation are the two primary forms of prostate cancer treatment. Each is considered to be about equally successful with side effects popping up at different times. Brachytherapy has worked well for some of our forum brothers but be advised it is considered to be outside of the mainstream as it is the choice of only 2% of PC patients. If you are comfortable being a two-percenter, then you should be fine. I note you used the phrase "cured of prostate cancer" more than once. Having dealt with it twice (How the hell can you get prostate cancer three years after your prostate has been removed?), I am of the personal opinion that you can never be confident that you are ever "cured", just like an alcoholic is an alcoholic for their entire lives, regardless of their sobriety. I view cancer in general as being equivalent to the "Whack a Mole" carnival game. If you knock it down in one place, it has a tendency to pop up somewhere else. John Wayne famously announced that he had beaten the Big C when he was operated on for lung cancer. A few years later, he died of stomach cancer. But maybe I'm just a pessimist. Finally, it is presumptuous to note in your history that your PC is "confined to the gland". At this point in your journey, it is impossible to know that. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: New Here - urologist wants to do biopsy

Posts.Content: Hi David: I strongly agree with Ron. Unless you have a reason to believe that your biopsy was flawed in some way (unlikely), there appears to be no need for a second biopsy. You have extensive cancer within the prostate, albeit of the lower-risk G6 variety. And keep in mind that if you choose surgery, that G6 could possibly be upgraded to a higher number upon surgical pathological examination of the excised prostate. Surgery or radiation appears to be the logical treatment choices -- both have nearly identical successful outcomes, on average.. However, if you have a recurrence following surgery as your primary treatment, you can always revert to salvage radiation to "clean up" anything remaining. If you select radiation as your primary treatment, surgery is no longer an option. It was that "second bite at the apple" that helped to make my decision for me and, lucky that I did, because I needed salvage radiation 3 years after DaVinci surgery. What worked well for me, though, is not for everyone. Only you can decide what is the best path for yourself. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Why Men and Couples Suffer Alone

Posts.Content: Hi gsteve: Glad to hear your PSA is still at zero. In many cases, "zero" is defined as any reading below 0.1 which is officially considered to be "undetectable", but may actually be detectable if you go to the second decimal. So, if you view my history at the end of my two years after DaVinci, I too was in the "undetectable" category at the same time that the cancer was once again beginning to rear its ugly head. Your last sentence is exactly what I would suggest. However, at the end of the 2nd year after DaVinci with no evidence of a recurrence, many uros recommend a PSA test only once a year. My feeling -- regardless of "medical protocol" -- especially with my history, is that I will never be comfortable waiting longer than every six months between PSA tests. Good luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Use of ultra sensitive PSA tests

Posts.Content: I love MichiganMan16. I love Michael F. But I must respectfully disagree on the subject of PSA possibly causing "anxiety", so let's just stay uninformed instead. As noted in the past, my knowledge of a PSA "creeping" up helped me to mentally deal with the need for salvage radiation when it came time to be zapped. As an old guy, I lean toward using analogies -- try this one: You live in Florida. You have a small inflatable pool in the back yard filled with 12 inches of water. Your 18-month-old grandchild is playing and splashing in the pool. You walk back into the house for just a few seconds. As you do, an alligator leaves a nearby swamp and heads for the pool. Question: Do you want to be alerted when the alligator is 100 yards away from the pool or just 2 yards away? Would you NOT want to know when it's 100 yards away because it may cause you "anxiety"? Jim

My Surgeon is the Professor of Urology and my Oncologist is the Professor of Medicine and Surgery, both at the University of Arizona Cancer Center. I figured I was in good hands. I've put in a call to see if I can accelerate this treatment schedule after the comments I've received here. Nick Welcome Nick: Your stats -- age 68 and G7 (3+4, for me) at the time of surgery -- are identical to mine. Was G7 your final post-surgery pathology result, also? The comments from Michael and MM16 are highly knowledgeable but somewhat subdued compared to what you will hear from me. Picture this: bright flashing neon red lights, loud bells gonging, sirens blasting...... Now, take a look at my history that shows my salvage radiation treatment (no HT - never mentioned) BEGAN at 0.11. If your decimal places are correct on your PSA tests, as noted by Michael, your current status of PSA 1.0 without follow-up treatment is TEN TIMES WORSE than when I commenced salvage radiation. My 40 sessions of SR resulted in NO side effects with the exception of some mild fatigue toward the end. Six years after surgery and 3 years after SR, my PSA remains at 0.00. I can only conclude that there must be some other medical reasoning for not addressing your status with some ACTION. Or the acclaimed doctor you listed may be suffering from early-onset Alzheimer's Disease. Thanks to his non-action, you MAY now be past the point of cure (as mentioned) but rather are simply looking for an extension of life treatment. And, based upon your rising PSA numbers, if you don't act QUICKLY you may not get that opportunity. Best of luck, Jim
