Posts.Title: 7 Month update

Posts.Content: Hi Fred: Well, your PSA is certainly nothing to be concerned about, but if two doctors have confirmed that there is an irregularity with respect to a hard nodule on your prostate, then it certainly seems prudent to investigate. A prostate biopsy is nothing more than a diagnostic tool that takes a very small sample of your prostate and sends it to the lab. A biopsy is the only test that can detect and confirm the presence of cancer in the prostate, which would be unusual at age 43 but not unheard of. Like most diagnostic tests, it is performed to rule out, not rule in, a particular disease. You could elect to do active surveillance (AS) and have the area re-checked in 3 to 6 months. Most prostate cancers are slow-growing and, therefore, a delay may be reasonable. However, there are also less frequent strains of prostate cancer that are fast-moving and can actually kill you rather quickly. So, if you delay, you are accepting somewhat of a risk. I would view your description of a biopsy as "overwhelming" to be somewhat overstated. The test is frequently performed in the doctor's office and takes about ten minutes to complete. There is rarely pain involved, but the procedure is uncomfortable and you may be sore for 24-48 hours. The test is not life-threatening. Others will follow with additional info. Please let us know how you make out. Good luck. Jim

Posts.Title: New Here - urologist wants to do biopsy

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by PDV Felt great Saturday and probably pushed. Swelling and pain increased throughout afternoon. Local hospital transferred me to Boston. Urinary tract infection and something called limphecile or something like that. In till tomorrow at least With all of the various contributions to this site by patients, I had never before heard of lymphoceles which is described by Wikipedia below as a likely surgical complication: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lymphocele It's apparently so unusual that the spellchecker on this site (cancerforums.net) does not recognize the word even though I have spelled it correctly. There is no explanation as to whether overexertion may have been a factor, but if it was, then your experience should be a clarion call to others to take it easy following surgery. Hope the worst has passed by now, Jim

Posts.Title: Stomach bloating after surgery....

Posts.Content: Hi Fred: Well, your PSA is certainly nothing to be concerned about, but if two doctors have confirmed that there is an irregularity with respect to a hard nodule on your prostate, then it certainly seems prudent to investigate. A prostate biopsy is nothing more than a diagnostic tool that takes a very small sample of your prostate and sends it to the lab. A biopsy is the only test that can detect and confirm the presence of cancer in the prostate, which would be unusual at age 43 but not unheard of. Like most diagnostic tests, it is performed to rule out, not rule in, a particular disease. You could elect to do active surveillance (AS) and have the area re-checked in 3 to 6 months. Most prostate cancers are slow-growing and, therefore, a delay may be reasonable. However, there are also less frequent strains of prostate cancer that are fast-moving and can actually kill you rather quickly. So, if you delay, you are accepting somewhat of a risk. I would view your description of a biopsy as "overwhelming" to be somewhat overstated. The test is frequently performed in the doctor's office and takes about ten minutes to complete. There is rarely pain involved, but the procedure is uncomfortable and you may be sore for 24-48 hours. The test is not life-threatening. Others will follow with additional info. Please let us know how you make out. Good luck. Jim

Posts.Title: New Here - urologist wants to do biopsy

Posts.Content: Hi mcnova: Welcome to the forum. Sorry you and your father have a need to be here. I can identify with his situation as I was also age 67 (see signature history below) when diagnosed with PC and my PSA level was similar. There are a number of suggestions that you will receive from those who come after me (surgery, radiation, etc.) on this site so I will speak only of the question you asked about waiting for higher scores before initiating treatment. My opinion: Don't. While surgery remains an option now, in a relatively short time, it may be one of the options taken off of the table as he reaches age 70. At that point, radiation may be the only hope for a "cure". And, to compound the dilemma, if he has surgery and the cancer returns (as mine did), he can then have salvage radiotherapy to eradicate the remaining cancer. On the other hand, if he selects radiation, he cannot (except in very rare instances) have surgery next because the prostate is deformed during radiation in such a way as to not permit surgery. Another issue is the Gleason 6 diagnosis; treatment now is almost always 100% successful as you read in Dr. Walsh's book. But a higher Gleason score may be indicative of a less successful outcome as it will possibly reveal a more aggressive strain of PC and/or show that the cancer has already spread to surrounding lymph nodes and, potentially, other organs. Right or wrong, I have never been a proponent of active surveillance. Nothing good can ever happen as the cancer isn't magically going to go away. Best of luck and I hope you find the info you seek and convince your Dad that action is indeed warranted at this point. Jim

Posts.Title: Questions to ask at upcoming Dr appt

Posts.Content: Welcome bassoneman: Over the next several days, you should expect to hear from patients and their care-givers who have already experienced the path that you are approaching. With luck, it will be as uneventful as my journey was, which was secondary, or salvage radiation, three years after surgery. A number of oncologists like to have patients with a full bladder prior to your 10-12 minute daily zap. Zap refers to radiation, not physical contact -- you will feel nothing as the machine circles around you, assuming you are receiving IMRT treatment. Originally, I had a 30-minute drive to receive my salvage radiation over two major highways that sometimes wind up in gridlock. I didn't like that scenario, as I was certain that I could not hold the fluid very long.. Instead, I found a highly skilled radiation oncologist just six minutes from home who did not require a full bladder. Finding him was like hitting a home run with the bases loaded in the bottom of the ninth. My best wish for you is that you find someone just like my RO. Some patients experience minor side effects with IMRT but my only SE was some very slight fatigue toward the end of my 40 sessions. It's been 3 1/2 years since my SR and as you can see from my signature, all looks well so far. Just had my latest PSA on Tuesday -- will get the results at the beginning of next week. You've found a group of very caring people who will be available to you with any help they can provide. All the best to you, Sir, Jim

Posts.Title: New here... TAD Nervous Start Radiation this week -

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Nick P MichiganMan Why am I waiting? I'm following the advice I'm given. My Surgeon is the Professor of Urology and my Oncologist is the Professor of Medicine and Surgery, both at the University of Arizona Cancer Center. I figured I was in good hands. I've put in a call to see if I can accelerate this treatment schedule after the comments I've received here. Nick Welcome Nick: Your stats -- age 68 and G7 (3+4, for me) at the time of surgery -- are identical to mine. Was G7 your final post-surgery pathology result, also? The comments from Michael and MM16 are highly knowledgeable but somewhat subdued compared to what you will hear from me. Picture this: bright flashing neon red lights, loud bells gonging, sirens blasting...... Now, take a look at my history that shows my salvage radiation treatment (no HT - never mentioned) BEGAN at 0.11. If your decimal places are correct on your PSA tests, as noted by Michael, your current status of PSA 1.0 without follow-up treatment is TEN TIMES WORSE than when I commenced salvage radiation. My 40 sessions of SR resulted in NO side effects with the exception of some mild fatigue toward the end. Six years after surgery and 3 years after SR, my PSA remains at 0.00. I can only conclude that there must be some other medical reasoning for not addressing your status with some ACTION. Or the acclaimed doctor you listed may be suffering from early-onset Alzheimer's Disease. Thanks to his non-action, you MAY now be past the point of cure (as mentioned) but rather are simply looking for an extension of life treatment. And, based upon your rising PSA numbers, if you don't act QUICKLY you may not get that opportunity. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: 7 Month update

Posts.Content: Hi David: I strongly agree with Ron. Unless you have a reason to believe that your biopsy was flawed in some way (unlikely), there appears to be no need for a second biopsy. You have extensive cancer within the prostate, albeit of the lower-risk G6 variety. And keep in mind that if you choose surgery, that G6 could possibly be upgraded to a higher number upon surgical pathological examination of the excised prostate. Surgery or radiation appears to be the logical treatment choices -- both have nearly identical successful outcomes, on average.. However, if you have a recurrence following surgery as your primary treatment, you can always revert to salvage radiation to "clean up" anything remaining. If you select radiation as your primary treatment, surgery is no longer an option. It was that "second bite at the apple" that helped to make my decision for me and, lucky that I did, because I needed salvage radiation 3 years after DaVinci surgery. What worked well for me, though, is not for everyone. Only you can decide what is the best path for yourself. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: 12 months and counting...

Posts.Content: "I am told most people die with PC and not of PC." Statistically, that's accurate, BUT at the same time, prostate cancer is the second leading cause of cancer deaths in men in the U.S. The good part of the equation is that, like colon cancer, when caught early and treated, prostate cancer is nearly always 100% curable. At the same time, whether through indifference or a belief that "most people don't die of prostate cancer", a total of thirty thousand men die each year from this disease. It needs to be taken seriously. "I had an MRI last April which did not show anything significant." Here's something significant: You have cancer. You have prostate cancer. "how long will I be laid up?" That's uncertain but for 30,000 guys last year, the answer is "permanently". Please -- do your homework -- read Dr. Walsh's book -- and realize this may be more than a simple inconvenience. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: New Diagnosis

Posts.Content: "However if the tumers start to grow at anytime they will move you into the treatment side of the study." Wow! If accurate, this almost borders on the bizarre. I am in 100% agreement with Michael F who is able to express his opinion much more eloquently than I am able to or inclined to. As a non-medical professional, I have always operated under the assumption that trials are primarily for patients who have already exhausted all reasonable means of potential cure. If metastases was wide-spread, then little would be left to interpretation. However, a single small spot on the lower back that tests positive makes me wince. What if it's a false positive? In this case, if I understand it correctly, the trial will give you a 50/50 chance of "treatment". Please forgive my bluntness, but if it was me, my knee-jerk response would be, "Screw that". Why be a guinea pig if treatment is still an option? Unless I am deemed to be terminal, I would want - no, I would demand - a 100% chance of treatment IMMEDIATELY. Am I missing something here? I truly wish you the very best, Sir, Jim

Posts.Title: What do you think

Posts.Content: Hi David: I strongly agree with Ron. Unless you have a reason to believe that your biopsy was flawed in some way (unlikely), there appears to be no need for a second biopsy. You have extensive cancer within the prostate, albeit of the lower-risk G6 variety. And keep in mind that if you choose surgery, that G6 could possibly be upgraded to a higher number upon surgical pathological examination of the excised prostate. Surgery or radiation appears to be the logical treatment choices -- both have nearly identical successful outcomes, on average.. However, if you have a recurrence following surgery as your primary treatment, you can always revert to salvage radiation to "clean up" anything remaining. If you select radiation as your primary treatment, surgery is no longer an option. It was that "second bite at the apple" that helped to make my decision for me and, lucky that I did, because I needed salvage radiation 3 years after DaVinci surgery. What worked well for me, though, is not for everyone. Only you can decide what is the best path for yourself. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: How bad is this?

Posts.Content: Well, I must admit that while I have experienced a few of your 10 items, I have never "suffered". Why, you might ask? Because if I avoided surgery and I croaked from prostate cancer, my "depression" would be a moot point. In my view, your blog is demonstrative of someone who simply loves to hear himself talk -- ad infinitum -- and has no place or value on this forum.
Posts.Title: Why Men and Couples Suffer Alone

Posts.Content: No, it's not early. You don't need a "better view of trending". YOU ALREADY HAVE A TREND. In the past, a post-surgery PSA reading of at least 0.2 at least twice was considered a confirmation of a biochemical recurrence. Many doctors have now trashed that and encourage commencement of salvage radiation at or near 0.1. Please review my history. Upon reaching 0.11 three years after surgery, I immediately started SR and, so far at least, it's worked out well. Don't screw around with this. Make an appointment with your surgeon to discuss his confirmation of a quick 7-month failure and his recommendations for a resolution. OR skip the surgeon and go directly to a radiology oncologist. You have touched on the fallacy of traditional one-numerical-decimal PSA testing wanting to avoid "unnecessary concerns or anxiety". Keeping a patient in the dark relative to a rising post-surgery PSA, IMHO, is like an ostrich sticking its head in the sand. It's like having a leak in your gas tank and not wanting to know that your car is about to blow up. Note: Thanks, Michael. Our posts passed in the interim. Frenchy: Have you had a post-SR PSA test yet that you could share with the OP?

Posts.Title: Rising PSA 7 months post prostatectomy

Posts.Content: Welcome Rob: Michael F and Chuck have done such a good job covering the subject, my only input is agreement that if you want to get the most accurate biopsy, currently the 3T MRI offers the best chance of not missing anything. Your concerns are similar to literally thousands of guys who visit this site. There is absolutely no reason to be terrified of anything. I know it's easy for me to say but you're looking at a diagnostic TEST only, for now. And, even under a worst case scenario, prostate cancer is nearly always curable when found early and treated. But don't put the cart before the horse (you'll hear a lot of silly old clichés here). Just take it one step at a time. We'll be here. Again, no one on this site is a medical professional but we've all been there - done that and we've been of help to a lot of people. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Need some advice, guidance and\or feedback on my recent issue

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Nick P MichiganMan Why am I waiting? I'm following the advice I'm given. My Surgeon is the Professor of Urology and my Oncologist is the Professor of Medicine and Surgery, both at the University of Arizona Cancer Center. I figured I was in good hands. I've put in a call to see if I can accelerate this treatment schedule after the comments I've received here. Nick Welcome Nick: Your stats -- age 68 and G7 (3+4, for me) at the time of surgery -- are identical to mine. Was G7 your final post-surgery pathology result, also? The comments from Michael and MM16 are highly knowledgeable but somewhat subdued compared to what you will hear from me. Picture this: bright flashing neon red lights, loud bells gonging, sirens blasting...... Now, take a look at my history that shows my salvage radiation treatment (no HT - never mentioned) BEGAN at 0.11. If your decimal places are correct on your PSA tests, as noted by Michael, your current status of PSA 1.0 without follow-up treatment is TEN TIMES WORSE than when I commenced salvage radiation. My 40 sessions of SR resulted in NO side effects with the exception of some mild fatigue toward the end. Six years after surgery and 3 years after SR, my PSA remains at 0.00. I can only conclude that there must be some other medical reasoning for not addressing your status with some ACTION. Or the acclaimed doctor you listed may be suffering from early-onset Alzheimer's Disease. Thanks to his non-action, you MAY now be past the point of cure (as mentioned) but rather are simply looking for an extension of life treatment. And, based upon your rising PSA numbers, if you don't act QUICKLY you may not get that opportunity. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: 7 Month update

Posts.Content: Before I retired, I had 300 people under me. I know it's different as a business owner, but I strongly believe that as long as your workers get paid on time and they receive their promised benefits, they have absolutely no right to know anything about my personal life. The same is true from the opposite side of the issue, unless the activities involved in a worker's personal life adversely impact their ability to adequately perform their job. Otherwise, you're opening a Pandora's Box of potential problems (unwanted excessive sympathy, what is your life expectancy questions, etc.). There is a lot of credibility in the old axiom that it's best to let sleeping dogs lie.

Posts.Title: Time for another biopsy?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Steve2017 Seems to me, all currently available treatments are from the caveman era. It's pretty disappointing. And then it seems you have to do a coin flip to choose the doctor that you want to mutilate or burn you. How sick is that. Sorry to be so frank in my opinion. I'm ready to deal with the after effects so I'll be flipping the coin soon. Time to move on to the rest of my life. I'm realizing that I have to develop a sense of humor to trudge through this mess to get to the GOOD SIDE. I guess comedy and tragedy really are two heads of the same coin. Steve: There is another way of looking at things. While you wear your "Why me?" hat, take 5 or 10 minutes and read the posts on the pancreatic cancer forum on this website. Then, come back here and bend all the way over and kiss your lucky ass that you have prostate cancer with nearly a 100% survival rate and NOT pancreatic cancer with an average 6% five-year survival rate. Jim

Posts.Title: Active Surveillance Cancer Upgrade Question

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by GunsmokeFan Jim215: thank you for your reply. How would we find out what percentage of patients choose this? or any treatment? And do you know how we could find statistics of rates of side affects (other than maybe what the doctor who does the focal cryotherapy may say)? Hi GF: Sorry for the delay in responding. It appeared to me from your husband's profile with multiple listings of PSA tests and an absence of primary treatment that your inquiry related to considering cryotherapy as primary treatment. Of course, Pratoman had the good sense to ask whether it was primary or secondary. Since my guess without research was that only about 2% of prostate cancer patients elect to have cryotherapy, I did a Google search. And I found that among all PC patients (primary and secondary), cryotherapy is selected by......2% of the men. It is described on many health care sites as being"...a viable alternative among a paucity of choices for patients who experience a biochemical recurrence after failed primary radiation treatment." As far as specific side effects, I wish I could provide some info but I do not have the resources to do so with any level of confidence. My first reaction was to being uncomfortable with the recommendations of "celebrity" doctors, like Dr. Katz and Dr. Oz on television who sometimes cloud an issue that may be quite straightforward. For example, Dr. Katz has stated that "over 80%" of prostate cancer patients do NOT need surgery or radiation as their primary treatment and he seems to have his own objectives by creating active surveillance foundations and selling books. Yes, there can be unwanted, sometimes quite serious, side effects from surgery or radiation, but PC kills 30,000 men every year and any attempt to guide patients away from primary treatment -- without examining the patient in person -- just rubs me the wrong way.

Posts.Title: Dr. Aaron Katz, New York?

Posts.Content: Hi Izicc: Welcome to the forum. You will find a fine group of caring people here who will readily share their personal experiences and provide information to the best of their ability. There are no conflicts of interest because no one is trying to sell you anything. At the same time, you may find posters who are in favor of a particular type of treatment, more so than an alternative, and that's OK because it worked for them. My only comments are: The nurse is correct that once the prostate is removed, the cancerous gland is gone but it's still very important to watch your PSA results post-surgery as the cancer can return (as shown in my history/signature below). One of the major benefits of having surgery instead of radiation (there's my bias kicking in) is that you can have salvage radiation after surgery but not surgery after radiation -- except in very rare cases. And it is also possible that your preliminary Gleason 6 could actually be pathologically upgraded to Gleason 7 post-surgery. Your doctor will be able to tell you his protocol for removal of lymph nodes (some docs take more than others). Best of luck to you and please keep us updated with your decisions/treatment/outcome which may be helpful to others. Jim

Maybe Chuck could provide some info on that subject. I understand what you mean by "how radiation works" but in the primary treatment, I suspect it is aimed at a particular tumor(s) while in the SR treatments it likely casts a kind of "spray" over the prostate bed area where the prostate once resided. Jim

Posts.Title: Longevity of Radiation Treatment

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by PDV Felt great Saturday and probably pushed. Swelling and pain increased throughout afternoon. Local hospital transferred me to Boston. Urinary tract infection and something called limphecile or something like that. In till tomorrow at least With all of the various contributions to this site by patients, I had never before heard of lymphoceles which is described by Wikipedia below as a likely surgical complication: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lymphocele It's apparently so unusual that the spellchecker on this site (cancerforums.net) does not recognize the word even though I have spelled it correctly. There is no explanation as to whether overexertion may have been a factor, but if it was, then your experience should be a clarion call to others to take it easy following surgery. Hope the worst has passed by now, Jim

Posts.Title: Stomach bloating after surgery....

Posts.Content: With all due respect, as usual, I probably fall into the category of Devil's Advocate. The discussion seems centered on testing, testing, testing. My take is this: why the hell is ANYONE talking about testing when -- as Chuck pointed out -- the patient has ALREADY been CONFIRMED to have prostate cancer. Instead of worrying whether something bad is going on with a constantly rising PSA -- "What should I do? What should I do?", to me, the answer is rudimentary: get it the hell out of there and let post-surgery pathology figure out what's actually in there. If I was the patient, with two brothers with PC, I would be shopping this morning at Wal-Mart for a robe and slippers for my overnight hospital stay following surgery. But I guess I'm just a crazy old man.

Posts.Title: Negative Biopsies but rapidly rising PSA

Posts.Content: Aaron: While I have no medical degree, based upon my knowledge of prostate cancer, at age 20, you have as much chance of having PC as you have of walking down the street and being hit in the head with a falling grand piano. It may be prostatitis, an infection of the prostate. A urologist should be able to quickly handle the problem. In the meanwhile, I would suggest that you don't "handle" it yourself. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Content: You may first want to check to see what percentage of prostate cancer patients pursue focal cryotherapy. If that number is around 2%, that means that 98% of patients have rejected it for various reasons. And if 98% of patients have rejected it, I would want to know why. I think you will find that the overwhelming majority of patients on this site have elected either surgery or radiation as their primary treatment, with each having roughly the same rate of success.

Posts.Title: A little learning is a dangerous thing . . .

Posts.Content: Hi jphil: As Southsider said, a full-body bone scan is routine and intended to rule out metastasis to other areas of the body. It's not impossible but it is unlikely in your husband's case with Gleason 6 & 7s. And a 3+4=7 Gleason score is better than a 4+3=7 score. The former is what both your husband and I presented. My urologist said that I shouldn't feel special because a 3+4=7 Gleason is just the run-of-the-mill type of cancer seen every day in his office. Not a big deal. Treat it and move on just like it never happened. Of course, you will want to arm yourself with enough info to proceed. Our moderator, Chuck, should be along shortly to fill in the basics. Best of luck. Jim

Posts.Content: Welcome Busby: I can't provide any info on your supplement but your search for a doctor who will perform a 3T MRI for you seems to be missing a key point. At age 55, nearly all insurance companies will decline to pay for a 3T MRI on the first biopsy. Unless you are prepared to pay out-of-pocket (and that's obviously your choice), you are aiming for the wrong target. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Finally on Day+1

Posts.Content: Hi PDV: First, let me say that you have pinpointed the target in the "big picture". We're still here. Sometimes on this site, as the months go by after treatment, there is a tendency in some quarters to complain about various side issues of this disease, some temporary, some permanent. What they often overlook is that they would have nothing to whine about if they weren't still around. Positive margins, for the most part, usually mean nothing. Sometimes, it can be a precursor to the return of PC as it was in my case, three years after surgery. But, even then, it can usually be addressed with salvage radiation to "clean up" anything remaining. For me, it was important to keep a close eye on the PSA tests and to act sooner employing salvage radiation, rather than later if you detect an upward trend in the numbers. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Positive focal margin

Posts.Content: Ron: Prior to my DaVinci surgery, I never had a catheter before -- didn't know how they worked -- didn't care as long as I didn't have one. There is no need to freak out because it's really a non-issue. Just like folks carry a smart phone everywhere today, the catheter goes everywhere with you. I experienced zero pain and zero discomfort with it but it was a nuisance, on the level that a barking dog next dog is a nuisance. When it's time to remove it (and you will be counting down the days), you just take a deep breath, blow out and the physician or nurse will painlessly slip it out. REALLY, not a big deal. A moderate annoyance, at best. I found that sleeping in a large recliner with the catheter bag on the floor (or in a bucket) to be superior to trying to sleep in bed and worrying that tossing and turning might somehow dislodge the catheter. Some patients actually try to function normally as if they didn't have the catheter by switching to the smaller leg bag retainer and going out to public places. I suppose that's where I fall into the wimp category because I was not nearly so courageous, electing instead to stay home until it was time for the catheter to be removed. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: 16 months Post OP, I give up

Posts.Content: Welcome brake: Ready2Fight is highly accurate in describing the best way to absorb the initial shock. It's the way that most engineers (I'm not one) analyze a major problem and work toward a solution which is to first break things down into smaller components. The results of the full-body bone scan on Monday will be most helpful because it will assist in being able to rule-in or rule-out certain methodologies in proceeding with treatment. And, as you have likely learned, some form of treatment or combination of treatments will be needed with his Gleason 8 diagnosis. No one here will sugarcoat the fact that G8 is an aggressive form of prostate cancer. But there is absolutely no reason to feel "hopeless". If your husband had to have cancer, this is the one he wants. Prostate cancer has very high survival rates and even in a worst case scenario, if a "cure" is not possible, the number of treatments available will often allow for a full life span. That's not to be taken lightly as, for example, a pancreatic cancer patient is looking at an average 6% five-year survival rate following diagnosis. Please let us know the results of the bone scan. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Urgent, panicked

Posts.Content: ".. because my BF becomes irritable when I push him or question him about things." Welcome: Relax. Your bf is not alone. In addition to all men being pigs, they are also inherently stupid, as in you sometimes must drag a thirsty horse to a watering hole. By age 58, I had spent a lifetime avoiding a DRE. My philosophy was adamant -- that's an "exit only" location. Don't even think about suggesting it to me. Somehow, with different doctors retiring and doctors' practices consolidating, I wound up with a female doctor named Maria, a tiny Italian girl with a bright disposition. As I was putting on my shirt after a routine exam, she said we weren't done yet and pulled on a plastic glove. I explained my position on the subject and respectfully declined. She walked to the door and locked it. She told me that I would have to throw her to the floor before she would allow me to leave without a DRE. Then, she held her gloved hand in front of my face and said, "Jim, look at my hand. I'm 99 pounds and my fingers are almost skeletal thin. You need to have this exam at your age. Who would you rather perform it? Me or some male doctor who is 260 pounds with fat, stubby fingers?". Oh, Maria. Yes, I caved. It was followed shortly thereafter by a colonoscopy that I had deathly feared (which wound up being so easy it was unbelievable - go to sleep, wake up to a cold orange juice). And a decade later, the PSA test that detected prostate cancer. Please advise your bf that he doesn't have a monopoly on stupidity, but there may be hope yet. Jim

Posts.Title: Question from New User about my boyfriend's high PSA score

Posts.Content: Let me see if I understand this post correctly. Walnut is willing to surrender one thousand lives in order to avoid some anxiety!! WHAT??? Would anyone reading this post volunteer to be among the 1,000 whose lives or the lives of loved ones would be lost? Let's take this a step further mathematically: The last U.S. census of 2010 showed a population of over 308 million citizens. Of that number, about half are male (150 million). Of the 150 million men, about 30% are 55 or older (roughly 45 million). Assuming this is Day One of the PSA era, if you could save one life in every 1,000 PSA tests, then 45 million PSA tests would hypothetically result in the saving of 45,000 lives. Do we surrender 45,000 lives to avoid "anxiety" in others? Is this even a valid argument? I would trade unlimited "anxiety" for the saving of ONE LIFE, let alone 45,000 lives saved.

Posts.Title: Greetings

Posts.Content: Charlie: Since less than 3 weeks have passed after your surgery, even though you may feel great, be sure to recognize that you are still in the healing mode. Walking is fine but no heavy lifting or exertion that might undo internal stitching. We are all just guys and caregivers who have been through the same thing that you have, so while we can't give medical advice, we can sometimes help others to avoid some of the pitfalls we encountered. For example, it's unfortunate that you didn't find us sooner as we would have never let you go to have the catheter removed without bringing protective guards and/or underwear. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Recent Bioipsy Results

Posts.Content: I understand your frustration but your reference to passing blood for weeks is far from the norm. As mentioned by others, I didn't experience any pain (discomfort, yes) but no pain and no bleeding at all. Try to think about it this way (and repeat after me): It's a diagnostic test -- it's only a diagnostic test, it's not open-heart surgery. You can do it. There's nothing special about us and we did it. Plus it has the benefit of sending each of us on a journey that, in some cases, may save our lives. This is one of only a few cancers that, if treated early, is nearly 100% curable. Many other cancers are found too late. Anxiety issues or not, this is an opportunity that should not be squandered. When you re-schedule with this doctor (who may have been dealing with an emergency) or some other doctor, explain to the staff that your level of anxiety regarding the biopsy needs to be addressed to avoid a repeat of your first experience. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: biopsy

Posts.Content: Hi Carol: It was completely unfair of you to post that link. Once I started reading, I couldn't stop until I reached the end. If it had been in book form, it would have reeled me in like a barracuda for at least 3 days straight. You're a wonderful writer. And the active surveillance you and your husband chose is fine, but in all of your text, I saw nothing regarding Tom's Gleason score. Usually, depending on that crucial number, AS relates well to a Gleason 6, not so much to Gleason 7 or higher. And, forgive me, but the idea that AS is beneficial and somehow contributes to scientific research is a bit of a stretch. In my view (slanted as it is), contributions to science are best left to lab rats. If a car is broken and has problem processing fuel through the engine, we fix it. Ergo, if a human is broken, I'm a great believer that he should be fixed (not in the neutered sense). As you may have read on this thread before stepping forward, there are people on this site who adamantly promote surgery, others are supportive of radiation and we also have a rabid contingent of brachytherapy zealots. All of those procedures, as you have probably already researched, have pros and cons, and at the same time are maddeningly nearly equally effective. I look forward to your future comments, particularly because I have already read your pre-novel. Jim

Posts.Title: Diary of a Prostate Cancer Wife

Posts.Content: I understand your frustration but your reference to passing blood for weeks is far from the norm. As mentioned by others, I didn't experience any pain (discomfort, yes) but no pain and no bleeding at all. Try to think about it this way (and repeat after me): It's a diagnostic test -- it's only a diagnostic test, it's not open-heart surgery. You can do it. There's nothing special about us and we did it. Plus it has the benefit of sending each of us on a journey that, in some cases, may save our lives. This is one of only a few cancers that, if treated early, is nearly 100% curable. Many other cancers are found too late. Anxiety issues or not, this is an opportunity that should not be squandered. When you re-schedule with this doctor (who may have been dealing with an emergency) or some other doctor, explain to the staff that your level of anxiety regarding the biopsy needs to be addressed to avoid a repeat of your first experience. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: biopsy

Posts.Content: Hi Wife: With a positive margin, as the doctor noted, there is a risk of recurrence. In my case, it returned 3 years post-surgery. With some other forum brothers, the recurrence happened quicker. By closely following my ultra-sensitive PSA results, I was able to mentally prepare and act to receive salvage radiation as soon as I saw an upward trend (please see below) before reaching a reading of 0.2. According to my doctor, this is not an unusual occurrence and not something to stress over, with respect to mortality concerns. He equated it to an automatic dishwasher that failed to wash all of the dishes the first time around (surgery) and required the last two dirty dishes to be hand-washed (salvage radiation). I sailed through the SR without any side effects or complications and my outcome has been excellent to date. My only recommendation is to keep a close watch on his PSA numbers. He may never need SR. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Finally decided to have Proton Beam Therapy

Posts.Content: Welcome JJ: It appears that you have done an exhaustive study on the subject of incontinence. As you have found, virtually every patient is different. One poster recently mentioned that he was completely dry one week after the removal of the catheter. I wish I could give you a specific date that you would see an end to the problem but I can only share my uro's experiences. He said that, on average, his patients were dry at the end of two months. Whether I was guided by that statement, I'll never know but on exactly the 60th day after my surgery, I entered the Land of the Dry and remained there to this day. And while he encourages the use of Kegels, as do nearly all doctors and publications on the subject, my doc said that continence would indeed return with or without the use of Kegels. Kegels will just shorten the time needed to return to normal. It sounds like you are very fortunate to have a job with the flexibility to remain in the healing mode for an extended period of time. Due to the demands of your job, my only suggestion would be to maximize the time before returning to work. And, at age 62, I'll bet you are looking forward to the day when you don't have to work grueling 12-hour shifts. I was lucky to snag an early retirement program at age 53 and I'm now entering my 21st year of retirement. If I can live just 5 more years, I will have collected a pension check longer than I worked for the organization and that's my goal. All the best to you, Jim

Posts.Title: Post Op Rant

Posts.Content: So often you hear that there is no need to act on the discovery of prostate cancer because "...it's likely something else will kill you first". But prostate cancer is the second leading cause of cancer deaths among men in the U.S. (estimated 29,480 deaths in 2014). That's a pretty impressive number. If you have the opportunity to catch it early and get rid of it, it just seems logical that you would want to do that. Because, as you get older, if nothing else DOES kill you first, then the prostate cancer absolutely will be your demise. If I had it to do over again, I would LEAP onto the operating table. Well, at my age, it would be more of a semi-leap.

Posts.Title: Should I Delay PSA Test After Taking a Long Hike?

Posts.Content: Joey: You didn't do anything wrong. Having your own thread just helps others to focus on your particular concerns. We're just a bunch of strangers from around the world who have had similar experiences and whose backgrounds may serve to aid each other, albeit in a non-medical expert environment. Before I retired, 300 people reported to me. Now, I can't get the dog to come in out of the rain. The idea of joining a forum or support group had always been foreign to me. I was always a leader, rarely a follower. "They" were just people who sat around saying "Oh, woe is me" and lamenting their misfortune. How wrong I was -- at least with respect to this group. With the exception of only a few isolated incidents, I have seen nothing but caring and compassion and a true desire to be of benefit to others, if possible. This mindset is personified by our esteemed moderator, Chuck, who tirelessly maintains an even-keel approach in dealing with so many different personalities. But, overall, it's just people helping people. Jim

Posts.Title: How do you process all the information?

Posts.Content: If your uncle did not want any of the "conventional" treatments for prostate cancer, I must question just how much accurate information you are receiving on the subject. For example, after being "diagnosed" -- "biopsy showed certain spread in the gland" -- unknown Gleason score -- borders on the ridiculous. If he was a Gleason 9 three years ago, he is likely terminal now. And, if he was diagnosed 3 years ago with prostate cancer, how many doctors visits has he had in those 3 years to address the issue? It sounds like he has stuck his head in the sand like an ostrich for 3 years while his PSA has gotten out of control and probably metastasized (regardless of negative cat scan and bone scan) BUT that was HIS choice. Naturopathic doctors may recommend healthy foods that DO NOTHING to cure cancer BUT that was HIS choice. Sounds like he just wants to do things HIS way. Unless he has asked you to step in and help control his health care and treatment, maybe he doesn't wish any intervention.

Posts.Title: Survey results from low risk patients who chose RP, RT, and AS

Posts.Content: Welcome brake: Ready2Fight is highly accurate in describing the best way to absorb the initial shock. It's the way that most engineers (I'm not one) analyze a major problem and work toward a solution which is to first break things down into smaller components. The results of the full-body bone scan on Monday will be most helpful because it will assist in being able to rule-in or rule-out certain methodologies in proceeding with treatment. And, as you have likely learned, some form of treatment or combination of treatments will be needed with his Gleason 8 diagnosis. No one here will sugarcoat the fact that G8 is an aggressive form of prostate cancer. But there is absolutely no reason to feel "hopeless". If your husband had to have cancer, this is the one he wants. Prostate cancer has very high survival rates and even in a worst case scenario, if a "cure" is not possible, the number of treatments available will often allow for a full life span. That's not to be taken lightly as, for example, a pancreatic cancer patient is looking at an average 6% five-year survival rate following diagnosis. Please let us know the results of the bone scan. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Urgent, panicked

Posts.Content: Patient satisfaction is another area to examine, with respect to the modalities chosen to combat prostate cancer. In every large scale survey I have seen, Cyberknife (SBRT) has consistently come in last, primarily due to the massive doses of radiation causing serious burns in some patients. I personally know two Cyberknife patients who experienced radiation burns that penetrated the anal wall. But don't take my word for it. Those independent survey results can easily be found online.

Posts.Title: Psa of 0.1 after op at 6 months no change, at 9 months number is 0.8.

Posts.Content: "If you screen men [aged 55 to 69] based on the protocol in those trials, every two to four years for 13 years, five out of 1,000 will die from prostate cancer. If you don't screen, six out of 1,000 men will die from prostate cancer," Bell said. "So the reduction in prostate cancer mortality is one in 1,000 or about 0.1 per cent." This figure of only 1 in 1,000 lives saved by PSA tests is the same ratio cited in the U.S. task force report. Let's say the numbers are correct (which I don't really believe, but let's say they are) Now, I may not be the world's great mathematician, but that means for every one million PSA tests performed, one thousand lives will be saved. Please forgive my ignorance, perhaps I'm missing something, but isn't the saving of ONE THOUSAND LIVES a good thing?

Posts.Title: So, what do you think about this?

Posts.Content: Hey Bad: That is so messed up. Just last week, a poster noted that Medicare approved his proton therapy for treating PC. Apparently, Blue Cross/Blue Shield remains back in the Stone Age. One thing jumps out at me. Because of the extra expense involved with proton therapy treatment, I would have guessed that BC/BS would have required you to receive a pre-approval letter from them prior to treatment. Now, nearly a year after treatment commenced, they mail you a "Screw You" letter? That's just not right. I would consult an attorney. Good luck, Jim

Posts.Title: My six month follow-up after Proton therapy at U F Health Proton Institute Florida

Posts.Content: Welcome brake: Ready2Fight is highly accurate in describing the best way to absorb the initial shock. It's the way that most engineers (I'm not one) analyze a major problem and work toward a solution which is to first break things down into smaller components. The results of the full-body bone scan on Monday will be most helpful because it will assist in being able to rule-in or rule-out certain methodologies in proceeding with treatment. And, as you have likely learned, some form of treatment or combination of treatments will be needed with his Gleason 8 diagnosis. No one here will sugarcoat the fact that G8 is an aggressive form of prostate cancer. But there is absolutely no reason to feel "hopeless". If your husband had to have cancer, this is the one he wants. Prostate cancer has very high survival rates and even in a worst case scenario, if a "cure" is not possible, the number of treatments available will often allow for a full life span. That's not to be taken lightly as, for example, a pancreatic cancer patient is looking at an average 6% five-year survival rate following diagnosis. Please let us know the results of the bone scan. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Hubby just diagnosed

Posts.Content: Oh, brother. I would love to be a fly on the wall as you explain to the wife-unit that some stranger on the Internet named "ddayglo" insists that you MUST have as much sex as possible RIGHT NOW. Not that I disagree, but that should be quite an encounter. You've probably read about government panels stating that unnecessary PSA tests and biopsies lead some men to have treatments/radiation/surgeries that lead to possible impotence and incontinence. And that something other than prostate cancer will likely kill you first. What they never mention is that if something else doesn't kill you first, then prostate cancer will indeed kill you. Prior to my DaVinci surgery, my Gleason score was 3+4=7 and it was explained to me that most men under 60 have surgery and most men over 70 have radiation. Between ages 60 and 70, the patient is left to decide. At age 68, I decided on the surgery. For me, it was a no-brainer. During the same month as my diagnosis, a local university president died of prostate cancer. He was also age 68. I know I'm not as smart as a university president but, apparently, he wasn't smart enough to have a PSA test. As noted above, at your age, surgery seems to be the right choice but you would serve yourself and your family well by doing as much due diligence as possible to consider the potential for unexpected outcomes. A Gleason score of 6 means you are not in imminent danger. You have time. It's very likely that your decision will remain the same and that's fine. I wish you the best. Jim

Posts.Title: Well Crap!

Posts.Content: Hi Steve: As someone who has completed 40 sessions of salvage radiation, I can attest to two things: First, it was a piece of cake -- for me, a little fatigue at the end -- nothing more. Secondly, with all due respect to Michael's travelogue of Boston sights (and I never disagree with Michael), I encourage you to Google the benefits of Centerfolds Boston, located on LaGrange Street, one of the highest rated strip clubs in Boston. It has 242 online reviews of which 88% are positive. With all of the crap that we have had to go through, you deserve to treat yourself to a lap dance. Of course, in the absence of a medical degree, I cannot attest to any improvement other than a 10-minute smile on your face. Wishing you the best -- always, Jim

As I awoke in the hospital recovery rooms from prostate surgery (2010), spine surgery (2011) and kidney stone surgery (2014), the daughter who lives locally was the first person to come into focus.

Posts.Title: HIFU Treatment Receives FDA Approval

Posts.Content: Hi PDV: First, let me say that you have pinpointed the target in the "big picture". We're still here. Sometimes on this site, as the months go by after treatment, there is a tendency in some quarters to complain about various side issues of this disease, some temporary, some permanent. What they often overlook is that they would have nothing to whine about if they weren't still around. Positive margins, for the most part, usually mean nothing. Sometimes, it can be a precursor to the return of PC as it was in my case, three years after surgery. But, even then, it can usually be addressed with salvage radiation to "clean up" anything remaining. For me, it was important to keep a close eye on the PSA tests and to act sooner employing salvage radiation, rather than later if you detect an upward trend in the numbers. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Here for my husband

Posts.Content: A second opinion is always a good idea. On this website, surgery or radiation is the normal response -- and you will get that from me also. At age 68, my hypertension and high cholesterol was well controlled by medication. I chose DaVinci robotic surgery. Zero side effects. Catheter bag at home for 8 days was a nuisance. But here's a primary consideration for making a decision of surgery or radiation: If you select surgery and the cancer returns, your Dad can then have radiation (as I did - see below). If you select radiation and the cancer returns, your Dad (except in very rare instances) cannot have surgery. During surgery, the prostate is removed as if very carefully peeling an orange. Radiation tends to destroy that possibility. Gather as much info as possible before deciding. Best of luck. Jim

Posts.Title: Maybe I'm too analytical, but I'll ask this question anyway.

Posts.Content: From Wikipedia: "Finasteride, sold under the brand names Proscar and Propecia among others, is a medication used for the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia (enlarged prostate)." As a non-medical professional, this is probably a dumb question, but your use of Finasteride is somewhat puzzling to me. If the primary application of Finasteride is for treatment of an enlarged prostate, why would you use it in the absence of a prostate? Combined with the addition of Pomi-T, you may successfully have MASKED the neon red blinking warning signs of increasing PSA numbers that “could” lead to life-saving salvage radiation. Congratulations -- NOT. The manipulated reduction in your PSA number post-surgery is counter-productive. Reducing the PSA number has no effect on the actual spread of prostate cancer. If you do reach the point of experiencing pain (hopefully this will not be the case), it may be from cancer metastasizing to the bones. And that's not a good thing.

Posts.Title: Maybe I'm too analytical, but I'll ask this question anyway.

Posts.Content: Hi Steven: Chuck covered it better than any of the rest of us could. You obviously have something going on but nothing that fits with anything I've ever seen before related to prostate cancer. At age 43, a PSA reading of 6 is not normal. If nothing is found and you still have problems, then a prostate biopsy may be in your future. No one welcomes the biopsy and, although most say it can't be described as painful, nevertheless, it is uncomfortable. But it is currently the ONLY way to confirm the presence of prostate cancer. Since the biopsy only reviews small sections of the prostate, sometimes the biopsy will be a false negative if it misses the actual cancer present. And I just wanted to reiterate what Chuck said about symptoms of prostate cancer. Most patients on this site never had a single symptom. They investigated only after receiving an abnormal PSA blood test reading. Thanks mainly to the widespread acceptance of PSA testing starting in 1992, overall deaths from PC have dropped 44%. We would be very interested in your outcome, PC or not. Best of luck, Jim

Different "strokes" for different folks. Jim

Posts.Title: Just feel comfort in posting here

Posts.Content: I think a key word here is "trending". If you see an upward trend, you do have a cause for concern. But your numbers are SO low that, as the others have pointed out, you are certainly in no imminent danger. I would be comfortable with waiting another year for your next PSA and, if you don't have that much patience, try every six months. Some sources recommend not even blinking at any PSA reading below 0.1, but I found it helpful (please see history below) watching the micro numbers climb so I could be prepared to take action when it was warranted. Officially, salvage radiation is recommended to be considered AFTER you receive PSA readings above 0.2 on two consecutive tests. Since my "trend" was distinctive, I signed up for SR after my PSA reached 0.11. But everyone is different. What's right for me is not necessarily the correct decision for anyone else.

Posts.Title: Psa post robotic prostate removal

Posts.Content: From Wikipedia: "Finasteride, sold under the brand names Proscar and Propecia among others, is a medication used for the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia (enlarged prostate)." As a non-medical professional, this is probably a dumb question, but your use of Finasteride is somewhat puzzling to me. If the primary application of Finasteride is for treatment of an enlarged prostate, why would you use it in the absence of a prostate? Combined with the addition of Pomi-T, you may successfully have MASKED the neon red blinking warning signs of increasing PSA numbers that “could” lead to life-saving salvage radiation. Congratulations -- NOT. The manipulated reduction in your PSA number post-surgery is counter-productive. Reducing the PSA number has no effect on the actual spread of prostate cancer. If you do reach the point of experiencing pain (hopefully this will not be the case), it may be from cancer metastasizing to the bones. And that's not a good thing.

Posts.Title: Back in the 0 Club!

Posts.Content: Four to six weeks seems fine for most jobs. However, when you say you may have to use physical force, that's another story because you certainly don't want to take a chance that some scumbag might punch you in the lower abdomen. Also, at 4 to 6 weeks, you'll probably not want to encounter the need to climb over a high fence while pursuing a subject. For those reasons, I would suggest stretching your return time somewhat longer.

Best of luck.

Posts.Title: New PSA Testing Recommendations

Posts.Content: Fairwind: By using Pomi-T to cut the PSA doubling time in half, doesn't that just "mask" the true PSA numbers? I see that you have already undergone salvage radiotherapy -- as have I -- but for others who are experiencing a chemical recurrence following a prostatectomy, isn't there a danger that masking an actual PSA reading will provide a false sense of complacency while the cancer possibly continues to spread unabated? I ask these questions, not because I have a finite answer -- I don't, but because I don't know whether delaying SR would be productive for a patient under this scenario. You've provided info on this site longer than most of us. What are your thoughts? Jim

Posts.Title: PSA rising after prostatectomy

Posts.Content: I concur with lancepeace. The commencement of hormone therapy, instead of surgery or radiation as the first line of defense, is telling. Although I know it is painful for you to imagine, is it possible that your Dad could have been shielding you from a diagnosis of a more aggressive form of prostate cancer? For example, if he had any Cat scans or full body bone scans following his initial diagnosis in 2008, they may have divulged metastasis to other areas of his body. You could start there to investigate if you are so inclined. Again, we are not doctors and at this point can only speculate. I, too, am very sorry for your loss.

Posts.Title: Here we go again

Posts.Content: Although you will find a number of different opinions on this site with respect to how to proceed, I think the majority of posters favor surgery over radiation, but not by a large margin. As you can see from my signature, that was my choice. However, as you go forward with your research, my history contains vital criteria. If you have surgery and the cancer returns, you can then turn to radiation to finish it off. If you choose radiation as your primary treatment and the cancer returns, surgery is not possible (except in extremely rare cases). That's what sold me on the surgery -- and lucky it did.

Posts.Title: Need to decide - what would you do and why did you choose it?

Posts.Content: With respect to being concerned about potential damage caused by salvage radiotherapy, my experience was the same as Allen's -- no change to ED or continence. But the issue of proposing radiation due to positive margins in the bladder neck in the absence of an increase in PSA is a head-scratcher. I know that the Mayo Clinic is considered to be top-of-the-line, however I would be inclined to get a non-Mayo second opinion before commencing with radiation.

Posts.Title: Radiation after robotic removal

Posts.Content: Hi Georgia Gal (in Michigan?? - is summer reduced to one week there?): Since you have already decided on surgery, I'd just like to add one more nugget of info which you have likely read about in Dr. Walsh's book but seems to be mentioned only infrequently on this thread: Unlike with primary radiation to treat the cancer, surgery provides the opportunity for a second bite at the apple, if necessary. I'm speaking of a possible recurrence and the fact that salvage radiation is then an option (please see my history below). Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Content: Hi loves: You're right to be concerned about Gleason 9 which is advanced cancer but I'm not telling you anything that you're not already aware of. If it was wholly encapsulted in the prostate, then you can breathe easier but still must be watchful in the future. If you haven't already received it, I strongly suggest you obtain a copy of the surgical report and study it carefully. Then, if you have any questions, you can ask the doctor at the next appointment. Immediately after surgery, my doctor said he felt they got it all but in actuality they didn't (see signature below). I wasn't smart enough to ask for a copy of the surgical report which stated that the margins weren't clear. Lesson learned. Best of luck to you both. Jim

Posts.Content: Hi lurover: Fear of the unknown can often lead to irrational conclusions. Prostate cancer is almost always treatable and curable. That's true for believers and non-believers alike. Millions of men have gone before you and the overwhelming majority of us look back on the experience as merely a small bump along life's highway. Try not to fret. And please be sure to come back after your surgery when members can offer suggestions about how to deal with nuisance items (like leakage, etc.). Best of luck. Jim

Posts.Title: Gleason 9, PSA 18

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Fairwind I also feel Jim's post is way out of line....We are not here to pass judgement on people especially when the criticism reaches the point of ridicule. Jim, that was uncalled for.... Fairwind: I understand your position. My objective was not to ridicule but rather to bring attention to the OP's history and his total disregard for flashing red lights AND, MORE IMPORTANTLY, how that impacts upon first-time visitors to this website. For example, anyone with a family history of PC, who ignores clear-cut warning signs (PSA of 10 for 5-6 years without follow-up) needs to have his case held up to the light as something that NEWBIES SHOULD NOT VIEW AS THE NORM. If it wasn't for unfiltered comments like mine "calling out" the OP for dereliction to saving his own life -- which, of course, is his right, any newbie reading his history could easily view it as acceptable conduct. Of all people, I don't need to remind you of the 30,000 PC deaths every year. A first-time viewer on this site could interpret haha's actions as being similar to his own and simply log off, thinking he's doing just fine, at least as well as haha. If not for fat mouth geezers like me, how else would he know? Being politically correct is not always correct. Jim

Posts.Content: With respect to being concerned about potential damage caused by salvage radiotherapy, my experience was the same as Allen's -- no change to ED or continence. But the issue of proposing radiation due to positive margins in the bladder neck in the absence of an increase in PSA is a head-scratcher. I know that the Mayo Clinic is considered to be top-of-the-line, however I would be inclined to get a non-Mayo second opinion before commencing with radiation.

Posts.Title: Here we go again

Posts.Content: I cannot believe that the PRIMARY treatment for prostate cancer is radiation at 58%. Although the date of the article was 2/19/15, the period studied was 2004-2007. The use of robotic surgery in the last 8 years -- AFTER this study was completed in 2007 -- has exploded in popularity. I would be interested in more up-to-date stats which, I feel certain, will show robotic surgery as the most utilized primary treatment now.

Posts.Title: Interesting Statistics on Prostate Cancer Treatment Options

Posts.Content: From Wikipedia: "Finasteride, sold under the brand names Proscar and Propecia among others, is a medication used for the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia (enlarged prostate)." As a non-medical professional, this is probably a dumb question, but your use of Finasteride is somewhat puzzling to me. If the primary application of Finasteride is for treatment of an enlarged prostate, why would you use it in the absence of a prostate? Combined with the addition of Pomi-T, you may successfully have MASKED the neon red blinking warning signs of increasing PSA numbers that “could” lead to life-saving salvage radiation. Congratulations -- NOT. The manipulated reduction in your PSA number post-surgery is counter-productive. Reducing the PSA number has no effect on the actual spread of prostate cancer. If you do reach the point of experiencing pain (hopefully this will not be the case), it may be from cancer metastasizing to the bones. And that's not a good thing.

Posts.Content: Tom: Where the hell did that come from? Do you have prostate cancer? Yes Is it serious? Yes Are you terminal? No How long did it take me (Gleason 3+4=7) to decide to proceed with treatment at age 68? About 30 seconds. No -- less. If you needed your car to get to work and it had a blown engine, how long would you take to decide how to proceed? You're that car, Tom, and you need to get fixed (not to be viewed as neutered). The time for hand-wringing is over. It's time for action -- ASAP. Best of luck. Jim

Posts.Title: Scheduling/choosing Treatment

Posts.Content: ^^^^^^What Chuck said. He covered a lot. You have already read a lot. Try to guard against too much information. No disrespect but it's really not rocket science. On this site, you will find many guys who chose surgery over radiation. The selling point of surgery for me was the extra grab at the brass ring if there was a recurrence post-surgery (please see below). Bingo -- for me there was a recurrence and I was able to use the salvage radiation three years post-surgery to clean up some remaining cells. If I had to do it all over again, I would change nothing. Be sure to factor in your age. My uro was in a group of 9 uros who, with rare exception, adhered to the following mantra: Under age 60 - surgery Between ages 60 & 70 - patient chooses between surgery and radiation Over age 70 - radiation At age 68, I decided that I wanted what the young guys were having. Now, at age 74, I am still (part-time) on the World Poker Tour. They even use me in a nationally broadcast television commercial. Best of luck.

Posts.Title: Current Literature to read before making my treatment decision

Posts.Content: Welcome Samie: In closely reading your post, I note that "open radical surgery" was offered, but there is no mention of the operation that is most frequently utilized today, which is DaVinci robotic prostate cancer surgery. Is that because your local hospital does not offer DaVinci? Normally, I am in lock step with my forum brother, lancepeace, but with a PSA of 39, I would be inclined to act fairly quickly in order to prevent the cancer from continuing to spread. And, as Michael has pointed out, surgery is sometimes supplemented by radiation if the cancer returns or if there is reason to believe that surgery was not successful in removing the prostate with the cancer wholly encapsulated. Your post talks about "surgery followed by probable radiation" which is somewhat unusual, unless the doctor believes that the cancer has already escaped the prostate gland. And, your husband talks about "downsides" to surgery, but seems to ignore the fact that the majority of patients, after performing their due diligence and weighing the risks -- and downsides -- of all forms of treatment, select surgery more often than any other corrective methodology. However, only he and you can make the determination as to what is right for him. As noted, Dr. Walsh's book is a great first step (we receive no royalties -- not trying to sell you anything). Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: So im ready for the surgery

Posts.Content: I concur with lancepeace. The commencement of hormone therapy, instead of surgery or radiation as the first line of defense, is telling. Although I know it is painful for you to imagine, is it possible that your Dad could have been shielding you from a diagnosis of a more aggressive form of prostate cancer? For example, if he had any Cat scans or full body bone scans following his initial diagnosis in 2008, they may have divulged metastasis to other areas of his body. You could start there to investigate if you are so inclined. Again, we are not doctors and at this point can only speculate. I, too, am very sorry for your loss.

Posts.Title: Prostate cancer death

Posts.Content: Hi Maverick: Congrats. I hope as you read this that nothing has changed. Like an old Chevy with parts wearing out, I have had to have surgery to remove kidney stones twice (2008 & 2014). Both times, they had to insert a long stent in the left ureter for about 7 days following surgery to prevent collapse. Both times, I had trouble with the stent. The last time, with the stent inserted on the 5th day after surgery, I could not pee. Not a drop. It happened at midnight. I called the on-call urologist and he said to stop by the office in the morning. For the next 8 hours, I drank nothing but understood that the body produces urine nevertheless. I don't scare easily but I had visions of my bladder filling up and bursting. At 8AM, they removed the stent early -- problem solved -- and I breathed a large sigh of relief. Crazy stuff happens when you get old. I keep looking up in case a grand piano is about to fall on my head. Jim

Posts.Title: Gleason 9, PSA 18

Posts.Content: Hi loves: You're right to be concerned about Gleason 9 which is advanced cancer but I'm not telling you anything that you're not already aware of. If it was wholly encapsulted in the prostate, then you can breathe easier but still must be watchful in the future. If you haven't already received it, I strongly suggest you obtain a copy of the surgical report and study it carefully. Then, if you have any questions, you can ask the doctor at the next appointment. Immediately after surgery, my doctor said he felt they got it all but in actuality they didn't (see signature below). I wasn't smart enough to ask for a copy of the surgical report which stated that the margins weren't clear. Lesson learned. Best of luck to you both. Jim

Posts.Title: So im ready for the surgery

Posts.Content: In answer to your question regarding open versus robotic surgery, the first thing that comes to mind is not just the down time but the down time with pain, not one of my favorite pursuits. With DaVinci, 8 days at home with the catheter was an annoyance but I had zero pain overall, although very uncomfortable for the first 24 hours following surgery. Never even needed an aspirin after 24 hours. When I compare my experience to a co-worker who had open surgery and literally suffered significant pain over two months, then for me it's a no-brainer. Robotic wins, hands down.

Posts.Content: It's probably not related to your shoulder issue (since it has been confirmed as metastatic) but I had a very strange resolution about ten years ago to frozen shoulder. I could not raise my right arm above my belt line. My orthopedic doctor scheduled me for the OR under general anesthesia. I asked how big the scar would be. He said that built-up cartilage had to be broken up, however there would be no need for a scalpel. Basically, they put me under the gas and then about 5 or 6 guys all pulled on my arm at once breaking apart the strictures. It worked great. There is probably a name for what they did but I don't have any idea what it is.

Posts.Title: Radiotherapy

Posts.Content: Welcome John: Although I'm from PA, your City by the Bay is my favorite, having visited 20 years in a row. My great-grandfather was one of the founders of a Utopian-type town just north of you in 1890. You've probably heard of it -- it's called Mill Valley. Anyway, others who are more qualified will be able to fill in the answers to many of your questions. As you have already discovered, surgery and radiation are the two primary forms of prostate cancer treatment. Each is considered to be about equally successful with side effects popping up at different times. Brachytherapy has worked well for some of our forum brothers but be advised it is considered to be outside of the mainstream as it is the choice of only 2% of PC patients. If you are comfortable being a two-percenter, then you should be fine. I note you used the phrase "cured of prostate cancer" more than once. Having dealt with it twice (How the hell can you get prostate cancer three years after your prostate has been removed?), I am of the personal opinion that you can never be confident that you are ever "cured", just like an alcoholic is an alcoholic for their entire lives, regardless of their sobriety. I view cancer in general as being equivalent to the "Whack a Mole" carnival game. If you knock it down in one place, it has a tendency to pop up somewhere else. John Wayne famously announced that he had beaten the Big C when he was operated on for lung cancer. A few years later, he died of stomach cancer. But maybe I'm just a pessimist. Finally, it is presumptuous to note in your history that your PC is "confined to the gland". At this point in your journey, it is impossible to know that. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: A little learning is a dangerous thing . . .

Posts.Content: I love MichiganMan16. I love Michael F. But I must respectfully disagree on the subject of PSA possibly causing "anxiety", so let's just stay uninformed instead. As noted in the past, my knowledge of a PSA "creeping" up helped me to mentally deal with the need for salvage radiation when it came time to be zapped. As an old guy, I lean toward using analogies -- try this one: You live in Florida. You have a small inflatable pool in the back yard filled with 12 inches of water. Your 18-month-old grandchild is playing and splashing in the pool. You walk back into the house for just a few seconds. As you do, an alligator leaves a nearby swamp and heads for the pool. Question: Do you want to be alerted when the alligator is 100 yards away from the pool or just 2 yards away? Would you NOT want to know when it's 100 yards away because it may cause you "anxiety"? Jim

Posts.Title: Gleason 9, PSA 18

Posts.Content: Welcome Samie: In closely reading your post, I note that "open radical surgery" was offered, but there is no mention of the operation that is most frequently utilized today, which is DaVinci robotic prostate cancer surgery. Is that because your local hospital does not offer DaVinci? Normally, I am in lock step with my forum brother, lancepeace, but with a PSA of 39, I would be inclined to act fairly quickly in order to prevent the cancer from continuing to spread. And, as Michael has pointed out, surgery is sometimes supplemented by radiation if the cancer returns or if there is reason to believe that surgery was not successful in removing the prostate with the cancer wholly encapsulated. Your post talks about "surgery followed by probable radiation" which is somewhat unusual, unless the doctor believes that the cancer has already escaped the prostate gland. And, your husband talks about "downsides" to surgery, but seems to ignore the fact that the majority of patients, after performing their due diligence and weighing the risks -- and downsides -- of all forms of treatment, select surgery more often than any other corrective methodology. However, only he and you can make the determination as to what is right for him. As noted, Dr. Walsh's book is a great first step (we receive no royalties -- not trying to sell you anything). Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Content: Welcome Frisco - glad to have you aboard: I have no reason to doubt the statement about Medicare but my first inclination -- with all due respect -- is to say "So, what?" PSA tests are relatively inexpensive and if Medicare decided not to pay, most patients would simply pay out of pocket because of the need to know where you are in the recovery progression. After someone has gone through treatment -- surgery or, in your case, radiation -- the cost of PSA tests is so inconsequential and so far down the worry scale, it's hardly worth thinking about. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: PSA test frequency covered under Medicare

Posts.Content: Hi loves: You're right to be concerned about Gleason 9 which is advanced cancer but I'm not telling you anything that you're not already aware of. If it was wholly encapsulted in the prostate, then you can breathe easier but still must be watchful in the future. If you haven't already received it, I strongly suggest you obtain a copy of the surgical report and study it carefully. Then, if you have any questions, you can ask the doctor at the next appointment. Immediately after surgery, my doctor said he felt they got it all but in actuality they didn't (see signature below). I wasn't smart enough to ask for a copy of the surgical report which stated that the margins weren't clear. Lesson learned. Best of luck to you both. Jim

Posts.Title: Gleason 9, PSA 18

Posts.Content: Although you will find a number of different opinions on this site with respect to how to proceed, I think the majority of posters favor surgery over radiation, but not by a large margin. As you can see from my signature, that was my choice. However, as you go forward with your research, my history contains vital criteria. If you have surgery and the cancer returns, you can then turn to radiation to finish it off. If you choose radiation as your primary treatment and the cancer returns, surgery is not possible (except in extremely rare cases). That's what sold me on the surgery -- and lucky it did.

Posts.Title: Gleason 3+3, Age 57

Posts.Content: Welcome Samie: In closely reading your post, I note that "open radical surgery" was offered, but there is no mention of the operation that is most frequently utilized today, which is DaVinci robotic prostate cancer surgery. Is that because your local hospital does not offer DaVinci? Normally, I am in lock step with my forum brother, lancepeace, but with a PSA of 39, I would be inclined to act fairly quickly in order to prevent the cancer from continuing to spread. And, as Michael has pointed out, surgery is sometimes supplemented by radiation if the cancer returns or if there is reason to believe that surgery was not successful in removing the prostate with the cancer wholly encapsulated. Your post talks about "surgery followed by probable radiation" which is somewhat unusual, unless the doctor believes that the cancer has already escaped the prostate gland. And, your husband talks about "downsides" to surgery, but seems to ignore the fact that the majority of patients, after performing their due diligence and weighing the risks -- and downsides -- of all forms of treatment, select surgery more often than any other corrective methodology. However, only he and you can make the determination as to what is right for him. As noted, Dr. Walsh's book is a great first step (we receive no royalties -- not trying to sell you anything). Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: At what stage does PC spread

Posts.Content: Hi mcnova: Welcome to the forum. Sorry you and your father have a need to be here. I can identify with his situation as I was also age 67 (see signature history below) when diagnosed with PC and my PSA level was similar. There are a number of suggestions that you will receive from those who come after me (surgery, radiation, etc.) on this site so I will speak only of the question you asked about waiting for higher scores before initiating treatment. My opinion: Don't. While surgery remains an option now, in a relatively short time, it may be one of the options taken off of the table as he reaches age 70. At that point, radiation may be the only hope for a "cure". And, to compound the dilemma, if he has surgery and the cancer returns (as mine did), he can then have salvage radiotherapy to eradicate the remaining cancer. On the other hand, if he selects radiation, he cannot (except in very rare instances) have surgery next because the prostate is deformed during radiation in such a way as to not permit surgery. Another issue is the Gleason 6 diagnosis; treatment now is almost always 100% successful as you read in Dr. Walsh's book. But a higher Gleason score may be indicative of a less successful outcome as it will possibly reveal a more aggressive strain of PC and/or show that the cancer has already spread to surrounding lymph nodes and, potentially, other organs. Right or wrong, I have never been a proponent of active surveillance. Nothing good can ever happen as the cancer isn't magically going to go away. Best of luck and I hope you find the info you seek and convince your Dad that action is indeed warranted at this point. Jim
