Posts.Title: Att: Rob Lee

Posts.Content: Hi David: I strongly agree with Ron. Unless you have a reason to believe that your biopsy was flawed in some way (unlikely), there appears to be no need for a second biopsy. You have extensive cancer within the prostate, albeit of the lower-risk G6 variety. And keep in mind that if you choose surgery, that G6 could possibly be upgraded to a higher number upon surgical pathological examination of the excised prostate. Surgery or radiation appears to be the logical treatment choices -- both have nearly identical successful outcomes, on average.. However, if you have a recurrence following surgery as your primary treatment, you can always revert to salvage radiation to "clean up" anything remaining. If you select radiation as your primary treatment, surgery is no longer an option. It was that "second bite at the apple" that helped to make my decision for me and, lucky that I did, because I needed salvage radiation 3 years after DaVinci surgery. What worked well for me, though, is not for everyone. Only you can decide what is the best path for yourself. Best of luck, Jim

My objective was not to ridicule but rather to bring attention to the OP's history and his total disregard for flashing red lights AND, MORE IMPORTANTLY, how that impacts upon first-time visitors to this website. For example, anyone with a family history of PC, who ignores clear-cut warning signs (PSA of 10 for 5-6 years without follow-up) needs to have his case held up to the light as something that NEWBIES SHOULD NOT VIEW AS THE NORM. Of all people, I don't need to remind you of the 30,000 PC deaths every year. A first-time viewer on this site could interpret haha's actions as being similar to his own and simply log off, thinking he's doing just fine, at least as well as haha. If not for fat mouth geezers like me, how else would he know? Being politically correct is not always correct. Jim

Posts.Content: Fairwind: In PA, Medicare Advantage plans carry ridiculously high premiums (the Philadelphia Inquirer profiled a Medicare Advantage couple whose monthly premium increased by 47% in one year), and deductibles and co-pays are so high (ie., $45 co-pay to see a GP, $65 to see a specialist) that having Medicare Advantage is almost like having no insurance at all. That's the reason why only 13% of Medicare recipients in PA select Advantage. Anytime that 87% of a group of people pick the original Medicare as their coverage, there is a reason for it. Most then buy a Medigap policy to pay for the Part A deductible and the remaining 20% of charges left unpaid under Medicare Part B plus the $147 annual Part B deductible (under Medigap Plans C, D and F). In the seven years I have had original Medicare and a Medigap Plan F policy, I have never had to fill out a single form or pay a penny for a deductible or co-pay, including a bill for $240,000 sent to Medicare for 40 sessions of salvage radiotherapy following a prostatectomy. Jim

Posts.Title: Important non-political Information for Medicare Patients.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by GunsmokeFan Jim215: thank you for your reply. How would we find out what percentage of patients choose this? or any treatment? And do you know how we could find statistics of rates of side affects (other than maybe what the doctor who does the focal cryotherapy may say)? Hi GF: Sorry for the delay in responding. It appeared to me from your husband's profile with multiple listings of PSA tests and an absence of primary treatment that your inquiry related to considering cryotherapy as primary treatment. Of course, Pratoman had the good sense to ask whether it was primary or secondary. Since my guess without research was that only about 2% of prostate cancer patients elect to have cryotherapy, I did a Google search. And I found that among all PC patients (primary and secondary), cryotherapy is selected by......2% of the men. It is described on many health care sites as being"...a viable alternative among a paucity of choices for patients who experience a biochemical recurrence after failed primary radiation treatment." As far as specific side effects, I wish I could provide some info but I do not have the resources to do so with any level of confidence. My first reaction was to being uncomfortable with the recommendations of "celebrity" doctors, like Dr. Katz and Dr. Oz on television who sometimes cloud an issue that may be quite straightforward. For example, Dr. Katz has stated that "over 80%" of prostate cancer patients do NOT need surgery or radiation as their primary treatment and he seems to have his own objectives by creating active surveillance foundations and selling books. Yes, there can be unwanted, sometimes quite serious, side effects from surgery or radiation, but PC kills 30,000 men every year and any attempt to guide patients away from primary treatment -- without examining the patient in person -- just rubs me the wrong way.

Posts.Title: PSA rising (slowly) after prostatectomy

Posts.Content: In answer to your question regarding open versus robotic surgery, the first thing that comes to mind is not just the down time but the down time with pain, not one of my favorite pursuits. With DaVinci, 8 days at home with the catheter was an annoyance but I had zero pain overall, although very uncomfortable for the first 24 hours following surgery. Never even needed an aspirin after 24 hours. When I compare my experience to a co-worker who had open surgery and literally suffered significant pain over two months, then for me it's a no-brainer. Robotic wins, hands down.

Posts.Title: Open or Robotic, which to choose

Posts.Content: Hi Izicc: Welcome to the forum. You will find a fine group of caring people here who will readily share their personal experiences and provide information to the best of their ability. There are no conflicts of interest because no one is trying to sell you anything. At the same time, you may find posters who are in favor of a particular type of treatment, more so than an alternative, and that's OK because it worked for them. My only comments are: The nurse is correct that once the prostate is removed, the cancerous gland is gone but it's still very important to watch your PSA results post-surgery as the cancer can return (as shown in my history/signature below). One of the major benefits of having surgery instead of radiation (there's my bias kicking in) is that you can have salvage radiation after surgery but not surgery after radiation -- except in very rare cases. And it is also possible that your preliminary Gleason 6 could actually be pathologically upgraded to Gleason 7 post-surgery. Your doctor will be able to tell you his protocol for removal of lymph nodes (some docs take more than others). Best of luck to you and please keep us updated with your decisions/treatment/outcome which may be helpful to others. Jim

Posts.Title: Unfortunately, I had to join this forum. :(

Posts.Content: Hi Fred: Well, your PSA is certainly nothing to be concerned about, but if two doctors have confirmed that there is an irregularity with respect to a hard nodule on your prostate, then it certainly seems prudent to investigate. A prostate biopsy is nothing more than a diagnostic tool that takes a very small sample of your prostate and sends it to the lab. A biopsy is the only test that can detect and confirm the presence of cancer in the prostate, which would be unusual at age 43 but not unheard of. Like most diagnostic tests, it is performed to rule out, not rule in, a particular disease. You could elect to do active surveillance (AS) and have the area re-checked in 3 to 6 months. Most prostate cancers are slow-growing and, therefore, a delay may be reasonable. However, there are also less frequent strains of prostate cancer that are fast-moving and can actually kill you rather quickly. So, if you delay, you are accepting somewhat of a risk. I would view your description of a biopsy as "overwhelming" to be somewhat overstated. The test is frequently performed in the doctor's office and takes about ten minutes to complete. There is rarely pain involved, but the procedure is uncomfortable and you may be sore for 24-48 hours. The test is not life-threatening. Others will follow with additional info. Please let us know how you make out. Good luck. Jim

Posts.Content: Hi gsteve: Glad to hear your PSA is still at zero. In many cases, "zero" is defined as any reading below 0.1 which is officially considered to be "undetectable", but may actually be detectable if you go to the second decimal. So, if you view my history at the end of my two years after DaVinci, I too was in the "undetectable" category at the same time that the cancer was once again beginning to rear its ugly head. Your last sentence is exactly what I would suggest. However, at the end of the 2nd year after DaVinci with no evidence of a recurrence, many uros recommend a PSA test only once a year. My feeling -- regardless of "medical protocol" -- especially with my history, is that I will never be comfortable waiting longer than every six months between PSA tests. Good luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Unfortunately, I had to join this forum. :(

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Nick P MichiganMan Why am I waiting? I'm following the advice I'm given. My Surgeon is the Professor of Urology and my Oncologist is the Professor of Medicine and Surgery, both at the University of Arizona Cancer Center. I figured I was in good hands. I've put in a call to see if I can accelerate this treatment schedule after the comments I've received here. Nick Welcome Nick: Your stats -- age 68 and G7 (3+4, for me) at the time of surgery -- are identical to mine. Was G7 your final post-surgery pathology result, also? The comments from Michael and MM16 are highly knowledgeable but somewhat subdued compared to what you will hear from me. Picture this: bright flashing neon red lights, loud bells gonging, sirens blasting...... Now, take a look at my history that shows my salvage radiation treatment (no HT - never mentioned) BEGAN at 0.11. If your decimal places are correct on your PSA tests, as noted by Michael, your current status of PSA 1.0 without follow-up treatment is TEN TIMES WORSE than when I commenced salvage radiation. My 40 sessions of SR resulted in NO side effects with the exception of some mild fatigue toward the end. Six years after surgery and 3 years after SR, my PSA remains at 0.00. I can only conclude that there must be some other medical reasoning for not addressing your status with some ACTION. Or the acclaimed doctor you listed may be suffering from early-onset Alzheimer's Disease. Thanks to his non-action, you MAY now be past the point of cure (as mentioned) but rather are simply looking for an extension of life treatment. And, based upon your rising PSA numbers, if you don't act QUICKLY you may not get that opportunity. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Telling employees at work

Posts.Content: Although you will find a number of different opinions on this site with respect to how to proceed, I think the majority of posters favor surgery over radiation, but not by a large margin. As you can see from my signature, that was my choice. However, as you go forward with your research, my history contains vital criteria. If you have surgery and the cancer returns, you can then turn to radiation to finish it off. If you choose radiation as your primary treatment and the cancer returns, surgery is not possible (except in extremely rare cases). That's what sold me on the surgery -- and lucky it did.

Posts.Title: Unfortunately, I had to join this forum. :(

Posts.Content: Welcome John: Although I'm from PA, your City by the Bay is my favorite, having visited 20 years in a row. My great-grandfather was one of the founders of a Utopian-type town just north of you in 1890. You've probably heard of it -- it's called Mill Valley. Anyway, others who are more qualified will be able to fill in the answers to many of your questions. As you have already discovered, surgery and radiation are the two primary forms of prostate cancer treatment. Each is considered to be about equally successful with side effects popping up at different times. Brachytherapy has worked well for some of our forum brothers but be advised it is considered to be outside of the mainstream as it is the choice of only 2% of PC patients. If you are comfortable being a two-percenter, then you should be fine. I note you used the phrase "cured of prostate cancer" more than once. Having dealt with it twice (How the hell can you get prostate cancer three years after your prostate has been removed?), I am of the personal opinion that you can never be confident that you are ever "cured", just like an alcoholic is an alcoholic for their entire lives, regardless of their sobriety. I view cancer in general as being equivalent to the "Whack a Mole" carnival game. If you knock it down in one place, it has a tendency to pop up somewhere else. John Wayne famously announced that he had beaten the Big C when he was operated on for lung cancer. A few years later, he died of stomach cancer. But maybe I'm just a pessimist. Finally, it is presumptuous to note in your history that your PC is "confined to the gland". At this point in your journey, it is impossible to know that. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: New Here - urologist wants to do biopsy

Posts.Content: Hi Fred: Well, your PSA is certainly nothing to be concerned about, but if two doctors have confirmed that there is an irregularity with respect to a hard nodule on your prostate, then it certainly seems prudent to investigate. A prostate biopsy is nothing more than a diagnostic tool that takes a very small sample of your prostate and sends it to the lab. A biopsy is the only test that can detect and confirm the presence of cancer in the prostate, which would be unusual at age 43 but not unheard of. Like most diagnostic tests, it is performed to rule out, not rule in, a particular disease. You could elect to do active surveillance (AS) and have the area re-checked in 3 to 6 months. Most prostate cancers are slow-growing and, therefore, a delay may be reasonable. However, there are also less frequent strains of prostate cancer that are fast-moving and can actually kill you rather quickly. So, if you delay, you are accepting somewhat of a risk. I would view your description of a biopsy as "overwhelming" to be somewhat overstated. The test is frequently performed in the doctor's office and takes about ten minutes to complete. There is rarely pain involved, but the procedure is uncomfortable and you may be sore for 24-48 hours. The test is not life-threatening. Others will follow with additional info. Please let us know how you make out. Good luck. Jim

Posts.Title: New Here - urologist wants to do biopsy

Posts.Content: Welcome Rob: Michael F and Chuck have done such a good job covering the subject, my only input is agreement that if you want to get the most accurate biopsy, currently the 3T MRI offers the best chance of not missing anything. Your concerns are similar to literally thousands of guys who visit this site. There is absolutely no reason to be terrified of anything. I know it's easy for me to say but you're looking at a diagnostic TEST only, for now. And, even under a worst case scenario, prostate cancer is nearly always curable when found early and treated. But don't put the cart before the horse (you'll hear a lot of silly old clichés here). Just take it one step at a time. We'll be here. Again, no one on this site is a medical professional but we've all been there - done that and we've been of help to a lot of people. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: A little learning is a dangerous thing . . .

Posts.Content: With all due respect, as usual, I probably fall into the category of Devil's Advocate. The discussion seems centered on testing, testing, testing. My take is this: why the hell is ANYONE talking about testing when -- as Chuck pointed out -- the patient has ALREADY been CONFIRMED to have prostate cancer. Instead of worrying whether something bad is going on with a constantly rising PSA -- "What should I do? What should I do?", to me, the answer is rudimentary: get it the hell out of there and let post-surgery pathology figure out what's actually in there. If I was the patient, with two brothers with PC, I would be shopping this morning at Wal-Mart for a robe and slippers for my overnight hospital stay following surgery. But I guess I'm just a crazy old man.

Posts.Title: Need some advice, guidance and\or feedback on my recent issue

Posts.Content: Hi jphil: As Southsider said, a full-body bone scan is routine and intended to rule out metastasis to other areas of the body. It's not impossible but it is unlikely in your husband's case with Gleason 6 & 7s. And a 3+4=7 Gleason score is better than a 4+3=7 score. The former is what both your husband and I presented. My urologist said that I shouldn't feel special because a 3+4=7 Gleason is just the run-of-the-mill type of cancer seen every day in his office. Not a big deal. Treat it and move on just like it never happened. Of course, you will want to arm yourself with enough info to proceed. Our moderator, Chuck, should be along shortly to fill in the basics. Best of luck. Jim

Posts.Title: Second Opinion on Prostate Biopsy

Posts.Content: I agree with Chuck. Some people may be able to forego a second opinion on a prostate cancer biopsy but I'm not one of them. Since a decision as to how to proceed is predicated on getting the biopsy result right, then I believe that $250 is money well spent. At age 56, I assume your husband is not on Medicare Disability since Medicare will pay for that second opinion. In that way, my wife saved $250 by being married to a geezer, one of very few such benefits.

Posts.Title: Second Opinion on Prostate Biopsy

Posts.Content: "I just pray that the results won't be cancer." Worst case scenario: it's prostate cancer. Best news possible: if you're going to have cancer, this is the one you want. Caught early, it is almost always 100% curable. Other cancers on this forum web site have a five-year survival rate as low as 6%. So, while some people may focus on the dreaded term "cancer" and the fear factor is naturally elevated, mortality issues rarely play a part in our prostate cancer thread. Instead, some guys exercise, while the rest of us play poker, drink beer and talk about all of the women who try to rip our clothes off. I join the others in stating that I've never heard of any side effects following a biopsy. Good luck with your biopsy today. Jim

Posts.Title: Prostate Biopsy Is Today

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by PDV Felt great Saturday and probably pushed. Swelling and pain increased throughout afternoon. Local hospital transferred me to Boston. Urinary tract infection and something called limphecile or something like that. In till tomorrow at least With all of the various contributions to this site by patients, I had never before heard of lymphoceles which is described by Wikipedia below as a likely surgical complication: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lymphocele It's apparently so unusual that the spellchecker on this site (cancerforums.net) does not recognize the word even though I have spelled it correctly. There is no explanation as to whether overexertion may have been a factor, but if it was, then your experience should be a clarion call to others to take it easy following surgery. Hope the worst has passed by now, Jim

Posts.Content: As Michael said, call the office back. Sometimes, you need to be assertive to get the results you need. For example, if you get an inflexible office clerk on the phone, insist that the doctor phone you back personally within the next 24 hours to resolve the situation. Twenty-two days with a catheter (unless medically necessary as described by Brandon) would have driven me to the highest point on a bridge.

Posts.Title: Catheter removal times?

Posts.Content: You may first want to check to see what percentage of prostate cancer patients pursue focal cryotherapy. If that number is around 2%, that means that 98% of patients have rejected it for various reasons. And if 98% of patients have rejected it, I would want to know why. I think you will find that the overwhelming majority of patients on this site have elected either surgery or radiation as their primary treatment, with each having roughly the same rate of success.

Posts.Title: Why Men and Couples Suffer Alone

Posts.Content: Hi gsteve: Glad to hear your PSA is still at zero. In many cases, "zero" is defined as any reading below 0.1 which is officially considered to be "undetectable", but may actually be detectable if you go to the second decimal. So, if you view my history at the end of my two years after DaVinci, I too was in the "undetectable" category at the same time that the cancer was once again beginning to rear its ugly head. Your last sentence is exactly what I would suggest. However, at the end of the 2nd year after DaVinci with no evidence of a recurrence, many uros recommend a PSA test only once a year. My feeling -- regardless of "medical protocol" -- especially with my history, is that I will never be comfortable waiting longer than every six months between PSA tests. Good luck, Jim

Again, no one on this site is a medical professional but we've all been there - done that and we've been of help to a lot of people. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Need some advice, guidance and\or feedback on my recent issue

Posts.Content: Ron: Prior to my DaVinci surgery, I never had a catheter before -- didn't know how they worked -- didn't care as long as I didn't have one. There is no need to freak out because it's really a non-issue. Just like folks carry a smart phone everywhere today, the catheter goes everywhere with you. I experienced zero pain and zero discomfort with it but it was a nuisance, on the level that a barking dog next dog is a nuisance. When it's time to remove it (and you will be counting down the days), you just take a deep breath, blow out and the physician or nurse will painlessly slip it out. REALLY, not a big deal. A moderate annoyance, at best. I found that sleeping in a large recliner with the catheter bag on the floor (or in a bucket) to be superior to trying to sleep in bed and worrying that tossing and turning might somehow dislodge the catheter. Some patients actually try to function normally as if they didn't have the catheter by switching to the smaller leg bag retainer and going out to public places. I suppose that's where I fall into the wimp category because I was not nearly so courageous, electing instead to stay home until it was time for the catheter to be removed. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: I see the newest US News Hospital Rankings are out.....

Posts.Content: Welcome John: Although I'm from PA, your City by the Bay is my favorite, having visited 20 years in a row. My great-grandfather was one of the founders of a Utopian-type town just north of you in 1890. You've probably heard of it -- it's called Mill Valley. Anyway, others who are more qualified will be able to fill in the answers to many of your questions. As you have already discovered, surgery and radiation are the two primary forms of prostate cancer treatment. Each is considered to be about equally successful with side effects popping up at different times. Brachytherapy has worked well for some of our forum brothers but be advised it is considered to be outside of the mainstream as it is the choice of only 2% of PC patients. If you are comfortable being a two-percenter, then you should be fine. I note you used the phrase "cured of prostate cancer" more than once. Having dealt with it twice (How the hell can you get prostate cancer three years after your prostate has been removed?), I am of the personal opinion that you can never be confident that you are ever "cured", just like an alcoholic is an alcoholic for their entire lives, regardless of their sobriety. I view cancer in general as being equivalent to the "Whack a Mole" carnival game. If you knock it down in one place, it has a tendency to pop up somewhere else. John Wayne famously announced that he had beaten the Big C when he was operated on for lung cancer. A few years later, he died of stomach cancer. But maybe I'm just a pessimist. Finally, it is presumptuous to note in your history that your PC is "confined to the gland". At this point in your journey, it is impossible to know that. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Prostate problems for 40 years - new symptoms, cancer questions

Posts.Content: ".. because my BF becomes irritable when I push him or question him about things." Welcome: Relax. Your bf is not alone. In addition to all men being pigs, they are also inherently stupid, as in you sometimes must drag a thirsty horse to a watering hole. By age 58, I had spent a lifetime avoiding a DRE. My philosophy was adamant -- that's an "exit only" location. Don't even think about suggesting it to me. Somehow, with different doctors retiring and doctors' practices consolidating, I wound up with a female doctor named Maria, a tiny Italian girl with a bright disposition. As I was putting on my shirt after a routine exam, she said we weren't done yet and pulled on a plastic glove. I explained my position on the subject and respectfully declined. She walked to the door and locked it. She told me that I would have to throw her to the floor before she would allow me to leave without a DRE. Then, she held her gloved hand in front of my face and said, "Jim, look at my hand. I'm 99 pounds and my fingers are almost skeletal thin. You need to have this exam at your age. Who would you rather perform it? Me or some male doctor who is 260 pounds with fat, stubby fingers?". Oh, Maria. Yes, I caved. It was followed shortly thereafter by a colonoscopy that I had deathly feared (which wound up being so easy it was unbelievable - go to sleep, wake up to a cold orange juice). And a decade later, the PSA test that detected prostate cancer. Please advise your bf that he doesn't have a monopoly on stupidity, but there may be hope yet. Jim

Posts.Title: A little learning is a dangerous thing . . .

Posts.Content: "I just pray that the results won't be cancer." Worst case scenario: it's prostate cancer. Best news possible: if you're going to have cancer, this is the one you want. Caught early, it is almost always 100% curable. Other cancers on this forum web site have a five-year survival rate as low as 6%. So, while some people may focus on the dreaded term "cancer" and the fear factor is naturally elevated, mortality issues rarely play a part in our prostate cancer thread. Instead, some guys exercise, while the rest of us play poker, drink beer and talk about all of the women who try to rip our clothes off. I join the others in stating that I've never heard of any side effects following a biopsy. Good luck with your biopsy today. Jim

Posts.Title: Prostate Biopsy Is Today

Posts.Content: Hi Izicc: Welcome to the forum. You will find a fine group of caring people here who will readily share their personal experiences and provide information to the best of their ability. There are no conflicts of interest because no one is trying to sell you anything. At the same time, you may find posters who are in favor of a particular type of treatment, more so than an alternative, and that's OK because it worked for them. My only comments are: The nurse is correct that once the prostate is removed, the cancerous gland is gone but it's still very important to watch your PSA results post-surgery as the cancer can return (as shown in my history/signature below). One of the major benefits of having surgery instead of radiation (there's my bias kicking in) is that you can have salvage radiation after surgery but not surgery after radiation -- except in very rare cases. And it is also possible that your preliminary Gleason 6 could actually be pathologically upgraded to Gleason 7 post-surgery. Your doctor will be able to tell you his protocol for removal of lymph nodes (some docs take more than others). Best of luck to you and please keep us updated with your decisions/treatment/outcome which may be helpful to others. Jim

Posts.Title: Need some advice, guidance and\or feedback on my recent issue

Posts.Content: This stuff makes me crazy!! First, in 2004, the President's Panel said no PSA tests for men over age 74. Then, in 2012, the same panel said no PSA tests for anyone because of possible anxiety and potential overtreatment. Now, there is a 92% increase in the number of advanced prostate cancer diagnoses among men ages 55 to 69. WELL, SUPRISE!! WHO THE F___ DIDN'T SEE THAT COMING? What ever happened to common sense? If men do not have PSA tests to find the cancer early and treat it, then it doesn't take a rocket scientist to figure out what will happen next. Prostate cancer -- that could have been cured -- will metastasize. Once it metastasizes, THERE IS NO CURE. People die. Is it just me or is the world spinning upside down? My mantra is this: if only one life is saved with the use of 1,000 PSA tests, then 1 million PSA tests will save 1,000 lives. Isn't that a good thing? Shouldn't saving lives be the primary objective here?

Posts.Content: This stuff makes me crazy!! First, in 2004, the President's Panel said no PSA tests for men over age 74. Then, in 2012, the same panel said no PSA tests for anyone because of possible anxiety and potential overtreatment. Now, there is a 92% increase in the number of advanced prostate cancer diagnoses among men ages 55 to 69. WELL, SUPRISE!! WHO THE F___ DIDN'T SEE THAT COMING? What ever happened to common sense? If men do not have PSA tests to find the cancer early and treat it, then it doesn't take a rocket scientist to figure out what will happen next. Prostate cancer -- that could have been cured -- will metastasize. Once it metastasizes, THERE IS NO CURE. People die. Is it just me or is the world spinning upside down? My mantra is this: if only one life is saved with the use of 1,000 PSA tests, then 1 million PSA tests will save 1,000 lives. Isn't that a good thing? Shouldn't saving lives be the primary objective here?

Posts.Content: Welcome Busby: I can't provide any info on your supplement but your search for a doctor who will perform a 3T MRI for you seems to be missing a key point. At age 55, nearly all insurance companies will decline to pay for a 3T MRI on the first biopsy. Unless you are prepared to pay out-of-pocket (and that's obviously your choice), you are aiming for the wrong target. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Finding the right doctor for 3T MRI + question on lycopene

Posts.Content: Welcome Rob: Michael F and Chuck have done such a good job covering the subject, my only input is agreement that if you want to get the most accurate biopsy, currently the 3T MRI offers the best chance of not missing anything. Your concerns are similar to literally thousands of guys who visit this site. There is absolutely no reason to be terrified of anything. I know it's easy for me to say but you're looking at a diagnostic TEST only, for now. And, even under a worst case scenario, prostate cancer is nearly always curable when found early and treated. But don't put the cart before the horse (you'll hear a lot of silly old clichés here). Just take it one step at a time. We'll be here. Again, no one on this site is a medical professional but we've all been there - done that and we've been of help to a lot of people. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Need some advice, guidance and\or feedback on my recent issue

Posts.Content: With all due respect, as usual, I probably fall into the category of Devil's Advocate. The discussion seems centered on testing, testing, testing. My take is this: why the hell is ANYONE talking about testing when -- as Chuck pointed out -- the patient has ALREADY been CONFIRMED to have prostate cancer. Instead of worrying whether something bad is going on with a constantly rising PSA -- "What should I do? What should I do?", to me, the answer is rudimentary: get it the hell out of there and let post-surgery pathology figure out what's actually in there. If I was the patient, with two brothers with PC, I would be shopping this morning at Wal-Mart for a robe and slippers for my overnight hospital stay following surgery. But I guess I'm just a crazy old man.

Posts.Title: Need some advice, guidance and\or feedback on my recent issue

Posts.Content: ".. because my BF becomes irritable when I push him or question him about things." Welcome: Relax. Your bf is not alone. In addition to all men being pigs, they are also inherently stupid, as in you sometimes must drag a thirsty horse to a watering hole. By age 58, I had spent a lifetime avoiding a DRE. My philosophy was adamant -- that's an "exit only" location. Don't even think about suggesting it to me. Somehow, with different doctors retiring and doctors' practices consolidating, I wound up with a female doctor named Maria, a tiny Italian girl with a bright disposition. As I was putting on my shirt after a routine exam, she said we weren't done yet and pulled on a plastic glove. I explained my position on the subject and respectfully declined. She walked to the door and locked it. She told me that I would have to throw her to the floor before she would allow me to leave without a DRE. Then, she held her gloved hand in front of my face and said, "Jim, look at my hand. I'm 99 pounds and my fingers are almost skeletal thin. You need to have this exam at your age. Who would you rather perform it? Me or some male doctor who is 260 pounds with fat, stubby fingers?". Oh, Maria. Yes, I caved. It was followed shortly thereafter by a colonoscopy that I had deathly feared (which wound up being so easy it was unbelievable - go to sleep, wake up to a cold orange juice). And a decade later, the PSA test that detected prostate cancer. Please advise your bf that he doesn't have a monopoly on stupidity, but there may be hope yet. Jim

Posts.Content: Allen: I'm not certain either but I just assumed that the radiation you and I received as salvage radiotherapy is probably at lesser doses than when it is applied as primary treatment. Maybe Chuck could provide some info on that subject. I understand what you mean by "how radiation works" but in the primary treatment, I suspect it is aimed at a particular tumor(s) while in the SR treatments it likely casts a kind of "spray" over the prostate bed area where the prostate once resided. Jim

Posts.Title: Longevity of Radiation Treatment

Posts.Content: Hi Izicc: Welcome to the forum. You will find a fine group of caring people here who will readily share their personal experiences and provide information to the best of their ability. There are no conflicts of interest because no one is trying to sell you anything. At the same time, you may find posters who are in favor of a particular type of treatment, more so than an alternative, and that's OK because it worked for them. My only comments are: The nurse is correct that once the prostate is removed, the cancerous gland is gone but it's still very important to watch your PSA results post-surgery as the cancer can return (as shown in my history/signature below). One of the major benefits of having surgery instead of radiation (there's my bias kicking in) is that you can have salvage radiation after surgery but not surgery after radiation -- except in very rare cases. And it is also possible that your preliminary Gleason 6 could actually be pathologically upgraded to Gleason 7 post-surgery. Your doctor will be able to tell you his protocol for removal of lymph nodes (some docs take more than others). Best of luck to you and please keep us updated with your decisions/treatment/outcome which may be helpful to others. Jim

Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer options

Posts.Content: FeatherBoy: Looking at your history, you must be getting close to the magical age of 65 to qualify for Medicare. Medicare will absolve you of nearly all pre-authorization BS. Until then, it looks like you are following a well-planned strategy. But be careful of Xanax. Ten years ago, at age 19, our only grandson died (after multiple in-patient and out-patient rehabs failed) from what the Medical Examiner said was a single Xanax pill and a single meth pill. I have learned over the years that Xanax can also have negative interactions with multiple other drugs. Jim

Posts.Title: Now I'm Getting A Little Nervous!

Posts.Content: Welcome Busby: I can't provide any info on your supplement but your search for a doctor who will perform a 3T MRI for you seems to be missing a key point. At age 55, nearly all insurance companies will decline to pay for a 3T MRI on the first biopsy. Unless you are prepared to pay out-of-pocket (and that's obviously your choice), you are aiming for the wrong target. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Content: Hi bhg: This website is a success because of the exchange of support, compassion and information shared among those who visit here. You may not be aware of it but you have already made a significant contribution. You mentioned that your husband has had 4 negative biopsies. This information, by itself, is huge because it seems like we spend a ton of time and effort just trying to get reluctant patients to undergo ONE biopsy because of unfounded fear and preconceived notions why they want to avoid the procedure. Thank you for that and we all wish your husband the best possible outcome and resolution. Jim

Posts.Title: Husband has PSA 14. Please need advice about using Finasteride.

Posts.Content: Hi Southsider: So, of your 3 biopsies, you had one core with G6 followed by no malignant cores followed by 3 cores with G6. My comment is that if you have another biopsy, you would do well to have a 3T MRI in advance to try to pinpoint areas of suspicion. As far as your "low risk" rating, I never had a lot of confidence in tests that only speculate and fail to provide finite information (like an X-ray showing a broken arm is finite). In Vegas, if you want to bet on the Kentucky Derby, you have a "low risk" of picking the winner. Does that help? Probably not much. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Finally on Day+1

Posts.Content: Hi DTrom: My path has been somewhat similar to yours. Although there is a small chance of error, please investigate the following: On your last PSA reading of 0.05, was that provided to you on a written lab report or verbally by a doctor's support staff member? While all of my doctors have been top notch, I have come across some support staff who served as WalMart greeters the week before. With that in mind, a number of labs report PSA findings as <0.05, which could actually translate to 0.00. If you received a verbal report, I would double-check to confirm that the "<" (less than) sign was not present. Good luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Post-RALP Catheter Removal

Posts.Content: On the subject of prednisone, just wanted to share a story: In May, 2003, my wife suffered the second of two neurological episodes within a six-month period. At the time, they were believed to be TIAs (mini-strokes), later diagnosed as actual modest strokes. In order to find a suspected area of plaque blockage that was breaking loose, she was given a test (called a TEE, transesophogeal echocardiogram) to view the area behind the heart, near her aortic arch. We arrived back home at 2PM when she laid down to take a nap. She awoke at 6PM with horrible itching of the scalp. A night without sleep followed. By the morning, we returned to the mid-sized hospital where the TEE was given and she was diagnosed as having a reaction to either Demerol or Versed, which were administered with the TEE and she was transferred to the ER. At this point, her entire scalp and the tops of her ears and abdomen were covered in bright-red rashes. For eight hours in the ER, she was given injections of Benadryl which did absolutely nothing to relieve her condition or discomfort. The ER doctor decided to send her home. That's when I went ballistic. I loudly pointed out to the entire staff (and patients within earshot) that it was THIS HOSPITAL that caused her problem and it was THIS HOSPITAL that didn't have a f___ing clue how to resolve the issue. It came very close to having security escort me from the property. After no improvement in 72 hours, I drove my wife into the city to the Dermatology Department of the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania where dozens of patients awaited their scheduled appointments with highly-skilled dermatologists -- many of whom who had waited months for their appointment. I approached an older woman at the registration desk, explained what had happened at the mid-sized hospital and literally begged her to have a dermatologist examine my wife, who hadn't had any sleep in 3 days. At first, she said it was impossible because all of the appointment slots were filled. When she saw I was starting to choke up, she asked me to take a seat. Ten minutes later, she asked if we could wait an hour for her to squeeze us in. Could we? Hell, yes, we could wait an hour. When the female Asian-American dermatologist examined my wife, she immediately left the room and returned with three of her colleagues who then each examined my wife. Next, they huddled in a corner of the room and the first doctor said it was good that we had come in when we did because the rash was starting to approach my wife's eyes and that could have been an even bigger problem. Their solution? Massive doses of injected and then oral Prednisone! I asked, "What if that doesn't work? Do you have a Plan B?". She looked at her colleagues, smiled and said, "Sir, this is the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania. We don't deal in Plan Bs. This WILL work". And, within 24 hours, it did. (Sorry for the length). On our follow-up appointment three weeks later, I brought a large box of Godiva chocolate for the clerk who found compassion in her heart to allow my wife to see a specialist.

Posts.Title: 3-Week Post-DaVinci Update - and a Question

Posts.Content: There are general practitioner doctors and then there are specialist doctors. My assumption is that the issues you describe have not yet been evaluated by a urologist or they would have been corrected by now. We are not doctors on this website and it's way too soon to jump to a self-diagnosis of possible prostate cancer. Recommendation: make an appointment with an experienced urologist. In addition to treating you, he will almost certainly run a PSA test. Then, please return and we can provide you with our experiences that may be relevant to your medical diagnosis. Good luck. Jim

Posts.Title: Treatment decision time.

Posts.Content: Welcome RF51: While I agree with virtually everything that Fairwind has stated above concerning your G8, be advised that there is a segment of the PC medical community that argues in favor of surgery first, in order to de-bulk the cancer. That would likely be followed with ADT and radiation. But you really must do your homework to decide what is best for you after gathering as much information of the subject as possible. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Surgery vs Radiation/Hormone

Posts.Content: You don't need to have a question to post. We're here and hoping for the best outcome, as you are. Try not to feel sad. You're doing everything you can for your Dad. Here's a very old silly little ditty that seems quite accurate here: "A son is a son until he takes a wife; a daughter is a daughter for all of your life". Our elder daughter, who works in the medical field selling heart valves, sat in with my wife and I and my lung cancer surgeon in March (Please see below). It was she who suggested a 3-month timeout before I had part of a lung cut out. The doctors reluctantly agreed. Three months later, the nodule shrank -- no cancer -- no surgery --and she was proven right. I am most grateful for her input.

Posts.Title: Over Treatment

Posts.Content: Logic1: I can only speculate that a "fear" of incontinence might arise if you have a dream that you are making a presentation onstage in front of hundreds of people, wearing white pants and you suddenly lose bladder control. Assuming that is a rare unrealistic scenario, know this: Millions of us have gone before you. For some of us the dripping ends rather quickly -- others, somewhat less fortunate, may take up to a year to reach full dryness. In my case, I reached the target in exactly 60 days. But the bottom line is that none of this will be a surprise because you've already researched the subject. So, as long as you prepare with adequate pads in place followed by shields once the flow has slowed, you're going to be just fine. I can't foresee any depression setting in because by that time you will know that you have been victorious in smiting the cancer. And getting rid of the cancer is paramount. Everything else is peripheral and meaningless. It's merely a bump along the pc highway, nothing more. Best of luck with your upcoming surgery. Jim

Posts.Content: FeatherBoy: Looking at your history, you must be getting close to the magical age of 65 to qualify for Medicare. Medicare will absolve you of nearly all pre-authorization BS. Until then, it looks like you are following a well-planned strategy. But be careful of Xanax. Ten years ago, at age 19, our only grandson died (after multiple in-patient and out-patient rehabs failed) from what the Medical Examiner said was a single Xanax pill and a single meth pill. I have learned over the years that Xanax can also have negative interactions with multiple other drugs. Jim

Posts.Title: Now I'm Getting A Little Nervous!

Posts.Content: "....their is no evidence of cancer besides the initial low grade score. I want to have the best information to contradict this advice for a biopsy." OK, maybe I'm a little dense but when is there "no evidence of cancer" when you are diagnosed with cancer? CANCER IS CANCER, LOW-GRADE OR NOT! Prostate cancer kills 30,000 men every year. Try asking their surviving family members if they believe it was a great idea for the deceased to avoid a second biopsy at any cost. Fairwind states the obvious much better than I possibly can, but are you seriously looking for support on this website from prostate cancer survivors to encourage you to reject a simple diagnostic -- yet uncomfortable -- test, recommended by your doctor, that could potentially save your life? C'mon, man!!

Posts.Title: Treatment decision time.

Posts.Content: ...it is only available to California residents due to drug laws and that a 30 day supply is $1,500. Ron: I, too, am sorry to read of your difficult problems at a young age. You will note below that I have also gone the DaVinci route and the salvage radiation route. But, please, step back for a moment and look at the big picture with respect to obvious scam artists. It is exactly these type of scumbags who prey upon those people who worry that they may have exhausted most conventional treatments. There is a special place in hell for them. You could write to MD Anderson to ask the administration if they stand behind Mr. Simpson's claims. Guaranteed, they won't. If you choose to investigate further, I would ask Mr. Simpson's representatives to provide you with copies of "drug laws" in each of the 49 states that don't permit the oil to be sold and the reasons why that is true. For example, dozens of states now permit the distribution of medical cannabis. And none cost $1,500 for a 30-day supply, which is patently ridiculous. It's a scam, Ron. Don't be a victim. Jim

Posts.Title: Image Guided Radiation Therapy - week by week

Posts.Content: Welcome to the group, Robin, and sorry you find yourself here. Well, holy crap, you sure have had quite a run of doctors. There will be others who chime in shortly but I'd be willing to bet that you won't hear from many other 28-year-olds on this website who have experienced prostate cancer. Not saying it's impossible, but you have already found that it's extremely unusual. We are not medical professionals on this site, so we can only offer to share our experiences which may or may not correlate with what you are suffering from. Let's go back to the low grade fever that you experience daily -- you said it makes you feel "dizzy" and "terrible". With all of the tests that you have had, has any doctor indicated that your problem might be related to neurology, rather than urology? Have you ever had an MRI or a scan of the head? The "dizzy" part of the low grade fever kind of points me in that direction, rather than worry about a somewhat elevated PSA reading for your age group. Stay tuned. More will follow. Best of luck. Jim

Posts.Title: Now I'm Getting A Little Nervous!

Posts.Content: PSA = 18.7 Assuming no infection, biopsy indicated. PSA = 11.4 Assuming no infection, biopsy indicated. Either way, biopsy indicated. An easy call, as confirmed by other posts. And I have no medical degree -- retired from a bus company (remember Ralph Cramden?) "I am thinking that I do not have a reliable PSA and really need some kind of base line in order to make treatment decisions." Doesn't make sense. A biopsy is a diagnostic test, not a treatment. If cancer is detected, the PSA is no longer relevant to ANY "treatment decisions". Your age, Gleason score and number of positive cores plus their involvement and your doctor's recommendations then become the basis for any "treatment decisions". Best of luck.

Posts.Title: Considering delaying biopsy. Thoughts, opinons welcome.

Posts.Content: Maybe I'm a little dense but I don't get it. The surgery is over; the prostate is gone; the worst is over; you made it. Could there be a recurrence, sure, but with an excellent pathology report you are likely in the 80-90% category of not having anything bad happen in the future. You're on target for reaching the Land of Dryness within the average period expected. I recognize that, because of your age, the ED is a concern; you know the numbers -- sometimes it takes up to 2 years to resolve and it's rare to return to the full potency of original equipment. Nevertheless, you have every reason to expect to live a full life-span as if you never had PC. I have friends on the lung cancer thread; it's hard for me to communicate with some of them through my tears because I know their future -- or lack of it. You saw a professional to be treated for your cancer. If you recognize that you're putting too much focus on the aftermath, then you could consider seeing a professional to deal with emotional trauma because, while the next PSA test is always troubling to most of us, you can't let it overcome you. As Chuck said, you're going to be just fine.

Posts.Title: Post-RALP Catheter Removal

Posts.Content: Hi Jim: If all goes well with surgery AND you take plenty of time to fully recover following surgery before returning to a strenuous job, then a year later you will look in your rear-view mirror at nothing more than a bump along life's highway. That's the scenario for most prostate cancer patients who choose surgery. Conversely, your Gleason 7 pre-surgery could possibly be upgraded post-surgery and your PC journey may not yet be over. In my case, as in about 15-20% of patients, the PC returned 3 years later but, because I had selected surgery as my primary treatment, I was able to get a second chance at a "cure" with salvage radiation. If you select radiation as your PRIMARY treatment, that "second chance" option is not available. My PC is gone for now, but honestly, no one can predict the future. I'm hopeful that I'm done with it. You've already taken Step #1 by getting Dr. Walsh's book. Only after doing extensive research can you determine what is the right path for YOU personally. But I will recommend this: Stay away from "alternative" medicines because they can never cure PC. Every once in a while we get a new patient who thinks he will be cured of PC by eating apricot seeds (or similar stuff). One hundred years ago, con artists tried to sell snake oil to people to "cure" all of their maladies. Be careful -- those snake oil salesmen still exist. You will get plenty more input here in the next few days. There are no MDs on this site -- only patients and caregivers who will gladly share their experiences in an effort to help others. And as bad as it is to get news that you have the Big "C", this is a cancer that you actually want, as it is virtually 100% curable when caught early and treated. Not so, with some other cancers (ie., pancreatic and lung). Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Just got diagnosed

Posts.Content: "....their is no evidence of cancer besides the initial low grade score. I want to have the best information to contradict this advice for a biopsy." OK, maybe I'm a little dense but when is there "no evidence of cancer" when you are diagnosed with cancer? CANCER IS CANCER, LOW-GRADE OR NOT! Prostate cancer kills 30,000 men every year. Try asking their surviving family members if they believe it was a great idea for the deceased to avoid a second biopsy at any cost. Fairwind states the obvious much better than I possibly can, but are you seriously looking for support on this website from prostate cancer survivors to encourage you to reject a simple diagnostic -- yet uncomfortable -- test, recommended by your doctor, that could potentially save your life? C'mon, man!!

Posts.Title: Advice for Newbie concerning prostrate MRI

Posts.Content: PSA = 18.7 Assuming no infection, biopsy indicated. PSA = 11.4 Assuming no infection, biopsy indicated. Either way, biopsy indicated. An easy call, as confirmed by other posts. And I have no medical degree -- retired from a bus company (remember Ralph Cramden?) "I am thinking that I do not have a reliable PSA and really need some kind of base line in order to make treatment decisions." Doesn't make sense. A biopsy is a diagnostic test, not a treatment. If cancer is detected, the PSA is no longer relevant to ANY "treatment decisions". Your age, Gleason score and number of positive cores plus their involvement and your doctor's recommendations then become the basis for any "treatment decisions". Best of luck.

Posts.Title: Considering delaying biopsy. Thoughts, opinons welcome.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ryguy3000 Hi everyone, Looking for some support/information here. My grandfather, who is 85 years old, has been visibly healthy as long as I've known him. He still lives on his own, takes no medications, drives, etc. The past 2 weeks, he's had really bad lower back/leg pain. He also had trouble urinating. After a blood test, it was determined he had a PSA level of around 11. We're now waiting for him to get an appointment with a urologist. Nothing is confirmed, but from what we've been told, it looks like it might be prostate cancer that spread to his bones. From what I've read, this is generally stage 4 prostate cancer. What is the prognosis on this? Do people usually get better with treatment? Thanks. Whoa. Whoa. And whoa again. If you buy into an automatic worst-case scenario (Stage 4 prostate cancer?), you are doing your grandfather a great disservice. As others have noted, there can be reasonable explanations that are not accompanied by dire outcomes. Try to deal only with the reality of confirmed test results and not rampant speculation. Best of luck.

Posts.Title: Image Guided Radiation Therapy - week by week

Posts.Content: Hi Mattie: A quick story. The year was 1970. A co-worker went out on medical leave for 8 months and returned to the job as merely a shell of his former 220 lb. frame -- he probably weighed about 130 lbs. He looked like death warmed over. I said, "What the hell happened to you?". The answer: Open surgery to treat prostate cancer. I made a mental note to myself that if I ever had cancer I hoped beyond hope that I didn't contract prostate cancer. Flash forward to 2010. My diagnosis: Prostate cancer. Damn. Whatever happened, I knew I didn't want to suffer like my former co-worker did forty years earlier. I assure you that your anxiety could not possibly have exceeded my fear. After researching the subject, I learned that the newer DaVinci robotic surgery no longer required being gutted with a scalpel but rather was performed by punching several small holes in the area of the lower abdomen where the surgeon's tools are now able to remove the offending cancerous prostate gland. I never actually understood how a catheter even worked, let alone having experienced one. Bottom line in my case (everyone is different -- some patients do have post-surgery problems but I believe they are the exception): My surgery was textbook -- I took a single pain pill within 24 hours of surgery -- never a need for more; The catheter was totally pain-free although admittedly a nuisance for 8 days at home -- I celebrated the day it came out; My surgeon said his patients experience some incontinence for about 2 months while others take longer to return to normal -- I was completely dry by the 60th day. In my case, the cancer actually returned 3 years later and I dealt with it. If you read multiple prostate cancer threads on this site, you will find many patients who have aggressive forms of the disease which were found late and/or that the cancer has metastasized to the point where a "cure" is no longer possible. Or read other cancer threads where the 5-year survival rate for pancreatic cancer is 6% and lung cancer is 18%. For you to thumb your nose at a potential cure while others would give anything to trade places with you, to be frank, seems short-sighted. You are not alone. Millions of men have traveled this path before you -- most with anxiety and dealing with some repellant stuff for a very short time frame -- and continued on with their lives just as if they never had prostate cancer. If they can do it, you can do it. Don't sell yourself short. Best of luck. Jim

Posts.Content: FeatherBoy: Looking at your history, you must be getting close to the magical age of 65 to qualify for Medicare. Medicare will absolve you of nearly all pre-authorization BS. Until then, it looks like you are following a well-planned strategy. But be careful of Xanax. Ten years ago, at age 19, our only grandson died (after multiple in-patient and out-patient rehabs failed) from what the Medical Examiner said was a single Xanax pill and a single meth pill. I have learned over the years that Xanax can also have negative interactions with multiple other drugs. Jim

Posts.Title: My wife is concerned because my PSA is slowly rising every 3 months

Posts.Content: Hi Steve: You are a very patient individual if you have suffered with BPH problems for 10-15 years without pushing for a resolution. However, IMHO while I certainly welcome new technologies like 1.5T or 3T MRIs, to "map' for a possible future fusion biopsy, all of those efforts appear to be "dancing around the edges" of simply forging ahead with a biopsy. And, as you know, a biopsy is the ONLY current diagnostic test that will give you the answers you seek. And if you wait another 15 years weighing all of your options, you may "age out" of a possible cure if prostate cancer surgery is warranted. My guess is that if your automobile demonstrated equal faulty operations, you would have had it diagnosed and repaired by now. My suggestion is to get the biopsy now and move ahead with whatever decisions need to be made. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Biopsy based on a Pi-Rad3 finding on a 1.5T MRI

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by brownie43 You stated you would be furious with the Dr. Well, it is the VA, and I forgot to mention that I am 73yrs. old. The first VA Urologist that I saw at the VA was a bit "put off" because I had a PSA in my labs., and said he would never order a PSA for anyone 70 or older but seeing as how someone else was ordering 'unnecessary lab work", he would do a DRE (enlarged but no bumps). Said if I came in dragging an oxygen bottle or such, he would not order more tests, etc. but I was a youthful 73, so lucky me. Anyway, he did order up another PSA and recommended a biopsy. Not sure how to get a second opinion at the VA, so will probably go to my Medicare PCP Welcome brownie: As Pratoman noted, your high PSA score may indicate a true Gleason score higher than G6. If you Google "average life expectancy of a male in the U.S.", you will get 74.4 years. Since I am currently 74.5 years, I'm past my expiration date but, for whatever reason, I feel able to do most things that I could thirty years ago (including traveling the country playing televised poker semi-professionally). https://www.dropbox.com/s/2tgsaqzh4a...ience.mp4?dl=0 But the VA, with a limited budget, clearly looks at you at age 73 as money wasted on a patient with a limited life expectancy, regardless of your robust abilities. By now, you should realize that a primary care physician is fine for treating someone with a boo-boo and can apply a Band-Aid to a knee. You're past that with a cancer (albeit mild G6) confirmation. But if the VA allows you to be treated by an outside Medicare PCP, why not try for an appointment with a non-VA urologist? He/she should be able to provide a second opinion relative to the recommendations of your radiologist, who is concerned about your enlarged lymph nodes. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Pc 101

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ryguy3000 Hi everyone, Looking for some support/information here. My grandfather, who is 85 years old, has been visibly healthy as long as I've known him. He still lives on his own, takes no medications, drives, etc. The past 2 weeks, he's had really bad lower back/leg pain. He also had trouble urinating. After a blood test, it was determined he had a PSA level of around 11. We're now waiting for him to get an appointment with a urologist. Nothing is confirmed, but from what we've been told, it looks like it might be prostate cancer that spread to his bones. From what I've read, this is generally stage 4 prostate cancer. What is the prognosis on this? Do people usually get better with treatment? Thanks. Whoa. Whoa. And whoa again. If you buy into an automatic worst-case scenario (Stage 4 prostate cancer?), you are doing your grandfather a great disservice. As others have noted, there can be reasonable explanations that are not accompanied by dire outcomes. Try to deal only with the reality of confirmed test results and not rampant speculation. Best of luck.

Posts.Title: Foley follies

Posts.Content: Welcome Hilander: Exploring possible odds and probabilities can be counter-productive. But you could look at it this way: Worst case scenario -- you have cancer. Best case scenario if biopsy is positive -- you have prostate cancer. Caught early and treated, it is one of only a few cancers that are nearly 100% curable. That's not something to be taken lightly as a review of some other cancers on this website will reveal. Just take it one step at a time and let us know your biopsy results. Posters on this site are not medical professionals but we (and in many cases, our care-givers) will be glad to share our experiences and offer support which you may find helpful. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Probability?

Posts.Content: Hi Jim: If all goes well with surgery AND you take plenty of time to fully recover following surgery before returning to a strenuous job, then a year later you will look in your rear-view mirror at nothing more than a bump along life's highway. That's the scenario for most prostate cancer patients who choose surgery. Conversely, your Gleason 7 pre-surgery could possibly be upgraded post-surgery and your PC journey may not yet be over. In my case, as in about 15-20% of patients, the PC returned 3 years later but, because I had selected surgery as my primary treatment, I was able to get a second chance at a "cure" with salvage radiation. If you select radiation as your PRIMARY treatment, that "second chance" option is not available. My PC is gone for now, but honestly, no one can predict the future. I'm hopeful that I'm done with it. You've already taken Step #1 by getting Dr. Walsh's book. Only after doing extensive research can you determine what is the right path for YOU personally. But I will recommend this: Stay away from "alternative" medicines because they can never cure PC. Every once in a while we get a new patient who thinks he will be cured of PC by eating apricot seeds (or similar stuff). One hundred years ago, con artists tried to sell snake oil to people to "cure" all of their maladies. Be careful -- those snake oil salesmen still exist. You will get plenty more input here in the next few days. There are no MDs on this site -- only patients and caregivers who will gladly share their experiences in an effort to help others. And as bad as it is to get news that you have the Big "C", this is a cancer that you actually want, as it is virtually 100% curable when caught early and treated. Not so, with some other cancers (ie., pancreatic and lung). Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Just got diagnosed

Posts.Content: Hi Hopper: Wishing you the very best of luck, as I have on other posts. DaVinci has been the methodology of choice for many men on this site and, if I had to do it over again, I would still go with it even though my cancer came back three years later and I had to have salvage radiation to knock it down. You're going to hate me for this but I just can't help it. Maybe the reason you were turned away on April 31st is because there are only 30 days in April. Sorry. Please give us an update as soon as you can. All the best to you, Sir, Jim

Posts.Title: 2.5 Days to go

Posts.Content: Hi Wendy: It would be easy for a majority of my forum brothers to suggest that DaVinci should be the default modality for your husband, particularly at age 56. And his biopsy doesn't show a particularly aggressive Gleason score -- again, advantage DaVinci. But with a PSA hovering around 20 which wasn't affected by antibiotics, indicating the source of that reading was likely not due to an infection, it's possible that something problematic is the cause. With that in mind, we are all sort of peeing into the wind (please pardon the pun) until you meet with the doctor on Wednesday to discuss the results of the CT and full body bone scan and weigh his recommendations. We could speculate; however, there is nothing more valuable than finite test results. Please let us know what happens on Wednesday and, from that point moving forward, our combined experiences may serve to help guide you toward a reasonable pathway to a resolution. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Biopsy Consult Question

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Fairwind You should not be concerned at all.... Are you reading the decimal placement correctly? At a PSA of 0.1 post-surgery, many ROs would be prepping a patient for salvage radiation. Assuming the most recent PSA result was not an error, another PSA of 0.1 or higher is currently considered to be a biochemical recurrence. As soon as I hit 0.11, I scheduled 40 sessions of SR after monitoring a clear-cut upward trend. This is exactly the reason why a single decimal point while monitoring PSA makes no sense IMHO because it lulls the patient into thinking <0.1 is just fine when, if fact, it could be climbing every 3 months (0.02, 0.04, 0.06, 0.07) and the patient remains totally in the dark. In this case, a second PSA reading of 0.1 or higher is very likely time for action. Chuck, Pratoman, Michael F, MichiganMan16, am I missing something here?

Posts.Title: Ugh, but not overly concerned

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by trinity3 Thanks DD - I am feeling a bit pressed because I don't have a year. I may only have 6 months before I will need to begin adjuvant radiation. Once that starts, I am told continence does NOT improve. So yes I am feeling a bit stressed. However, I think there have been lots of folks who have very good continence in 4 months...hopefully I will be counted among them. As for other activities - I am laying low as instructed. Steve As stated, everyone is different with respect to recovery. I think the one year period noted was to include nearly everyone. My uro said that among his post-surgery patients, the AVERAGE time to reach the Land of Total Dryness was roughly 2 months. I reached that plateau on exactly the 60th day. Best of luck.

Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed 56 year old husband with PSA of 21 and 3/14 cores postitive-help!

Posts.Content: Maybe I'm a little dense but I don't get it. The surgery is over; the prostate is gone; the worst is over; you made it. Could there be a recurrence, sure, but with an excellent pathology report you are likely in the 80-90% category of not having anything bad happen in the future. You're on target for reaching the Land of Dryness within the average period expected. I recognize that, because of your age, the ED is a concern; you know the numbers -- sometimes it takes up to 2 years to resolve and it's rare to return to the full potency of original equipment. Nevertheless, you have every reason to expect to live a full life-span as if you never had PC. I have friends on the lung cancer thread; it's hard for me to communicate with some of them through my tears because I know their future -- or lack of it. You saw a professional to be treated for your cancer. If you recognize that you're putting too much focus on the aftermath, then you could consider seeing a professional to deal with emotional trauma because, while the next PSA test is always troubling to most of us, you can't let it overcome you. As Chuck said, you're going to be just fine.

Posts.Title: I Guess I'm Paranoid!

Posts.Content: Hi Jim: If all goes well with surgery AND you take plenty of time to fully recover following surgery before returning to a strenuous job, then a year later you will look in your rear-view mirror at nothing more than a bump along life's highway. That's the scenario for most prostate cancer patients who choose surgery. Conversely, your Gleason 7 pre-surgery could possibly be upgraded post-surgery and your PC journey may not yet be over. In my case, as in about 15-20% of patients, the PC returned 3 years later but, because I had selected surgery as my primary treatment, I was able to get a second chance at a "cure" with salvage radiation. If you select radiation as your PRIMARY treatment, that "second chance" option is not available. My PC is gone for now, but honestly, no one can predict the future. I'm hopeful that I'm done with it. You've already taken Step #1 by getting Dr. Walsh's book. Only after doing extensive research can you determine what is the right path for YOU personally. But I will recommend this: Stay away from "alternative" medicines because they can never cure PC. Every once in a while we get a new patient who thinks he will be cured of PC by eating apricot seeds (or similar stuff). One hundred years ago, con artists tried to sell snake oil to people to "cure" all of their maladies. Be careful -- those snake oil salesmen still exist. You will get plenty more input here in the next few days. There are no MDs on this site -- only patients and caregivers who will gladly share their experiences in an effort to help others. And as bad as it is to get news that you have the Big "C", this is a cancer that you actually want, as it is virtually 100% curable when caught early and treated. Not so, with some other cancers (ie., pancreatic and lung). Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Just got diagnosed

Posts.Content: Welcome MB from another guy who has chronic kidney stones (surgery to remove them twice - 7 trips to the ER in the last 7 years): The second post -- "take it one step at a time" -- is on point. I suspect your doctor was sending you for an ultrasound to determine the size of your prostate and then would have likely taken the next step to the PSA test and a urologist referral. Many guys who come to this site for the first time have concerns that are similar to yours. However, you seem on the verge of expecting the worst when there is no evidence yet of anything that bad. Like Chuck said, gather the results from the uro and come back to us. We'll try to share our experiences and provide support to the best of our abilities. For now, calm down. The sky is not falling. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Doctor found nodule during DRE, my first ever, no PSA record.. long history of UTI

Posts.Content: Welcome to the group, Robin, and sorry you find yourself here. Well, holy crap, you sure have had quite a run of doctors. There will be others who chime in shortly but I'd be willing to bet that you won't hear from many other 28-year-olds on this website who have experienced prostate cancer. Not saying it's impossible, but you have already found that it's extremely unusual. We are not medical professionals on this site, so we can only offer to share our experiences which may or may not correlate with what you are suffering from. Let's go back to the low grade fever that you experience daily -- you said it makes you feel "dizzy" and "terrible". With all of the tests that you have had, has any doctor indicated that your problem might be related to neurology, rather than urology? Have you ever had an MRI or a scan of the head? The "dizzy" part of the low grade fever kind of points me in that direction, rather than worry about a somewhat elevated PSA reading for your age group. Stay tuned. More will follow. Best of luck. Jim

Posts.Title: 29 years old, high PSA

Posts.Content: Hi Mattie: A quick story. The year was 1970. A co-worker went out on medical leave for 8 months and returned to the job as merely a shell of his former 220 lb. frame -- he probably weighed about 130 lbs. He looked like death warmed over. I said, "What the hell happened to you?". The answer: Open surgery to treat prostate cancer. I made a mental note to myself that if I ever had cancer I hoped beyond hope that I didn't contract prostate cancer. Flash forward to 2010. My diagnosis: Prostate cancer. Damn. Whatever happened, I knew I didn't want to suffer like my former co-worker did forty years earlier. I assure you that your anxiety could not possibly have exceeded my fear. After researching the subject, I learned that the newer DaVinci robotic surgery no longer required being gutted with a scalpel but rather was performed by punching several small holes in the area of the lower abdomen where the surgeon's tools are now able to remove the offending cancerous prostate gland. I never actually understood how a catheter even worked, let alone having experienced one. Bottom line in my case (everyone is different -- some patients do have post-surgery problems but I believe they are the exception): My surgery was textbook -- I took a single pain pill within 24 hours of surgery -- never a need for more; The catheter was totally pain-free although admittedly a nuisance for 8 days at home -- I celebrated the day it came out; My surgeon said his patients experience some incontinence for about 2 months while others take longer to return to normal -- I was completely dry by the 60th day. In my case, the cancer actually returned 3 years later and I dealt with it. If you read multiple prostate cancer threads on this site, you will find many patients who have aggressive forms of the disease which were found late and/or that the cancer has metastasized to the point where a "cure" is no longer possible. Or read other cancer threads where the 5-year survival rate for pancreatic cancer is 6% and lung cancer is 18%. For you to thumb your nose at a potential cure while others would give anything to trade places with you, to be frank, seems short-sighted. You are not alone. Millions of men have traveled this path before you -- most with anxiety and dealing with some repellant stuff for a very short time frame -- and continued on with their lives just as if they never had prostate cancer. If they can do it, you can do it. Don't sell yourself short. Best of luck. Jim

Posts.Title: Looking for advice and emotional support with new Prostate Ca diagnosis.

Posts.Content: We could be seated next to a stranger on a train who could use our experience and yet he and/or we would never know it. As much as the Internet gets such bad press about child predators and other horrible stuff, it's the virtual anonymity of the web that allows us to share vital info. Can you imagine a guy turning to a female stranger on a bus platform and asking her how her husband's erections are doing? Yet, here it is just daily interaction in efforts to help other human beings. We may not save lives here (or maybe we do in some cases) but there is an unspoken mission to help others while looking for nothing in return, except good news. In 73 years, I had never been on a forum before (physical or virtual), I am a non-Facebooker, I am a non-texter (didn't they do that tap-tap-tap of messages 150 years ago with the invention of the telegraph -- seriously, I don't get it) and yet I feel committed to this particular forum because of the potential to actually help others who may encounter similar experiences to mine. In my view, very little of this positive energy would be possible without the regular input of our steady, voice-of-reason moderator, Chuck. I've become a prostate cancer forum addict.

Posts.Title: a simple thanks

Posts.Content: MM: As soon as I saw a PSA upward trend, three years after surgery, I was pounding on the door of the salvage radiation treatment center and requesting to be zapped. So far, so good in my case. As Pratoman pointed out, with your surgical pathology report of Gleason 9 and positive margins, the idea of "waiting and monitoring" is something that I could have never considered. In my view, any side effects can be ignored when survival is the primary objective. But that's just one guy's opinion. I wish you the best, Jim

Posts.Title: " AR/SR vs. PSA Monitoring & Waiting"

Posts.Content: In February, a close friend was touring Ireland with a group when he took ill. His wife e-mailed us each night for the 10 days he was in a local hospital where tests were run to determine his problem (eventually diagnosed back in the States as an abdominal aortic aneurysm). Her description of the conditions in the Ireland hospital approached the unthinkable for U.S. citizens. She explained that she had to shop nearly every day to provide him with basic necessities. Patients had to supply their own soap, toothbrush and toothpaste, shaving supplies, toiletries and even their own hospital gowns. Her husband shared a room with seven other men, one of whom had been in the same hospital for more than a year because doctors still hadn't been able to successfully diagnose his problem. It sounded very much like a Third World country. Now, you say that robotic surgery, which has been available in many countries for more than a decade "...is not an option here". The other posters suggested changing doctors. I suggest, if possible, you change countries for his treatment. In the meanwhile, we look forward to your posting of his biopsy results (number of cores taken, number of positive cores, the percentage involvement of each positive core, etc.). A normal PSA result combined with an aggressive Gleason 9 score seems highly suspect.
