Posts.Title: Father with Gleason 9 & PSA 2.5

Posts.Content: Welcome Hilander: Exploring possible odds and probabilities can be counter-productive. But you could look at it this way: Worst case scenario -- you have cancer. Best case scenario if biopsy is positive -- you have prostate cancer. Caught early and treated, it is one of only a few cancers that are nearly 100% curable. That's not something to be taken lightly as a review of some other cancers on this website will reveal. Just take it one step at a time and let us know your biopsy results. Posters on this site are not medical professionals but we (and in many cases, our care-givers) will be glad to share our experiences and offer support which you may find helpful. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Probability?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by trinity3 Thanks DD - I am feeling a bit pressed because I don't have a year. I may only have 6 months before I will need to begin adjuvant radiation. Once that starts, I am told continence does NOT improve. So yes I am feeling a bit stressed. However, I think there have been lots of folks who have very good continence in 4 months...hopefully I will be counted among them. As for other activities - I am laying low as instructed. Steve As stated, everyone is different with respect to recovery. I think the one year period noted was to include nearly everyone. My uro said that among his post-surgery patients, the AVERAGE time to reach the Land of Total Dryness was roughly 2 months. I reached that plateau on exactly the 60th day. Best of luck.

Posts.Title: Urination Control In First 24 hours post surgery

Posts.Content: If you have any specific questions, there are plenty of people here who can likely respond with first-hand histories of how they've dealt with certain issues. I've found that a wealth of general knowledge can be gained by simply reading various threads under prostate cancer. Each story is a little different from the previous one. My history was a PSA of 4.95 -- 2 cores of 12 positive -- 3+4 Gleason -- had DaVinci robotic surgery in 2010 - cancer came back in 2013 -- try explaining to someone that you still have prostate cancer but you have no prostate -- 40 sessions of radiation followed -- PSA now 0.00. Yes, you do need a "plan of action" but accept the fact that you are not in "imminent" danger. Then, take a deep breath and soldier on, gathering as much info as reasonably possible. We'll be here.
Posts.Title: newly diagnosed but staying positive

Posts.Content: We could be seated next to a stranger on a train who could use our experience and yet he and/or we would never know it. As much as the Internet gets such bad press about child predators and other horrible stuff, it's the virtual anonymity of the web that allows us to share vital info. Can you imagine a guy turning to a female stranger on a bus platform and asking her how her husband's erections are doing? Yet, here it is just daily interaction in efforts to help other human beings. We may not save lives here (or maybe we do in some cases) but there is an unspoken mission to help others while looking for nothing in return, except good news. In 73 years, I had never been on a forum before (physical or virtual), I am a non-Facebooker, I am a non-texter (didn't they do that tap-tap-tap of messages 150 years ago with the invention of the telegraph -- seriously, I don't get it) and yet I feel committed to this particular forum because of the potential to actually help others who may encounter similar experiences to mine. In my view, very little of this positive energy would be possible without the regular input of our steady, voice-of-reason moderator, Chuck. I've become a prostate cancer forum addict.

Posts.Title: a simple thanks

Posts.Content: Welcome Hilander: Exploring possible odds and probabilities can be counter-productive. But you could look at it this way: Worst case scenario -- you have cancer. Best case scenario if biopsy is positive -- you have prostate cancer. Caught early and treated, it is one of only a few cancers that are nearly 100% curable. That's not something to be taken lightly as a review of some other cancers on this website will reveal. Just take it one step at a time and let us know your biopsy results. Posters on this site are not medical professionals but we (and in many cases, our care-givers) will be glad to share our experiences and offer support which you may find helpful. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Probability?

Posts.Content: "For those that have gone before me, will it remain that way? What can I expect in the coming years? " Hi Frenchy: As you know, every case is different so predicting the future is a fool's errand but three plus years after SR, I keep cranking out only zeros on my PSAs, as shown below. No reason for you to expect anything different. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Back in the Zero Club

Posts.Content: Welcome Gene: As far as your decisions to date? Kudos. As far as your decision to pursue adjuvant radiation prior to reaching a particular trigger point (>0.1, etc.), more kudos. Everything that I have read in recent years tells me that success comes more often by being proactive, rather than wait before seeking more treatment. Surely, you can see in my signature that salvage radiation has treated me fine, so far. But,, as you well know, a G7 is a whole lot different than a G9 and I make no attempt to equate the two. I can only tell you that I'm still vertical, sucking air and continue to remain above the grass line at soon-to-be age 74. All the best to you, Sir, Jim

Posts.Title: New to the "Club"

Posts.Content: R2F: OMG! You SHOULD sleep soundly tonight based on his performance so far post-surgery AND the favorable pathology report. Pratoman touches on one area that many patients experience angst over when they really shouldn't. Every guy has a different time frame for reaching full continence. And, over and over, we have seen instances when a patient sees more leakage one day than the preceding day and they become depressed and start feeling sorry for themselves because "...it's not getting better, it's getting worse AND this is ONLY happening to me..." when, in fact, it is simply normal and part of the healing process. It should not be a cause for concern. Kegels are great (don't overdo what is recommended by his doctor) but my uro explained that even if no Kegels were performed, a return to full continence will still occur -- it would just take a little longer. The other side of the coin can be too much confidence after continence returns and he just wants to move on and forget about PC altogether. It's still vitally important to continue PSA testing at whatever interval is suggested by his doctor. Congrats and best wishes, Jim

Posts.Title: Update and Final Pathology

Posts.Content: MM: As soon as I saw a PSA upward trend, three years after surgery, I was pounding on the door of the salvage radiation treatment center and requesting to be zapped. So far, so good in my case. As Pratoman pointed out, with your surgical pathology report of Gleason 9 and positive margins, the idea of "waiting and monitoring" is something that I could have never considered. In my view, any side effects can be ignored when survival is the primary objective. But that's just one guy's opinion. I wish you the best, Jim

Posts.Title: " AR/SR vs. PSA Monitoring & Waiting"

Posts.Content: Excellent news. Now, just take it one day at a time. Slow and steady wins the race. When in doubt during recovery, err on the side of caution with rest. Some patients feel fine from the second day and try to do too much too soon. Best wishes, Jim

Posts.Title: Surgery went well!

Posts.Content: In February, a close friend was touring Ireland with a group when he took ill. His wife e-mailed us each night for the 10 days he was in a local hospital where tests were run to determine his problem (eventually diagnosed back in the States as an abdominal aortic aneurysm). Her description of the conditions in the Ireland hospital approached the unthinkable for U.S. citizens. She explained that she had to shop nearly every day to provide him with basic necessities. Patients had to supply their own soap, toothbrush and toothpaste, shaving supplies, toiletries and even their own hospital gowns. Her husband shared a room with seven other men, one of whom had been in the same hospital for more than a year because doctors still hadn't been able to successfully diagnose his problem. It sounded very much like a Third World country. Now, you say that robotic surgery, which has been available in many countries for more than a decade "...is not an option here". The other posters suggested changing doctors. I suggest, if possible, you change countries for his treatment. In the meanwhile, we look forward to your posting of his biopsy results (number of cores taken, number of positive cores, the percentage involvement of each positive core, etc.). A normal PSA result combined with an aggressive Gleason 9 score seems highly suspect.

Posts.Title: " AR/SR vs. PSA Monitoring & Waiting"

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Fairwind You should not be concerned at all.... Are you reading the decimal placement correctly? At a PSA of 0.1 post-surgery, many ROs would be prepping a patient for salvage radiation. Assuming the most recent PSA result was not an error, another PSA of 0.1 or higher is currently considered to be a biochemical recurrence. As soon as I hit 0.11, I scheduled 40 sessions of SR after monitoring a clear-cut upward trend. This is exactly the reason why a single decimal point while monitoring PSA makes no sense IMHO because it lulls the patient into thinking <0.1 is just fine when, if fact, it could be climbing every 3 months (0.02, 0.04, 0.06, 0.07) and the patient remains totally in the dark. In this case, a second PSA reading of 0.1 or higher is very likely time for action. Chuck, Pratoman, Michael F, MichiganMan16, am I missing something here?

Posts.Content: Only 8 days total for me. Never even switched to the leg bag. Hunkered down in my mancave. No pain but hated even minute with the bag. It was mentally challenging that I couldn't go anywhere without it. Schedule a celebration for Friday, after the removal.

Posts.Title: Foley follies

Posts.Content: When my 40 SR sessions were over, I brought in four 2-lb boxes of chocolates for the tech staff while mentioning that it's good to have an extra layer of fat. In case you become seriously ill, you can afford to lose the fat but if you're a stick figure to start out, then "Poof", you could be gone.

Posts.Title: Post Robotic Prostate Cancer Surgery - 3 years later

Posts.Content: Welcome MB from another guy who has chronic kidney stones (surgery to remove them twice - 7 trips to the ER in the last 7 years): The second post -- "take it one step at a time" -- is on point. I suspect your doctor was sending you for an ultrasound to determine the size of your prostate and then would have likely taken the next step to the PSA test and a urologist referral. Many guys who come to this site for the first time have concerns that are similar to yours. However, you seem on the verge of expecting the worst when there is no evidence yet of anything that bad. Like Chuck said, gather the results from the uro and come back to us. We'll try to share our experiences and provide support to the best of our abilities. For now, calm down. The sky is not falling. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Doctor found nodule during DRE, my first ever, no PSA record.. long history of UTI

Posts.Content: R2F: OMG! You SHOULD sleep soundly tonight based on his performance so far post-surgery AND the favorable pathology report. Pratoman touches on one area that many patients experience angst over when they really shouldn't. Every guy has a different time frame for reaching full continence. And, over and over, we have seen instances when a patient sees more leakage one day than the preceding day and they become depressed and start feeling sorry for themselves because "...it's not getting better, it's getting worse AND this is ONLY happening to me..." when, in fact, it is simply normal and part of the healing process. It should not be a cause for concern. Kegels are great (don't overdo what is recommended by his doctor) but my uro explained that even if no Kegels were performed, a return to full continence will still occur -- it would just take a little longer. The other side of the coin can be too much confidence after continence returns and he just wants to move on and forget about PC altogether. It's still vitally important to continue PSA testing at whatever interval is suggested by his doctor. Congrats and best wishes, Jim

Posts.Title: Update and Final Pathology

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Fairwind You should not be concerned at all.... Are you reading the decimal placement correctly? At a PSA of 0.1 post-surgery, many ROs would be prepping a patient for salvage radiation. Assuming the most recent PSA result was not an error, another PSA of 0.1 or higher is currently considered to be a biochemical recurrence. As soon as I hit 0.11, I scheduled 40 sessions of SR after monitoring a clear-cut upward trend. This is exactly the reason why a single decimal point while monitoring PSA makes no sense IMHO because it lulls the patient into thinking <0.1 is just fine when, if fact, it could be climbing every 3 months (0.02, 0.04, 0.06, 0.07) and the patient remains totally in the dark. In this case, a second PSA reading of 0.1 or higher is very likely time for action. Chuck, Pratoman, Michael F, MichiganMan16, am I missing something here?

Posts.Title: Ugh, but not overly concerned

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by brownie43 You stated you would be furious with the Dr. Well, it is the VA, and I forgot to mention that I am 73yrs. old. The first VA Urologist that I saw at the VA was a bit "put off" because I had a PSA in my labs., and said he would never order a PSA for anyone 70 or older but seeing as how someone else was ordering 'unnecessary lab work", he would do a DRE (enlarged but no bumps). Said if I came in dragging an oxygen bottle or such, he would not order more tests, etc. but I was a youthful 73, so lucky me. Anyway, he did order up another PSA and recommended a biopsy. Not sure how to get a second opinion at the VA, so will probably go to my Medicare PCP Welcome brownie: As Pratoman noted, your high PSA score may indicate a true Gleason score higher than G6. If you Google "average life expectancy of a male in the U.S.", you will get 74.4 years. Since I am currently 74.5 years, I'm past my expiration date but, for whatever reason, I feel able to do most things that I could thirty years ago (including traveling the country playing televised poker semi-professionally). https://www.dropbox.com/s/2tgsaqzh4a...ience.mp4?dl=0 But the VA, with a limited budget, clearly looks at you at age 73 as money wasted on a patient with a limited life expectancy, regardless of your robust abilities. By now, you should realize that a primary care physician is fine for treating someone with a boo-boo and can apply a Band-Aid to a knee. You're past that with a cancer (albeit mild G6) confirmation. But if the VA allows you to be treated by an outside Medicare PCP, why not try for an appointment with a non-VA urologist? He/she should be able to provide a second opinion relative to the recommendations of your radiologist, who is concerned about your enlarged lymph nodes. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Pc 101

Posts.Content: Pratoman: Thanks for your views. In reading your reference numbers, XJC3 cited PSA numbers of 1.0 to 2.0 for certain advanced scans and Chuck referred to PSA numbers of 0.1 to 0.2 to consider commencement of salvage radiation. You're not viewing those numbers as being equal, right? I just can't imagine ANYONE risking the occurrence of possible metastasis while waiting for your PSA to hit 1.0. XJC3 takes the opposite view and suggests that EVERYONE should wait until the PSA hits 1.0 when a Choline scan MIGHT show a more definitive area where cancer has spread to. In my view, waiting until reaching a PSA of 1.0 post-surgery is a sure-fire way to lead to unnecessary deaths. I'd love to see a show of hands on the issue. Jim

Posts.Title: Salvage Radiation I hope a good question?

Posts.Content: Hi XJC3: When I read the words "...makes sense to do nothing until PSA reaches a level detectable by PET Choline or Acetate...", I interpreted that to mean you supported that view. Our paths are very similar except you started your journey about 5 years earlier than mine. And with negative margins (compared to a small margin for me), you had every right to expect that your surgery was a slam-dunk success story. The fact that it took more than 9 years post-surgery and post-salvage radiation to find the spot just outside the prostate bed must be frustrating beyond belief. Hopefully, for the patients who come after us, that "gray area" will shrink and the tests of the future will be able to identify the location and source of any suspect cancer sites post-surgery. And, while I have good PSA numbers post-surgery and post-salvage radiation, I have little confidence they will remain that way in the future and I will follow you into some type of HT program. Fortunately for you, the HT seems to be doing the job. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Salvage Radiation I hope a good question?

Posts.Content: Hi Breezy: Well, it looks like we're back to Square One if your Dad has not had a biopsy. When you were asked for a Gleason score and your Dad's history, we thought a clearer picture would emerge, but without a biopsy your Dad has not been diagnosed with cancer because ONLY a biopsy --nothing else -- will make that determination. Not a blood test -- not a DRE. ONLY a biopsy. So, regardless of what the doctor may believe, as of now your Dad does not have prostate cancer. To repeat, it's not cancer until a biopsy says it's cancer. You really can make good use of Dr. Walsh's book to get a better understanding of the disease, including diagnosis, treatment options and follow-up. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Doctor found nodule during DRE, my first ever, no PSA record.. long history of UTI

Posts.Content: If you have any specific questions, there are plenty of people here who can likely respond with first-hand histories of how they've dealt with certain issues. I've found that a wealth of general knowledge can be gained by simply reading various threads under prostate cancer. Each story is a little different from the previous one. My history was a PSA of 4.95 -- 2 cores of 12 positive -- 3+4 Gleason -- had DaVinci robotic surgery in 2010 - cancer came back in 2013 -- try explaining to someone that you still have prostate cancer but you have no prostate -- 40 sessions of radiation followed -- PSA now 0.00. Yes, you do need a "plan of action" but accept the fact that you are not in "imminent" danger. Then, take a deep breath and soldier on, gathering as much info as reasonably possible. We'll be here.

Posts.Content: Welcome Gene: As far as your decisions to date? Kudos. As far as your decision to pursue adjuvant radiation prior to reaching a particular trigger point (>0.1, etc.), more kudos. Everything that I have read in recent years tells me that success comes more often by being proactive, rather than wait before seeking more treatment. Surely, you can see in my signature that salvage radiation has treated me fine, so far. But,, as you well know, a G7 is a whole lot different than a G9 and I make no attempt to equate the two. I can only tell you that I'm still vertical, sucking air and continue to remain above the grass line at soon-to-be age 74. All the best to you, Sir, Jim

Posts.Title: Frequency and Urgency of Urination

Posts.Content: Hi Breezy: Well, it looks like we're back to Square One if your Dad has not had a biopsy. When you were asked for a Gleason score and your Dad's history, we thought a clearer picture would emerge, but without a biopsy your Dad has not been diagnosed with cancer because ONLY a biopsy --nothing else -- will make that determination. Not a blood test -- not a DRE. ONLY a biopsy. So, regardless of what the doctor may believe, as of now your Dad does not have prostate cancer. To repeat, it's not cancer until a biopsy says it's cancer. You really can make good use of Dr. Walsh's book to get a better understanding of the disease, including diagnosis, treatment options and follow-up. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: 25 yrs old - my dad was diagnosed with Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Bill: My uro told me before surgery that the "average" time to put incontinence in the rear view mirror is about two months. As I watched the calendar, amazingly, I was completely dry on the 60th day and have remained so, ever since. As you have seen on this site, some guys are dry very quickly while others take a year or more to find the Promised Land of Dryness. For me, the catheter (my first ever) was more challenging than the subsequent leakage. Although there was never any pain involved, I found it to be difficult to mentally cope with. The catheter removal remains one of the best days of my life. Now, I primarily deal with kidney stones, two of which had to be surgically removed. It's always something -- kind of like an old Chevy with parts wearing out. Jim

Posts.Title: HMS SRT Log 1 down 33 to go

Posts.Content: Welcome MK: On this site, most contributors naturally reflect upon their experiences with prostate problems. That's normal. But the symptoms you describe don't seem to fit with routine prostate issues, as stated by your doctors. Since you have a background in healthcare, have you considered the possibility that the discomfort could be coming from the remnants of kidney stones passing through? I know that it may be a stretch (pardon the pun) but my history, not shown in my signature, includes seven episodes of moderate to severe kidney stone activity in the last seven years, two of which required surgery to remove the stones. In most instances, the pain was crippling. If you have not already checked out this possibility, I believe accepted medical protocol is to have an ultrasound test of your kidneys and ureters. It may be a long shot but something to consider. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Content: Welcome MK: On this site, most contributors naturally reflect upon their experiences with prostate problems. That's normal. But the symptoms you describe don't seem to fit with routine prostate issues, as stated by your doctors. Since you have a background in healthcare, have you considered the possibility that the discomfort could be coming from the remnants of kidney stones passing through? I know that it may be a stretch (pardon the pun) but my history, not shown in my signature, includes seven episodes of moderate to severe kidney stone activity in the last seven years, two of which required surgery to remove the stones. In most instances, the pain was crippling. If you have not already checked out this possibility, I believe accepted medical protocol is to have an ultrasound test of your kidneys and ureters. It may be a long shot but something to consider. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Latest PSA up

Posts.Content: If that is what you have decided on, then stick with it and don't look back. I'm just a little confused about the issue with your dear wife. You ruled out surgery because you need time to recover and feel like you cannot do that while caring for your wife and there is not an alternative caregiver available for her. But when you add up all of the time when you are getting HT and 9 weeks of radiation daily, doesn't the same issue of caring for your wife come into play? The total amount of travel and treatment time are probably about the same. I seem to recall an old cliché about not allowing short term problems to interfere with long-term solutions, but I'm old and I'll be damned if I can think of it. Just a thought. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Need any info on HDR therapy with 4 weks of follow up IGRT

Posts.Content: I never cease to be amazed at the number of guys -- most of whom don't see doctors on a regular basis -- who have never heard of the PSA test. One fellow, a highly-educated 53-year-old, said he was not aware of such a test. When I told him that prostate cancer deaths had dropped by 44% since the PSA test was first widely accepted in 1992, he was stunned. I tell everyone who will listen to get a PSA no later than age 50 and then every year thereafter, regardless of what the President's Death Panel recommends.

Posts.Title: Family History?

Posts.Content: Hi Breezy: Well, it looks like we're back to Square One if your Dad has not had a biopsy. When you were asked for a Gleason score and your Dad's history, we thought a clearer picture would emerge, but without a biopsy your Dad has not been diagnosed with cancer because ONLY a biopsy --nothing else -- will make that determination. Not a blood test -- not a DRE. ONLY a biopsy. So, regardless of what the doctor may believe, as of now your Dad does not have prostate cancer. To repeat, it's not cancer until a biopsy says it's cancer. You really can make good use of Dr. Walsh's book to get a better understanding of the disease, including diagnosis, treatment options and follow-up. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: 25 yrs old - my dad was diagnosed with Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Allen: While the doctor is probably correct, I would agree with newporter and want to know the date of your friend's last colonoscopy. The husband of my wife's best friend is one of those guys who hasn't seen a doctor in 20 years, also age 69. He had really bad rectal pain. Finally, he agreed to have a colonoscopy and they didn't reach the midway point before finding a large malignant mass in the colon. He's had chemo and a colostomy bag (supposed to be temporary) for 8 months. Surgery is scheduled for February after the mass is reduced. Best of luck to your friend. Jim

Posts.Title: Prostate info for friend

Posts.Content: "Since SR is usually only targeted to the prostate bed, and recurrence may be outside of the bed, then it seems to me that it makes sense to do nothing until PSA reaches a level detectable by PET Choline or Acetate." As a surgery and salvage radiation survivor, I am confused by your question, XJC3. If the tests you cited can only be relevant to identifying prostate cancer mets to areas outside the prostate bed after reaching a PSA of 1.0 or above, then they are of NO VALUE to a patient whose cancer is believed to be exclusively present in the prostate bed who needs to proceed with SR, as is often the case. That's because if you wait until your PSA reaches a reading of 1.0 to 2.0 post-surgery, you have given the cancer an opportunity to spread to those very same outlying areas. Maybe I'm missing something here -- I certainly welcome more input from my forum brothers.

Posts.Title: Prostate info for friend

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Ready2Fight Jim, Michael & MM, Does this mean that generally if you don't reach <0.1 by 3 months post op you will not hit it or can it still go down on the next test? Hi R2F: It still "could" go down but the 3-month mark normally is the standard by which a determination is reached for success or failure of the surgery. (I should qualify that. Removal of the prostate was not actually a "failure' in the sense that, especially with a Gleason 8, the surgeon has debulked the cancer). A few doctors lean toward the 6-month PSA reading but I think they are in the minority. It should actually be undetectable at 3 months and if this gentleman has posted his true PSA, that didn't happen here. Jim

Posts.Title: Salvage Radiation I hope a good question?

Posts.Content: Hi XJC3: When I read the words "...makes sense to do nothing until PSA reaches a level detectable by PET Choline or Acetate...", I interpreted that to mean you supported that view. Our paths are very similar except you started your journey about 5 years earlier than mine. And with negative margins (compared to a small margin for me), you had every right to expect that your surgery was a slam-dunk success story. The fact that it took more than 9 years post-surgery and post-salvage radiation to find the spot just outside the prostate bed must be frustrating beyond belief. Hopefully, for the patients who come after us, that "gray area" will shrink and the tests of the future will be able to identify the location and source of any suspect cancer sites post-surgery. And, while I have good PSA numbers post-surgery and post-salvage radiation, I have little confidence they will remain that way in the future and I will follow you into some type of HT program. Fortunately for you, the HT seems to be doing the job. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Salvage Radiation I hope a good question?

Posts.Content: Pratoman: Thanks for your views. In reading your reference numbers, XJC3 cited PSA numbers of 1.0 to 2.0 for certain advanced scans and Chuck referred to PSA numbers of 0.1 to 0.2 to consider commencement of salvage radiation. You're not viewing those numbers as being equal, right? I just can't imagine ANYONE risking the occurrence of possible metastasis while waiting for your PSA to hit 1.0. XJC3 takes the opposite view and suggests that EVERYONE should wait until the PSA hits 1.0 when a Choline scan MIGHT show a more definitive area where cancer has spread to. In my view, waiting until reaching a PSA of 1.0 post-surgery is a sure-fire way to lead to unnecessary deaths. I'd love to see a show of hands on the issue. Jim

Posts.Title: Newly Diagnosed, Am I on the right track?

Posts.Content: Radiation can sometimes cause constrictive areas in the urethra. Tamsulosin (Brand name: Flomax) was first marketed in 1996 and has many beneficial traits. In addition to treating BPH - enlarged prostate - it can help with the passage of kidney stones. Also, it promotes a more even flow after a catheter has been removed post-surgery, which is the reason I successfully took Flomax for several months. A more detailed explanation of Flomax can be Googled under the Wikipedia website.

Posts.Title: Flomax

Posts.Content: Steve: The marketing efforts on behalf of SBRT (Cyberknife, etc.) tends to focus on brevity rather than effectiveness. "We can cure your cancer in FIVE visits. You must be an IDIOT if you're going to agree to 40 sessions of traditional radiation therapy". But, sometimes it's best to stick with the gold standard (35 to 40 sessions), proven effective over decades. If you do a search of "satisfied patients" among all forms of prostate cancer treatments, SBRT -- Cyberknife, etc. -- is invariably at the bottom of the list. Massive doses of radiation all at once have not been proven to be a good thing, with respect to PC. I personally know of two friends with PC who live in Florida and who both underwent Cyberknife and both experienced radiation burns that penetrated the rectum wall. One patient is still in daily pain, three years later. SBRT seems most successful for isolated tumors, such as brain tumors, rather than prostate cancer that often contain multiple diffuse tumors. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Just learned my biopsy was positive

Posts.Content: Hi Bill: My uro told me before surgery that the "average" time to put incontinence in the rear view mirror is about two months. As I watched the calendar, amazingly, I was completely dry on the 60th day and have remained so, ever since. As you have seen on this site, some guys are dry very quickly while others take a year or more to find the Promised Land of Dryness. For me, the catheter (my first ever) was more challenging than the subsequent leakage. Although there was never any pain involved, I found it to be difficult to mentally cope with. The catheter removal remains one of the best days of my life. Now, I primarily deal with kidney stones, two of which had to be surgically removed. It's always something -- kind of like an old Chevy with parts wearing out. Jim

Posts.Title: How long after the drips started???

Posts.Content: Hi Jack: If I found myself in your position with a difficult G10 to deal with and a surgeon whose judgment you question, I would simply ask him if he is in no hurry because he has doubts about a favorable outcome. I know its hard to read those words but I would want to know his true views on the subject rather than just go through the motions. In all fairness, I would also ask the radiologist oncologist about his expectations that treatment will be totally successful. Then, with that additional information secured, you can move ahead with whatever treatment you are comfortable with, armed with a realistic prognosis. I apologize if that view is too direct, however I am a great believer in stepping back and looking at the big picture, without sugar-coating anything. I wish you the very best, Jim

Posts.Title: PSA levels went lower with trial drug

Posts.Content: Hi Fisher: I'm not the only poster on this site who has had surgery and, when the cancer returned, I needed salvage radiation to knock it down. But I would ask you to urge him to read my history and the current success that I experienced due to salvage radiation. As Chuck and Fairwind have stated, more information is needed for us to really get some perspective on his situation. However, if he is simply frustrated that surgery did not rid him of prostate cancer (and we don't know that without more details), he needs to know that others have faced similar situations and acted to resolve the issue and ultimately were victorious. You could point out that if he isn't willing to take the steps necessary to act to save his life, then all of the investment in time and the good work of the surgeon will be lost. And, yes, I said the good work of the surgeon because if the prostate is gone and there was cancer present, the surgeon has removed a major part of the problem -- called debulking the cancer. If he has thrown up a wall of denial, you could encourage him to receive a psychological consultation to try to figure out why he doesn't want to continue to attempt to fight to remain with us. BTW, my 40 sessions of salvage radiation were a piece of cake -- sailed through it without a single side effect. You lay on a table for 10 minutes while a machine circles around you. The patient feels nothing -- never any pain or discomfort, unless they didn't fluff the pillow. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Psa 5,928

Posts.Content: I never cease to be amazed at the number of guys -- most of whom don't see doctors on a regular basis -- who have never heard of the PSA test. One fellow, a highly-educated 53-year-old, said he was not aware of such a test. When I told him that prostate cancer deaths had dropped by 44% since the PSA test was first widely accepted in 1992, he was stunned. I tell everyone who will listen to get a PSA no later than age 50 and then every year thereafter, regardless of what the President's Death Panel recommends.

Posts.Title: Family History?

Posts.Content: Lujo: You mentioned that your Dad "should have had much longer to live". On websites like this one, throughout the world, I've seen that sentiment expressed over and over again. Please, please don't be offended but statistical averages say you are wrong. As of 2012, the last year for which data are available, an adult male has a life expectancy of about 74 years while an adult female's life expectancy is between 77 and 78 years. At nearly age 77, your Dad beat the average by almost 3 years. My lifelong best friend passed at age 53, far below the average mortality age. I'm 72 and may possibly beat the average. I know it's hard to accept that someone who we love so dearly is subject to such cold hard stats but, outside of our control, we all create the "average" life expectancy. Note: Allen, I believe the five year survival rate refers to those still alive after five years (and who may continue to live many years beyond the 5-year snapshot).

Posts.Title: Prostate cancer diagnosed after death

Posts.Content: Your bone scan and CT Scan show no mets. So, as long as the cancer is encapsulated within the prostate, you're not too late. And you should have every expectation for a full cure. Which relates back to your first question: if it's still fully contained, then 20% or 80% really doesn't matter if they get it all out. Being nervous is normal, but try not to agonize over the issue or you may drive yourself crazy. I always say, "Millions have gone before me -- millions will go after me". Try to relax.

Posts.Title: Tumor Load

Posts.Content: Pratoman: In looking back at your earlier thread, I note that newporter gave you some valuable and insightful advice. Assuming you are still meeting with a surgeon in mid-December, you scheduled an MRI probe in late December and you have actually set up surgery for the soonest possible date, here is my thinking: I retired from a planning department -- in advance of implementing a Plan A, I almost always had a fallback Plan B written out. Use your waiting time to be productive. Write down the pros and cons (what is important to you, not to me or any other poster) listing why you favor each particular pathway to a resolution and the reasons why you don't want to pursue that avenue. For example, some patients just want the prostate OUT -- everything else is secondary. Others are more concerned with potential side effects -- ED, incontinence, etc. In my case, the decision was based almost entirely on having a back-up plan. Remarkably, my Plans A and B fell neatly into place 3 years apart. As you likely know by now through your research, if you have surgery first and the cancer returns, you can have salvage radiotherapy to eradicate any remaining or returning cancer. If you have radiation as your primary treatment, you can't have surgery as a secondary option (rarely speaking). In 2010, I chose DaVinci surgery. I was left with a small positive margin. In 2013, the cancer returned and I had salvage radiotherapy which, knock on wood, has left me with repeated PSA results of 0.00 over the last year. Of course, no one knows what the future may hold but so far so good. I must caution you that I am highly biased toward surgery first for the reasons cited and others on this site may strongly disagree. So, again, what's right for me may not be what's best for you. However, few would argue against creating a list and having a plan in place. And it won't hurt to have a brown paper bag next to the list if you feel like you may be about to hyper-ventilate. Remember -- all of the above is useless if you croak from having a heart attack worrying about something that does not rise to the level of irrational anxiety you seem to be experiencing. We've all "been there - done that". Repeat after me. You're going to be fine. Jim

Posts.Title: Tumor Load

Posts.Content: Perhaps not, but a PSA of 0.00 (see below) IS indicative of a better outcome after SR than a PSA of 2.0 a year after the latest treatment. Not sure if you're in denial but your "battle" is certainly not over. It's your life and your decision to forego further follow-up treatment but my guess is that 98% of patients who found themselves in the same situation would not be declaring victory over anything. In four days from now, I will reach the 5-year mark since my surgery and I'm still looking over my shoulder.

Posts.Title: Recent Tests

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Pottk I First psa results after Jan 26 surgery PSA .1 no cancer is detectable at at this time. Last step left is incontinence issue. Don't want to let the air out of your balloon but a PSA test of .1, more than 3 months after surgery shows just the opposite. Ain't nothing to celebrate here. Hell, on the subject of accuracy, even your date of surgery in the signature looks like it's wrong by a year. If accurate, combined with a G8 pre-surgery (what did the surgical path report show for a confirmed Gleason score?), you are almost certainly headed for either adjuvant or salvage radiation. I am most stunned that your doctor hasn't advised you accordingly, by now. It's not that I am unsympathetic to your case, but no doctor should mislead you into thinking you are finished with this disease.

Posts.Title: New zero club member

Posts.Content: Hi Chester: When you said "early" salvage radiation, you really meant early. I haven't seen any patient with SR commencement numbers that low (0.023) so far. I started SR at 0.11 and I thought I was on the early side. And, as usual, just as I start typing my question about how on earth did you get an insurer to approve it, of course, there is Michael already on top of the issue, as always. I suppose you are correct about the PPO, Chester. Throughout my employment career, I insisted on the superior coverage, even if it cost me significantly more, in order not to endure having to obtain "May I?" referrals from gate-keeper doctors whose in-network job and income depended on NOT sending a patient to a specialist, unless absolutely necessary. While my SR has resulted in all 0.00 readings in the last 4 years, I have never gone to the third decimal. Congrats. Jim

Posts.Title: Post SRT PSA decline

Posts.Content: Hi Max: I was roughly your same age when I was diagnosed with a pre-surgery Gleason score of 3+4=7 in 2 out of 12 cores, which remained the same on my surgical pathology report. Although I didn't require adjuvant radiation after DaVinci surgery, I had a positive margin and my PC returned three years post-surgery (please see below). At that point, I had 40 uneventful sessions of salvage radiation three years ago which seems to be holding the beast at bay. The only side effects of the SR was some slight fatigue toward the end of the SR treatment. You are fortunate to have the downgrade to your Gleason score post-surgery. It appears from your path report that adjuvant radiation may be in your future, but most likely will be determined by your upcoming PSA test in 6 weeks from now. Recognize that your situation is not uncommon and there is no reason to believe that follow-up radiation (AR or SR) will not result in a true cure. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Content: I could be wrong -- often am. But from what I read of your exercise regimen (walk up to 20 miles a week?), is it possible you're doing too much? Everyone's body reacts differently. At the end of 2 months, I was dry after doing about 20% of your exercise schedule. Is my experience relevant? Who knows, but it may be worth toning it down for a week or two to look for improvement.

Posts.Title: Exercise Bicycle

Posts.Content: The heavy blood in the urine may or may not be the routine result of your husband's surgery. With respect to his severe abdominal pain, I note that you were given a diagnosis of bladder spasms (a normal post-surgery problem) only to find out later that he has an infection of an unknown source. You were told that you would be notified of the test results relative to the infection and if they found anything concerning "they would let you know". Sort of "Don't call us, we'll call you". It all comes down to the level of treatment/non-treatment that you are willing to accept. Personally, I would insist on receiving a copy of the test results as soon as they are available, regardless of whether they are positive or negative. You visited the hospital two days ago and he was given an antibiotic. But today you have a lot of blood in the catheter bag which concerns you both. My experience is that the squeaky wheel gets the oil. I would suggest calling for the test results, request a hard copy and advise the doctor of your concerns about the heavy blood loss. If you aren't satisfied (and some fellow posters may see this as an over-reaction), I would drive back to the hospital and badger them until you get the answers that you are satisfied with. Always best to err on the side of caution, in my view. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Fever and pain?!?!

Posts.Content: "With this much involvement and samples is it remotely possible that the lab screwed this up?" Hi Medic: Probably not, but as others have noted, a second opinion of the slides is a prudent recommendation. And if six positive cores are confirmed, there is always the chance that your G6 will be re-adjusted to some G7 post-surgery. You are unusually young at age 42 to have to deal with this issue, but even with the potential for side effects, given the same parameters, I would want that sucker gone. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Diagnosed today, What do the number mean?

Posts.Content: "But will Medicare make me wait till it hits .2, which is the AUA guideline? " Pratoman: I posed that very question to our forum brothers and sisters a couple of months ago without a response. While I had no problem receiving approval from Medicare to start SR at 0.11 PSA, my guess would be that there IS some number already identified that might preclude starting SR as early as Chester did. On the other hand, Medicare has rarely posed any authorization problems over the last ten years for me and my wife. I find it hard to believe that a program run by the Federal Government works so smoothly, for the most part. Jim

Nodule lights up indicating likelihood of lung cancer -- Location not conducive to biopsy. 3/17/14 - Three top doctors say it MUST come out via a wedge re-section. If cancerous, the entire right middle lobe must be surgically removed. 6/13/14 - Nodule shrank by 1/3. Not cancer. Surgery cancelled. Next scan 9/14. Nodule "resolved" - gone. Posts.Title: Post SRT PSA decline

Posts.Content: As Fran posted, it took him a year to get dry. I was very lucky -- dry after 2 months. A lot of men think that a heavy leakage is unusual, when in fact it's normal after the catheter comes out. As embarrassing and uncomfortable as it is, I would emphasize that we ALL have experienced the same leakage, just of various degrees. One step at a time.

Posts.Title: Dad's catheter and staples removed today...

Posts.Content: Hi Chester: When you said "early" salvage radiation, you really meant early. I haven't seen any patient with SR commencement numbers that low (0.023) so far. I started SR at 0.11 and I thought I was on the early side. And, as usual, just as I start typing my question about how on earth did you get an insurer to approve it, of course, there is Michael already on top of the issue, as always. I suppose you are correct about the PPO, Chester. Throughout my employment career, I insisted on the superior coverage, even if it cost me significantly more, in order not to endure having to obtain "May I?" referrals from gate-keeper doctors whose in-network job and income depended on NOT sending a patient to a specialist, unless absolutely necessary. While my SR has resulted in all 0.00 readings in the last 4 years, I have never gone to the third decimal. Congrats. Jim

Posts.Title: Post SRT PSA decline

Posts.Content: Welcome MrEd: Although surgery and radiation are considered to be equally successful primary treatments, I believe you will find a tendency to skew toward surgery on this site. It's unfortunate that you waited until age 62 to have your first PSA since you may have been able to initiate treatment prior to reaching a somewhat worrisome Gleason of 4+3 @ 90%. But as long as the cancer is contained in the prostate (the negative bone scan is great news), you can have every expectation that treatment will result in a "cure". I always hesitate to use the word "cure" because none of us really know what the future holds. Others will chime in shortly. Wishing you the very best outcome, Jim

Posts.Title: Hi, new member

Posts.Content: I agree with Chuck. A biopsy is indeed warranted. It's only a diagnostic test, not open-heart surgery and while we can choose to identify instances that rarely occur (deadly infection, please!!), only a biopsy will give an accurate picture. One question does come to mind: Why bother going to a doctor -- any doctor -- if you already decided what you were or were not going to do based on your 2,000 pages of reading on the topic? And it sounds like since you have all of the answers, why bother coming to a website where thousands of patients are willing to share their actual experiences? I will not comment on a 63-year-old male who ejaculates daily. But not for me to say. It sounds like you have a good "grip" on the subject.

Posts.Title: Can someone please explain what transection of Prostatic Parenchyma means....

Posts.Content: There may have been changes/adjustments/improvements since I had my full body scan prior to surgery four years ago, but I don't recall a 3-hour wait after the nuclear injection. I don't remember the name of the medication used (others can probably fill in this part) but I was told that it identified locations where cancer may have adhered to bones by "lighting up" those areas like a neon sign on the scan. Please keep in mind that neither I nor others on this site are medical professionals and therefore the doctors treating your Dad can certainly give a much better explanation than my meager recollections. In answer to your question about the previous CT scan, it's my understanding that the full body scan is much more definitive. Oh, and the table is tilted in many ways to allow the medication to reach all parts of the body. Hope that helps. Please let us know how your Dad makes out with the test.

Posts.Title: Dad had first appointment with surgeon

Posts.Content: While I don't wish to contribute to your anxiety, there is one more issue and then I'll shut up. You mentioned that if surgery was to be scheduled, you had selected the open method rather than robotic because of a timing glitch waiting for the operation. In looking back on your earlier threads, I note that you said your Dad is age 71. At 71, he is already on the outer periphery of being a surgery candidate (my urology group usually recommends radiation at that age). But the issue is compounded by the selection of open surgery which can be much more painful and his recovery time period will be elongated.

Posts.Title: Dad had first appointment with surgeon

Posts.Content: Hi Mom2two: Chuck pretty much answered your question in full. I can only add my personal experience. Prior to having my surgery, a full body bone scan was mandated. It was explained to me that if the cancer showed up elsewhere (metastasized), then surgery would not be an option. My understanding was that if I was not a surgical candidate, the doctors were certainly not "giving up" but they were conceding that a "cure" was not possible at that point. Then, the focus would shift from a curative pathway to a methodology to extend life. As you've probably read, there are many, many ways (radiation, hormone therapy, etc.) to accomplish that goal. But let's not put the cart before the horse (that cliché should show my age) and hope for the best results with the bone scan. Best of luck to you and your Dad. Jim

Posts.Title: Dad had first appointment with surgeon

Posts.Content: Hi Myrtha: Welcome to the forum and sorry you find yourself here. First and foremost, slow down. You just learned at 4AM today that your partner living in another state has metastatic prostate cancer and you then come up with something called "stadium treatment" that doesn't appear on a Google search. Metastatic prostate cancer means that the cancer has spread to other areas and/or organs of the body. There is no magic bullet -- stadium treatment or otherwise -- to solve the problem. There is no "cure" to be found. Various treatments using radiation and/or hormone therapy can help to extend life. But without any details, such as PSA history, the biopsy results, the staging of the cancer, etc., it is next to impossible to help with any specific information. Please get back to us with any information you can share. Best of luck. Jim

Posts.Title: Exercise Bicycle

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by regress Sage information, Jim. I agree that my doubling time is a big issue here. Do you know if, at numbers < 0.2 and a 4+3, cancer is likely to metastasize? Or would one typically need to have a much higher cell population (and hence higher PSA) to start to see that happen? Hi Max: With respect to your question about the likelihood of the cancer metastasizing, as someone who is not afraid to offer an opinion, I must confess that I would be overstepping my bounds to try to formulate an answer because I'm simply not qualified to do so. I think that's an issue that can best be answered by a medical professional. As you know, on this site, we are not doctors and can merely share with you the experiences that we have had -- both good and bad. For example, some patients select radiation as their primary treatment while others, like you and I, chose surgery. One of the primary benefits to surgery is that you have a second bite at the apple with salvage radiation to "clean up" any residual cancer. If you had chosen radiation as your primary treatment and the cancer returned, then surgery is rarely an option available to you. My urologist spoke of SR as nothing more than a house-keeping type of chore that sometimes occurs when all of the cancer is not eradicated at the time of surgery. As you can see from my history, it has worked well for me but, of course, no one can predict the future. I note that you have concern for side effects of radiation but that, almost always, relates to the experiences of those who choose it as their primary treatment, not SR. I can relate to you that I have never had a single problem of any kind from salvage radiotherapy and a number of other posters fall into the same category. Again, I wish you only the best -- except for the difference in age, we have followed a very similar path. Jim

Posts.Content: Hello Hiway: You have probably read a number of posts on this site where people have experienced various problems with side effects following surgery. It's only natural that patients, like you, who are about to undergo the surgery, focus on this area. But, if you do, you are missing the forest for the trees. Shu put it best when he said your primary focus should be the eradication of the cancer. Everything else is merely peripheral. Some people do experience long-term problems but the majority deal with issues that I can only describe as nuisances, such as the catheter for 7-10 days and sort-term incontinence. No need to be afraid of anything -- Hell, if you have dealt with lung cancer, then as Allen said, this WILL be a walk in the park. Fairwind even printed out an itinerary for you. And you'll be able to tell everyone who will listen that your journey to a potential full cure for prostate cancer began on Groundhog Day. Best of luck. Jim

Posts.Title: Scared of Meeting da Vinci

Posts.Content: Hi Regress: Chuck is absolutely correct with respect to accepted medical protocol. According to guidelines, you should wait to begin salvage radiotherapy until AFTER you post a PSA score >0.2 on two consecutive PSA tests. I respectfully take an alternate position. Although you list a favorable surgical pathology report, you must accept that your surgery failed. Your cancer has returned (as mine did 3 years post-surgery -- please see history). Here's what you won't find in the protocol: As recently as five years ago, many urologists waited to send a patient for SR only after his PSA reached >0.5. As recently as twelve years ago, many urologists waited to send a patient for SR only after his PSA reached >1.0. Do you detect a trend here? I did and decided that I wanted SR when I hit 0.11 on the PSA scale and commenced treatment at 0.16. In my view, acting sooner is better than letting the returning cancer an opportunity to spread. In just 5 months, since Oct., 2014, your PSA has more than doubled (PSADT). That, in itself, should be a red flag to your doctor. Sometimes -- not always -- it's best to throw the protocol book out the window. That's just the opinion of one grumpy old geezer. Best of luck. Jim

Posts.Content: Hi Hab: Do you have a family history of prostate cancer? While I'm not a fan of active surveillance, with only one core involved and a Gleason 6 and no family history of PC, I'm surprised that AS was not one of the options recommended. And although surgery and radiation, including seeds, are about equal in the success rate, brachytherapy (seeds) are actually selected by a very small percentage of prostate cancer patients. It sounds that, although this is your third biopsy, you may wish to investigate further. Our moderator, Chuck, should arrive shortly with a suggestion to buy a book written by Dr. Walsh, considered "The Bible" on PC. Per your question, as you can see from my history, I was one of those patients who experienced a return of PC following a DaVinci robotic prostatectomy surgery and I was able to receive salvage radiotherapy which, to date at least, has been successful in knocking down the cancer. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: torn between two treatments

Posts.Content: I agree with Chuck. A biopsy is indeed warranted. It's only a diagnostic test, not open-heart surgery and while we can choose to identify instances that rarely occur (deadly infection, please!!), only a biopsy will give an accurate picture. One question does come to mind: Why bother going to a doctor -- any doctor -- if you already decided what you were or were not going to do based on your 2,000 pages of reading on the topic? And it sounds like since you have all of the answers, why bother coming to a website where thousands of patients are willing to share their actual experiences? I will not comment on a 63-year-old male who ejaculates daily. But not for me to say. It sounds like you have a good "grip" on the subject.

Posts.Content: Hi Larry: Welcome. Since you already have a surgery date scheduled, I assume you have had a CAT Scan and full-body bone scan, as flkjr asked. And, if you did, congratulations, you have already won the first major step in dealing with this disease. If the cancer had metastasized in any significant degree to other areas of your body, it's likely that there would be no surgery. The people who frequent this site can provide insight into nearly every aspect of their experiences, before and after receiving treatment. Please feel free to ask any questions and, when you come out on the other side, consider sharing your story which may be helpful to others. Best of luck. Jim

Posts.Title: Seeking Opinions -> PSA Changes After RALP

Posts.Content: Hi mj: As a fellow PA resident, allow me to relate a PA story from six years ago. In Sept., 2010, at age 68, I was diagnosed with prostate cancer and had DaVinci surgery. Although it returned 3 years later and I had salvage radiation to knock it down, I remain cancer-free today. Tomorrow morning, I have a 6-month appointment with my urologist who has followed my case closely. In Sept., 2010, also at age 68, the president of Ursinus College in Collegeville, PA died from prostate cancer. College presidents are pretty smart guys. Your Item #6: 6. At my age, slow growing prostate cancer may not kill me before other things do. If that college president relied on that old wives tale, then he guessed wrong. He's dead as are 30,000 other men in the U.S who die each year from this disease. You don't want to be one of those 30,000 people who guess wrong. Good luck, Jim

I think that's an issue that can best be answered by a medical professional. As you know, on this site, we are not doctors and can merely share with you the experiences that we have had -- both good and bad. For example, some patients select radiation as their primary treatment while others, like you and I, chose surgery. One of the primary benefits to surgery is that you have a second bite at the apple with salvage radiation to "clean up" any residual cancer. If you had chosen radiation as your primary treatment and the cancer returned, then surgery is rarely an option available to you. My urologist spoke of SR as nothing more than a house-keeping type of chore that sometimes occurs when all of the cancer is not eradicated at the time of surgery. As you can see from my history, it has worked well for me but, of course, no one can predict the future. I note that you have concern for side effects of radiation but that, almost always, relates to the experiences of those who choose it as their primary treatment, not SR. I can relate to you that I have never had a single problem of any kind from salvage radiotherapy and a number of other posters fall into the same category. Again, I wish you only the best -- except for the difference in age, we have followed a very similar path. Jim

Posts.Title: Seeking Opinions -> PSA Changes After RALP

Posts.Content: Hi mj: As a fellow PA resident, allow me to relate a PA story from six years ago. In Sept., 2010, at age 68, I was diagnosed with prostate cancer and had DaVinci surgery. Although it returned 3 years later and I had salvage radiation to knock it down, I remain cancer-free today. Tomorrow morning, I have a 6-month appointment with my urologist who has followed my case closely. In Sept., 2010, also at age 68, the president of Ursinus College in Collegeville, PA died from prostate cancer. College presidents are pretty smart guys. Your Item #6: 6. At my age, slow growing prostate cancer may not kill me before other things do. If that college president relied on that old wives tale, then he guessed wrong. He's dead as are 30,000 other men in the U.S who die each year from this disease. You don't want to be one of those 30,000 people who guess wrong. Good luck, Jim

Posts.Title: Concerns about getting biopsy

Posts.Content: Hi Hab: Do you have a family history of prostate cancer? While I'm not a fan of active surveillance, with only one core involved and a Gleason 6 and no family history of PC, I'm surprised that AS was not one of the options recommended. And although surgery and radiation, including seeds, are about equal in the success rate, brachytherapy (seeds) are actually selected by a very small percentage of prostate cancer patients. It sounds that, although this is your third biopsy, you may wish to investigate further. Our moderator, Chuck, should arrive shortly with a suggestion to buy a book written by Dr. Walsh, considered "The Bible" on PC. Per your question, as you can see from my history, I was one of those patients who experienced a return of PC following a DaVinci robotic prostatectomy surgery and I was able to receive salvage radiotherapy which, to date at least, has been successful in knocking down the cancer. Best of luck, Jim

Posts.Title: torn between two treatments

Posts.Content: Hi Regress: Chuck is absolutely correct with respect to accepted medical protocol. According to guidelines, you should wait to begin salvage radiotherapy until AFTER you post a PSA score >0.2 on two consecutive PSA tests. I respectfully take an alternate position. Although you list a favorable surgical pathology report, you must accept that your surgery failed. Your cancer has returned (as mine did 3 years post-surgery -- please see history). Here's what you won't find in the protocol: As recently as five years ago, many urologists waited to send a patient for SR only after his PSA reached >0.5. As recently as twelve years ago, many urologists waited to send a patient for SR only after his PSA reached >1.0. Do you detect a trend here? I did and decided that I wanted SR when I hit 0.11 on the PSA scale and commenced treatment at 0.16. In my view, acting sooner is better than letting the returning cancer an opportunity to spread. In just 5 months, since Oct., 2014, your PSA has more than doubled (PSADT). That, in itself, should be a red flag to your doctor. Sometimes -- not always -- it's best to throw the protocol book out the window. That's just the opinion of one grumpy old geezer. Best of luck. Jim

Posts.Content: Hi Larry: Welcome. Since you already have a surgery date scheduled, I assume you have had a CAT Scan and full-body bone scan, as flkjr asked. And, if you did, congratulations, you have already won the first major step in dealing with this disease. If the cancer had metastasized in any significant degree to other areas of your body, it's likely that there would be no surgery. The people who frequent this site can provide insight into nearly every aspect of their experiences, before and after receiving treatment. Please feel free to ask any questions and, when you come out on the other side, consider sharing your story which may be helpful to others. Best of luck. Jim

Posts.Title: Keep that pomegranate juice flowing

Posts.Content: Hello Hiway: You have probably read a number of posts on this site where people have experienced various problems with side effects following surgery. It's only natural that patients, like you, who are about to undergo the surgery, focus on this area. But, if you do, you are missing the forest for the trees. Shu put it best when he said your primary focus should be the eradication of the cancer. Everything else is merely peripheral. Some people do experience long-term problems but the majority deal with issues that I can only describe as nuisances, such as the catheter for 7-10 days and sort-term incontinence. No need to be afraid of anything -- Hell, if you have dealt with lung cancer, then as Allen said, this WILL be a walk in the park. Fairwind even printed out an itinerary for you. And you'll be able to tell everyone who will listen that your journey to a potential full cure for prostate cancer began on Groundhog Day. Best of luck. Jim

Posts.Title: Scared of Meeting da Vinci

DoctorRecommended.Sample: Waiting another 3 months, after a uro has suggested a biopsy, has the added risk of allowing the cancer to spread if it happens to be of the fast-moving aggressive (though less prevalent) variety. So, while you're trying to think of reasons not to have the biopsy, you could possibly be reaching a point where some treatment options, like surgery, could be eliminated due to metastasis....Hi Mike: Michael F provides excellent observations relative to your inquiry. As a DaVinci AND salvage radiation patient, I would simply add the following: In my case, my urologist recommended and worked closely with a radiation oncologist following a PC recurrence 3 years after DaVinci....Although you have undoubtedly read that incontinence following a prostatectomy varies greatly among patients, if it is of concern to you after 4 weeks post-surgery as it appears to be, contact your surgeon and discuss the issue. The discharge paperwork provided by my surgeon suggested that I would not likely find dryness until the end of the second month....Your last sentence is exactly what I would suggest. However, at the end of the 2nd year after DaVinci with no evidence of a recurrence, many uros recommend a PSA test only once a year....However, playing Devil's Advocate as I often do (not to be confused with my respected forum brother ASAdvocate -- I'm highly jealous of Sweden, btw, with their disproportionate supply of hot blondes), I would like to mention two caveats: First, the initial Gleason score may not tell the whole story if there are higher-Gleason score critters still hiding in his prostate; Second, and this is a big one, many doctors prefer to not perform surgery on prostate cancer patients after roughly age 70 and depending upon the overall health of the patient. Since your husband is nearing that age group, I mention this because if he is going to fire the surgery bullet, the window of opportunity may be rapidly closing....As a DaVinci AND salvage radiation patient, I would simply add the following: In my case, my urologist recommended and worked closely with a radiation oncologist following a PC recurrence 3 years after DaVinci. In the 2 years since I received salvage radiation, I alternated visits between the urologist and oncologist as they monitored my PSA levels which, thankfully, have remained at 0.00....As a general rule of thumb -- and there are always exceptions -- in my doctor's group of 9 urologists, they lean toward surgery before age 60, it's a toss-up between surgery and radiation between ages 60 and 70, and over age 70 radiation is the treatment of choice. Even a person who is a "fit" age 77 may be encouraged to forego surgery to avoid a potential traumatic reaction to the rigors of surgery -- both open and robotic....However, just as I watched my PSA rise post-surgery and was prepared to act, you may want to ask his doctor at what "trigger" point he would recommend moving forward with salvage radiation. As "Another" states, sooner has been proven better that later....However, at the end of the 2nd year after DaVinci with no evidence of a recurrence, many uros recommend a PSA test only once a year. My feeling -- regardless of "medical protocol" -- especially with my history, is that I will never be comfortable waiting longer than every six months between PSA tests....Now, you say that robotic surgery, which has been available in many countries for more than a decade "...is not an option here". The other posters suggested changing doctors....Welcome Joy -- and fellow PA resident -- Go Little League World Series: I, too, agree that your husband's G6 stats lean strongly toward a path of active surveillance. However, playing Devil's Advocate as I often do (not to be confused with my respected forum brother ASAdvocate -- I'm highly jealous of Sweden, btw, with their disproportionate supply of hot blondes), I would like to mention two caveats: First, the initial Gleason score may not tell the whole story if there are higher-Gleason score critters still hiding in his prostate; Second, and this is a big one, many doctors prefer to not perform surgery on prostate cancer patients after roughly age 70 and depending upon the overall health of the patient....In the past, a post-surgery PSA reading of at least 0.2 at least twice was considered a confirmation of a biochemical recurrence. Many doctors have now trashed that and encourage commencement of salvage radiation at or near 0.1....If his doctor feels that a PSA every three months is reasonable, that sounds OK. However, just as I watched my PSA rise post-surgery and was prepared to act, you may want to ask his doctor at what "trigger" point he would recommend moving forward with salvage radiation....If accurate, combined with a G8 pre-surgery (what did the surgical path report show for a confirmed Gleason score?), you are almost certainly headed for either adjuvant or salvage radiation. I am most stunned that your doctor hasn't advised you accordingly, by now....After a prostatectomy, I asked my pulmonologist if the cancer believed to be in my right lung was related to my prior prostate cancer. He advised that when escaping from the prostate, cancer usually finds its way to the nearest organs (bladder, kidney, liver, pancreas, etc.) before it would reach the lungs....I'll keep you posted if we hear anything else too Wishing everyone a Happy Memorial Day Weekend and Good PSA test results Gina Hi Gina: Five years ago, after two hospitalizations for kidney stones, including one surgery to remove a stone that completely shut down my left ureter in unbearable pain, my uro started me on a medication (Urocet-K) to hopefully prevent future kidney stone issues. It's good to have a positive outlook for the future but be advised that these horse-size pills that I choke on twice a day, are not the panacea one might hope for....
